HEADLINE: Q&A/Pamela Thomas-Graham;
Author Explores Issues Through Heroine

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
PAMELA THOMAS-GRAHAM is not Nikki Chase, the heroine of her mystery novels, but the two have much in common. Both are black professionals with Harvard degrees, and through Nikki Ms. Thomas-Graham is able to explore many issues, including racial profiling, interracial dating and the role of flamboyant black activists.
Ms. Thomas-Graham, who lives in Chappaqua, is a graduate of Harvard-Radcliffe College, and the Harvard Law and Business Schools. She is the first black woman to be named a partner at McKinsey & Company in Manhattan, the world's largest management consulting concern. Recently, she was named by Consulting magazine as one of the 10 most influential consultants in the United States. 
 Her writing career began with "A Darker Shade of Crimson," a book set at Harvard, and continues with her new book, "Blue Blood," released in May and set at Yale (both Simon & Schuster). She is at work on a third "Ivy League Mystery," whose setting will be Princeton. Ms. Thomas-Graham is married to Lawrence Otis Graham, who drew national attention after writing about the racial attitudes he experienced as a busboy at a Greenwich country club. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Ms. Thomas-Graham:
Q. How much of Nikki is you?
A. We have some traits in common because we're obviously both young black women working in environments that are traditionally white male environments, and we're both deeply steeped in Harvard. But we're pretty different. I'm married, a mother and living in New York, and she's single, living in Cambridge, and she's certainly a lot more adventurous than I am.
Q. Both of you had Detroit roots. What have you left behind in Detroit?
A. It's one of the themes I explore in the book -- this whole idea of having grown up in a city like Detroit, which is a majority black population, a city which has a lot of economic difficulties and continues to although they're starting to come out of it. My heroine is living in this environment in Cambridge, which is predominantly white. Her work life has very few people of color in it. My work life is similar.
One of the themes I explore in this new book is how it feels to then suddenly be thrust into a new situation, which does remind you a lot of home. For in this book Nikki does end up in New Haven, which is in many ways similar to Detroit. And so it's a very sharp visceral reminder to her of her upbringing, and it brings back to her a lot of questions as to what her responsibilities are to the black community and people who are less advantaged economically than she.
She is trying to combine that feeling of obligation and the desire to contribute with her ambition to be successful professionally. I think a lot of black professionals face those same kinds of issues.
Q. How have you dealt with those issues?
A. Well, I try to do a few different things. I do believe that being excellent in my professional life is an important part of making a contribution to the African-American community because it is quite important for people to believe that black professionals are excellent at their work and that they can achieve and succeed in exactly the same way as their white counterparts.
In addition to that I do try to use the skills I've learned in the corporate environment to work with not-for-profit organizations that really do provide services not just to the African-American community but to communities that are not as privileged economically. I sit on the board of the American Red Cross in Greater New York, and I try to utilize some of the business skills I've learned to help them use their money wisely. And I try to talk with young people who are considering business careers. A lot of young people -- and it's not exclusively black young people -- don't really understand how exciting business careers can be.
Q. Living in Chappaqua is very different from living in White Plains. Compare and contrast them.
A. Both of them are terrific communities. My husband is a longtime resident of White Plains. We really felt embraced by the community there, where we were for almost eight years. Chappaqua is clearly a much smaller community. Our son was born a year ago, and we felt Chappaqua would be a nice environment for him to be in because it is a much smaller community and is largely comprised of people with young children.
Q. Your husband, Lawrence, a Democrat, is considering a run for Congress. If he does, what would that mean to you? You talk about "power couples" in your book, and you are clearly part of one.
A. To be honest, that label "power couple" has almost started to become pejorative. Because the reality is, Lawrence was highly successful when I met him and I had achieved quite a lot before I met him. Clearly, I think that the two of us combined are even more than the two of us separate. But the reason I married him is he is incredibly supportive of my professional goals and I of his. We draw strength from each other.
Q. He has written about many racist things that have happened to him. I take it your experiences were not like that.
A. I think I have experienced racism in my life in ways that are probably more subtle than some of the things Lawrence has gone through, primarily because I am a woman. My situations have been much more the case where people have not taken me seriously, have assumed I'm the secretary on the team, as opposed to the partner on the team. I have been followed through stores on Madison Avenue because people assume that I as a young black woman couldn't have the income to be shopping there. I've never had a violent confrontation, but I've had many instances of feeling diminished and demeaned because of people's attitudes toward me as a black woman.
Q. In your book Nikki is stopped for "driving while black." Much has been written on the subject of racial profiling. How do you balance what the police call good police skills with not following racist policies?
A. I think what really angers black professionals about this whole situation is that it literally is such a visceral reminder that the color of our skin is the first and only thing that some people see. They don't see how we're dressed. They don't see our facial expressions. They don't see how we conduct ourselves. All they see is a black person doing something they assume a black person should not be doing.
Q. Nikki has a white boyfriend. And your character acknowledges that this is a big issue in the black community. Talk about that.
A. A lot of people have told me that it is very realistic that someone in my heroine's situation would have this issue to deal with because the reality is that there are just not as many black men who are in college at all and particularly not in the Ivy League.
I was talking to someone at Harvard in the freshman class, and she said there were roughly 100 black freshmen and 75 of them are women. So, statistically, black women have to confront this issue. My own view, because I'm quite the romantic at heart, is that you should be with the person you're in love with irrespective of their background.
Q. Your book includes a black activist, someone like the Rev. Al Sharpton. You seem to have some ambivalence about such people.
A. This is clearly a voice for people who don't have a voice and I think no matter what any of his detracters say, people like Al Sharpton speak for people who otherwise would not be heard.
At the same time, I think even his closest admirers would say there is clearly an element in all these figures of needing to be recognized, wanting to have the microphone, wanting to be front and center. So it raises an important issue: what is the right leadership model, particularly for a minority group that has traditionally had economic problems? Is there only one model? How do you achieve a state where there are multiple voices?
Q. And what is the answer?
A. I'm sure that's a whole other book. But one of the reasons I'm so excited that Lawrence is considering running for Congress is, he is clearly a person of courage who has dealt with racism issues but also has reason, judgment and balance. He is the kind of person we need, not just speaking for the black community but for all of us. If Lawrence wins, he will be the first black ever to be elected north of New York City in the entire state of New York.

HEADLINE: Call It Easy Street or Windfall, Lottery Gold Can Fade Fast

BYLINE: By DAN GRABEL 

 BODY:
IF 1999 is an average year for lottery winners in Westchester County, five people will achieve the promise of "a dollar and a dream" and win the jackpot offered by New York state every Wednesday and Saturday. Sixty-three residents have made the big hit since the lottery began 33 years ago.
Because betting is down by 4 percent, the lottery division of the state's Department of Taxation and Finance will be creating new ways to attract business. That is a constant effort because some players get bored and others need a jolt, like a $10 million jackpot, to spark their interest. 
 But that wasn't the case with a player from Irvington who recently won. At a news conference held in Irvington, an ebullient John F. Buckhout who facetiously described himself as "a sanitation engineer," became the state's 87th Lotto millionaire last Wednesday when he picked up a pre-tax check for $3.25 million. Mr. Buckhout immediately hired a financial planner at Lehman Brothers, bought his wife, Stephanie, a shiny Cadillac sports utility vehicle and is trying to buy a season pass to the New York Jets games.
One of Mr. Buckhout's colleagues on his garbage route said that generally a group of Irvington workers bought a Lotto ticket and coffee when they stopped at Zarrilli's delicatessen on Main Street. But on a recent Saturday, when they were off work, Mr. Buckhout went into the delicatessen alone and bought the winning ticket. It was worth $7 million for a 20-year payout. Mr. Buckhout chose the cash instead.
The latest lottery versions appeal to different regions of the state: Big Apple Lotto, Long Island Lotto, Upstate Lotto and Western N.Y. Lotto. Among those four, the game you play depends on the region where you buy the ticket. The estimated weekly top prize is $110,000. While you may have your heart set on millions, Jeff Perlee, until recently the director of the lottery, said, "Research shows people play not just for the jackpot, but a chance to win any prize."
Lottery officials say that under the new format announced in March, which reduced the number selection from 54 to 51, there are "better odds and more chances to win." But not for the jackpot, where the odds went from roughly 12 million to 1 to 18 million to 1 and the cost of a game went from 50 cents to $1.
The No. 1 ticket seller in Westchester is Homefield Bowl on Sawmill River Road in Yonkers, which sold $923,776 worth of games last year. Which is the luckiest shop? With only five jackpots in the county in 1998, no one shop is regarded as the hot place. Gail Felder of White Plains, buying chances on Main Street, said, "If I win something here, this will be my lucky store."
The lottery started out with just one type of game, and now there are more than two dozen lottery and instant cash versions, with more being introduced as quickly as some inventive genius can devise a new way to make a long shot appealing. While the lottery's annual profit of about $1.5 billion is supposed to help finance education, the money goes into the state's general fund and becomes what the politicians like to call "fungible." That means Albany lawmakers mix the dollars with all other income, and it could end up anywhere.
The prize money's destination is a bit easier to follow: it goes into winners' bank accounts. But, almost universally, Wednesday and Saturday's high-profile winners disappear into anonymity after the first blush of publicity. Finding them is a job for Sherlock Holmes. The most anonymous men and women in Westchester are the people who have hit the jackpot.
Statewide, there have been more than 1,182 new millionaires in these games of chance where $1 may put the winner on easy street -- but not always for life. Con artists, telemarketers and long-lost real and fake relatives are quickly on the phone to relieve the winners of some of their cash, and just as quickly those phones become unlisted numbers. Winners often turn the pot of gold into a new home in a new location, making the search for winners almost impossible.
Nevertheless, hours on the phone finally uncovered a few Westchester winners and revealed that having a reputation as a millionaire is not as enviable as losers might think.
Phyliss Penzo of Yonkers shared a $6 million prize with Robert Cunningham of Dobbs Ferry in 1984. After Federal and state tax bites, their annual earnings come to around $100,000 -- not a great fortune in today's economy. Ms. Penzo, a former pizzeria waitress, said the money had not changed her life that much, but she was grateful for the windfall. She and her husband, Robert, fixed up the old family home, and she takes care of her elderly mother and her grandchildren. The Penzos never went on a glamorous cruise. For a couple of years they were hounded by callers who had something to sell. In five years the annual payout will end. Millionaire? It was temporary.
Robert Cunningham was a Yonkers detective when he bought some Lotto tickets and shared them with Ms. Penzo instead of giving her a tip at the pizzeria. He is retired and lives modestly in his old home, which he renovated. He bought a Cadillac and, with his wife, Gina, has taken trips to Alaska, the Canadian Rockies and the District of Columbia.
The Cunninghams had an unlisted phone number for a few years. "I'm not wallowing in money, and, yeah, like Phyliss, I still play Lotto," Mr. Cunningham said.
Carmen Kramer of Mamaroneck and her daughter Karen shared a $10 million prize in 1998. She said: "The win gives you a lot of security. Luck is the name God uses when he wants to be anonymous. God has been good to me."
Bernice Hunter Lemon of Ossining, a single mother with three children, bought a $1,000-a-Week-for-Life ticket in the summer of 1997 but did not claim her prize until December of that year. She is guaranteed no less than $1 million.
When a 40-year-old telephone operator, Yvonne Wright of Mount Vernon, was asked why she chose Quick Pick, the automatic number selector, instead of selecting her own six numbers, she said, "I don't have time to sit down and write out six numbers." Good thing she didn't. The machine picked winners worth a $10 million prize in 1995.
Dorothy T. O'Connor of White Plains, a widow and a secretary, won $6 million in 1992 and takes her prize over 20 years at $285,715 a year, before state and Federal taxes. Does she still play Lotto? Her answer: "Lightning may strike twice."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Grand Army Plaza;
Spaces that March to Different Drummers

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
ONE of Donald J. Trump's current projects, raising the sunken plaza in front of the General Motors Building, on the east side of Fifth Avenue from 58th to 59th Streets, brushes against one of New York's early preservation battles and focuses attention on the entire Plaza area itself. For the construction of the General Motors Building in 1968 followed bitter protests over its changes to the Grand Army Plaza, complaints that remain unresolved even by the work in progress.
As a work of design, the double court on the west side of Fifth from 58th to 60th Streets, was nothing special in the 19th century, little more than two plots of grass and paving. But the hotels that ringed the area by the 1890's gave it a de facto importance. 
 When the Plaza Hotel, with its white masonry with a green roof, was built in 1907, today's Grand Army Plaza in front was still unformed. But in 1911 the publisher Joseph Pulitzer died, leaving $50,000 in his will for a fountain to be erected on the site.
The design by Carrere & Hastings for the new plaza was serene and peaceful, a layered fountain leading up to Karl Bitter's "Abundance" statue. It included free-standing columns and balusters to set the area apart -- elements that were built, but later removed -- and a closely spaced ring of topiary trees trimmed as cubes, which was never carried out.
In 1926, the owner of the Plaza Hotel, Harry S. Black, bought the 1892 Savoy Hotel and other buildings directly facing his hotel to erect by 1928 a new 29-story apartment hotel, the Savoy Plaza. Designed by McKim, Mead & White, the newer building played a skyscraper foil to the Plaza Hotel, with a white marble base, white brick and a giant green tiled roof.
Gradually, this white-and-green color scheme became the dominant theme of the Plaza, with the Bergdorf-Goodman, Squibb and other buildings following suit; the white played off nicely with the marble of the Carrere & Hastings fountain. The 1939 W. P. A. Guide to New York City praised the "extraordinary unity" of the surrounding buildings.
The announcement that an investment group would demolish the Savoy Plaza for a new office building came in August 1964 in a city just rocked by the loss of Penn Station. The outlook, even for the most important buildings, seemed bleak; the Landmarks Preservation Commission was not established until the following year.
In October 1964 the architects and teachers Elliot Willensky and Norval White, who had picketed at Penn Station to protest its demolition, organized their students in a demonstration at the Plaza to protest the demolition of the Savoy Plaza. Signs included "Renege on Rampant Wrecking" and one placard, "Landmarks Preservation Weak," was a bitter satirical jab at Mayor Robert F. Wagner, who had just declared "Landmarks Preservation Week" but had not put any law into effect. One student, Miles Kurland, carried a sign "Save the Seagram Building." He told The New York Times that he was "thinking ahead."
The architect of what became the General Motors building, Edward Durrell Stone, designed a 50-story shaft with angled piers of white marble -- "a white building for a white plaza," he told The Times in 1964. In accord with the 1961 zoning law revision, the tower set back from the street to create a plaza -- considered by city regulations an amenity, which in turn permitted the building to be taller.
But instead of the typical open space with fountains and benches, this one was really a shopping plaza. Excavating the front area allowed a perimeter of stores around a sunken plaza, reached from the street by a stairway on Fifth.
This voided the possibility of a grand, central approach to the building, but it also reduced and isolated the traffic on the plaza. Besides, recalls Hicks Stone, son of Edward Durrell Stone and also an architect, since the retail space was underground it did not count against the building's zoning allowance and "the annual rent exceeded the amount of the architect's fees."
The most serious issue raised was not the appearance of the new building, but its overall effect on the Grand Army Plaza, seen as one of New York's few successful open spaces -- a space defined by an even perimeter of complementary buildings, but broken by the notch for the General Motors Plaza.
The sunken plaza was "a sick planning joke," wrote Ada Louise Huxtable in The Times in 1966. It was "a poor man's Rockefeller Center skating rink," wrote Peter Blake in New York Magazine in 1968, the year the building was finished.
W HO needs a plaza on a plaza?" say the 1978 and 1988 editions of the AIA Guide to New York City, by Willensky and White. But Business Week quoted Arthur Dooley, general manager of the Plaza Hotel, as saying that the new building "opened up air space and improved the general feeling around the area."
Edward Durrell Stone was one of those who brushed off criticism. In 1968 he gave a reporter for Business Week this account of a conversation he just happened to overhear by two men gazing upon the new structure: " 'It's more beautiful than the Taj Mahal,' " one exclaimed. 'They ought to knight the s.o.b. who designed it,' said the other.' " And in 1972 Stone told Paul Goldberger, for a profile in The Times on the architect: "There isn't a taxi driver in New York who won't say the General Motors Building is the most beautiful thing in the city."
Last year Mr. Trump bought, with Conseco, an insurance company based in Carmel, Ind., the General Motors Building and leased part of the ground floor to CBS, which will use it for a live morning news show with the rest of the plaza as a backdrop. The customary name inflation has followed -- signs on the construction fence now read "General Motors Building at Trump International Plaza" -- and Mr. Trump has rethought the sunken retail area. "Sunken plazas in general don't work, and that plaza never worked," he says. "The only retail space in New York that's below street level that's worked is the space in Trump Tower."
So, working with the landscape architects Thomas Balsley Associates and the architects LeClere Associates, Mr. Trump is covering most of the sunken plaza, recapturing that area for retail space with a small entry stairway. The roof of the new retail space will form a new open plaza, several steps above grade, with fountains and seating areas on either side, and a central walkway from Fifth Avenue to the General Motors Building; it will be finished next year.
Asked if, from a real estate point of view, he would prefer having the old Savoy Plaza on the site of the present General Motors Building, Mr. Trump -- whose Trump International Hotel and condominium apartments overlooks 59th Street on the opposite side of Central Park -- hesitated a moment. "Well the GM building is . . . 2 million square feet," he said with emphasis. "But I believe that when I finish, the G.M. building will top the Savoy Plaza esthetically as well."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
Where the Ante Is Always Going Up

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER 

 BODY:
THIS is the story of five brothers and a temptation-filled city. It is the story of how one of those brothers picked up three cards from a poker table and found himself staring into the pit of personal destruction. It is the story of a monumental effort by some of this nation's best minds to address a vexatious, volatile issue. It is, in fact, a darned complicated story, so we'll dispense with any more of these irksome foreshadowing sentences.
The gist of it is, my four brothers and I, not to mention my father and a brother-in-law, recently held our first ever men's-only reunion, picking Atlantic City for the honor. For three days we did all the things men do when they get together without chaperones. 
 Most of those things are, of course, unprintably boring, so we'll here discuss only one: our attempt to sample the casino life style without encountering bankruptcy. In this regard, two of the five brothers succeeded admirably -- they walked into several casinos, took appreciative note of the flashing lights, and left. Another brother contented himself with looking like a common, contemptible tourist, playing only the quarter slot and video-poker machines.
And two of us went for the real thing: the card tables. I'm ashamed to admit that although I try to do everything I can to support New Jersey's economy, including buying lottery tickets, I had never been in a casino before. Fortunately, brother Dale had, and he taught me the basics: never buy chips with $20 bills (too small; you look like a rube), never yell "Good golly jeepers!" when you hit 21 at the blackjack table.
He also taught me how to play a seductive little game called Let It Ride. It's a simple game built around a five-card poker hand. You're dealt three cards, then the dealer shows a fourth card, and a fifth. If you have a pair of 10's or higher among those five cards, you win something. As the hand unfolds, you're given two chances to pull back some of your bet if things aren't going well.
I was playing at the cheapest table there was, where the minimum bet to start a hand was $30. I was about halfway through losing $100 when it happened: The dealer gave me my three cards, and they were all 7's.
I had three of a kind with two cards still to be revealed. If either one was a 7, my $30 bet would turn into a 50-to-1 payoff. Brother Dale immediately started gambling-addiction counseling, but it was too late.
Let me relate the backdrop against which this was all happening. A few days before our visit, the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, which spent two years examining the explosion of gambling, issued a thorough, balanced report. It is by no means anti-gambling, but it urges states that have rushed rabidly into the lottery and casino business to stop and think it through.
It's a significant document that ought to provoke discussion. And how have we reacted in the month since its release? "New Jersey Yawns at Federal Report on Gaming," read a headline in the Atlantic City paper. The article had comments from the Mayor, legislators and others who seemed to feel the report couldn't possibly be significant. Many admitted that they came to that conclusion without actually reading it.
Dr. James C. Dobson, president of Focus on the Family and the commission member most concerned about gambling, says that's about what he expected from the politicians, given the way money and influence work. But he still has hope that the commission's efforts won't be for nothing.
"Who would have believed 30 years ago that the American people could be weaned away from cigarettes?" he said. "How did that happen? It happened because the facts were presented. If this commission starts that process, then I'll feel my time will have been well spent."
Back at the casino, Dale was dragging me out the door. There had been no fourth 7, no big payoff. I was sure there would be one in the next hand, or the next, but he wasn't buying.
Later, hogtied to a chair in my hotel room, I had time to think. Here's what I thought:
Anyone who says gambling isn't addictive is nuts. Anyone who says Atlantic City -- a beach town where no one goes to the beach, a town with absurd opulence on one block and ragged poverty on the next -- is healthy is nuts. Anyone who thinks a state that was once built on things like farming and glass is better off now that it relies increasingly on gaming is -- well, is looking at three 7's, foolishly thinking the fourth is on the way.

HEADLINE: Life Through the Eyes of Teen-Age Girls

BYLINE: By ALIX BOYLE 

 BODY:
ADOLESCENT girls feel an overwhelming pressure to be smart, beautiful, popular and mature. That pressure, from parents, peers, and the media, can lead to depression, eating disorders, self-mutilation and sexual experiences that happen too soon.
So says 18-year-old Sara Shandler, a student at Wesleyan University and the author of "Ophelia Speaks" (HarperCollins, 1999), a book of essays by teen-age girls ages 12 to 18 on topics ranging from eating disorders and body image to teen pregnancy and relationships with parents. She said she hopes girls will take away the message that they are not alone and their experiences aren't unique. 
 "I wrote the book in the hope that other teen-agers would see themselves in the book and be helped by that and so parents and other adults could understand us better," Ms. Shandler said. "I hoped they would see who we are in our own words."
Ms. Shandler, who has kept a journal since she was 8, read "Reviving Ophelia," a chronicle of the problems of teen-age girls in the 1990's by the psychologist Mary Pipher. But Ms. Shandler said she thought, although the book had merit, its message was filtered through adult eyes.
On the way home from a family vacation, Ms. Shandler's father, Michael, suggested that she write her own book and call it "Ophelia Speaks." Ms. Shandler, then a 16-year-old junior at Amherst Regional High School in Amherst, Mass.,mailed 7,000 letters to junior high and high school principals and school psychologists. She asked them to pass along her letter requesting contributions to her book to the girls in the school.
More than 800 girls responded and 75 essays eventually were published in the book. Ms. Shandler starts each chapter with a brief introduction about the topic. She writes briefly about her own experiences, then comments on the essays from girls who live in different regions of the country and come from differing racial and economic backgrounds.
On depression, Ms. Shandler writes: "The worst night of my life I envisioned my own funeral, my death by suicide. I curled up in a tight ball, paralyzed by my imagination. My parents were the only people who cried at the service.
"Writing here is only the third time I've confessed those deathly images. The next day, I tearfully told my 10th-grade boyfriend. Later, I confided in my journal. Now, I tell you."
Ms. Shandler goes on to say that, although she is the daughter of a therapist, she didn't seek help, but wished she had. Instead, she practiced self-therapy by reading feminist authors like Alice Walker, writing in her journal about her feelings, and sitting and thinking.
"I didn't like myself and I had a thousand reasons," she said. "I was just not turning out to be the person I wanted to be." Eventually, the depression lifted.
In the chapter on first sexual experiences, Ms. Shandler reports that she lost her virginity a month before her 15th birthday, and that most girls who wrote to her wished they had waited for a "more perfect time" to have sex.
"No one wrote about feeling satisfied by first-time sexual relationships," Ms. Shandler writes. "Instead of feeling love and commitment, girls consistently reported disappointment and disillusionment."
But girls have always felt the pressures of growing up. What makes today's adolescents different?
"There's not one answer," Ms. Shandler said. "To say just one thing oversimplifies it. But I could point to a few things like the media representation of women. We equate thinness with success. There's also the pressure to have a good job when you finish school and be successful. The feminist movement came with some incredible benefits, but it has its downfalls as well. I think there's more pressure to be a mini-adult from the time we're very young."
Ms. Pipher, the author of "Reviving Ophelia," was unavailable to comment on Ms. Shandler's book.
Books like "Ophelia Speaks" are useful because they encourage young women to talk about their feelings, said Elizabeth Rubin, a licensed clinical social worker in Guilford who treats adolescents and has led discussion groups for middle-school girls.
"The more you can get girls to articulate what's going on in their interior lives, the better," Ms. Rubin said. "The process of giving voice to an experience can be very validating. Research has shown that young women don't trust their own perceptions, they don't listen to that little voice inside them. This book reinforces that."
In choosing a boyfriend, for example, women and girls may not listen to their inner voice telling them that the guy is wrong for them. Later, in therapy, a woman may admit that the internal signals were there, but she didn't listen, Ms. Rubin said.
Ms. Rubin asked the Adams Middle School in Guilford to refer girls who were reluctant to speak up in class or who might benefit from having a place to discuss the same issues raised in "Ophelia Speaks." The girls talked about fearing they wouldn't be popular if they answered too many questions in class or appeared too smart. Others were unhappy because their bodies were not the same as the models in fashion magazines.
After attending the discussion group, one girl had the courage to confront a male teacher for his sexist behavior and several others filed a complaint with the principal about boys who were repeatedly harassing them in the halls.
Those who study teen behavior said that, in many ways, life has improved for teen-agers, said Dr. John Schowalter, an adolescent psychiatrist and director of clinical services at the Yale Child Study Center.
Teen-age girls are more careful about sexuality and teen-age pregnancy rates are down. Use of hard drugs is down. Fewer teens are dying in alcohol-related car accidents. Tobacco use by teen-agers is starting to fall, Dr. Schowalter said.
But, Dr. Schowalter said cases of anorexia and bulimia have increased in the last 15 years, probably due to greater recognition that bulimia is a disease that must be treated.
There are more female role models who are not rail thin than there were a generation ago, including Oprah Winfrey, Rosie O'Donnell, Attorney General Janet Reno and Secretary of State Madeline Albright.
"When people write about adolescence, they remember the pain about that time, the date they didn't get, the cliques and that their face was bursting with zits," Dr. Schowalter said.
But it would be hard to prove, scientifically, that it's more stressful to be a teen-ager now that it ever was, he said.
Ms. Shandler has no other books in the works and is waiting to see where "Ophelia Speaks" will take her. Although she has not declared a major, she suspects her studies will have something to do with writing.
"Being a teen-age girl is impossible to put into one sentence," Ms. Shandler said. "That's why I had to do a whole book."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2750 words

HEADLINE: Filling the Space Atop Symphony Space

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WHAT'S gray, 108 feet 11 inches long, 5 feet 5 inches high and weighs 23 tons? Answer: The solution to a vexatious and long-running development dilemma on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
Occupying a large lot on a busy intersection, the Symphony Space performing arts center at Broadway and 95th Street has attracted many would-be developers over the years who almost always wanted to tear the place down. The dilemma was that the nonprofit Symphony Space, starved for money though it was, could not bear to sacrifice its quirky auditorium, which was patched together from a 1915 market hall and former ice-skating rink. 
 The solution rumbled over the George Washington Bridge early in the morning of July 10 and, by nightfall, had been hoisted into place: five enormous steel girders long enough to span the width of the auditorium, allowing 17 floors of apartments to be constructed over the theater.
"Normally, a foundation is below ground," said Joseph Zelazny, the president of Kreisler Borg Florman, the construction manager of the $89 million project. "Here, it is above an existing building."
The concrete and steel platform that is created around these girders will support a load of 13,600 tons (27.2 million pounds), according to the engineers, Jacob S. Grossman and Chen Li of Rosenwasser/Grossman.
Including the theater and retail space at the base, the building will have 22 stories in all, towering over the quaint cottages and gardens of the landmark Pomander Walk to the west. There will be 285 rental apartments, 71 set aside for lower-income tenants. It is to be finished at the end of 2000. The project is being developed by the Related Companies and designed by Costas Kondylis Associates.
Starting with several million dollars from the sale of its air rights to Related, Symphony Space will launch a capital campaign to create an endowment, rehabilitate its main theater and rebuild the Thalia theater downstairs. This project is designed by the Polshek Partnership.
As a crane lifted the first girder skyward last Saturday morning from the back of a flatbed trailer almost half the length of a city block, Isaiah Sheffer, the co-founder and artistic director of Symphony Space, watched intently from a nearby Broadway median. Suddenly, he burst into song: "O beautiful for spacious skies . . ."
He might as well have been singing "All My Trials." Or "The Long and Winding Road."
Ever since the mid-80's, Symphony Space has been trying to exploit the economic potential of its property while maintaining its off-beat spot in the city's cultural firmament. Real estate figures as canny and experienced as the Zeckendorf and Rose families, Christopher M. Jeffries and Philip E. Aarons, Leonard Boxer and Charles A. Goldstein have come and gone, frustrated by the complexities and uncertainties of the site.
What is now Symphony Space was built in 1915 by Vincent Astor as the 95th Street Market. Thomas Healy bought the building in 1917 and converted the 20,000-square-foot main hall into the Crystal Palace skating rink and the fish market downstairs into the Sunken Gardens restaurant. He built the three-story Healy Building at 94th Street.
On an adjacent mid-block site running from 94th to 95th Street, Healy developed Pomander Walk in 1922. A tiny patch of Tudor England on the Upper West Side, this is a double row of cottages facing one another across a walkway lined by gardens.
The Crystal Palace became the Symphony Theater and the Sunken Gardens became the Thalia, a cinema designed by Raymond Irrera and Ben Schlanger that was one of the city's best-known revival houses.
In January 1978, Mr. Sheffer, a writer and director for theater and television, and Allan Miller, an orchestra conductor who is now a documentary filmmaker, rented the Symphony Theater for a 12-hour Bach marathon. The next day, with coins donated by concertgoers, they opened a bank account under the name Symphony Space.
Symphony Space quickly became "a sort of artistic town square for the neighborhood," wrote Peter Salwen in "Upper West Side Story" (Abbeville Press, 1989).
By the end of 1978, it bought the building for $10,010 from Broadwest Realty Corporation and leased back the retail space to Broadwest, which also owned Pomander Walk and the Healy Building. Significantly, Symphony Space granted Broadwest an option to repurchase the theater building as far into the future as 2003.
IN 1981, Broadwest sold its properties, leases and option to Bradford N. Swett and Pergola Properties for $4.8 million. The new owners converted Pomander Walk into a co-operative and served notice on Symphony Space in 1985 that they would exercise the purchase option. Among Pergola's plans was to tear down Symphony Space and replace it with a multiplex.
Symphony Space, meanwhile, was trying to work out its own development deal and battling the purchase option in court. That case was not resolved until June 1996 at the Court of Appeals in Albany.
At issue was whether an option to purchase commercial property was covered by the Rule Against Perpetuities, a judicial concept originating in the 17th century whose purpose is to prevent the "dead hand of landowners reaching into future generations," as the court put it. In the case of corporations, the rule in New York State is that a property interest is void unless it vests within 21 years. The Symphony Space option ran more than 24 years.
Unanimously, the Court of Appeals found that the option "violates the statutory prohibition against remote vesting and is therefore unenforceable." Symphony Space emerged with clear title to its own home.
"What we sought to do was preserve Symphony Space as a community resource -- in perpetuity," said Steven M. Alden of Debevoise & Plimpton, a lawyer who has represented the organization since 1978.
"I wept," recalled Joanne Cossa, the executive vice president and managing director of Symphony Space, when word of the decisive legal victory came down.
A month later, she wept again.
A bill arrived for $770,000 in real estate taxes on the retail space, which had been leased to Pergola and Mr. Swett. "We quickly learned that they hadn't paid their taxes for quite a number of years," Ms. Cossa said. The notice came from a collection agency for an investment partnership in Connecticut that had purchased the tax lien from the city. "There was simply no way," Mr. Sheffer said, "that we could raise money to pay off someone else's taxes."
Fresh from winning control of its building, Symphony Space now faced foreclosure.
There were three choices, said William L. Haines, the chairman of the Symphony Space real estate committee and former chairman of its board. Least palatable was clearing the 95th Street site and starting over. A second choice was simply to renovate the commercial space and find higher-end retail tenants.
But with the residential real estate market percolating again, Mr. Haines sought a developer interested in the more complicated prospect of buying the Healy Building, assuming the tax liability and devising a way to preserve Symphony Space.
Last summer, he turned to a fellow board member from the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation: Jeff T. Blau, executive vice president of the Related Companies, headed by Stephen M. Ross.
"Steve had a reputation for being able to get from here to there," Mr. Haines said.
By purchasing the Healy Building, Related opened up the full Broadway blockfront for development. Before it could proceed, however, Related had to settle lawsuits involving Mr. Swett, Symphony Space and the retail tenants. It also had to pay the back taxes, which had built up with interest to more than $1.25 million.
Related also had to move quickly to take advantage of a year-end reallocation of bonding authority that would permit the sale, through the city Housing Development Corporation, of $89 million in low-interest, 30-year bonds, exempt from city, state and Federal taxes, to finance the project.
The use of tax-exempt bonds ordinarily obliges a developer to set aside 20 percent of the units for lower-income families, with 80 percent at market rates, and Related is an experienced builder of "80-20" projects.
But in the Symphony Space project, Mr. Blau said, city officials negotiated a 25 percent set-aside in return for speeding the application. Those units will be rented to tenants whose incomes are no higher than 60 percent of the current $50,000 median for the area (or $30,000 for a family of four).
Related will build 11 low-income apartments at 221 West 105th Street to qualify for a 20 percent zoning bonus under the city's "inclusionary housing" program. This yields an extra 40,000 square feet -- roughly 40 apartments -- on the Broadway site. The overall development will have 325,000 square feet of gross floor space, including retail space below grade and the theaters.
Under the deal, Symphony Space will own its auditorium and the Thalia. Related will take title to everything above the top of the theater itself, in an arrangement known as a "fee above a plane." To accommodate construction, Symphony Space will be dark for four months, through October.
Neither Related nor Symphony Space would disclose how much was being paid for the development rights, amounting to more than 200,000 square feet. In today's market, air rights might easily trade for $50 a square foot, suggesting an amount in the neighborhood of $10 million or higher.
That would be a nice neighborhood, but Symphony Space officials said they must raise at least $5 million to build a new lobby, marquee, box office, bathrooms, heating and air-conditioning systems, elevator for the disabled, dressing rooms, offices and backstage area. After that is finished in 2001, they hope to rebuild the Thalia, primarily as a repertory movie house.
"We offered to knock down the theater and build them a brand new, state-of-the-art theater," Mr. Blau said. The answer was no; Symphony Space had to be kept.
Mr. Sheffer and Ms. Cossa feared a crippling loss of momentum from being closed for demolition and reconstruction. "You lose your place with artists and funders if you're out of business two years," he said.
They were also devoted to their old hall. "The space itself is a large part of our success," Mr. Sheffer said. "You can have 832 people and it feels homey."
Ms. Cossa said even the blacked-out skylights contribute to the ambiance, by making the low room seem a bit higher, and may augment the acoustics. "It is magical," she said, "and we didn't want to mess with this space and wind up with something worse."
Enter Rosenwasser/Grossman Consulting Engineers. Among several hundred projects in New York City, the 45-year-old firm engineered the Westyard Building, 450 West 33d Street, which spans the 220-foot-wide railroad cut leading from the Hudson River tunnel into Pennsylvania Station.
One of their first proposals was to insert a column through the west gallery of the auditorium, which would have cut off 30 to 40 seats. "Couldn't the column go against the wall?" Mr. Sheffer asked. "That's a very long span," Mr. Grossman replied.
The most obvious spanning method -- structural steel trusses -- was ruled out because such trusses would be too large to assemble in place and too heavy to build elsewhere, transport and raise into position. They would also be so tall that the building would lose a full floor of apartments.
Instead, Mr. Grossman and Mr. Li proposed to erect five steel girders to serve as the supporting core for two gigantic concrete beams filled with hundreds of steel reinforcing rods, or rebar.
"This is not something we invented for this project," Mr. Grossman said, "but we've never done it on this scale."
Each beam will be 11 feet high after the concrete is poured and formed. The south beam will be 8 feet wide, with two steel girders at its core, spanning the auditorium at a slight angle. The north beam will be 10 feet wide, with three girders at its core.
The beams are supported on the east side by angled concrete supports known as shear walls and on the west side by steel columns that have been erected in two holes chopped through the far end of the auditorium. Much larger concrete columns will be poured around those steel members.
The girders are cambered -- or bowed -- 6 inches. They will straighten out under compression from the tremendous weight above but still clear the saw-tooth skylight bulkheads atop Symphony Space.
The girders were made by Metropolitan Steel in Sinking Spring, Pa., about 110 miles southwest of New York, for the Skyline Steel Corporation of Brooklyn, the subcontractor.
They arrived in Manhattan before dawn on July 10. The flatbed trailers composed a caravan nearly one-quarter of a mile in length, parked along Broadway from 94th to 99th Street. A crane with a 200-foot-long hydraulic boom stood in front of Symphony Space to lift the steel into position.
It took only seven minutes to hoist the first girder off the truck and set it down. A small crew of ironworkers stationed around the Symphony Space rooftop guided the giant pieces into place, seemingly with no more exertion than would be needed to move a bureau around a bedroom.
One worker, Steve Coffin, was almost balletic in his movements. As he and his colleagues clambered surefootedly over the girders, Tom McClain of Seamus Henchy and Associates, the project manager for Symphony Space, marveled. "It takes you back to our arboreal past," he said.
TWENTY or so contractors, architects, engineers, Symphony Space officials and family members watched the spectacle from a Broadway median. Making a cameo appearance was the actor Jonathan Hadary, who has performed readings at Symphony Space. He stopped by on his way to breakfast.
Knots of pedestrians gathered across the street in front of the Key West Diner and Hotel Newton. Brian McClave, who lives nearby, offered his 3 1/2-year-old daughter, Margot, the best seat in the house: atop his shoulders. "That guy better watch his fingers up there, right?" said he to her.
Not everyone welcomes 285 new apartments where the subway station is already crowded and the streets already congested. A passerby who recognized Mr. Sheffer, but did not identify himself, called out angrily and sarcastically as he walked by: "Congratulations. A 22-story building. That's really responsible of you."
There is ill will toward Mr. Sheffer on Pomander Walk, too. "I have had all my neighbors say to me, 'I'll never go into Symphony Space again,' " said Stan Clickstein, a retired woodworker who lives on the walk and was a leader in an unsuccessful fight against the project. "He sold us down the river. People believe that."
"We're outraged," he said. "We feel violated. And we feel there's nothing we can do because they're building as of right."
Like others on the walk, John Cates, a painter and actor, lovingly tends his garden. "The main thing we're worried about is that we're going to lose our sunlight," he said.
Preservationists are also angry at Mr. Sheffer for the gutting of the Thalia's Art Moderne interior, since they believed he intended to preserve it. Mr. Sheffer said that what he promised to preserve was the name, nature and function of the Thalia. But he added that distinctive architectural features like fountains, art glass, signs and tiles had been salvaged for eventual reuse.
The renovation of Symphony Space and the Thalia is designed by James Stewart Polshek, who said he took the job because it offered the "opportunity for Symphony Space to express itself as an independent, progressive, vital cultural institution."
Naturally, that has caused some tension with Mr. Kondylis, whose design for the apartment building hearkens back to the Upper West Side's Art Deco past. "Even though it stands out -- and I believe the identity of Symphony Space should stand out -- it should somehow be sympathetic to the rest of the building," Mr. Kondylis said.
Mr. Sheffer is confident that esthetic differences can be resolved. But it is obvious that he looks forward to the end of his unsought 15-year career as real estate developer. "I would rather have spent the time writing and directing," he said.
And yet, standing on the stage of Symphony Space, surveying the oddly proportioned but undeniably gemutlich auditorium, Mr. Sheffer said: "Look at this place. I don't regret saving it for a moment -- even if it did inconvenience some engineers."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 14; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: DESTINATIONS;
From the Fields to a Parking Lot Near You

BYLINE: By JOSEPH D'AGNESE 

 BODY:
"WE grow for taste!" blared the sign on Sy and Elida Griskonis's truck, parked one recent Thursday in the lot behind the Fleet Bank in Livingston. The couple had arrived early to stake out their spot and display produce and plants grown on their 60-acre farm in Blairstown. From arugula to zucchini, basil to thyme, nasturtiums to hot pepper plants, they had it all. As a customer paid for her selections, the burly, bearded Mr. Griskonis couldn't help but boast, "The lettuce was cut 24 hours ago."
When was the last time a supermarket made such a claim? 
 "This is how we develop our income," Mr. Griskonis said later. "If it weren't for these markets, we wouldn't be able to stay in New Jersey."
Farmers' market season has arrived, and throughout the state, shoppers are heading to parking lots surrounding city halls, banks, train stations and schools to buy food directly from the people who till the soil. For citizens of Livingston, the opening of the market this year is a long-awaited triumph. "We've wanted one here for a long time," said Susie Fishbein, a resident. "We live in New Jersey and it's so nice to buy the produce that they're famous for right here in my backyard -- my bank's backyard."
As recently as the early 1990's, many of the northern suburbs, not to mention such cities as Newark, Jersey City and Hoboken, lacked such markets. In fact, a group of homeowners who tried to start a market in Madison back then encountered resistance from City Hall and from local supermarkets that feared unfair competition. But today, the New Jersey Council of Farmers and Communities, formed seven years ago following the establishment of fledgling markets in Monclair, Millburn and Madison, boasts a roster of 32 markets, five of them new this year.
The council acts as a kind of community matchmaker, pairing vendors with cities and towns. Early in the season, inspectors visit farms to verify that each grower is planting enough crops to meet its market commitments. Later, inspectors visit markets to certify that no produce of dubious origin has appeared en route.
Thanks to the markets, farmers can reap retail prices on products they would normally sell to wholesalers at lower prices. And customers can add farm-fresh produce to their summer tables. A win-win situation.
But finer benefits lurk beyond the easy economics. Wander the makeshift stalls and striped awnings at these so-called "urban markets," and you will spot community activity seldom found in supermarkets. Customers visit with neighbors. Children nibble fruit and play among the tables as Mom and Dad shop. Farmers sell produce, chatting, unloading, tidying and occasionally muttering about the lack of rain. And through it all, bunches, pints, quarts of Jersey-grown produce disappear into brown paper bags.
At the Livingston market, Kim LaPrete and her brother James offered 35 types of baked goods, from anisette toast to loaves of challah. In the course of the season the LaPrete family bakery in Clifton, Baker's Bounty, attends three other farmers' markets in the state. Two full-time bakers and five family members from 4 P.M. to 11 A.M. That loaf of raisin bread in the counter box, for example, came out of the oven sometime this morning.
As Ms. LaPrete worked in her booth, a customer asked, "Do you have anything that's sugar-free?" Mr. LaPrete offered one of their dietetic muffins, but his sister pointed out that almost all the family's breads -- 12 types, including round loaves, rings, and twists -- are sugar-free, and low in salt, too.
At a market in Madison the same day, Harriet Buckner, who works at Alstede's Farms in Chester, arranged turnips, radishes, beets and spinach in wicker baskets for an effect that more resembled a still life than a commercial display. On nearby table, delicately striped gooseberries cooled their heels beside gleaming red currants. Mrs. Buckner, who planted some of the seeds for these plants herself, blushed when a visitor complimented her work. "I used to be an art major," she said. "I tend to look at it as a painting, I guess."
Mrs. Buckner's daughter, Emily, 13, in a blue Alstede's T-shirt, shorts and flip-flops, rang up sales while Mom greeted customers. "This is a good market," Mrs. Buckner said between setting out bunches of lettuce. "You really get to know people. Last year, in our last week, some customers were bringing me gifts to say goodbye."
That parting moment is still a way off. For now, the sport utility vehicles and Volvos will head to the weekly market in Madison in search of something fresh but fleeting: honest produce plucked from local soil.
In the dead of winter, supermarkets do sell tomatoes and corn, albeit blander versions of the summer crop. For a culture used to this kind of out-of-season convenience, said Barbara Stevenson, vice president of the farmers and communities council, farmers' markets can be something of an education. "It's fun to watch the produce change with the seasons," she said. "In a few weeks, you'll see. They start having melons and sweet peppers and peaches."
But each turn of the growing season also means leaving well-loved crops behind. At his table in Livingston, a Port Murray farmer named James Kesler sold three types of cherries from his 146-acre orchard. In the coming weeks, he will offer apricots, plums, peaches, pears and apples. But on this day the pints and quarts on his folding table held the bounty of a crop that in New Jersey lasts a mere two weeks, at best: deep-red bings, yellow-tinged Queen Annes and tiny, almost translucent, crimson sour cherries.
Now and then, Mr. Kesler, 65, a broad-shouldered man in red suspenders, would let a customer try one or two of his berrries. They were firm, dripping with juice, and very sweet. "That's the last of them," he reminded people. "You can't get fruit this good unless it was just picked off a tree."
Livington Farmers' Market, Fleet Bank parking lot at 92 South Livingston Avenue. Thursdays noon to 6 P.M. The market began July 1 and will run till Oct. 28. For information, call: (973) 992-8080.

Both markets operate Thursdays, 3:30 to 7:30 P.M. For information, call: (973) 593-8496.

HEADLINE: A Skirmish Over the Hepatitis B Vaccination

BYLINE: By LISA SUHAY 

 BODY:
FOR as long as the vaccine for Hepatitis B has been in general use, some parents have been fighting it.
Now it is New Jersey's turn. 
 By late June -- the last legislative session before the summer recess -- a measure making the Hepatitis B vaccine mandatory for all school age children had already passed the State Assembly and was headed for a Senate vote.
Until that time, the State Department of Health had supported the measure. But then the Senate added an amendment, introduced by State Senator C. Louis Bassano, a Republican from Union, that would have allowed parents to decide whether to inoculate their children for Hepatitis B -- usually transmitted through sexual contact or intravenuous drug use -- and the measure was left off the legislative calendar.
At that point, state health officials chose to take the issue out of the hands of legislators and began writing a rule requiring the vaccination -- without allowing parents the option of refusing.
Mr. Bassano put it this way in a telephone interview: "They wanted the summer to write it themselves using the power to make rules and regulations to subvert the legislative process. They didn't want parents to have a choice and this was the way to achieve that goal."
Assemblyman John Wisniewski, a Democrat from Sayreville who was co-sponsor of the bill, said in a telephone interview: "The language in the amendment was just too broad. It almost seemed to negate the mandate. Still, I would have continued to support it if the Health Department had not made the decision to write it while the Senate was out of session for the summer. After all, something is better than nothing."
Mr. Bassano and some parents now say they are prepared to fight the department's mandate and demand public hearings on the basis of medical concerns and the right of parental choice.
"We're not talking about a childhood disease here," Senator Bassano said. "This is an attempt to deal with the problems faced by drug users, homeless people and those who keep company with hookers."
He said the health department supported the legislation until he added the amendment allowing parents a philosophical objection. Currently in New Jersey, parents can claim only a religious objection to vaccination.
Mr. Bassano said mandating the vaccine raised several questions that had to be addressed through the legislative process.
"Some parents in my constituency have concerns over the safety record of this vaccine," he said. "They say giving this vaccine to children is more risk than benefit. These questions were asked of me by parents and I think they should be considered publicly."
The Hepatitis B vaccine was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1986, and the advisory committee on immunization practices of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a recommendation for universal use of the vaccine in newborns and children in 1991.
The vaccination is now mandatory in 42 states -- including New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Delaware. But for as long as the vaccine has been used, some parents have fought it.
The National Vaccine Information Center, a parents' group in Washington, issued a report last year stating that of the millions of children born last year in the United States, a total of 24,775 adverse events, including 439 deaths, said to be linked to the vaccine were reported to the Federal drug agency.
Barbara Loe Fisher, a co-founder of the group, said the raw numbers of reported adverse effects linked the vaccine to long-term "multiple sclerosis-like symptoms, including joint pain, and cognitive problems."
But a spokeswoman for the F.D.A., Lenore Gelb, cautioned against drawing conclusions from the data.
"We would have to separate out the reports filed from those complaints that we found to be really vaccine related," Ms. Gelb said. "There are a lot of things that happen to children that could account for the damage in the claims filed."
Aside from concerns over ailments possibly related to the vaccine, Senator Bassano said the number of reported cases of Hepatitis B among children in the state was too low to justify a mass vaccination.
He cited New Jersey Department of Education records for children, from birth to age 18, that showed only three cases of Hepatitis B among the state's children in 1997. In two cases, he said, the victims were 15 and the third was 18.
Speaking of the rules being drawn up by the Health Department, Mr. Bassano said: "They are trying to treat the wrong set of people with this vaccine. They can't reach the adults through education, so this is their solution. I think it is a poor one."
But Marilyn Riley, a department spokeswoman, said the mandate was part of a larger effort to update the state's vaccination rules.
"This is being done because all the department's vaccination rules are about to sunset in April of 2000," Ms. Riley said, referring to when the rules would expire. "That made it a good time to include the Hepatitis B vaccine in with the others."
She said the mandate would go through the Public Health Council and should be released in the next several months. "There is a 30-day period for public comment once it's written," she said.
But Mr. Bassano said that was not good enough, contending that his constituency wanted to add the parental choice amendment or stop the mandate.
While the New Jersey mandate will require all children be vaccinated against Hepatitis B by the time they reach school age, or age 5, Ms. Reynolds said hospitals had adopted the practice of urging parents to immunize their children at birth.
"I think it's because the baby is right there where they have more control over the situation," she said. "They were testing the mothers for the disease and deciding on a case-by-case basis about the babies. Now, I guess they just decided to skip testing the mothers and just immunize all the babies."
According to Ms. Reynolds, the Hepatitis B vaccine is the only inoculation given at birth. Children then get booster shots, one at 2 months of age and another at 4 months.
All other immunizations -- including measles mumps and rubella (MMR), diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DPT), polio (orally administered) and Hepatitis A and Influenza B and chicken pox -- are administered at 2 months and again at 4 months, 8 months and 10 months.
"Once the level of availability and use of a certain vaccine becomes routine and people get used to it, then states begin to mandate it," Ms. Reynolds said. "Since so many states are suddenly making these mandates, the Hepatitis B vaccine must have reached that sort of comfort level with the general public."
She added: "We cannot say that vaccines are 100 percent safe. We cannot say they are 100 percent effective. We can say that the benefits outweigh the risks.
Consider the risk from the diseases themselves. We cannot risk the return of these diseases."
But Jackie French of Cranford is not sure.
Mrs. French is the mother of three children aged 9, 6 and 2. She said her youngest child, Patrick, suffered permanent damage after receiving his third booster for diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis.
Now she makes it her business to investigate whatever vaccine is proposed for mandatory use.
It was Mrs. French, pleading with Mr. Bassano, that led the Senator to look further into the issue and to draft the amendment allowing parents to forgo the vaccination based on philosophical objections.
"We were doing something to protect our child from disease and instead it has destroyed our lives," Mrs. French said.
Michael Belkin, a financial and economic forecaster from Manhattan, has been at the forefront of the fight against the Hepatitis B vaccine since the death of his 5-week-old daughter Lyla Rose in September 1998.
In May, Mr. Belkin was the lead witness in Congressional hearings into the Hepatitis B vaccine. He said his daughter became fussy after the vaccination, went to sleep and never woke up.
He said an autopsy ruled out choking, but found swelling of the brain. "Look in any neurology textbook and it will tell you about post-vaccinal encephalomyelitis, brain swelling following vaccination," Mr. Belkin said. "It can happen with any vaccination."
He called the Hepatitis B vaccine "the Ford Pinto of the vaccine world with the exploding gas tank. It should not be given to newborns or small children."
Sue Collins of Long Hill Township presents the kind situation that the state Department of Health worries about. She does not vaccinate her son for any disease, and plans to educate him at home.
Mrs. Collins said that after reading about the possible adverse effects associated with vaccinations, she chose not to inoculate her son Zachary, now 3, for anything.
Mrs. Collins, who runs a support group called Freedom of Vaccine Choice, said: "A lot of people don't want to hear about the risks. They don't want to buck the system. They would rather paint us as crazies or fanatics, when we are simply asking for the right to make an informed decision."
For her part, Mrs. French said that while she would never again immunize a child for any disease, she was not asking other parents to adopt her attitude.
"What I want is for parents to ask more questions and have the freedom to make the decision for themselves once they have learned all they can," she said. "Parents shouldn't have to lie to the government claiming some religious belief when they really object to the safety of the vaccine or the rational behind it."
 
Delay Urged for Vaccine With a Trace of Mercury
CHILDREN are vaccinated for their own good. In the case of vaccinations that contain a mercury preservative, health experts say that the number of shots given to small children may amount to too much of a good thing.
As part of the Food and Drug Administration's modernization act of 1997, the Federal agency was required to review and assess the risks of all food and drugs containing mercury.
What they found was that the preservative Thimerosal (methyl mercury) is present in such inactive, or nonlive vaccines, as those for Hepatitis B, diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTAP) and Hepatitis A and Influenza B. It is not present in live vaccines like measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) and chicken pox.
The drug agency then shared that information with the World Health Organization and the American Academy of Pediatrics.
Earlier this month, the pediatrics organization and the Public Health Service put out a joint news release that might have confused some parents.
On the one hand, parents were assured: "There are no data or evidence of any harm caused by the level of exposure that some children may have encountered in following the existing immunization schedule. Infants and children who have received Thimerosal-containing vaccines do not need to be tested for mercury exposure."
But the bulletin went on to say, "The recognition that some children could be exposed to a cumulative level of mercury over the first six months of life that exceeds one of the Federal guidelines on methyl mercury now requires a weighing of two different types of risks when vaccinating infants."
The risks, according to the release, include the possibility of contracting of a damaging or deadly disease through nonvaccination or facing the "unknown and probably much smaller risk, if any, of neurodevelopmental effects posed by exposure to Thimerosal."
A spokeswoman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Barbara Reynolds, said: "These vaccines have had mercury in them since the 1940's. The concern is not with individual vaccines, which are well within the recommended limits, but with the effect of giving multiple vaccines to children within the first six months of life. It is primarily of concern for low-birth-weight babies."
In the joint bulletin, the health service and the pediatrics organization recommended that the Hepatitis B vaccine, currently administered to newborns while still in the hospital, be delayed from birth until between 2 and 6 months.
As a result of the announcement, some states recently announced they would revamp vaccination schedules or at least consider the possibility.
On July 9, health officials in New Mexico asked parents to wait until children were between 2 and 6 months before administering the Hepatitis B vaccine, commonly given at birth. And last Monday, officials at with the New York State Health Department gathered to discuss the state's vaccination policy, a spokeswoman said.
"The schedule is flexible, and we are looking into altering it to recommend that the Hepatitis B shot not be given to newborns but to children closer to 6 months of age," said the spokeswoman, Kristine Smith.
The approach being taken by the centers is a request to drug companies to manufacture a mercury-free vaccine, a development that Ms. Reynolds said was more than a year off.
In the meantime, she said, "we recommend that children continue to adhere to their current immunization schedule." LISA SUHAY

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
AnotherEntry for King of the Sky

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
FROM Mario Garnero's penthouse office in a skyscraper he built here, the view invokes the way Mario de Andrade, Brazil's modernist writer, once described this city -- "a great mouth with a thousand teeth." In almost every direction, crops of steep structures jut out of the concrete in a show of the magnitude of Sao Paulo, the third-largest metropolis in the world, after Tokyo and Mexico City.
But Mr. Garnero, 61, a business tycoon with interests ranging from waste treatment to telecommunications, plans his newest and grandest venture for a spot eclipsed by this jagged skyline, in the decrepit, neglected downtown district where the city's first high-rises were built in the 1920's. There he hopes to build the world's tallest skyscraper, 1,622 feet high. Modeled on the Vedic temples of India, it would surpass the 1,483-foot Petronas Twin Towers of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. 
 "This building will be the symbol of Sao Paulo's new era, of a post-industrial Sao Paulo in a league with the world's great cities," Mr. Garnero said.
To compete with tallest-building projects that are planned or under way on other continents, Mr. Garnero, a tall man himself, with a penchant for pinstriped suits, is teaming up with the investment arm of the followers of the Indian-born guru, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. The Maharishi Global Development fund, whose assets are gathered mainly from contributions by practitioners of the guru's twice-a-day meditation methods, has agreed to be the main investor in the project, with a role in overseeing its design. The Maharishi fund and Mr. Garnero hired Minoru Yamasaki Associates, the architectural firm based in Rochester Hills, Mich., that conceived the World Trade Center in Manhattan.
The resulting design for the 103-story Sao Paulo Tower, unveiled in May, has stirred up a tempest. Stylistically, it has nothing in common with the postmodern skyscrapers erected here during the relative economic calm of the 1990's, nor does it resemble the drab high-rises of earlier decades, many of which seem better suited to Eastern Europe under Communism than to subtropical southeastern Brazil.
Inside the Sao Paulo Tower, which will look something like a layered pyramid with ornate touches, will be hotels, offices, residential apartments, a convention center, a university and, during the workday, about 50,000 people, Mr. Garnero said. At the top will be a restaurant within a golden crown.
Aside from the surprise expressed by some architects over the unusual design, most critical views center on the project's contribution to a troubling trend -- the confining of more and more aspects of public life within buildings. In crime-plagued Sao Paulo, better-off residents increasingly retreat into gated communities and guarded shopping malls.
"This is a fortress, a mega-intervention in a city dying for public space," said Raquel Rolnik, an architecture professor at the Catholic University of Campinas.
Another well-known expert, the urban planner Jorge Wilheim, said, "We need this building like we need a hole in our head."
Other Brazilian architects defend the project, saying it could bring new creative energy and international attention to Sao Paulo. "This building would catalyze popular hope," said Edison Musa, the president of a national association of architects and chairman for Latin America of the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat. Mr. Musa likened the Sao Paulo Tower to American skyscrapers, including the Empire State Building, that were finished during the Depression. "It is an affirmation of our national capacity," he said.
BRAZIL has long had faith in the idea that the design of its buildings and cities can bring positive change. This thinking was behind the construction 40 years ago of a new capital, Brasilia, deep in the savannas of the country's interior. And just as the inventors of Brasilia have defended their creation from criticism that it is artificial and sterile, so the architects of the Sao Paulo project stand by their design.
"We didn't want a cookie-cutter repeat of other tall buildings," said Henry Guthard, senior vice president of Minoru Yamasaki. "When seen silhouetted against the sky, this building will be striking."
As the controversy unfolds over the building's design and its eventual impact on the city's crazy-quilt sprawl, a more urgent issue presses: financing. The Maharishi fund, which manages assets of roughly $600 million, is committed to raising money through donations, borrowing and returns on its investments to provide half the estimated $1.6 billion needed to complete the building. If construction is to begin as planned in January, the fund's managers and Mr. Garnero will have to drum up the other half quickly.
"Money is currently so expensive that one has to wonder where they will get it," said Daniel Citron, the chief financial officer of Brazil Realty S.A., a large developer of commercial real estate here. Indeed, many people in Sao Paulo's real estate industry have expressed doubt whether the project can get off the ground at a time when domestic interest rates for real estate lending are above 25 percent.
There are also questions about the supply of tenants, given the market's doldrums as the country just begins to emerge from recession.
If the project is built, there are chances it will not retain the title of tallest building for very long. Investors in Shanghai; Taipei, Taiwan, and Melbourne, Australia, are also competing to erect the world's tallest building. A real estate firm in Chicago, where the Sears Tower reigned as the world's tallest until 1996, unveiled plans last month for another contender, although, at 1,537 feet, it would be shorter than Mr. Garnero's.
That hasn't kept Mr. Garnero from knocking with gusto on the doors of potential partners. He hopes to interest Brazilian investment firms and pension funds that have invested in other developments in Sao Paulo.
So far, the attention attracted by the project has helped renovate the public image of Mr. Garnero and his business empire, gathered under the merchant bank Brasilinvest. Brazil's highest court recently cleared Mr. Garnero of accusations of fraudulent financial transactions in the 1980's.
The managers of the Maharishi fund are confident about the plans. "There are always people who think small," said Benjamin Feldman, a member of the fund's board who is responsible for its activities in Latin America. "Any great endeavor is criticized by people who have no understanding of it."
