SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 845 words

HEADLINE: CALLINGS;
This Broker Really Takes A Long View

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN; Laura Pedersen-Pietersen is a Manhattan author and public speaker. Her column profiling people whose work is their passion appears the third Sunday of each month.
E-mail: yourmind@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I CAN'T see what all the fuss is about," said Frank W. Fletcher, a 95-year-old stockbroker. "My father was pushing a hand mower well into his 90's."
And the way things are going in the workplace, there may soon be no fuss whatsoever about people toiling into their 90's -- or even their 100's. Not only are Americans living and working longer, but in some fields, older workers are even being sought out. 
 Consider the investment business, where a stampeding bull market has produced legions of silver-haired millionaires-next-door. Many older investors prefer to work with a broker of their own generation, said David W. Wiley 3d, 44, who is Mr. Fletcher's boss at Wiley Bros./Aintree Capital, a brokerage firm in Nashville.
Recruiting the elderly is not just a brokerage-business phenomenon. Seventy-something models are hired to appear in glossy makeup ads aimed at great-grandmothers on the go, and 60-year-old engineers are being hauled out of retirement by the cruise-ship-full to work on Year 2000 problems. (After all, they installed the stuff.)
 Mr. Fletcher was born on Oct. 3, 1903, four months after an engineer named Henry formed the Ford Motor Company and 10 weeks before Orville Wright made that famous flight. When folks muttered about "the Depression" back then, they meant the four years after the Panic of 1893.
In 1920, when Mr. Fletcher was a teen-ager, the market crashed again, leaving four million people out of work. "A dress rehearsal for the big one," he said.
The big crash, in 1929, came just four weeks after he married -- and the very week that he and his bride, Mary, visited the New York Stock Exchange. "The Government did all the wrong things back then -- we needed Alan Greenspan," said Mr. Fletcher, an unabashed admirer of the current Federal Reserve chairman.
After graduating from Vanderbilt University in 1925, Mr. Fletcher joined his family's wholesale food business, soon becoming president and staying until the company was sold in 1954. That year, at 51, Mr. Fletcher started his second career, joining the Eisenhower Administration as deputy director of the Agency for International Development. His first overseas posting, in Amman, Jordan, coincided with the Suez crisis. "It wasn't exactly the time or place to be wearing an 'I like Ike' button," he said.
In 1959, he returned to Nashville, to work on the Presidential campaign of Richard M. Nixon. But after John F. Kennedy's inauguration in 1961, he again had to decide what to do with the rest of his life. Some friends were ready to pull out the golf clubs, but retirement at 58 held no appeal for him.
He became an insurance salesman. "I gave it a year," he recalled, "but selling insurance just didn't fit my personality." A friend suggested the investment business and invited him to join Aintree Capital.
There, in 1962, he began his fourth career. "I loved this business from the start," he said. "And the good thing about it is that you can be a broker while you play golf. In fact, people here expect it of you."
He dispenses investment advice -- his current favorite stocks are Lincoln National Life, Lucent Technologies and BellSouth -- but also career advice. To the young (anyone under 90), he says, "Do something you enjoy, and you'll probably be successful."
Mr. Fletcher is his own best example. "Every day something new is happening with the markets," he said, "so it's always exciting to me, never boring."
His son, Frank Jr., 56, a stockbroker in Greenville, S.C., offers another perspective. "When you're married to a Nashville social queen, as he's been for decades, you'd better find a job to go to every day, or you'll be out doing yard work before you know it," the younger Mr. Fletcher said. Whatever the reason, Frank Sr. has clearly had a successful marriage. He and Mary, now 91, will celebrate their 70th anniversary this fall.
IN the meantime, there's work to be done. And it's not always a cakewalk.
Mr. Fletcher said that, as a broker, there are disadvantages to getting old. "Customers have died or turned their affairs over to banks and investment companies," he said. "And the young people coming up want to deal with people in their own social circle."
But Mr. Wiley, Mr. Fletcher's boss, sees many pluses. "Frank has a great sense of humor," he said, "and he's as mentally effective as any 40-year-old, and sometimes more so." Mr. Wiley said older workers add continuity and a much-needed long-term perspective about the markets.
A co-worker, J. Anthony Curcio, said: "He's a voracious consumer of financial commentary. Every morning he reads the business papers with a four-inch magnifying glass, and if he sees an article that would be of interest to another broker he takes it right to them."
Mr. Fletcher has no plans to retire, but he acknowledges that there are some things outside work that he can no longer manage. "I can't play golf anymore, I can't drink as much as I'd like and there's one other thing I can't do -- but I can't remember what it is, so I guess it doesn't matter."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); JORDAN (72%);

HEADLINE: COPING;
The Plight Of the Polite

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
CAN you be a real New Yorker if you can't kvetch?
Competitive complaining is the city's favorite sport. Eavesdrop anywhere New Yorkers gather -- in the subway, in stores, in line waiting for the next working A.T.M. -- and you are bound to hear them playing can-you-top-this, in tones that range from irritation to outrage. 
 But when my fellow Gothamites are riffing on crazy cabbies or subway psychos or traffic or tourists or rats or Rudy, not to mention everything that has happened to them in the last 72 hours, I tend to be tongue tied.
Call it the plight of the polite. Raised from birth to say, "Fine, thank you, how are you?" I find it hard to complain. It is never the winter of my discontent, or the spring or the summer, either.
Such cheeriness, I have discovered, makes other New Yorkers nervous. They think I'm hiding something.
The first time I met a certain senior city official, we were in the middle of discussing some arcane economic data when he suddenly barked, "Why are you so smiley?" He nodded at my explanation -- a naturally sunny disposition -- but made it clear he didn't buy it.
When I went to his next news conference, I made sure to ask a rude question, so that he would stop thinking I'm a space alien. We've gotten along fine ever since.
If you are preternaturally polite, New Yorkers tend to take you for a simp, a sap or, worst of all, an out-of-towner. My friend Doreen, who is originally from Illinois, says that when she takes taxis, the drivers routinely say, "You're not from around here, are you?"
The giveaway? "You said please." Ooooops.
Doreen says she cannot help it, and neither can I. Even when I was in labor, according to my husband, I said please and thank you to all the doctors and nurses, even when they were informing me that I could not have an epidural painkiller, after all. And when they asked me how I was feeling, I said, "Fine, thank you, how are you?" Mercifully, I can't remember.
On the job, being whine-deprived is a handicap. After all, "If you aren't complaining, how will they know you're working?" asks my pal Allan, who is a master of the rant-and-rave. Fortunately, for reporters politeness is not as much of a problem as you might expect. It's amazing what people will say if you just murmur, "Oh, really?" and let them ramble on.
Why am I complaint-challenged? I really am a New Yorker. I grew up in a suburb just outside the city, and have spent most of my adult life in Manhattan. I'm as irony-infused as the next person, as cynical, sarcastic, smart-mouthed. People outside the city almost always peg me as a New Yorker (though that may be the all-black wardrobe). But in the five boroughs, I'm Little Mary Sunshine. A scary possibility is that I have lived a charmed life, and so have nothing to gripe about -- yet.
On the other hand, I go to the dentist, get called for jury duty and stand in line at Worth Street for my driver's license, just like other people. And I just got my first speeding ticket.
It's genetic, says my husband, who in our household is in charge of worrying, complaining and cooking. (I try to be decorative, and to make the bed.)
It is true that my grandmother has reached the age of 93 in large part by refusing to acknowledge the unpleasant. Though she has been living in and around New York since the days of speakeasies, it has not rubbed off on her. Grandmother's idea of criticism is to call someone "a difficult individual." (Translation: hell on toast.)
I like to think that studying history has something to do with it. After all, a century ago New York was packed with starving children, and people died of injuries scarcely more serious than a hangnail. Compared to those days, who in the city isn't better off?
But ever since I said those things at a dinner party and got branded as a weirdo, and possibly a right-wing Republican, I have tried to adopt protective coloration.
I have learned to swear like a sailor, so I can sound outraged even when I am only irked. It has become almost second nature to make rude gestures at cars that run red lights, and to holler, "Excuse me!" when somebody slams me in a subway scrum. I even hang up on strangers who call me at home (though not, I confess, without saying "No, thank you.").
But I'm not sure that I'm setting the right example for my 3-year-old daughter, Elizabeth, who refers to New York as "my city" (when she's not calling it You Nork). The other day, when a neighbor stopped in the lobby to ask Elizabeth how she was, I heard her tiny, piping voice reply, "Fine, thank you, how are you?"

HEADLINE: PRELUDES;
Joining PeaceCorps Inc.

BYLINE: By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN the past, it was easy to spot Peace Corps volunteers. They wore Birkenstocks and loose-fitting, gauzy garb. They often had wide-eyed notions of saving the world. To many of them, "capitalism" was a four-letter word.
No more. Today's Peace Corps volunteers -- 80 percent of whom are in their 20's -- still want to help the world, but they also want to help themselves. Many volunteers have business degrees and view the Peace Corps as a two-year internship, culminating with a return home to a job with a top company. What better way to gain experience than by helping a developing nation get its corporate feet on the ground? 
 "I'm definitely joining to improve my skills for a better job," said Beth Atkinson, 22, who recently received a bachelor's degree in business administration from Indiana Wesleyan University. Next month, she heads for Mali in West Africa to help craftsmen and entrepreneurs form businesses. "You hear a lot of talk about global business, and I thought there's no better way to go than this," she said.
Richard Campbell, now 28, has similar feelings. After getting a bachelor's degree in finance in 1993 from Morehouse College in Atlanta, Mr. Campbell became a loan analyst for Nationsbank in Nashville. He wasn't thinking about joining the Peace Corps. "It was for people who couldn't find jobs," he said.
Then a college friend told him that he was going to Nairobi as a business consultant for the Peace Corps. Mr. Campbell realized that the Peace Corps offered the opportunity for foreign work experience and the chance to explore his African-American roots. Mr. Campbell enlisted and spent two years setting up village banks in Mali. A month after returning to the United States in August 1996, he entered the M.B.A. program at Howard University, completing it in May 1998. Today, he is a consultant at PricewaterhouseCoopers in Washington, working on the financial statements of the Agency for International Development. "I had to compete to get that project, and the Peace Corps experience helped me win it," he said. "You can get real international business experience without having to slave in an office for a number of years."
About 850 of the nearly 6,600 Peace Corps volunteers now work with businesses, and the number is growing, said Mark Gearan, the Peace Corps director, though the organization's fluid nature makes specific numbers hard to come by. An 8 percent budget increase in the current fiscal year, to $240 million, will permit recruiting of an additional 52 business consultants.
Two schools have also become involved. Four years ago, the University of the Pacific and the Monterey Institute of International Studies, both in California, started M.B.A. programs in conjunction with the Peace Corps. In the programs, a half-dozen students spend their first semester or two on campus, then two years with the Peace Corps in a developing country, and then a final semester or two back in the United States.
Why the new interest in the Peace Corps? Are young people turning more idealistic?
"I once heard a volunteer asked, 'Are you doing this to pad your resume or are you a do-gooder?' " Mr. Gearan recalled. "And he said, 'Both.' There's a question of wanting to do well and wanting to do good at the same time."
For all the stories of money-grubbing buccaneers, business graduates are often idealistic. "There's a feeling among young people today that they're going to make a better product and help the world," said David Strauss, a principal with Art and Science Group, a consulting firm in Baltimore that examines student trends. "They see themselves as visionaries."
Some former volunteers also see the Peace Corps as a way to learn what they don't want to do. Andy Drennan, 32, joined after receiving a master's degree in international marketing from Thunderbird University in Glendale, Ariz. He turned down a corporate position to go to Chile for two years. "My friends were getting high-paying jobs in investment banking and thought I was crazy, but I wanted to see what it was like in a nonprofit organization," he said. When he returned, he took a job as an account executive with Union Carbide in Somerset, N.J.
"I realized that nonprofit wasn't for me," he said. "It didn't pay enough."

HEADLINE: For Him: The Perfect Lawn Is a Status Symbol Again

BYLINE: By TOM CONNOR 

 BODY:
CAN I walk on it?" first-time visitors often ask Robert Esernio as they stare at his property in Mahopac, N.Y. There's no mistaking Mr. Esernio's lawn. In a development of similar new houses with mostly burnt, brown lawns lumpy from the excavator's backhoe, his is the really green, rolling, luxuriant one, the one with mowing lines like straight brush strokes up and down a fine piece of suede.
The question strikes Mr. Esernio as both absurd and entirely appropriate. "Of course, they can walk on it," he says. "It's a lawn." And yet this is more than a lawn. It's as nearly perfect an expanse of uniformly green turf as one is likely to find outside of England, and for the last seven years it has been his passion. 
 Riding a John Deere GT275 sit-down mower with a 48-inch cutting deck, thatching and aerating attachments and hydrostatic drive (for easier turns and straighter lines), Mr. Esernio cuts his lawn seeded with rye and bluegrass every five days, not once a week ("It's happier when it's cut every five days," he says), keeping it three and a half inches high. ("Any shorter, and the roots would burn out.") He pushes a Sears 22-inch hand mower around the perimeter and in the pool area ("I need the workout") and fertilizes with the Scott four-step program four times a year. ("The most important thing about lawns is feeding them.")
An accountant with three children, Mr. Esernio, 40, has spent thousands of hours and tens of thousands of dollars, including a $3,500 underground sprinkler system, to recreate, in effect, a portion of the outfield at Yankee Stadium. "I like the straight lines," he says. "I'm a little perfectionist about it. I find myself turning the tractor around behind trees so as not to wear out the same areas."
Forget expensive stone walls enclosing the grounds. Forget antique Belgium block driveways with 10,000-square-foot houses for a family of three at the end. Lawns, once again a suburban status symbol, are bigger. As John Henske, a landscaper in Fairfield, Conn., says, "To quote a former employer, 'For some guys it's the biggest thing they own.' "
This may not be the case with Mr. Esernio, of course, but he's far from alone in his obsession. In the waning summer evenings of the millennium, suburban men seem as devoted to their lawns as their fathers were in the golden age of lawn maintenance, the 1950's, the era of suburban migration, the crew cut and conformity.
If middle-aged sons today have less time than their fathers did, they have more money and more lawn. And perhaps more hubris. Despite environmental concern with pesticides and herbicides and a brief fling with prairies and meadows in the 1980's, many suburban males want their lawns to look like ballparks and putting greens. Even this summer's drought in the New York region hasn't appreciably slowed the latest love affair with lawns.
Real lawn guys no longer call their lawn "lawn," of course. "If you're serious about your lawn, if you're an aficionado of grass, you refer to it as 'turf,' " says Edmund Hollander, a landscape designer in Manhattan with clients in the Hamptons and other suburbs.
In the spring, Village Hardware, a narrow, 80-year-old store in Southport, Conn., was stacked to its tin ceiling with bags of Green Power fertilizer and moss-killing lime. The stack disappeared quickly. "Sales were up big time from a few years ago," says Glenn Oesterle, the store's owner. "Customers are looking for a better-looking lawn without spending a fortune. Also, a lot of people have gone back to buying fertilizers in the bag and doing it themselves because they're displeased with the lawn services."
The National Garden Association, which has been conducting an annual survey of homeowners for the Gallup Organization for 20 years, reports a significant increase in homeowner spending on lawn care products, from $6.5 billion to $8.5 billion between 1993 and 1998. Bruce Butterfield, market research director for the association, which is based in Burlington, Vt., attributes the increase to the strong economy, but also to a change in lawn-owner attitude.
"I think people are starting to have a little more respect for their lawns," Mr. Butterfield says. "It's a lot like putting your best face forward in the neighborhood. There's kind of a domino effect. If your neighbor is using a Scott's four-step program and your lawn looks like hell, you're going to want to do something, too."
In the Eisenhower era, they called this keeping up with the Joneses, and something of the same materialism and competition has returned in a decade of similar prosperity and political complacency.
The 1980's and 90's have also seen the second coming of suburban sprawl. The relentless march of American suburbs -- gobbling up farmland in Pennsylvania, encroaching on forests outside Seattle -- has made sprawl an unlikely campaign issue for Vice President Al Gore and has no doubt also spurred lawn-product sales. At the Scott Company, the country's biggest producer of lawn fertilizer, sales have skyrocketed in three years, from $228 million to $442 million.
Doug Reed, a landscape architect in Cambridge, Mass., traces the 90's resurgence of lawn fixation to the latest wave of migrants from the cities. "I've noticed with urban clients that the lawn plays an important role in their pursuit of a kind of idealized country living," he says.
Especially for guys who didn't know anything about lawns growing up. "On the old estates out here, the lawn wasn't the focus," says Jim Kiley, who has a degree in turf management and who works for Whitmores, a landscaping contractor in Amagansett, N.Y. "But the clients we have now want it to look like springtime year-round. It's a guy thing. A lot of investment bankers grew up in Brooklyn and never had a lawn, so it means everything to them."
Whitmores sprays fussy clients' lawns with a concentration of iron two or three days before a party, turning the grass a desired shade of blue-green.
Where 1950's fathers and 1990's sons differ is that many lawn-obsessed men today seem content to pay others to create turf perfection for them. And in these money-spewing times, when grass is another commodity, fast grass beats slow grass by a mile. Most guys want lawns now.
Tom Alfredo, a landscaper in Armonk, N.Y., put a 20-man crew to work hand-laying sod over a seven-acre parcel in Bedford. "Here's the problem in our business -- the best lawn is a seeded lawn, but nobody wants to wait three to four months for the lawn to grow in," Mr. Alfredo says. "What they're buying is a sod farmer's time and efforts to produce a seeded lawn. Sod is instant lawn."
During this summer's drought, which landscapers say damaged even sprinklered lawns and cut into their crews' productivity, Mr. Alfredo's company has made deliveries of 6,000 gallons of water, at about $1,000 a tankerload, to a number of customers' lawns.
In the latest Agriculture Department survey, the sale of farm-raised sod rose almost 70 percent in 1997 over 1992. The demand may help explain something of a sod shortage this summer at the Delea & Sons sod farm in East Northport, N.Y., which sells 400 to 500 acres of sod a year to exterior designers and landscapers in the Hamptons, as well as to Yankee and Shea stadiums.
But not everyone wants to pay someone else, even those who can afford to. For an increasing number of the turf obsessed, no green is as good as the green you tend yourself. At Home Depot, the mecca of do-it-yourself, with more than 820 stores nationwide, the lawn and garden department has seen "a double-digit increase over last year," says Jerry Shields, the chain's senior public relations manager. For Home Depot, he says, "it's probably a billion-dollar business."
Jim Brooks, 51, a partner in an East Hampton insurance agency, put himself through college by working on the greens and grass tennis courts at the Maidstone Club. For 25 years, Mr. Brooks has reseeded and mowed his own quarter-acre lot himself. "You just take pride in the property and the look of the property," he says. He adds that he cuts the lawn "because the phone doesn't ring when I'm mowing."
For some men, moreover, mowing connects them with childhoods when they spent summer evenings in the backyard with their fathers. "I'm drawn deeper into the lawn with each pass, nearly identical to the previous," writes Warren Schultz in his new book, "A Man's Turf: The Perfect Lawn" (Clarkson Potter, $35). "I'm working over old ground. I'm lifted out, transported back to other lawns and the aura that rises from them. This lawn is thick with memories of every lawn I've ever cared for. And every lawn is marked with the footsteps of my father."
Did somebody mention Robert Bly? There's no need to head to the wilderness, thumping on tom-toms, to get in touch with the specters of fathers past, like the legions who followed the "men's movement" some years ago. The late-90's man need only fire up the Toro.
Then again, some men would just as soon forget the lawns of their youth. Christopher Rosow came of age on four acres in the Greenfield Hill section of Fairfield, Conn. "My father was more into not mowing the lawn," he recalls. "He was more interested in me mowing it."
Now 28, Mr. Rosow lives in a tiny, 1822 house in Southport Village, not far from his parents' home, with a 6-by-20-foot yard. He laid the lawn with sod from Home Depot -- "I like instant gratification," he says -- which he cuts with a secondhand Scott reel mower, the acoustic kind of mower that makes a satisfying clicking sound when you push it. "It takes maybe 6 minutes to mow and 10 minutes to trim with the weed whacker," Mr. Rosow says.
Another recent development and realization is that turf may not be exclusively a guy thing at all. "I think women are catching on to our little secret," Mr. Schultz says. "In the course of writing the book, I talked with women who said: 'You know, growing up I never really got the lawn. But I really like it.' "
Cheryl Minikes and her husband, Michael, who live in Manhattan during the week, bought a weekend home on five undeveloped acres in East Hampton nine years ago. Before Mrs. Minikes knew it, she was planning lawns, installing a putting green and overseeing their care. "I was born in the Bronx," she says. "I didn't know from a lawn. But the more I got involved, the more I wanted it to be perfect. I can't help it. My husband loves it, but it's my charge. So we don't fight over it. We don't discuss it. I tell him what I want to do, and he rolls his eyes, and that's it."
Mr. Henske, the Connecticut landscaper, maintains Martha Stewart's three-acre Turkey Hill property in Westport, which could stand up to any man's in a turf competition. "For an unirrigated lawn, it's as close to perfect as you can get," he says. "She has a bunch of guys full time, and they do a good job. But what keeps the lawn from perfection is that there's constant activity and change. There are footsteps all over the lawn, and she has dogs."
Still, the obsession with lawns seems overwhelmingly a male prerogative, maybe the next big guy thing after smoking cigars and swilling martinis. Women already have other outlets for self-expression.
"When I was pregnant the first time," says Kathy Esernio, the wife of Bob Esernio, he of the sit-down mower with the 48-inch cutting deck in Mahopac, "I remember him coming to me and saying, 'I feel it's almost time for me to start the lawn.' "

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TREMONT;
Ghana Dream Homes Inc.

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL 

 BODY:
Looking to buy that first home but frustrated by high prices in the suburbs? Consider a visit to Kwasi Kissi's real estate office on East Tremont Avenue, where a newly constructed three-bedroom house goes for just $45,000.
Just one catch: it's in Ghana. 
 Mr. Kissi, 49, established the Ghanaian-American Real Estate and Investment Group in 1998 to help his fellow West African immigrants tackle the maddening logistics of purchasing real estate 5,000 miles from New York City.
"It is a major objective of all Ghanaians to save enough money in the United States to build a house at home so they can live comfortably ever after," he said.
But in the past there were a lot of risks. Mr. Kissi said many of his customers had previously been duped into purchasing houses on land with inaccessible roads or no power and water. Others wired money to relatives, only to find their savings gone and no house to show for it when they went back to Ghana.
To avoid such problems, Mr. Kissi works closely with a few large-scale housing developers in Ghana. He is also the only agent based in New York who is accredited by the Home Finance Company, a leading mortgage lender in Ghana founded in 1990 with World Bank money.
He takes pains to prove his legitimacy, producing dozens of files on his customers and photographs of houses. Leading Ghanaians vouch for him.
Then there are the customers. Frankie Ahinful, 45, a technician for a Honda dealer in the Bronx, recently made a down payment through Mr. Kissi on a $60,000 three-bedroom house with servants' quarters in Tema, just outside Accra, the capital. His elderly mother will live there, he said, and he will use it for vacations.
"Ghanaians want to own homes in Africa, but we don't have the connections to do it correctly, beautifully," said Mr. Ahinful, who also wants to own a house in the United States someday.
Selete Avoke, 38, a researcher for the Department of Education, heard about Mr. Kissi in Washington. He was skeptical. In 1995, he had purchased land in Ghana only to find out that the owner had simultaneously sold the same parcel to someone else. Impressed by Mr. Kissi's professionalism and the mortgage company's link with the World Bank, he put down a deposit on a $25,000 two-family retirement house in Accra.
Mr. Kissi said business was slow at first, but it has been picking up through word of mouth and advertisements in publications like Asenta, a monthly newspaper published in the Bronx for the estimated 15,000 Ghanaians in New York City.
Mr. Kissi doubts that all of them will need his services. "Don't forget that the Pilgrims thought they were going back home someday too," he said. SETH KUGEL

HEADLINE: In Georgia, Days of Wine and Roadsters

BYLINE: By PETER PASSEL 

 BODY:
SO what does the nicotine skin patch have to do with wine, golf champions and, yes, really cool sports cars? Royalties from the transdermal patch have helped to pay for the Panoz family's delightfully disparate conglomerate, a host of enterprises that includes Georgia's only serious winery and the company that builds a car the racing legend Parnelli Jones has dubbed "the great American roadster."
The story really begins in the backwaters of West Virginia, where Donald Panoz, the son of an Italian-born professional boxer, was born. By his late 20's Mr. Panoz, an entrepreneurial sort, had acquired a couple of drugstores in Pittsburgh. Then in 1960, with financial backing from friends who played for the World Series-winning Pittsburgh Pirates, he started Mylan Laboratories, a pharmaceutical company that would become a power in the generic drug business. 
 Rolling the dice again in 1969, he took his wife, four daughters and son to Ireland to start another company, the Elan Corporation, a pioneer in through-the-skin delivery of medications. He struck gold: The stock market now values Elan at $8 billion; it was in the news this month after scientists at a subsidiary said they had developed a potential vaccine for Alzheimer's disease.
The Georgia connection dates from 1981, when Mr. Panoz (pronounced PAY-nose) was scouting locations for the drug maker. The ever-restless entrepreneur decided to combine pleasure with profit, and in the process managed the nearly impossible: making potable wines from European varietal grapes grown in the hot, humid hills of the South. Chateau Elan's first offerings were marketed in 1985. An art gallery, hotel, golf courses and conference center followed in short order on the 3,500-acre site in Braselton, 45 miles north of Atlanta. Next came a spa and a line of bottled waters (both projects of Donald's wife, Nancy) and, for a time, the Gene Sarazen World Golf Open.
And what would a great golf course be without affluent retirees and weekend duffers camped near the fairways? Lots in the Panoz-sponsored development start at $85,000, and finished houses run $1 million or more -- real money in the Atlanta market. Never one to think small, Mr. Panoz, who retired as chairman of Elan in 1996, has since bought 30,000 acres near Modesto, Calif., with plans to offer a similar package of winery, golf and indulgences to San Franciscans with quality time and money to burn.
For all his fascination with the consumables of the good life, Mr. Panoz never admitted any enthusiasm for fast iron. Indeed, he once told a reporter that he didn't know how to open the hood of his Lexus.
But his son, Danny, 39, is definitely a gearhead. While working with the family business in Georgia, he dreamed of building a high-performance sports car. Others have climbed this mountain without success, partly because the finished product was too expensive to sell at a profit. Danny Panoz planned to make his car both affordable and reliable by buying most components off the shelf from the big auto makers.
He got his chance in 1989, adopting an innovative chassis design from a tiny, failed Irish sports-car startup called TMC and opening a modest factory down the road from Chateau Elan. The first vehicle from Panoz Auto Development, a somewhat austerely finished open-top roadster that Danny Panoz describes as "perfect for bikers," rolled off the assembly line in 1992.
With an outlandish hot rod-retro body reminiscent of the all-show, not-much-go Plymouth Prowler, and a monster Ford V8 for muscle, the Panoz Roadster was bound to turn a few heads. And of course, it graced the covers of car-buff magazines with lots of pages to fill each year. But curiosity quickly morphed into respect, with the early reviews ranging from encouraging to ecstatic. Car and Driver called it "the best street-legal, turn-key, cottage-industry roadster available in the United States." Today, a few dozen Ford dealers sell a more refined version of that original Panoz Roadster, and many more can service it, since the drivetrain comes largely from the Mustang.
In Phase 2 of his operation, Danny Panoz designed the Esperante, a less playful-looking and far more polished "grand touring" sports car with plenty of room for two well-fed Americans and even a trunk that can handle a couple sets of golf clubs. This aluminum-bodied convertible has an updated, 320-horsepower version of the Roadster's V8, which was developed by Ford's Special Vehicle Team; a handcrafted leather interior, and styling cues from Jaguar and a half-dozen other European sports cars. It is to go on sale this fall for about $80,000.
"The Esperante will almost match the performance of a 12-cylinder Ferrari, yet cost $200,000 less," Danny Panoz promised. The people in Armani suits from Modena may not be losing much sleep over the competitive threat from rural Georgia. But the auguries are promising.
The Panoz story hardly ends here. In 1995, Papa Panoz, who was about to retire as chairman of his pharmaceutical house, was searching for another challenge. He decided to plunge into the race car business with all the enthusiasm, smarts and deep pockets that he had brought to Chateau Elan.
Panoz Motorsports hired Adrian Reynard, the race car designer, to build a carbon-fiber car, and Jack Rousch, the maven of sports car engines, to produce the innards for a vehicle that superficially resembles the Esperante. It added a team of drivers recruited from racing's top echelons and instantly became a power to reckon with in the take-no-prisoners world of motor sports.
Panoz race cars hold their own with the best from McLaren, Ferrari and BMW, placing in the top 10 at Le Mans the last two years, and winning the Grand Prix at Mosport, near Toronto, in June. And they are pushing the envelope of racing technology, developing the first electric-gasoline hybrid car for the track. "This much success, this quick, is just amazing," said Brock Yates, an automotive writer whose books include a biography of Enzo Ferrari.
Does racing make economic sense? The money spent on vroom and zoom largely comes from multimillionaires with time on their hands, or from oil, tire, auto and cigarette companies with products in need of racing's reflected glory. Think of Cadillac, now heading back to Le Mans.
The $10 million-plus that Don Panoz acknowledges spending on his racing program will no doubt sell a few more Esperantes. "Building successful race cars gave our sports cars instant credibility," his son said.
But with that kind of money, you might convince NASA to launch an Esperante into orbit. If there is any commercial method to Panoz's racing madness, it's probably in the sale of tickets rather than cars. In 1997, Don Panoz acquired both Road Atlanta, an ailing track in Georgia, and Sebring, the legendary race circuit in Florida. With a few home-team winners, Panoz Motorsports may yet fill the bleachers. And who wants to second-guess a man who made a fortune on the nicotine patch?

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
The Bounce From Stock Buybacks

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Alexandria, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week.
E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
BURNED once, shame on you; burned twice, shame on me. That variation on an old saying explains much investor behavior. It takes a lot to persuade investors who have already lost money in a given stock to keep believing in it if it keeps falling, no matter what its fundamentals.
Consider the market's typically tepid reaction when a company says it will be repurchasing its stock on the open market. Many such stocks have taken multiple hits, and are at depressed levels as the announcements are made. 
 Officemax, which traded early last year near $20 a share, took two blows last fall: The overall market had a sharp correction, and the company missed Wall Street's third-quarter earnings estimates by 4 cents a share. The stock fell to below $7. Though the shares jumped a little after the company announced two repurchase programs, one late last year and another earlier this year, the stock is still trading at not much more than half its 1998 high.
Such a lukewarm reaction notwithstanding, it is difficult to imagine a more unambiguously bullish sign than a company's decision to use its spare cash to buy back its shares. After all, when a company puts its own cash on the line, it must be confident that the stock will climb. And it often does, beating the market in a pattern known as the repurchase effect.
Studies have demonstrated the effect. One, covering all United States stocks from 1980 to 1990, found that the average company announcing a repurchase plan will beat the market by a cumulative 12.1 percentage points for the four years after the announcement. The average value stock with such a plan does even better, outperforming the market by 45.3 points, on average, over the next four years.
FOR investors, the repurchase effect has another advantage: You don't have to be a day trader to exploit it. Many other strategies, by contrast, require almost immediate action. To fully capitalize on a surprise announcement in a company's earnings, for example, you often have to trade within hours of the announcement.
Not so with stock repurchase plans. Because the market's initial reaction is so muted, there is generally plenty of potential remaining for investors who act several weeks later.
It seems too good to be true. So, naturally, a number of skeptical professors have speculated in recent years that the repurchase effect is nothing more than a statistical fluke, and have predicted that it will disappear when studied in other places and times.
That is why another recent study is good news. Three professors -- David Ikenberry of the Jones Graduate School of Management at Rice University, Josef Lakonishok of the University of Illinois and Theo Vermaelen of Maastricht University in the Netherlands -- focused on another place and time, Canadian stocks in the 1990's, and found the repurchase effect alive and well.
Another confirmation of sorts is seen in the reverse image of a repurchase: a corporate decision to issue shares, either through initial public offerings or secondary offerings. Study after study has shown that companies issuing shares lag behind the market for several years thereafter. Moreover, the pattern holds not only in the United States, but also in several other countries.
An investment newsletter, too, shows the positive results of the repurchase effect. The Buyback Letter, edited by David Fried, is the only one that I know to base its approach solely on the effect; it has had a 32.2 percent return, annualized, from the beginning of 1997, soon after its birth, through May of this year, according to The Hulbert Financial Digest. That compares with a 25.3 percent return for the Wilshire 5000, a broad market index. In contrast, New Issues, published by the Institute for Econometric Research and perhaps the best-known I.P.O. newsletter, produced a 19.9 percent annualized return over that period.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNION SQUARE;
The Greening of 14th Street: Seedy Remnant Closes

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
The last remnant of 14th Street's seedy past, an adult video store near Third Avenue, closed last week. In years gone by, the block was the domain of crack-addled prostitutes and transients who lived in the Sahara, a single-room-occupancy hotel above the sex shop, one of several that had operated in the vicinity over the last 20 years.
The X-rated store's operators agreed to leave after the building's new owner offered them $100,000, according to someone close to the negotiations. Its departure makes possible the construction of a 15-story building on the corner with apartments and retail space, and opens a new chapter for the neighborhood, according to David Gmach, executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation and Business Improvement District. 
 "We are very excited about the new residences and stores that will serve as an anchor for East 14th Street," he said.
Over the past several years, the renaissance of 14th Street has crept eastward with the opening of new businesses and the construction of new dormitories for New York University. For years, the Sahara was a notorious 140-room S.R.O. known for prostitution and drug sales. In 1985, to avoid prosecution on charges of harassing tenants and allowing drugs and prostitution, the owners agreed to sell the building. Despite the agreement they held on to it.
Except for the sex shop, the building has been vacant since 1990. Late last year, an auction was conducted by a court-appointed receiver. In March, Alex Forkosh, a developer, submitted the winning bid of $8.5 million.
Marian Glazer, the managing agent of 200 East 15th Street, an apartment building that has commercial properties on Third Avenue next to the former pornography shop, has high hopes. "In the early 90's we had a hard time renting the space to quality retailers," he said. "When they would see what was going on next door, they would get very nervous. I'm happy because the neighborhood will finally become what we would like it to become."
But Mr. Donald Bruce, who owns O Sweet Cheeses at 141 Third Avenue, a few doors from the former video store, said the establishment had never bothered him.
"The scaffolding is more dangerous," he said, referring to the structure that has been on the building for at least a year. He said muggers could hide in the shadows. Mr. Bruce, a longtime resident of the area, said the store's customers didn't hang around and the store was conservative about displaying its merchandise.
After the store closed its doors on Tuesday, there were rumors that it would reopen elsewhere on East 14th Street. But Mr. Gmach said that was unlikely because of the zoning provisions for sexually oriented businesses, which the city has been aggressively enforcing for the past year, closing dozens of strip clubs and adult video stores, or forcing them to scale back their X-rated merchandise to less than 40 percent of the retail space. "Under current zoning they cannot just open up another store," he said. ERIC V. COPAGE

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Picked Up andDusted Off, A Ski Chain Starts Anew

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
BY late last week, word had spread around the Killington area in Vermont, where the economy depends upon the ski trade, that something even better than a heavy snowfall was on its way. It was a heavy downpour of cash.
An investment group controlled by the Texas billionaire Robert Bass had agreed to buy $150 million of convertible preferred stock in the American Skiing Company, the debt-laden owner of the Killington ski area and eight other resorts in New England and the Rockies. On the surface, it seemed to be a peculiar move for someone as sharp as Mr. Bass, considering that the stock market value of the company is slightly less than $150 million. 
 The deal gives the group, Oak Hill Capital Partners, a 48.5 percent stake in the company and infuses enough money into the ski conglomerate to help it finish some of its projects and pay off part of its more than $400 million in debt.
The deal came in the nick of time. Coming out of a rough winter of little snow and few skiers, American Skiing was forced to cut the pay of some employees in Killington and elsewhere and to lay off others. It also put an inn, a golf course and other assets up for sale. With $95 million in accounts payable as of April, and a $7 million interest payment due this month, scant summer revenues would not fill the gap.
Even the Wall Street firms that American Skiing had hired to pin down money, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and ING Barings, were coming up empty.
"They had shopped around a similar deal, a convertible preferred, to the usual cast of suspects -- other financial buyers, strategic partners and existing shareholders," said Christine Lumpkins, a ski industry analyst with Bear Stearns.
For more than two months, nothing came through, possibly because American Skiing's chairman and founder, Leslie B. Otten, who had built up the company from one resort in 1994, did not want to give up control. He currently owns 50.1 percent of the stock, and the restructuring will reduce his stake to 26.2 percent.
David O'Leary, who follows American Skiing for Alpha Equity Research in Portsmouth, N.H., said the deal was a necessary one for Mr. Otten, but not a good one for some American Skiing shareholders.
"If you bought the stock at $18, you've got to be pretty angry that they are selling half of the company for $5.25," he said. American Skiing made its initial public offering in November 1997 for $18 a share. The stock dropped to a low of $2.375 in April and closed at $4.8125 on Friday.
Although the stock market value of the company was only $146 million on Friday, "the value of all of those assets is worth more than that stock is selling for," said John J. Rohs, an analyst with Schroder & Company.
American Skiing has begun millions of dollars' worth of development on hotels and time-share apartments at many of its properties, including Steamboat in Colorado and the Canyons in Utah, which must be completed for the 2002 Winter Olympics.
Hollis Rafkin-Sax, a spokeswoman for Oak Hill, said Mr. Bass and his partners were long-term investors who saw potential in the resorts under construction.
"Many are less developed than their competitors, and real growth opportunities," she said.
Mr. O'Leary noted that Oak Hill stands to make at least $63.75 million from an 8.5 percent dividend over the next five years, after which it must convert its preferred stock to common stock. And if American Skiing has another bad winter this year, he said, the arrangement means that "Oak Hill gets paid before Les Otten gets paid."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
At the Desk, Off the Clock And Below Statistical Radar

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
YOUNG assistant professors at Cornell University once had time to paint their own houses. Now nights and weekends are devoted to research and writing as they struggle to win tenure. "Painting your own house is not something you even think about anymore," said Robert Frank, a tenured Cornell professor today who did his own painting as an assistant in the 1970's.
Software engineers at Xerox are similarly afflicted. A few sometimes get their work done by 5 P.M., says Leslie Perlow, a University of Michigan sociologist who has studied software engineers at Xerox and other technology companies. But they dare not go home, fearful that their bosses might conclude they are shirkers who stick to the easiest assignments. "We don't know how to assess the value of a knowledge worker in these new technologies, so we value those who work into the night," Ms. Perlow said. 
 There is much debate over whether Americans are spending more time at work or at leisure, and which activities to call "work" and which "leisure." But two things are clear: People on fixed salaries for a 35-hour or 40-hour week are the fastest-growing segment of the work force, and increasingly they work beyond their weekly schedules for no extra pay. The Labor Department's surveys have found that workers who say they toiled 49 hours or more a week have risen to nearly 19 percent of the private-sector work force, from 13 percent in 1976.
EVEN John Robinson, a University of Maryland sociologist who has challenged such data, is beginning to come around. He argues that survey respondents tend to exaggerate when asked to recall how many hours they have worked, and he prefers data from time diaries, in which each day's activities are recorded that day. His diary-based figures showed Americans spending fewer and fewer hours at work until 1985, but gradually more since then.
People are still exaggerating, Mr. Robinson said: they tell pollsters they worked, say, 60 hours in a week when they actually worked only 50. "But there are more people now in the exaggerating class," he said.
No sector of the work force is growing more rapidly than workers on fixed salaries: managers, administrators, engineers, technicians, lawyers, researchers, programmers, consultants. They constitute roughly 40 percent of all workers today, up from 34 percent in 1982. Such workers rarely get overtime pay, particularly those earning more than $40,000 a year. And the changing nature of work in America adds to the pressure on them to work more hours.
The new pressures include some obvious ones: more competition; more people vying for fewer tenured slots, like those at Cornell; the reluctance of corporations to offer job security over a lifetime. But there is also what sociologists describe as a shift away from routine, repetitive work that can be packaged in eight-hour days. The new mode is "project" work that must be done in a hurry, often without clearly defined guidelines.
Senior managers at the technology companies studied by Ms. Perlow often bid on software projects by promising to deliver in two months when everyone knows three months are required, she said. But even in routine trades like commercial baking, the new mode of work appears.
For example, many bakeries once filled standing orders from neighborhood stores, said Richard Sennett, a New York University sociologist who has studied bakeries. The work was routine. Supervisors and workers knew their daily tasks. But now many bakeries vie for orders from all over a city, and the supervisors find themselves constantly changing work schedules or ingredients, tasks that add hours to their workdays.
"If you are manual labor in this process, it shows up in your hourly wages," Mr. Sennett said. "If you are a salaried employee, the sky is the limit."
THE growing number of hours worked by salaried workers is not yet reflected in some key Labor Department statistics, leaving the impression that America's economic performance is better than it probably is. For example, the nation's productivity -- output for each hour worked -- has risen rapidly in recent years, suggesting that corporate America is becoming more efficient.
But the Bureau of Labor Statistics calculates productivity using the hours reported by employers, not employees. For salaried workers, the bureau often is working with scheduled hours, not actual hours. What's more, the bureau assumes that supervisory workers in the service sector -- a category where hard numbers are lacking -- work roughly the same amount of time as hourly, nonsupervisory workers.
The upshot is that the hours worked by as many as 16 percent of all workers are probably underreported, bureau officials said. Undercounting hours has the effect of exaggerating the nation's productivity growth and hourly wages.
That is the arithmetic. The psychological aspect is more ingrained. "We have incorporated the longer hours into our self-image," said Stephen Rose, a labor economist, "and we have come to accept that to be really successful you have to work a lot of hours." 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Economist Laureate, Quill in Hand

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
AT 90, John Kenneth Galbraith has just published his 34th book, "Name-Dropping," (Houghton Mifflin, $26) a memoir featuring F.D.R. and Eleanor, Jack and Jackie, Adlai and L.B.J. He has been speaking to packed auditoriums, and now he is ready to hop on a plane to London, where he will be giving a speech on "The Unfinished Business of the Century." And he is already hard at work on Book No. 35. "I get uneasy unless I've spent part of every day writing," he said.
Economics may have become a science, but for the better part of this century, Mr. Galbraith has shrewdly insisted on treating it as a branch of belles lettres. In several books over the last couple of decades, Mr. Galbraith, who was perhaps the only economist at Truman Capote's 1966 Black and White Ball, has been mining a rich vein of history: his own. 
 He writes from memory -- "I never kept a diary," he says. His beginnings belie his born-to-the-manor manner and the grand Victorian, a few hundred yards from Harvard Square, where he lives. He describes himself as a southern Ontario farm boy who to this day never wakes up without a feeling of satisfaction at having escaped "hard, tedious, boring toil." Interestingly, it was his grasp of the realities of that life that gave him entree, back when farm politics dominated American politics, into Washington and Harvard.
His memories are less of his long academic career than of his glamorous political assignments. During the Depression, he was briefly a junior speech writer for President Franklin D. Roosevelt. An early sojourn at Cambridge University made him a disciple of the British economist John Maynard Keynes, of whom he says, "I discovered that his advice was always right, but politically disastrous."
An initial stint at Harvard in the 30's proved less than a triumph. When he left briefly to visit Princeton, he got a telegram from his dean saying, "Accept any available offer!" He did take one, but the exile at Princeton -- "still back in the pre-Keynesian, classical era," he said -- was mercifully brief, thanks to the outbreak of World War II. Hired by the Department of Agriculture, he was ultimately charged with keeping a lid on all prices. He recalls his experience as price czar as the highlight of his career. "In terms of authority and power," he said with a grin, "life has been downhill ever since."
A few days after the war ended, President Harry S. Truman sent Mr. Galbraith to Germany to interrogate Albert Speer, Hitler's economic minister. In contrast to other Hitler henchmen, notorious drug addicts and drunks, Speer proved to be a suave master of spin, in command of snappy American idiom and, in Mr. Galbraith's eyes, the only Nazi who made the enemy "worth the wartime effort and sacrifice."
Soon back at Harvard, Mr. Galbraith wrote speeches and served as an economics tutor to every liberal Democratic Presidential candidate from Adlai Stevenson and John F. Kennedy to George McGovern. At one point, Mr. Galbraith thought he might like to become a Senator from Massachusetts, though the idea didn't go far. His imposing height of 6 feet, 8 inches was always an advantage, he acknowledges. So was the colossal self-assurance. When he once complained to President Kennedy that he didn't see why The New York Times had to call him arrogant, Kennedy replied: "I don't know why not, Ken. Everyone else does."
He came by his success as an author after relentless practice and some false starts. When one of his first efforts, blaming the rise of monopolies for the Depression, was still at the printing press, he wanted to pull it back. As soon as he read Keynes, he said, "I decided the book was wrong, but it was too late." Later, he quietly dropped it from his list of publications.
It was ever upward from there, with classics of social criticism like "The Affluent Society" (1958) and "The New Industrial State" (1967). His biggest hit was "The Triumph" a novel of State Department intrigue published in 1968 and optioned four times by Hollywood.
Time hasn't mellowed him much. Mr. Galbraith's new book, like so many of his old ones, pokes at fellow economists and what he sees as their erroneous but convenient beliefs. He plans to call it "The Economics of Innocent Fraud."
Asked whether he didn't think the 1990's were a lot like the golden 60's, he sat up very straight. 'There is no comparison!" he nearly shouted, launching into a riff on the dangers of unchecked speculation. "We have a much greater speculative bulge than in the 60's," he said. "Prices are going up, so people buy. That justifies the expectation, so they buy more. It's a classic bubble."
He refrains from predicting how the current economic boom will end, explaining: "All my wrong predictions will always be remembered. My right ones not."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Looking for Attention With a Billion-Dollar Message

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
AFTER jurors announced a staggering verdict of $4.9 billion against General Motors on July 9, a juror explained the panel's fury at the company. "We're just like numbers, I feel, to them," he said. "Statistics."
Message sent: The jurors concluded that the auto maker had risked lives to save a few dollars on each car, and they were incensed. Rejecting the auto maker's claim that it had been careful, the jury set $107.6 million as the sum to compensate six people for medical and other expenses after they were severely burned when a fuel tank exploded in a crash. 
 The exclamation point came in the punitive damage award of $4.8 billion.
Sending messages is the purpose of punitive damages, defined by law as punishment for especially outrageous conduct.
"The system awards punitive damages not out of concern for the plaintiff but out of concern about the defendant's conduct," said David W. Leebron, an expert on injury law who is the dean of the Columbia Law School. "It is to send a message both to the defendant and others who might consider conduct like the defendant's in the future."
The award in the G.M. case is almost certain to be reduced by appeals courts. But the case is the latest to highlight a ferocious battle over whether punitive damages should be reined in, modified or, perhaps, eliminated.
The view that punitive damages give plaintiffs' lawyers a windfall and provide little benefit was part of the Republican rejection last week of a Democratic proposal to expand what are now extremely limited rights of patients to sue managed health care companies. Most patients can sue only for the value of the care denied but cannot win punitive damages.
Across the country, states are experimenting with new rules for punitive damages. Judges and scholars are advancing new ideas about how awards should be set. And some scholars and business lawyers argue that the American legal system should join those of many other countries, which do not allow civil juries to award punitive damages at all.
Under the banner of tort reform, many state legislatures are capping the amount of punitive damages people can recover. Increasingly, state courts are striking down other new laws limiting liability suits, saying they violate state constitutional guarantees. But so far challenges to punitive damages caps have not met with great success.
Perhaps more than any other legal device, punitive damages are products of a view of the legal system as an economic tool. In a free-market system, the thinking goes, the fear of financial losses from private suits may work better than regulation ever could to keep products safe.
But as huge punitive damage awards have become Exhibit A for the argument that the legal system is little more than a lottery, critics have said the main contribution of punitive damages is to inhibit business without making products safer.
"You can't design and build a product to the standards of a future jury in California, because you don't know what those standards are," said Steve Morrison, a lawyer in Columbia, S.C., and a former president of the Defense Research Institute, a national organization of trial lawyers who defend corporations.
In Europe, where he has defended manufacturers, Mr. Morrison said, litigation of civil cases is more rational because punitive damages are viewed as penalties like criminal sanctions that should be sought only by government.
SOME scholars say the big American verdicts, and the fear of them, result in "over-deterrence," or excessive caution to avoid litigation that hampers the free market system. Decisions about product safety like the proper location of automobile gas tanks, they say, ought to be left to regulators.
Industry lobbyists offer a list of drugs and other products that do not get to American consumers because of executives' fears of punitive damages. According to the American Tort Reform Association, a group that lobbies for limitations on liability law, the risk of punitive damages reduced the number of companies making football helmets in the United States from 20 in the 1960's to 2 by the late 1980's.
Defenders of punitive damages have their own list of products that have been improved after juries hit their makers with big punitive damage awards. According to Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group, punitive damages helped convince manufacturers to change the design of tampons that had caused toxic shock syndrome, and forced makers of baby pajamas to produce them without flammable fabrics.
Some legal scholars argue that judges traditionally give jurors too much leeway. "Juries don't have any guidance about how much is appropriate to punish," said Polly J. Price, a professor at Emory University School of Law in Atlanta. That, some experts say, has created punitive damage inflation, as incensed jurors pick bigger and bigger numbers out of the air. And some say juries should be given formulas that take into account such things as how much it would have cost to make a dangerous product safer.
In 1996, the United States Supreme Court issued its most expansive decision on punitive damages in an Alabama case. The decision left a great deal of room for interpretation and did not adopt a formula. It did say courts reviewing punitive damage awards should consider the "degree of reprehensibility" and the ratio between punitive and compensatory damages.
THE Justices said a punitive damage award of $2 million was "grossly excessive" when the compensatory damages were only $4,000 in a consumer fraud case involving a new BMW that had been painted to cover scratches. The court said the ratio of $500 in punitive damages to each $1 of compensatory damages was too big, but it did not specify an acceptable ratio.
Some states have passed laws setting dollar limits, like $250,000 in medical malpractice cases. In other states, legislators have focused not so much on the amount of the awards as on the fact that the money was going to plaintiffs and their lawyers.
At least nine states, including Florida, Georgia and Kansas, are experimenting with new laws that reduce the incentive to sue by giving plaintiffs only a portion of any punitive damage award; 25 percent, for example, with the remainder going to the state.
To business lawyers, such solutions do not deal with the heart of the problem: the sheer size of verdicts, no matter how rare or how likely to be overturned. Mr. Morrison, who has defended automobile manufacturers and pharmaceutical companies in liability cases, says the main problem is that juries are told only to figure out how much punishment is enough.
"It is a subjective standard based on how outraged a particular jury is," Mr. Morrison said.
To defenders of punitive damages, of course, that is exactly the point. The messages jurors send with their verdicts are determined by how outraged they are.

HEADLINE: The World: Meanwhile, Back in Bosnia;
Slowly Starving Serb Defiance

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: SREBRENICA, Bosnia

 BODY:
AFTER years of obstinacy, the Serbs finally gave in here last month. Local Serb nationalists allowed the majority Muslim town council -- elected in absentia more than two years ago -- to take official control of a town that has stood as a symbol of Serb defiance and brutality in Bosnia.
Four years ago this month, Bosnian Serb soldiers hunted down and killed as many as 7,000 mostly unarmed Muslim men in the rugged hills surrounding Srebrenica, a town the United Nations had declared a "safe area" and vowed to protect. Since the war ended in 1995, local Serb nationalists have used tactics ranging from endless negotiations to rock-throwing mobs to prevent the town council from meeting. 
 But in a scene hardt to imagine only a few months ago, two dozen Muslim politicians calmly sat down with 20 of their Serb counterparts in the lobby of a local hotel on June 29 for the inaugural session of the town council of the "new Srebrenica."
Nesib Mandzic, a Bosnian Muslim high school principal who unsuccessfully begged the Bosnian Serb Army commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, to spare the lives of thousands of Muslims four years ago, presided over the meetings as nothing less than Srebrenica's new Muslim mayor.
For the last month, Mr. Mandzic and other Muslim town councilors have lived in the hotel under the protection of American soldiers. This summer they should be the first Muslims to move back to Srebrenica.
Bent Jensen, a former Danish policeman who is the international community's special representative to Srebrenica, said the explanation for the Serb change of heart was simple. "There are no jobs," he said. "People are having trouble feeding themselves. They are on their knees."
FOR four years, the Clinton Administration has used its veto in the World Bank and other aid institutions to enforce what critics call a heavy-handed blockade of most relief to Srebrenica because of Serb recalcitrance. While Muslim and Croat leaders also thwart some efforts by members of other ethnic groups to return to their homes, Serb leaders in Srebrenica and other nearby towns are viewed as the most obstinate in Bosnia.
As a result of the blockade, the 12,000 Serbs who now inhabit Srebrenica -- most of them refugees from Sarajevo -- have spent four years living in the crumbling ruins of a town with 80 to 90 percent unemployment, no potable running water and a wretched sewage system. The NATO bombing that destroyed the Serbian economy this spring may have been the final blow. Many of the Serbs who had jobs actually worked in nearby towns in Serbia, Mr. Jensen said. They are now unemployed.
The denial of aid and the NATO bombing may be having similar effects in other hard-line towns in eastern Bosnia. Andy Bearpark, the head of the international resettlement task force here, said Serbs in towns known for defiance are taking initial steps to allow some Muslims to return to their homes in exchange for Western aid. "There is still a long way to go," he cautioned.
Some Western diplomats cite the signs of initial success here as proof that the same policy should be used in Serbia. The Clinton Administration is vowing to block most international aid to Serbia until President Slobodan Milosevic is forced from power. But skeptics have predicted that this policy would merely punish ordinary Serbs.
Among Serb civilians in Srebrenica, resentment of the United States and NATO simmers. A group of people selling buckets of blueberries in front of a bombed-out building complained that the new Muslim-led government was being forced on them.
The suffering has also clearly bred resentment of local Serb hard-liners. But whether that frustration can spark wide public opposition to the Serb nationalists was difficult to predict. The strongest sentiments expressed by the Serbs of Srebrenica as they watched their triumph of four years ago slowly being reversed were cynicism and despair, not anger and calls for action.
"The old government was stealing the aid sent here," said a Serb woman who would not give her name. "The new one will probably do the same."

HEADLINE: The World;
Getting Real in the Other China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
HERE'S a riddle: How do you make a country richer and more democratic and at the same time outmaneuver a huge, luggish neighbor that wants to "reunify" with you?
Here's an answer (and Beijing won't like this): Ask the President of Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui. 
 Last week, Mr. Lee again upset the apple cart of international opinion when he declared that Taiwan would no longer adhere to the principle that the Chinese mainland and it were part of the same country. This may sound silly to an outsider, since the Chinese civil war ended exactly 50 years ago, but ever since then Taipei and Beijing have been bickering over the use of the name China.
Mr. Lee, 76, is a master politician who has repeatedly defied, and surpassed, the expectations of him. A shrewd strategist with an eye on the voter, he has presided over a remarkable flourishing of democracy and economic growth while holding on to power for nearly 12 years, at the same time keeping his enormous Chinese neighbor at bay.
Perhaps most impressive is the way Mr. Lee has kept his Nationalist Party, once dominated by thugs, at the top of Taiwan's political heap. And he has done that while steadily cutting away at the party's original premise: that it represents all of China. Instead he has focused on the governing of Taiwan alone.
How has he done it? Mr. Lee likes to talk about his vision of democracy, and his conviction as the first native-born President of Taiwan that his country needs an identity separate from China. His greatest skill may be keeping his rivals off balance with sly tactical maneuvering, and by appealing to voters.
Yet a central element of Mr. Lee's success is often overlooked: His moves point toward more democracy and self-determination, two concepts that have proved stunningly popular this century, at least with voters. Though he plays a risky game with China, his strategy is based on political ideas far more resilient than all the inertia that favors the status quo.
Chiang Kai-shek, the vanquished leader of the Nationalist Party who retreated to Taiwan in 1949, refused to recognize the legitimacy of the Government in mainland China. So did the United States until 1972. When President Nixon traveled to Beijing that year, his main obstacle was the Taiwan question. So the "one China" policy was born, allowing Washington, Beijing and Taipei to agree to the fiction that there was only one China and that its two halves would reunify eventually. The beauty of this lie was that it allowed both sides to get around the truth -- that China has no control over its highly successful ideological rival. This is a truth that makes the Chinese hopping mad and liable to do dangerous and unpredictable things.
By dropping the one-China stance last week, Mr. Lee has taken another step toward acknowledging that messy truth and thereby upsetting the delicate arrangement that made his country's prosperity possible. Although he has not actually declared independence, or changed Taiwan's formal name from the Republic of China, he is insisting that Taiwan be considered its own state. The United States, Taiwan's leading patron, expressed dismay at Mr. Lee's action and reaffirmed its support for one China led by Beijing.
Mr. Lee's assertions may sound dangerous in the face of China's threats to take military action toward reunification if peaceful means fail. China responded to Mr. Lee in its state-run media last week, calling him a "troublemaker." How it reacts over the coming months, especially to Taiwan's presidential elections next March, is anyone's guess.
Though many people fret at China's rumbling, even more seem to be embracing the way Mr. Lee is calling Taiwan its own country, which, after all, has been a reality for 50 years. "A lot of people in Taiwan are very happy to hear their President finally say the truth," said Yang Kai-huang, a political science professor at Soochow University in Taipei. Professor Yang and other political analysts see other motives behind the move. They see Mr. Lee trying to undercut James Soong, a long-time ally Mr. Lee dropped from his top circle two years ago because he was too popular and independent minded. Mr. Soong announced his candidacy for President on an independent line Friday.
There is an obvious merit in Mr. Lee's refashioning of the Nationalist Party line toward China that is closer to reality. Many Chinese grow up steeped in a way of thinking that teaches that respect for authority is more important than honesty. Chinese culture does not have a monopoly on political hypocrisy, of course, but it seems to tolerate a mind-boggling degree of saying one thing while doing another.
TO some Chinese, that subtlety need not change.
"I am a man. Do I need to say it out loud?" asked Eric Wang, a Taiwanese businessman who runs a plastics business in mainland China.
Yet in Taiwan, life has changed so much since the one-China formula, becoming so open and modern minded, that many others object to an old policy that they see as so badly out of date as to be offensive.
Mr. Lee's latest moves, in his final year in office, may be geared toward his legacy. History will not be uniformly kind to him. Among his ill-considered actions is offering the United Nations $1 billion only if it would let Taiwan join. (The United Nations said no.) A book recently published under Mr. Lee's name made the wacky suggestion that China be split into seven autonomous regions, including Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Yet among Mr. Lee's big achievements is ushering in a presidential election in 1996, arguably the first time a Chinese society had freely elected a leader. Political analysts detailed how Mr. Lee appeared to manipulate public opinion in a risky way, deliberately angering China so much that it held military exercises off the coast of Taiwan just before the election, which rallied voters to Mr. Lee's side and gave him a decisive victory.
Mr. Lee came out looking like a master. But his legacy will not be based only on his electoral victory; there is also the fact that a genuine presidential election was held at all.
