HEADLINE: The Nation: Agony of Victory;
America Finds It's Lonely At the Top

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is impossible to pinpoint the moment when America's successes in the 1990's moved from a topic of grudging admiration around the world to a constant source of annoyance at Washington's triumphalism to a rationale for mistrust and resistance.
Perhaps the clincher was envy over the Dow's dramatic ascent from a little over 2,000 at the start of the decade to a little over 11,000 this year. Maybe it was the dawning realization that people around the globe are all flicking on the same Windows operating system in the morning, on their way to navigating an Internet dominated by American innovations and businesses and driven by Intel inside everything. Maybe it was when the United States, in the wake of the Asian economic crisis, began offering tutorials on American-style capitalism, and insisting that the world's financial architecture be rebuilt to American building codes. 
 But surely the capstone was Kosovo. Whether Washington intended this outcome or not, the war demonstrated to allies and potential adversaries alike how much more formidable American military technology has become since the Persian Gulf war. Europeans got a rude awakening when they learned that the gap between the United States' capability and their own had so widened that they now have to rethink their we'll-build-it-on-the-Continent mentality.
And nothing sent a greater chill through the Kremlin and the Chinese leaders' compound next to the Forbidden City than the image of those B-2 bombers lazily lifting into the air over Missouri at midday, flying an 11,000-mile, 32-hour mission to drop laser-guided weapons over Belgrade -- and getting back in time for dinner the next evening. Feeling the need to stake out some ground, Moscow hastily flew a ragtag force into Kosovo, and Beijing boasted last week that it had the neutron bomb -- don't-mess-with-us messages that undercut the Clinton Administration's talk of strategic partnerships with old cold war adversaries.
Of course, the world looks very different to Americans, who have already moved beyond the Kosovo war. In the national self-image, America's pillars of global power -- unparalleled financial clout, unmatched technological prowess and unchallenged military reach -- are separate entities, bits of a far more fragile mosaic. Sure, times are good, but Americans don't feel particularly powerful now, even with the Russians broke, the Chinese consumed with unemployment and slowing growth, and the Japanese unable to get their breath back.
But talk to Thai politicians stewingover what they view as an American conspiracy to keep their candidate from running the World Trade Organization, or scan the People's Daily, or listen to talk radio in Toronto, and it becomes clear that America's triple threat -- the dollar, the Pentium III chip and the B-2 -- is now also its biggest diplomatic challenge. It may be a case of being too powerful for one's own good.
OR as Michael Mandelbaum, a professor at Johns Hopkins University, puts it, "If you are the 800-pound gorilla, you're concentrating on your bananas and everyone else is concentrating on you."
Of course, the reactions differ dramatically when America talks to friends like the Western Europeans and to potentially hostile powers. Nonetheless, officials at the State Department, the Treasury and the Pentagon, who agree on precious little, all say fear of America's widening lead has become the subtext of nearly every major conversation they hold around the world.
It underlies Europe's near-panic over the precipitous fall of the euro, the new currency meant to represent a more economically powerful Europe. And it underlies Russia's perpetual negotiations to avoid national default, in which Moscow fights every step of the way as the International Monetary Fund -- synonymous with Washington in the Russian view -- demands economic reforms in return for aid.
"What we need is a policy of strategic reassurance," a Clinton Administration official lamented, "a way of demonstrating that not only is this power benign, but that it isn't a zero-sum game."
BUT turning that desire into policy isn't easy. The new Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, warns against trying to fix the world, noting that "we cannot want prosperity and reform in any country more than its people do."
"It's our challenge," he says, "to succeed as the first outward-looking, non-imperialist, continental superpower." The unspoken comparison is with the old Soviet Union, which was continental but expansionist and the continental but inward-looking China.
From other capitals, though, Washington doesn't look so benign. Its push for more open markets around the world is often viewed as nice ideological justification for speeding the pace at which more efficient American companies can drive their foreign competition into the ground. Meanwhile, the White House jumps when American companies complain that low-cost imports are hurting American workers: In the past two weeks alone, Washington has announced restrictions on cheap steel from Russia and Brazil and cheap lamb from Australia and New Zealand. No matter how it defends such moves as legal responses to "dumping," from overseas it looks more like protectionism.
On top of that is puzzlement over the deliberately vague "Clinton Doctrine." It doesn't get much press in the United States, but everywhere else there is speculation over how far the Americans might extend the principles of Kosovo, intervening inside other nations' borders to enforce "international values" of humanitarian treatment or human rights. Russia looks at Kosovo and worries about Chechnya; China looks at it and worries about Tibet and Taiwan.
An intense decade of global competition and technological innovation has only heightened the contrast between America's view of its power and the very different view held by the rest of the world.
Europeans struggling with 12 percent unemployment and Japanese trying to emerge from a lost decade look at America's surging markets and employment rolls and see a train speeding by so fast that it looks uncatchable. When Americans look at the same facts, many get as queasy as Alan Greenspan, wondering how long the boom can last. (That insecurity, some economists think, has actually helped spur America's growth, sustaining the pressure for cost-cutting and productivity gains.)
When foreign companies look at the pace of American technological development, they see a gap far greater than a decade ago. But American corporate executives look over their shoulders and worry. "You sense quite the opposite of triumphalism from c.e.o.'s," said Jeffrey Garten, the dean of the Yale School of Management. "They feel they are in a brutally competitive world, and they think they are in a race for their lives."
The developing world holds a similar fear. The United Nations Development Program issued a report last week arguing that the digital divide is widening faster than ever. Twenty-six percent of Americans use the World Wide Web, it said, compared to 3 percent of Russians and a tiny fraction of a percent of the population of South Asia. The United States has more computers than the rest of the world combined. In other words, the faster rich nations log on, the further they pull ahead of countries that aren't even plugged in. But the closest the report came to advocating a solution was a 1-cent tax on long E-mails, with the revenue earmarked for connecting up the rest of the world.
The perception gap grows whenever the subject turns to the lessons of Kosovo and American military power. Washington looks back at the events of the spring and wipes its brow, relieved that it got through with negligible casualties and no ground troops. It sees a truly multinational mission: After all, there was Prime Minister Tony Blair, feeling his oats, arguing for ground troops.
The European allies emerged with a different view: The war was won with American air power that homegrown military technology cannot match. Meeting last week in Washington to review the war, European defense contractors and officials concluded that trans-Atlantic mergers of defense contractors -- something both Europe and America have long resisted -- are now inevitable.
The Chinese saw Kosovo through another lens. When Thomas R. Pickering, the Under Secretary of State, went to Beijing last month to explain the series of mistakes that led to the accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, a senior Chinese official said China believed that the United States was involved in Kosovo simply to test its latest armaments, according to American officials who have reviewed transcripts of the conversation.
"I don't think that we appreciate how this integration of financial, military and technological power looks from the outside," said Gerrit Gong, the director of Asian studies at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "It makes random, unconnected events seem like part of a plan for America to hog the road."
THIS may be a problem without a solution. Perhaps it could be eased with a little less talk of America as the "indispensable nation" -- Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's phrase -- and a little more attention to sharing technology and the wealth it creates.
That, however, is not exactly the mood that Congress is in. Nor is the Administration so inclined; it is trying to get through its last 18 months with no more ethnic wars, no more economic collapses around the globe and no abrupt end to the age of prosperity.
"Economic progress is a Faustian bargain," concludes Mr. Mandelbaum. "You gain a lot, you pay a price. That's what international politics is all about."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: The World;
Now That the Wars Are Over, Utopia Seems More Distant

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
THE warm and fuzzies have vanished from peacemaking.
There is a cold-blooded quality to the resolution of ethnic and territorial conflicts in today's world. Rosy visions of multi-ethnic harmony, often imposed by outsiders, have turned steely. Even the impulse to provide such visions as window-dressing seems to be gone -- from the Balkans, Northern Ireland and the Middle East. 
 Ehud Barak, the new Prime Minister of Israel, is determined to be the great peacemaker of his country's history, to resolve century-old conflicts once and for all.
But the former general, while he has traded in his olive drabs for an olive branch, does not spout a vision that could even remotely be considered utopian. His hard-nosed peace, which he presented to President Clinton in Washington last week, sounds less like something positive and more like a double negative: not war.
Mr. Barak, leader of the Labor Party, talks bluntly about putting up "high fences" between Israel and its neighbors. He primarily describes peace as a way to enhance Israel's security.
It is a baldly grim message compared with the idealism about regional cooperation, even harmony, voiced by predecessors who chose to wear the mantle of peacemaker. Mr. Barak's campaign pledge to "separate" from the Palestinians summed it up with a starkly unromantic slogan: "We are here and they will be over there."
Similarly, in the Balkans, there is very little official talk any more of forging or recreating mixed societies. In 1995, Tito's dream of unifying the South Slavs got a final nod in the Dayton peace accords, which, for public relations purposes, were wrapped in the rhetoric of harmony. But with Bosnia now rigidly divided and the Serbs exiting Kosovo, there is little pretense of establishing Serbian-Albanian friendship leagues.
Even as it urges Serbs not to leave, NATO is reconciled to separating peoples.
It could be argued that peace has always been more about exhaustion than aspiration. Belligerent parties finally realize they are not going to reach their objectives through armed conflicts; their people are tired of paying the price of sustained warfare.
But there does seem to be a change in the air, a new pragmatism that sees the hopeful dream of peace with harmony as naive, even as an obstacle to ending conflicts.
Perhaps it is a kind of battle fatigue with peacemaking, too; conflicting peoples would just as soon carve out a conflict-free zone and be done with it.
In Northern Ireland, peace the concept has become truce the (near) reality. Talk of integrating schools and sports has given way to divvying up parliamentary spoils and "decommissioning" paramilitary weapons.
In 1976, the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to two Irish women, Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams, grass-roots peace activists who preached inter-religious reconciliation -- and led a movement that went nowhere. Last year's Nobel Peace Prize celebrated two unapologetic partisans -- David Trimble, the Unionist leader, and John Hume, the Irish Republican leader -- who attempt no straddling of worlds.
Last week, the continuing strains brought the pact close to a breaking point when Mr. Trimble refused to let members of a new power-sharing Cabinet be named unless the Irish Republican Army began to disarm. Such is the tense and guarded quality of this peace.
In the Mideast, Mr. Barak is not playing games with his tough talk.
A veteran of Israeli-Arab battlefields and someone who personally led missions to assassinate Palestinian terrorists, he is not inclined to hold hands with Yasir Arafat and sing "Kumbaya."
In an interview last week, Mr. Barak could not bring himself to echo Mr. Arafat's description of him as "friend and partner." He raised his eyebrows, said Mr. Arafat was not exactly a card-carrying member of the B'nai B'rith and settled on "partnerish rival" to describe him.
But, beyond his personal feelings, Mr. Barak is also acting in a perfectly calculated manner. As a leader, he does not want to go beyond what the body politic can endorse. And he has decided that the Israeli public cannot unite around a utopian notion of peacemaking.
Following in the footsteps of Yitzhak Rabin, who was assassinated by a right-wing extremist in 1995, any Israeli leader intent on forging peace agreements is going to tread cautiously through the ideological minefields.
For Mr. Barak to dress up his peacemaking as a visionary thing would be to risk violent social unrest at the worst or to face political paralysis at best. Israelis are prepared to swallow the bitter pill of making territorial concessions to the Palestinians and even to the Syrians. Like Mr. Barak, they are ready to free Israel of what he calls the "burden of ruling the Palestinians."
They are not ready to take down the barbed wire.
This hard-bitten approach mediates between the grand neighborly visions of some of Mr. Barak's leftist predecessors and the hostile skepticism of the Prime Minister he defeated, Benjamin Netanyahu, who said he believed in peace but never sounded conciliatory.
No less than Theodor Herzl, Israel's founder, envisioned a commercially integrated Middle East, although his writings reveal a keen colonialist mentality. ("The creation of our State would be beneficial to other countries," he wrote.)
DECADES later, when Abba Eban addressed the United Nations in 1967, he had a fully realized dream. "In peaceful conditions, we could imagine communications running from Haifa to Beirut and Damascus in the north, to Amman and beyond in the east, and to Cairo in the south," he said. "The opening of these blocked arteries would stimulate the life, thought and commerce in the region beyond any level otherwise conceivable."
Even the unsentimental Mr. Rabin, Mr. Barak's mentor, spoke of "turning swords into plowshares" and forging an economically integrated region.
But it was Shimon Peres, first as Foreign Minister under Yitzhak Rabin and then as the Prime Minister after Mr. Rabin's assassination, who became the Israeli leader most associated with the utopian vision of peace with harmony.
Mr. Peres scoffed at and continues to scoff at the notion of high fences. He coined the idea of a New Middle East.
Politically, he was mocked by many for his lofty thinking; one remark -- that hotels would be of greater strategic importance than checkpoints on Israel's borders -- is still repeated by his detractors with contempt.
But the reality of what is likely to transpire falls somewhere between Mr. Barak's and Mr. Peres's visions.
No matter what Mr. Barak says, the fact is that the Palestinians and the Israelis are not "here" and "there," not with settlements dotting the West Bank and a large Palestinian population living in Jerusalem.
In the immediate future, there is no real way to dissociate the two, not when Israel mans the borders, collects the taxes, employs 100,000 Palestinian laborers and depends economically on Palestinian consumers. And there will have to be cooperation if not collaboration -- on security, on the millennial tourism business, and so on.
MR. BARAK may be calling greater attention to building fences than bridges, but his new Industry and Trade Minister, Ran Cohen, said he plans to build industry zones "in a massive way" on the borders between Israel and the Palestinian territories and perhaps between Israel and Jordan.
"What is peace without economic agreements?" Mr. Cohen said in an interview. "Prime Minister Barak may not be highlighting it, but it is self-evident that this lies in our future."
On a grass-roots level, too, there are scores of local people-to-people projects that suddenly feel very free to flourish, from collaborations between Israeli and Palestinian firefighters, birdwatchers and tour guides to recent Internet chat sessions between Israeli and Lebanese teen-agers discussing the bombardment of Lebanon.
On the ground, then, the hard-nosed vision may be softened by those infected with the more idealistic view of peace, or with what Mr. Rabin referred to as the profit motive. "No one will come here because of our winning smiles," he said at an economic summit in Amman. "They all want to make money."
Down the line, even in Kosovo, the aspirations of peace with harmony may come back to life.
Partition plans and segregation are the crisis solution, but if Slobodan Milosevic were to be toppled someday, if a more democratic Serbia evolved, and if livelihoods could be restored, perhaps there could be a power-sharing arrangement with Albanian Kosovo.
Not far away, the European Union sits as a practical model of the power of commerce to reconcile old enemies; the message, however muted today, is not entirely lost on the Balkans.
Advocates of a grand peace may be out of fashion but they are not extinct.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 521 words

HEADLINE: Go Slow on Tax Cuts

 BODY:
Cutting taxes always sounds good in Washington, and it may be inevitable that Congress will pass a tax cut before next year's election. But if that is to happen, the grandiose cutting plans proposed by the chairmen of the Congressional tax-writing committees need to be scaled back substantially.
Economically, this is an inappropriate time for any tax decrease. With the economy booming and the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in an effort to slow growth and prevent inflation, a fiscal stimulus package would have the opposite effect, and could persuade the Federal Reserve that it will need to raise interest rates more than would otherwise be necessary. 
 But the most important defect of the plans by Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Senator William Roth, the chairman of the Finance Committee, lies in their sheer scope. Rather than simply pass a tax cut that would take effect in the next year or two, both Republican bills call for major cuts to be made well into the next decade. The Archer bill even has cuts to take effect in 2009, three Presidential elections from now.
Mr. Archer's bill, as passed by his committee on a party-line vote, is expected to cut Government revenue by $864 billion over the next 10 years, and by much more in years after that as some major provisions -- including a repeal of all estate taxes, even for billionaires -- are phased in. The Roth bill calls for cuts of $792 billion over the 10 years. A more moderate plan from Senate Democrats led by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan proposes cuts of $295 billion, still more than the $250 billion President Clinton has suggested.
The Republican proposals are based on estimates that the Government will otherwise run huge surpluses in coming years. But those estimates are inherently questionable, and the surpluses could vanish if the economy were to weaken. In addition, the surplus figures are based on the assumption that spending will be held down in accord with previous budget compromises, even though it appears likely that this Congress will be unable to abide by the harsh spending cuts required to meet those targets. Congress should first pass its spending bills and only then turn to the issue of taxes.
If there are to be tax cuts, they should be targeted at middle- and lower-income taxpayers. While some adjustments to estate taxes may be in order, Mr. Archer's plan to eliminate the tax is a giveaway to the wealthy that would severely damage the Government's finances after it took effect in 2009. Similarly, there is no reason to further cut capital gains taxes, as Mr. Archer proposes.
Any bill that is passed should target the abusive tax shelters used by some companies to avoid paying taxes. The Republicans say they are still studying Clinton Administration proposals.
Most important, a tax cut bill should not have provisions that would decimate Government revenues 5 or 10 years from now. If the present optimistic economic forecasts prove to be accurate, there will be more than enough time for a future Congress to consider those reductions.

Housing Grant

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
White Plains will receive a grant from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for emergency repairs to houses owned by the elderly.
The city will receive $25,150 through the Restore Program, created to pay for emergency repairs and eliminate unsafe conditions. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, the county's Republican leader, said that many elderly residents cannot afford to make repairs to the houses they have occupied for many years. 
 Through partnerships with counties, towns, cities, villages, private developers and nonprofit corporations, the state helps finance acquisition, construction and rehabilitation of affordable housing and provides assistance to low-income home buyers and renters. On a state level, the money for White Plains is administered by the New York Housing Trust Fund Corporation. The city's Community Development Agency then processes the money. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: Old Thinking atthe Fed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Despite the Fears, Inflation Still Refuses to Materialize," (Economic View, June 20) skillfully explained the evidence that there are virtually no indications of actual or incipient inflation in our economy today -- and little reason for the Federal Reserve to want to make restrictive moves in monetary policy. Indeed, the Producer Price Index for June, reported on Wednesday, actually declined. 
 What remains a mystery is the basis for the Fed's compulsion to raise rates last month, even though its chairman, Alan Greenspan, had been acknowledging that we are in the midst of an extraordinary technology boom that is lowering costs and expanding productive capacity at rates never seen before.
The answer, I believe, is that the Fed has no economic model to fit the present environment of technology-driven growth. The Fed, unable to discard its obsolete thinking about economic expansion, remains dependent on historical economic data that no longer apply to our economy.
The Fed, for example, has dwelled on the fact that labor markets are too tight, while the reality is that scarce labor is a strong incentive for companies to innovate rapidly and invest in new technology. The inflation fears seem to be unaffected by the tight rein on aggregate demand imposed by a large and growing Federal budget surplus. The Fed also seems oblivious to the fact that stock market gains tend to be self-limiting and cannot fuel increased consumer spending for very long.
Worst of all, the Fed shows no signs of recognizing that its worries about inflation for several years now have been terribly wrong. The country is entitled to more accountability than it is now getting from the Fed.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., July 14
 
The writer, an economist, is a retired assistant vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Unemployment in the State Rose a Bit in June

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
The number of jobs available in New Jersey increased in June, but the unemployment rate also rose slightly to 4.9 percent from 4.7 percent in May, according to the state Department of Labor.
The unemployment rate has remained below 5 percent for the past 20 months as the number of jobs continues to grow, said Kevin Smith, labor department spokesman. The unemployment rate remains above the national average, which has been between 4.3 percent and 4.5 percent for the past eight months. 
 The number of jobs grew by 1,600 last month, Mr. Smith said. Private, service-sector jobs and retail trade employment grew the most in June, offsetting job losses in manufacturing and government. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: DATABANK: July 12-July 16;
A Happy Return to Technology Stocks

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Investors hovered around technology companies like bees near honey, lifting the Nasdaq to three consecutive highs. For the week, the technology-heavy index climbed 2.5 percent. For the year, it is up 30 percent.
"This has been a technology rally, and I think that's good for the overall market," Barry Hyman, an analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum told Reuters. "The technology sector has been and will remain the leading sector." 
 Otherwise, it was a ho-hum week on Wall Street. Companies reporting earnings revealed few surprises. And economic data that showed tame inflation numbers came and went relatively unnoticed. "If someone told me on Monday that the inflation figures would be just great, I would have thought that the whole market would really go up," Ralph Bloch, chief market analyst at Raymond James & Associates, told The Associated Press. "But that didn't happen because there's always something out there that can hold this market back."
 That something may have been the tension mounting between Taiwan and China, which sent Asian markets into a tailspin on Friday. Investors also waited for earnings reports this week from companies like I.B.M., Microsoft and General Motors. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: Mayor Improves Image of Birmingham but Not Racial Split

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 14

 BODY:
For the last 20 years, each time he walked into the City Hall he transformed, Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. has passed by the name T. Eugene Connor carved into the building's cornerstone.
It is just a name now, one of a list of dead men who voted to erect the building, and most people do not even notice it. Even if it had included Mr. Connor's better-known nickname, Bull, the carving would still seem as out of place among Birmingham's new skyscrapers and polished corporate headquarters as a hieroglyph telling an ancient story of conflict. 
 That sense of distance between the snarling dogs of Bull Connor, the former Police Commissioner who became the symbol of intolerance in the days of the civil rights movement, and the placid, prosperous Birmingham of today is due in significant part to two decades of quiet work by Mr. Arrington, who will retire on Monday at age 64.
When Mr. Arrington took office in 1979 as the city's first black Mayor, Birmingham was still struggling to shed its national reputation as "Bombingham," the city where racial divisions became explosive in the 1960's and where any police shooting threatened to turn into a confrontation. One of Mr. Arrington's first efforts was to integrate and tame the Police Department, and the effect was immediate.
Dr. Bernard Kincaid, a black member of the City Council who is usually one of Mr. Arrington's sharpest critics, said: "At the time he became Mayor, if you were an African-American who was stopped by the police, you didn't know if you were going to be shot and a gun dropped beside you. Arrington stopped that dead in its tracks. The outright fear, that shook you down to your boots, is gone."
The city's economy, crumbling in 1979 after Birmingham's giant steel plants began to close, has been renewed by a carefully managed shift toward health care, biotechnology and banking.
The unemployment rate, which soared above 20 percent during the recession of the early 1980's, is now 4.3 percent, and new businesses continue to move into 80 square miles of largely vacant land Mr. Arrington annexed for the city's growth. Many of those businesses are taking advantage of substantial tax incentives that he has offered in consultation with a tight circle of local executives.
But for all that he has accomplished in the region, the Mayor remains a divisive figure in Birmingham. The son of sharecroppers, a former zoology professor whose political savvy cannot conceal a quiet, scholarly core, Mr. Arrington was never as forceful or well known as the other "first black mayors" who dominated their cities for 20 years, figures like Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, Coleman Young of Detroit and Richard Hatcher of Gary, Ind. Yet, like so many other black mayors, Mr. Arrington never attracted more than a small fraction of the white vote in his five terms, or established lasting biracial coalitions with other politicians or white suburbs.
Tens of thousands of white residents moved to the suburbs during his tenure, leaving the city with a 70 percent black majority and shrinking the population by 11 percent, to 252,997 last year from 284,413 in 1980.
An undercurrent of racial tension continues to define the region's politics, even at the smallest level. Last week, after the Arrington allies who control the City Council voted to rename a major street in his honor, white members of the County Commission grumbled that the new name would require merchants on the street to get new stationery.
"It has been good for Birmingham's image to have someone like Arrington, who is obviously smart and thoughtful, and provided steady leadership," said Robert J. Norrell, a historian of the civil rights movement at the University of Tennessee who lived in Birmingham for many years and worked for Mr. Arrington's first mayoral campaign. "But since the 1950's, Birmingham has been deeply and angrily divided over race, and he hasn't been able to overcome that. Of course, it's hard to imagine anyone who could."
Sitting in his office this week while aides scooped hundreds of honorary plaques off the walls and into packing boxes, Mr. Arrington was unapologetic about the exclusively black nature of his political organization, the Jefferson County Citizens Coalition, which became the main vehicle for black enfranchisement in Birmingham, often at the expense of biracial unity.
"Well, we never said whites couldn't come, but it was a black organization and we'd like to keep that in place," the Mayor said. "Political power was something blacks didn't have in this town until the 1980's, so we said, 'Let's organize, let's bloc-vote, let's mobilize.' Now people say we've got a political machine, and they resent it. But that's a copout. You can't blame everything wrong in Birmingham on Bull Connor and Richard Arrington."
Though it may have proved annoying to many white residents, his effective marshaling of black political power in a state long famous for its absence has made him an iconic figure to his supporters.
"From the first time I met him, I was in awe of him," said Norman B. Davis Jr., a black investment banker in Birmingham who recently was appointed Alabama's superintendent of banks. "This was a man with incredible vision, who knew what he had to do to keep the city strong despite white flight and the death of the steel industry. To many blacks, he'll always be a hero, but unfortunately, a lot of whites never gave him a chance."
Many white voters and elected officials were put off by what they saw as cronyism in the awarding of contracts and the hiring of key personnel, a sense that was only enhanced when the Federal Government began looking into those issues in a series of investigations in the 1980's and 90's. Mr. Arrington always said the inquiries were racially motivated, and in 1992 he spent a day in jail rather than turn over documents to the United States Attorney.
Two former allies were found guilty of fraud in connection with the construction of the Civil Rights Institute, a museum of the struggle for equality that is now a popular tourist attraction. Mr. Arrington was named an unindicted co-conspirator in a kickback scheme, but the Justice Department later withdrew that designation.
"He has taken care of his friends, but the only white people he cares about are the corporate leaders," said Craig Sanderson, who is white and the president of the Crestwood Community Association, which represents a mostly white neighborhood on the east side. "I think there are some good things that he did, but I wish he hadn't played the race card so often."
The city's physical face is also showing signs of wear in some places. Many roads, school buildings and low-income neighborhoods seem forgotten. Birmingham's symbol, a 56-foot iron statue of Vulcan that lunges over the city from Red Mountain, has deteriorated so badly that the council voted last week to spend $1 million to take it down before it falls. Private donors plan to raise an estimated $10 million to repair and restore it.
Mr. Arrington acknowledges that the most serious criticism from his opponents -- that he has neglected the school system -- is legitimate. Birmingham's schools now rank 109th out of the state's 128 school districts in achievement test scores, according to a recent study by The Birmingham News.
The ranking actually represents a recent improvement. The Mayor does not have direct control over the school system. But the City Council, which Mr. Arrington controls, appoints the school board.
"What I regret most of all is, I didn't know the schools were in quite as bad a shape as they were," said Mr. Arrington, who has eight children, most of whom attended public schools. "I just did not deal much with the schools, because I had a zillion other problems to deal with. I felt I had less authority and clout there than I did in other areas."
He is stepping down now, he said, because he has done all he can do and believes the city needs new leadership. But even his method of departure has caused a stir. Because he is leaving three months before his term is up, his close ally William Bell, the City Council president, will become interim Mayor and have a leg up in his campaign to succeed Mr. Arrington in the Oct. 12 election. Other candidates, including Councilman Kincaid, have complained that the move is a high-handed attempt to preserve the Mayor's dynasty.
"He cannot anoint his own successor," Mr. Kincaid said.
But unless the black vote begins to splinter badly, most of Mr. Arrington's successors are likely to be black, thanks to an assertion of power by the once-powerless that seemed unimaginable before he took office. Mr. Arrington is explicit in hoping that his successors will use the political tools he provided to create an eventual racial reconciliation that he could not achieve.
"When I was first elected, a lot of people expected this town to go to pot, and I think we surprised them," he said. "That's going to continue. And the next mayor won't have to fight a lot of the battles that I fought."

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns Against G.O.P.'s Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Stepping up his attack on Republican tax-cutting proposals, President Clinton said today that the cost of the tax bill moving through the House would rise to unimaginable levels and threaten the nation's ability to deal with its most pressing long-term problems.
Citing a new estimate by the Treasury Department that the cost of the House tax bill would "explode" from $864 billion over the first decade to $3 trillion in the 10-year period starting in 2010, Mr. Clinton said the country could not afford to allocate anywhere near that much money to tax cuts without first shoring up Social Security and Medicare. 
 Instead, Mr. Clinton said, Congress and the Administration should focus first on shoring up Social Security and Medicare, both of which will come under severe financial strain in the next few decades as the baby boom generation retires and life expectancies increase.
The Republican plan would also crimp the Government's ability to use projected Federal budget surpluses to pay down the national debt, and could eventually send the country back into a spiral of budget deficits and rising debt reminiscent of the 1980's, Mr. Clinton said.
"At the very time the nation will be confronting the demographic challenge of the baby boom," Mr. Clinton said in his weekly radio address, "the Republican plan will blow a $3 trillion hole in the Federal budget, threatening our ability to secure Social Security and Medicare for the next generation and risking return to the era of deficits with high interest rates and economic stagnation."
Tax cuts of the size contemplated by the Republicans, Mr. Clinton said in his national radio address, "quite simply are bad economic policy."
Republicans defended their plan as prudent, and said Mr. Clinton was straining to come up with a justification for why Washington should not return to taxpayers the growing pile of excess Federal revenue.
Democrats predicted dire consequences for the economy each time taxes have been cut in the last few decades, most recently in 1997, Republicans said. But each time, they said, the economy has been strengthened, propelling the United States to new levels of prosperity.
In the Republican response to Mr. Clinton's radio address, Gov. Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin said the Republicans are "drawing a clear line in the sand" with plans for a big tax cut.
"The issue of tax cuts highlights the differences between the parties," he said. "The Democrats, they see surplus dollars and they always look for ways to spend them on new programs; while Republicans see surplus dollars and they look at ways to cut your taxes."
The $864 billion plan, authored by Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, uses virtually all the surplus over the next decade except for the portion that goes to Social Security. It was approved by the committee along party lines on Wednesday, and is scheduled to go to the full House later this month. The Senate Finance Committee will take up a $792 billion 10-year tax cut on Tuesday.
Although Mr. Clinton has threatened to veto both bills or any blended version of them, he has signaled his willingness to negotiate a compromise.
Neither side, however, is quite ready to strike a deal. Republicans are intent on passing their bills, even in the face of a veto threat, to draw a clear distinction about their differences with Mr. Clinton and his party as the 2000 election approaches.
For his part, Mr. Clinton is happy to wait a few months, because White House officials believe Republicans are stumbling into a budget trap of their own making that will weaken their negotiating position.
Administration officials said Republicans will be unable to pass all the necessary appropriations bills this year without violating strict spending caps that both parties have pledged to honor.
Only after the Republicans' budget bind becomes clear, probably around or just after the end of the Government's fiscal year on Sept. 30, is Mr. Clinton likely to judge the time right for serious talks on tax and spending issues, Democrats said.
In the meantime, both parties are and testing out new arguments to keep the pressure on the other side.
Congress limits its long-term tax and spending projections to 10 years, judging that to be the longest horizon over which economists and budget analysts can make halfway credible estimates.
Concern about the long-term cost of the current House Republican proposal has been particularly acute among Democrats because of the way the plan works. Rather than putting the entire package of tax cuts into effect immediately, the plan phases them in gradually over the next 10 years to match the expected growth of the budget surplus.
As a result, it is not until the cuts are are fully phased in 2009 that their full cost in foregone revenues is realized. For the House plan, the cuts start out at $4.6 billion next year and reach $203.4 billion in 2009.
While clearly somewhat speculative if not outright guesswork, the Treasury study cited by Mr. Clinton today tries to project the costs starting in 2009, and to look in particular at some of the provisions whose costs could be expected to continue increasing at the fastest pace.
Among them is the proposed repeal of the inheritance tax on large estates. The lost revenue would be just $3 million next year, growing to $15.2 billion by 2009, according to Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation, for a total of $75.3 billion over the first decade.
But according to the Treasury estimates, the cost in 2009 would be considerably higher, $46 billion, and would grow to an average of $57 billion a year for the following decade, benefiting just a tiny handful of wealthy taxpayers and their heirs, said Gene Sperling, the White House economic adviser.
The central feature of the House tax plan, its 10 percent reduction in all income tax rates, would likewise show a steep cost increase, Mr. Sperling said, growing from just over $400 billion in the first decade to $1.5 trillion in the second 10 years.
"The reason why this is such a threat to our long-term fiscal health and our ability to preserve Medicare and Social Security is that this is exactly the period -- between 2010 and 2020 -- when Medicare becomes insolvent, when Social Security first comes under strain, and when we first see the challenges of the baby-boom retirement," Mr. Sperling said.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Tax-Cutting Proposals in Congress"
Congress is considering two Republican tax-cutting bills. In the House, the Ways and Means Committee approved legislation last week cutting taxes by $864 billion over the next 10 years. On Tuesday, the Senate Finance Committee will take up a proposal that would cut taxes by as much as $792 billion over that period. President Clinton has promised to veto anything along the lines of either proposal.
Although they are similar in scale, the two bills take very different approaches to reducing taxes for individuals and companies. The following is a description of their main provisions.
 
Personal Income Taxes
 
HOUSE
Would reduce income tax rates by a total of 10 percent in four steps over 10 years.
Current tax bracket -- 15.0%
...in 2001 would become -- 14.7%
...and by 2009 would become -- 13.5%
 
Current tax bracket -- 28.0%
...in 2001 would become -- 27.3%
...and by 2009 would become -- 25.2%
 
Current tax bracket -- 39.6%
...in 2001 would become -- 38.7%
...and by 2009 would become -- 35.7%
COST -- $405 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would reduce the 15 percent income tax rate -- the lowest of the five brackets -- to 14 percent, starting in 2001. Would also expand the 14 percent bracket so that fewer taxpayers must pay the next-highest rate of 28 percent.
Cost -- $297.5 billion over 10 years.
 
Married Couples
 
HOUSE
Would reduce the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that leaves many couples paying more in combined taxes than they would individually if single. The main provision would gradually increase the standard deduction for a couple filing jointly to twice the level of the standard deduction for a single filer (this year the deduction for married couples is $7,200 while the deduction for single people is $4,300).
COST -- $44.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would eliminate the marriage penalty. Married couples filing joint returns would have the option of filing single returns on a combined tax form, enabling them to take the standard deduction for single people rather than the standard deduction for joint filers, which is less than twice as big. But they would both have to take the standard deduction or itemize, and the change would not take effect until 2005.
COST -- $117.7 billion over 10 years.
 
Minimum Tax
 
HOUSE
Would gradually repeal the individual minimum tax, which was created to insure that wealthy people paid a fair share of income tax even if they were able to take advantage of deductions and other breaks, but which has increasingly applied to middle income taxpayers.
COST -- $81.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would limit the effects of the alternative minimum tax by allowing personal exemptions to be included in determining tax liability.
COST -- $96.1 billion over 10 years.
 
Savings and Investment
 
HOUSE
Would gradually repeal the individual minimum tax, which was created to insure that wealthy people paid a fair share of income tax even if they were able to take advantage of deductions and other breaks, but which has increasingly applied to middle income taxpayers.
COST -- $81.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would limit the effects of the alternative minimum tax by allowing personal exemptions to be included in determining tax liability.
COST -- $96.1 billion over 10 years.
 
Pensions
 
HOUSE
Would change a wide variety of technical rules to allow more generous pensions, and would gradually increase the maximum annual contribution to 401(k) programs, to $15,000 from $10,000.
COST -- $14.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
In addition to changes in rules for retirement accounts and 401(k) programs, would modify many technical pension rules to allow more generous pensions.
COST -- Included in savings and investment provisions listed above.
 
Education
 
HOUSE
Would increase the annual contribution on education IRA's to $2,000 from $500. Would allow the accounts to be used to pay for private elementary and secondary school expenses as well as college.
COST -- $3.6 billion over 10 years.
 
Would provide tax breaks for bonds issued to finance public school construction.
COST -- $2.5 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would increase the deductibility of interest on student loans by lifting a five-year limit on deductibility and increasing the income level that determines eligibility for the deduction. Would make permanent a tax break for employer provided tuition assistance and expand the program to graduate level courses.
COST -- $12.2 billion over 10 years.
 
Health Care
 
HOUSE
Would create a deduction for health insurance expenses for which the taxpayer pays at least half of the premium.
COST -- $34.2 billion over 10 years.
 
Would create a deduction for long-term care insurance expenses for which the taxpayer pays at least half the premium.
COST -- $8 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would create a deduction for health insurance expenses for which the taxpayer pays at least half of the premium.
 
Would create a deduction for long-term care insurance expenses for which the taxpayer pays at least half the premium.
Would create an additional deduction for caretakers of elderly family members.
COST -- $52.2 billion over 10 years.
 
Inheritance Tax
 
HOUSE
Would phase out the estate and gift tax, which is currently levied on estates and gifts valued at $650,000 or more.
COST -- $75.3 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would reduce the estate and gift tax. Would reduce the top rate to 50 percent from 55 percent and 53 percent. Would change the unified credit that excludes most estates from taxation to an exemption. Would increase the exemption to $1.5 million from $1 million starting in 2007.
COST -- $63.1 billion over 10 years.
 
Business Taxes
 
HOUSE
Would gradually reduce the capital gains rate paid by corporations to 25 percent from 35 percent.
COST -- $15 billion over 10 years.
 
Would allow multinational corporations to deduct more of their interest expenses.
COST -- $24.8 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would allow multinational corporations to deduct more of their interest expenses.
COST -- $14.8 billion over 10 years.
 
Miscellaneous
 
HOUSE
Would provide a variety of breaks to special interests, from makers of fishing tackle boxes to insurance companies and owners of nuclear power plants.
COST -- $6.2 billion over 10 years.
 
SENATE
Would provide breaks for a variety of special interests, from railroads to makers of broadhead hunting arrows.
COST -- $5.6 billion over 10 years.

HEADLINE: Aspen Journal;
Footing Security Bill for President Upsets a Big-Money Town

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo., July 17

 BODY:
 This is a town of good and plenty, where a majority of the population can be divided roughly between the haves and the have mores.
While ski slopes in winter and cultural events in summer have made Aspen one of America's vacation meccas, it is now an impressive symbol of the nation's economic boom: for almost 60 percent of those who pay real estate taxes in Pitkin County, where Aspen is the county seat, their residences here are second homes. 
 And what second homes. Small Victorians near downtown sell for as much as $3 million; lavish houses hugging the surrounding mountainsides go for much more. But not all of Aspen's 5,600 year-round residents are always so thankful that they live and work in wonderland. A fair number of them are upset that the town government is absorbing the costs of a major Democratic Party event next weekend that will include a visit by President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
The event is largely planned as a thank-you from the Democratic National Committee to some of its biggest campaign donors, 100 or so people who have given $50,000 each or helped raise $100,000. The weekend also includes a fund-raising picnic at the (second) home of Senator Dianne Feinstein of California.
Last summer, when the Democrats staged the first such weekend event here, Mr. Clinton's visit helped them raise about $1 million. This year, they expect to raise even more.
With all that money around, many Aspenites, including Sheriff Bob Braudis, cannot understand why local taxpayers have to pay for all the added security needed for a Presidential visit. Last year, Sheriff Braudis said, the event cost the town $89,000 for things like food, housing and even radio batteries for 300 officers from neighboring law-enforcement agencies who volunteered to help out.
"They were like flood victims," Sheriff Braudis said. "We housed them and fed them at the high school and gave them cots to sleep on. The janitor had turned off the boiler for the summer, so they all had to take cold showers, then wake up to pancakes for breakfast."
And it was not as if the volunteers got the glamorous jobs, he added.
"The Secret Service cleared the bridges, looking for any bombs," the sheriff said. "But then we had to guard the bridges 24 hours to make sure no one planted any. When Clinton went to sleep, so did the Secret Service."
While Presidential trips are fairly routine in their security requirements and the demands they place on the local venue, Aspenites assert that someone else -- the Secret Service, the White House, the Democratic Party -- should pay for what is essentially a political event.
The Aspen Daily News recently asked readers in its "Tipline," "Who should pay for Clinton's visit?" The paper reported on June 27 that "not one person believes that the local taxpayers should pick up the tab."
A collection of reader responses was printed under the headline "Tipliners to Clinton: 'Pay up, or stay out.' "
Mayor Rachel Richards, who prevailed in a four-way nonpartisan election last month, said she was thrilled to have the big-money Democrats in town. Ms. Richards played down any inconvenience they might be to the town or this year's $22.7 million budget, pointing out: "Aspen is a community that likes to have controversy before breakfast every morning. They need something like this."
Sheriff Braudis said he had appealed to the Democratic National Committee for a gesture of good will in the form of a donation to local charities to match the city's costs. His reasoning went this way: "If I have to pay $20,000 for this out of my budget, that's $20,000 I don't have for other programs."
So far, he said, the Democrats have not responded to his plea. But Jenny Backus, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said, "The D.N.C. has not received any such request, and if we did, we would refer it automatically to the Secret Service."
At the very least, Sheriff Braudis said the local authorities now had a clearer idea of what help they must provide next week, based on experience. Last year, the sheriff said, he told Joe DiSalvo, the department's director of investigations and security coordinator for the event, to do whatever the Secret Service and the White House requested.
"We gave them the world," Mr. DiSalvo said, and that even included officers patrolling on horseback. But this time, Mr. DiSalvo told the Secret Service that the number of officers would be pared down to 175. And if the President's protectors wanted horseback patrols, they had better bring their own horses.

HEADLINE: Key Opposition Leader Joins Rally Asking Milosevic to Resign

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: KRAGUJEVAC, Serbia, July 17

 BODY:
A leading opposition politician, Vuk Draskovic, appeared today for the first time at a rally calling for the resignation of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the formation of a transitional government leading to new elections.
Mr. Draskovic urged a festive crowd of about 20,000 people not to seek revenge or pursue a violent path that could lead to "civil war." While he spoke of the need for Serbs "to discuss and accept the shame for what was done in Kosovo," he also criticized NATO for allowing the Albanians after its air campaign to force Serbs from the province and asked, "Why does someone not threaten the Albanians with bombing?" 
 By attracting a crowd twice as large as his rivals did on Thursday here, some 80 miles south of Belgrade, Mr. Draskovic attempted to assert leadership over the democratic opposition to Mr. Milosevic and his Government.
But the crowd, although enthusiastic enough, fell short of party hopes for 30,000 to 50,000 people, and Mr. Draskovic delivered a passionate but wandering address. He gave his supporters little more direction than to keep demonstrating, in the hope that Mr. Milosevic will somehow agree to resign and call early elections.
Senior Draskovic aides said, however, that they had little hope that rallies alone, without evidence of serious cracks in Mr. Milosevic's police and armed forces, would bring any quick change in Belgrade.
Mr. Draskovic, who had been a part of Mr. Milosevic's Government for most of the war over Kosovo, had resisted the idea of street demonstrations until 10 days ago. But his rivals among the opposition, gathered as the Alliance for Change, were collecting thousands of ordinary Serbs in towns outside Belgrade for their own rallies calling for Mr. Milosevic to resign after the disastrous war with NATO.
Mr. Draskovic was also urged by a senior American diplomat, Robert S. Gelbard, in a recent meeting outside Serbia, to join his rivals in a common platform, to enhance the chances for a more unified opposition to Mr. Milosevic, who retains a strong grip over most national news media.
Mr. Draskovic is a bitter rival of Zoran Djindjic, the president of the Democratic Party and a leader of the Alliance. While the two men led the large anti-Milosevic street demonstrations of the winter of 1996-97, which forced Mr. Milosevic to recognize opposition victories in local elections, the two men quickly parted amid mutual charges of egotism and hypocrisy.
That rivalry worsened when Mr. Draskovic entered the Milosevic Government in January and Mr. Djindjic then fled to Montenegro during the bombing, saying his life was at risk from the police. Even today, Mr. Draskovic criticized party leaders "who left the country to hide or refused a call-up notice" to fight during the war, as Mr. Djindjic also did, saying that the draft was a form of harassment from Belgrade.
Some senior Draskovic aides admitted that this rally in Kragujevac, which is controlled by Mr. Draskovic's party and where he began his failed bid for the Serbian presidency in 1997, was as much aimed at asserting priority over Mr. Djindjic as hastening Mr. Milosevic's departure.
Mr. Draskovic has called for another rally next Saturday in Nis to try to increase the pressure on Mr. Milosevic. But he has criticized Mr. Djindjic's call for large marches on Belgrade from Serbian cities as both risky and likely to fail, and his aides are quietly pushing the Democratic Party to replace Mr. Djindjic as president, possibly with Zoran Zivkovic, the popular Mayor of Nis.
On Thursday here, other Alliance leaders called on Mr. Draskovic to join them, with his Serbian Renewal Party leading the Alliance.
But Mr. Draskovic said today that his party "will resist pressure to join anyone," and said that all parties should compete on their own in any new elections. But pressed by the Americans, he has allowed other opposition parties to have more access to Studio B, the Belgrade television station his party runs, and he has provided a radio frequency for the independent journalists of B92, a station taken over during the war by Milosevic allies.
The split between the parties of Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Djindjic, so visible in Belgrade, did not disrupt the ruling coalition here, said Vesna Pajevic, who is the deputy director of the city's executive and a member of Mr. Draskovic's party.
In an interview today, she criticized Mr. Draskovic for paying too little attention to the regions and their problems and too much attention to his personal position. She said, "We need unity and a concrete program to tell people exactly what you will do for them if they vote for you -- what you will do for the 60,000 unemployed here in Kragujevac," whose biggest employer, the car factory Zastava, was destroyed by NATO bombs.
On this question, Mr. Draskovic was silent today, although state television on Friday night led with a Government plan to employ 20,000 Zastava workers immediately and start making 50,000 cars a year again "soon." However fantastic the report, said Mrs. Pajevic's husband, Velimir, "it will give people hope and buy Milosevic more time."
Mrs. Pajevic said she urged Mr. Draskovic today in a meeting to worry less about winning over supporters of Mr. Milosevic and to seize the moment when the Government appears at its weakest.
But she admitted that the system the President created had deprived Serbs of self-confidence and made them unwilling to risk "what little they have."
Mr. Pajevic, a pediatric surgeon, said sadly: "There can be hundreds of meetings like this, but there is not a critical mass. People come and get it off their chests, and then they go home more quietly."
He laughed sourly. "Serbia has 178 parties and every party leader is an egomaniac," he said. "We have been very unlucky in both our Government and our opposition."

Killings in Kosovo Put at 10,000
At least 10,000 people were killed by Serbian forces during their three-month campaign to drive the Albanians from Kosovo, according to war crimes investigators, NATO peacekeeping troops and humanitarian agencies struggling to keep up with fresh reports each day of newly discovered bodies and graves. 1

The announcement comes the day after reports that Defense Secretary William S. HEADLINE: Long Island Congressman Quits G.O.P., Citing 'Extremists'

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: QUOGUE, N.Y., July 17

 BODY:
Representative Michael P. Forbes, a mercurial Republican who has frequently butted heads with House Republican leaders, announced today that he was becoming a Democrat because his own party had been captured by "extremists."
He accused the Republican leadership of being "tone deaf" to the concerns of average Americans on issues from health care to education to the environment. 
 Sweating profusely in the blistering sunshine during a news conference outside his gray-shingled home on Long Island, Mr. Forbes repeatedly slammed his former party's leadership with the kind of harsh oratory that Democrats once used against him.
"With no Communist menace to rail against, and with an American economy that is the strongest to be sustained in our lifetime, the national Republican Party over the last four and a half years has allowed itself to become defined through the actions of extremists in the House of Representatives," said Mr. Forbes, who is in his third term.
"It's become angry, narrow-minded, intolerant, uncaring, incapable of governing at all, much less from the center."
Democratic officials said Mr. Forbes, 47, is the first Congressional Republican to switch to the Democratic Party in nearly a quarter-century -- a period in which they said at least 10 Democrats in Congress flipped to the Republican side.
Mr. Forbes, who once did the unthinkable by voting against Newt Gingrich when Mr. Gingrich was running for re-election as Speaker of the House in 1997, has for years been an outcast in the Republican Party, and his defection is not expected to draw other centrist Republicans into the Democratic fold.
But the move still seems like an important psychological victory for the Democrats as they seek to capture the House next year. Before the defection, the Republicans had 223 House members and the Democrats had 210. With Mr. Forbes's defection, the Democrats now need to win just five additional seats to be in the majority.
"I really think you are seeing a party in a real state of difficulty," Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, said of the Republicans. "You may be seeing a realignment taking place."
House Republicans played down the significance of the move, suggesting that Mr. Forbes was a political loner who could be less than stable in Congress.
"Michael's decision to leave the resurgent Republican Party for the minority party is, like many of his past actions, inconsistent and erratic," said Representative Thomas M. Davis 3d of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. "Last year, he voted to impeach Democrat Bill Clinton. Last month he endorsed George W. Bush for President and today, he chooses to side with the party of higher taxes and bigger government."
Mr. Davis said the Republicans would do "everything we can" to unseat Mr. Forbes next year. Among the names of challengers being circulated in Republican circles are the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney; New York Assemblyman Fred W. Thiele Jr. and State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle.
Mr. Forbes, who won re-election last year with 64 percent of the vote, said he expected to be the target of Republican retribution not just in next year's election but also in the house, where the Republican leadership is likely to block his bills and strip him of his seat on the powerful House Appropriations Committee.
But Mr. Gephardt said he would ask Democrats on the Appropriations Committee, which allocates Federal funds, to step aside so that Mr. Forbes can retain his seat. He also vowed to do "everything I can" to get Mr. Forbes re-elected, though he said he could not promise that there would not be a primary.
At least one Democrat, Tony Bullock, chief of staff to New York's senior Democratic Senator, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, has said that he might challenge Mr. Forbes in the primary. But Democratic officials said today that an effort was already under way by party officials to urge Mr. Bullock to back off.
Mr. Forbes has told Democratic officials that he has not yet decided whether to retract his endorsement of Governor Bush of Texas, who is the Republican front-runner in the polls. In his news conference today, the Congressman was careful not to attack Mr. Bush directly.
Vice President Al Gore, who is seeking the Democratic nomination to replace Mr. Clinton, issued a statement today praising Mr. Forbes as a man of "principle and integrity."
In a sign of the symbolic importance of the defection, leaders in both parties waged a tug-of-war for his heart and mind in recent days.
Since Thursday, when the rumors began spreading in Washington that Mr. Forbes might defect, Mr. Davis, Alfonse M. D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki have called Mr. Forbes and asked him to reconsider, Democratic officials said.
Mr. Forbes first began toying with the idea of switching parties in early June at a dinner with two Democratic Representatives from New York, Eliot L. Engel of the Bronx and Gary L. Ackerman of Queens, said John Calvelli, Mr. Engel's chief of staff. The next week, Mr. Forbes discussed the idea with Mr. Gephardt, then on July 2 with President Clinton at the White House. Mr. Forbes said neither man made him any promises.
Mr. Forbes was elected in the Republican tide of 1994 that gave the party control of Congress. But he soured on the party after the Government shutdown in 1995 and after repeated efforts by conservatives to gut Federal environmental rules.
After he voted against Mr. Gingrich in 1997, he became a pariah in the party. But his stock seemed to rise last year when Mr. Gingrich quit Congress and Mr. Forbes's close friend, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, was expected to become Speaker. Indeed, many Democrats say they Mr. Forbes voted for impeachment largely to please Mr. Livingston.
But Mr. Livingston also quit Congress when it was revealed that he had had an extramarital affair, and Mr. Forbes's fortunes fell once again.
Mr. Forbes is not easy to peg ideologically, and he will be somewhat to the right of House Democrats. He supports Democratic initiatives to expand Federal spending on day care, to protect the environment, to revamp campaign finance laws and to regulate health maintenance organizations. But he also opposes abortion and often votes against gun control.
In an indication of the balancing act Mr. Forbes may now be forced into, he was sharply questioned today at his news conference by an abortion rights advocate, an environmental advocate and a local Republican leader.
He said changing parties would not cause him to change his positions on major issues.
"My voting record is one I'm very proud of," he said.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
It's Taking Care Of Political Business

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Retail politics.
That's the first thing New Hampshirites mention when they argue that their state, more than any other, deserves the right to hold the nation's first Presidential primary. And the same is true of Iowans when they contend that their state should always hold the first Presidential caucuses. 
 By "retail," these proud New Englanders and Midwesterners mean old-fashion politicking in which candidates get down on the ground and meet and greet voters personally in their homes, in coffee shops and at small rallies. The impersonal "air game" of flashy television advertising that dominates campaigns in most other states, the argument goes, does not work in compact, folksy, down-to-earth New Hampshire and Iowa. Politicking in those two states, it is said, is like politicking used to be -- and still should be.
So far, most candidates buy that argument, or at least go along with it.
But is retail really retail?
The answer seems to be yes and yes -- that is, retail politics in a political sense really does bring unusually large numbers of candidates and voters face to face, as in clerk and customer, and in the classic retail sense, or business sense, in that it pumps money, big money, into the economy.
A new survey commissioned by the Library and Archives of New Hampshire's Political Tradition found that in the 1996 campaign, retail politicking resulted in one of every five New Hampshire voters personally meeting at least one candidate, and often more. By contrast, in a state like California, the average voter can go the better part of a lifetime, if not an entire lifetime, without meeting a candidate.
Further, the study found that all the running around, eating, advertising and renting of rooms, cars, auditoriums and workspace by candidates, political consultants and reporters, created 1,500 temporary jobs and pumped over $210 million into the New Hampshire economy.
"That's our answer for why New Hampshire works," former Gov. Hugh Gregg, the chairman of the Library and Archives organization, said in releasing the study.
The study, based on a survey of travel, business, tax and Federal Election Commission data, along with interviews with campaign workers and media specialists, also concluded that the New Hampshire primary offered the state a huge opportunity to promote itself at no cost because of the news media coverage given the quadrennial event. The state received more than 20,000 media mentions in 1996, the study said, going on to estimate that they were read, heard or seen by upwards of 150 million people around the country.
But if the promotion opportunity is to be fully exploited, the study added, the state needs to impress visiting reporters that more New Hampshirites hold high-technology jobs these days than milk cows and wear flannel shirts.

HEADLINE: Freeways Make an Easy Scapegoat for Sprawl;
Encourage Diversity

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Contrasting freeway-building policies in Salt Lake City and Milwaukee illustrates what this country is all about: people in different communities making different choices (front page, July 14). These cities are Exhibit A against the "smart growth" plan advocated by Vice President Al Gore, which would impose a single one-size-fits-all model from Washington. 
 A diverse society needs places like Milwaukee and Salt Lake City. The error belongs to neither city but to the "experts" who insist that every town must follow the policies they prefer.
 
JOHN L. GANN
Glen Ellyn, Ill., July 15, 1999
 
The writer is a consultant in urban development.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
BOSTICK, JUANITA DIANE

 BODY:
BOSTICK-Juanita Diane Age 68, of NYC, died on July 14, 1999, at her Tudor City residence. Funeral services will be on Friday, July 23, at 10 AM, at Ridout's Elmwood Chapel in Birmingham, AL, with Dr. R. Maurice Boyd of the City Church of New York, officiating, with burial at Elmwood Cemetery. Visitation will be at Ridout Chapel, Thursday, 5-7 PM. A "Memorial Celebration" is planned in NYC on August 19. For details call 212632-1308. Diane is survived by three brothers. Educated in Birmingham school system, Diane received her BS degree in home economics from the University of Alabama and did graduate study at NYU School of Retailing. After serving as Field Secretary for Phi Mu, she began her career with Avondale Mills in 1953 and climbed the corporate ladder from Designer in Sylacauga, AL, to Stylist, then Assistant VP in NYC, before being promoted to VP for Fabric Design in 1978, breaking the glass ceiling before others even dreamed of doing it and serving as an inspiration and advocate for career women. Diane was featured in articles in Women's Wear Daily, Daily News Record, Birmingham News and several textbooks. She served on the Home Economics Advisory Board at Auburn University, the Advisory Committee of the Institute for Women Executives at UA; and spoke to many college classes and groups. She was a member of: Women's Wear Committee Color Association of the US; the Fashion Group, Inc, serving on the Board of Governors and numerous committees; the NY Fashion Designers; International Needlepoint Guild; and Who's Who in American Women. Diane was a founding member of the City Church of New York; worked with the Talbot Perkins Children's Services; chaired a Benefit Concert for Project Hope; was active in Tudor City Association; was a member of the DAR and UDC. The University of Alabama was Diane's first love and she served it faithfully, and was honored by the University in return. She was Regional VP of the National Alumni Association; received the "Distinguished Alumna Award"; served on the Advisory Board of the Women's Athletic Program; was co-founder of The Greater NY Alumni Association, one of the strongest and most active in the nation. This chapter inducted Diane into its "Hall of Fame" and elected her "Honorary President" for life and established the J. Diane Bostick Endowed Scholarship Fund for clothing, textiles, and interior design students. The College of Human Enviromental Sciences twice presented Diane with The Agnes Ellen Harris Distinguished Alumnus Award, its highest honor, once for career accomplishments and once for her love and commitment to the College. Memorials may be made to the J. Diane Bostick Scholarship Fund, c/o The University of Alabama, Box 870158, University, AL 35487. 
http://www.nytimes.com
