HEADLINE: New Neighbors Pushing at the Edge;
Brooklyn Hasidim Seek to Expand Into a Black and Hispanic Area

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE

 BODY:
Like many of his neighbors in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Charles O'Connor has grown accustomed during the last few months to frequent and unwanted visits from strangers interested in buying the home he has owned for 35 years. One day, though, the banging on his front door was like an alarm. Mr. O'Connor opened it to find a man hammering up a "For Sale" sign, even though he had already told the man's real estate company that he did not wish to sell.
"I said: 'What are you doing? This is my house,' " Mr. O'Connor recalled. "The man said, 'Are you sure?' and kept on going." 
 Since there is an auto parts shop directly behind it and vacant lots are a stone's throw away, Mr. O'Connor's four-story home near the edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant would not seem a desirable address. Yet his neighborhood has become the latest front in a long battle for living space involving Hasidim in Williamsburg, who have no room to expand, and their predominantly black and Hispanic neighbors in adjacent parts of Brooklyn.
For decades, as their numbers have swelled, the Satmar Hasidim have pushed east and north, colliding with resistance, particularly from Hispanic residents, in a fight as much about identity and cultural differences as real estate. Now the same struggle has started to the south, where the Hasidim are not only trying to buy homes from people like Mr. O'Connor but are also seeking variances to rezone about 40 industrial lots for condominiums, co-ops and apartments.
He and other longtime residents, fearful of rising rents and a loss of jobs, are accusing Hasidic leaders of block-busting and shady dealings. Many complain that they have been harassed by repeated nighttime knocks on their door from Hasidim interested in buying their property, and some say potential buyers have told them it would be wise to leave before the area becomes inhospitable.
Mr. O'Connor said potential buyers have told him to put up a "Not for Sale" sign if he wants to avoid further inquiries. It is a step some of his neighbors have already taken.
"People are afraid because of all the zoning changes from commercial to residential, and because the Hasidic community is buying all the available residential properties," said Peter Crisci, the Bishop of the Cathedral of St. Lucy, where many residents attend church. "They are afraid that these people are coming into the community not to build it up, but to create a community within a community, and that doesn't work."
The Hasidim dismiss the complaints as unrealistic, saying that they should be praised for trying to revitalize a sagging area of closed warehouses and boarded-up row houses that is just now beginning to benefit from dropping crime rates and an interest in its many loft spaces. Hasidic leaders and the developers working for the religious community say that most of the resistance is based on stereotypical beliefs that border on anti-Semitism.
"It is basically saying, 'Stay out of here,' " said Rabbi David Niederman, executive director of United Jewish Organizations. "I would hate to characterize why, but what has been said at various meetings is scary."
There have been numerous meetings at which each side's complaints about the other have been discussed, but those meetings have produced no real agreement, and have stopped. The Hasidim have pushed on with their development plans, further angering residents, who have responded with a lawsuit and letter-writing campaigns to politicians.
Last month, the Kent Avenue Block Association won a lawsuit in State Supreme Court to stop a plan to turn a commercial lot into housing for the Hasidim. The court sent the request for a zoning variance back to the Board of Standards and Appeals. Lawyers for the neighborhood group said other lawsuits might follow.
Meanwhile, Melvin Foster, chairman of a community group called the Neighborhood Stabilization Task Force, has lobbied local and state political leaders for support, and one of them, State Senator Velmanette Montgomery, a Democrat whose district includes Bedford-Stuyvesant, expressed sympathy. Mr. Foster also helped spur city planners to begin talking about rezoning the area to balance the community's needs for jobs and housing.
The controversy centers on a predominantly light-industrial area from Flushing Avenue south to DeKalb Avenue, and between Classon Avenue on the west and Marcy and Nostrand Avenues on the east.
According to the city's Board of Standards, which decides on variance requests, in the last three years developers have been allowed to build 385 units of housing in former manufacturing spaces in this area and in the most southern edge of Williamsburg. Variances that would add 433 more units in the area are before the board.
Although Pat Pacifico, a spokesman for the board, said the amount of housing was relatively small, some land use experts have worried that the variances will amount to a rezoning of the area. The housing is designed for Hasidic occupants, Mr. Pacifico said, noting that the variances describe buildings made up of three- to seven-bedroom apartments with amenities like kitchens suitable for observing kosher rules: they have two sinks and space for two refrigerators, so that meat and dairy products can be kept separate.
The Hasidim and their lawyers say they are merely doing what any well-organized group could accomplish by paying attention to land use law. They add that the housing will help the local economy, bringing in businesses and increasing the tax base. They talk of creating a neighborhood where people feel safe walking the streets at night. Residents say the neighborhood is already reasonably safe.
Rabbi Niederman says that developers have sought the Hasidim because they need housing and, unlike others, are willing to pay for new development. He characterizes the movement into Bedford-Stuyvesant as a reshuffling that would leave other apartments in Williamsburg open to "Jew, Latino, poor or rich."
But such thoughts give many longtime residents in Bedford-Stuyvesant pause. They speak of a past when they could walk to work and businesses flourished. They recall the hard times that followed, the crime and the closing of shops, a time when some say the neighborhood "burned like the South Bronx." Now that the future looks brighter, they worry that the benefits are headed toward somebody else.
At a community meeting, Wilfredo Perez, 23, said he and other residents were repeatedly "harassed" by individuals and real estate agents "asking us to sell or asking us who the landlord is so they can sell our homes out from under us."
"I've been here for 22 years and I don't want to be kicked out," added Beatrice Ponnelle, 49. "This is a low-income community and they're coming up with housing that nobody can afford even if we were allowed into it."
Rents have almost doubled during the last two years, and landlords are now charging up to $900 for one-bedroom apartments. Pointing to warehouses where relatives once worked, residents are worried about variances allowing their conversion to residences, cutting out even more jobs in their neighborhood. In one variance case, a developer bought out a manufacturer who threatened to block the construction of apartments in a factory next to his. The manufacturer then moved his business and its jobs to another area in the borough, his lawyer said.
These concerns could surface in any neighborhood facing development and a new population mixture. But residents in Bedford-Stuyvesant are also confronting a question of identity. A movement of mysticism founded in the 18th century, Hasidism requires practitioners to hold themselves apart from the secular world. They have their own religious court system, schools, kosher businesses and security patrols.
Fearing they will be slowly isolated, members of Mr. Foster's task force and other residents of Bedford-Stuyvesant talk of how their corner bodegas will be replaced by kosher groceries and how their longtime friends with be pushed out by a religious community. Realistically or not, they fear becoming second-class citizens who are ordered around on their own streets.
Already, residents say, some Hasidim in the area have complained about the ringing of church bells, and others have painted no-parking stripes on their streets to reserve spaces for cars and Hasidic school buses. Other homeowners say hopeful buyers are unwilling to take no for an answer.
"I can't see in one eye and can't walk the stairs, but they don't feel sorry that you're 83 years old and in bad health," said Francine Palmieri, who had her more able-bodied tenant, Peter Recine, 89, place a "Not for Sale" sign on their building's front door.
But residents like Abe Stein, 51, an Orthodox Jew who has lived in Bedford-Stuyvesant for 20 years and has run a manufacturing business there for 16, said that the unrest was being caused by people "who don't understand that the Hasidim are trying to live within the community."
While he said he had thought about selling his die-cutting factory for housing for the Hasidim, he added, "No one is trying to tell anyone that only Hasidim can live here."
Relations between the Hasidim and other residents remain tense, and some residents are beginning to worry that the current disagreement may turn into a replay of the groups' past disputes.
In the late 1970's, Hispanic and black residents in Williamsburg began to clash with Hasidic residents over what they considered preferential treatment given to Hasidic applicants seeking federally subsidized housing. Some Hispanic residents also complained that they were harassed by Hasidic security patrols while the police turned a blind eye to complaints about the patrols.
Both sides have tried to reconcile over the years, but the fuel that drives their animosity -- the lack of affordable housing in and around Williamsburg -- has remained.
"If the Hasidics move in, bias incidents could flare up," said Ruben R. Pratts, a member of Community Board 3 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, "because nobody here is going to stand by and be manhandled." He said neighbors have already been challenged by Hasidic security patrols.
The difficulty of changing such attitudes is not lost on Rabbi Niederman, who says he continues to urge talk with his neighbors to the south and wants to show them that the Hasidim are their "allies, not adversaries."
"Some people out there are instilling fear," he concluded. "But I would venture to say to any of them, 'Come to Williamsburg, come into the housing projects, and tell us we are not good neighbors.'
"We have African-Americans, Latinos, everybody, and everybody feels safe and secure," he said. "We want to make this area a better place to live for everyone."

HEADLINE: Fast Track Isn't Fast Enough

BYLINE: By Mack McLarty; Mack McLarty was President Clinton's first chief of staff and his special envoy for the Americas.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"This is our fast track." So said leaders of the European Union last month as they signed the Rio Declaration calling for free-trade talks between the union and Latin America and the Caribbean. Although the obstacles to any substantive agreement are large, this challenge to United States leadership in the hemisphere must not be ignored.
Since Congress failed last year to give President Clinton fast track negotiating authority, trade in the Americas has been stalled. In my view, it is time to rethink our approach. For the sake of free trade, it's time to abandon fast track -- at least for now. 
 Fast-track legislation, developed in the early 1970's to smooth Congressional consideration of trade agreements, now threatens by its absence to stop trade negotiations before they start. Let's put the horse back before the cart. Rather than asking Congress to consider broad, abstract fast-track authority, President Clinton should send Congress a concrete free-trade agreement.
When presented with specifics, Congress repeatedly votes pro-trade. Congress has supported the North American Free Trade Agreement, the World Trade Organization and trade relations with China. A recent poll by the Association of Women in International Trade shows that Democrats, Republicans, business owners and, yes, even union members support the concept of free trade by a 2-to-1 ratio.
The challenge is to tap this broad support. It is easier to put a human face on trade when tangible benefits are at hand. With a real agreement before Congress, the winners know who they are and can mobilize public opinion. The few hurt by such an agreement can be helped with worker retraining and transition assistance.
The most logical candidate for a free-trade agreement is Chile, a country whose center-left Government shows sensitivity to environmental concerns and working conditions, a country whose economy is a model for Latin American and the world.
This spring in Santiago, I urged the Chilean Government and business leaders to renew their quest for an agreement with the United States. I received a warm response, and President Eduardo Frei's new chief of staff -- Jose Miguel Insulza, the former Foreign Minister -- recently endorsed such bilateral trade talks.
I now urge the Clinton Administration to stop waiting for fast track. The United States and Chile should begin talks this summer on an agreement, using Nafta as a model. Chile has said that it would comply with the vast majority of Nafta's terms, including labor and environmental provisions. Such an agreement would complement Chile's membership in Mercosur, South America's trade bloc.
Of course, without fast track, Chile could make politically sensitive concessions only to see Congress try to change the agreement. But Chile can stipulate that it will not accept amendments -- the same option available to any sovereign state negotiating with the United States. If Chile coordinates carefully with Congress and the Administration, an agreement is within reach.
The United States exports more than $4 billion worth of goods each year to Chile, amounting to a $1.5 billion trade surplus. We sell more to Chile, a country of 14 million people, than we do to India, a country of almost a billion. But our companies and workers are now at a competitive disadvantage to competitors in Canada and Mexico, who already have free-trade agreements with Chile.
I see encouraging signs that members of Congress in both parties are tired of the old polarized trade debate. It is time to capitalize on this opportunity. A trade agreement with Chile can be a bridge between South America and North America. As an old friend of mine might say, it would be the bridge to the 21st century.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Resume Trade Talks With Beijing

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
A senior Commerce Department official will travel to China next week for the first round of economic talks between the two nations since NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, the Clinton Administration said today.
David Aaron, Commerce Undersecretary for International Trade, will be in Beijing on July 26-27 for discussions with senior Chinese trade and industry officials. 
 Administration officials said they hope Mr. Aaron's trip will help restart talks Beijing broke off in anger following the May 7 bombing, which NATO insists was an accident. He will be the first American official since the bombing to make a trip to Beijing that is not directly related to the bombing. Other American officials have visited to explain to China that NATO mistook the embassy for a Yugoslav military site and to discuss compensation for the Chinese who were killed or injured.
The United States would like to resume talks on China's 13-year effort to join the World Trade Organization. For that to occur, China will have to strike a deal lowering numerous barriers to sales of American manufactured goods and farm products in China.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Raises Tax on Food From Europe

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
In the latest round of a continuing dispute with Europe, the United States today imposed tariffs intended to double the price of imports as familiar as Dijon mustard from France and as obscure as the "guts, bladders and stomachs of animals (other than fish), whole and pieces thereof."
The tariffs, announced by the Deputy trade representative, Peter Scher, had been expected. They will take effect July 29 and are intended to cover $116.8 million in annual imports, almost all of it food, from members of the European Union. 
 United States trade officials were reacting to a European Union ban on United States beef treated with growth hormones. The World Trade Organization, which sets rules for global commerce, declared last week that the European ban was unjustified because there was no scientific evidence of a health danger linked to hormone-treated beef.
"We would like nothing better than getting to a negotiated settlement," Mr. Scher said. "Retaliation doesn't solve the problem."
The penalties announced today do not cover two popular products that had been considered for high tariffs: Evian and Perrier mineral water, both imported from France.
Pork products make up the biggest category subject to the tariffs. Other foods include Roquefort cheese, truffles, chocolate and lingonberry and raspberry jams. There are two non-food products on the list: yarn and glue products, both from France and Germany.
Britain is exempt from the tariff sanctions because British officials support the United States position that the ban on beef should be lifted, Mr. Scher said.
Mr. Scher said the list of products to be penalized was intended to inflict the most economic damage on France, Germany, Italy and Denmark. France and Germany each account for 24 percent of the imports to be affected; Italy, 21 percent, and Denmark, 15 percent. Therefore, he said, they have the most incentive to get the European ban on United States beef overturned.
The products facing the punitive action are subject to few if any tariffs now, Mr. Scher said, adding that Washington is not really interested in the revenue that higher tariffs might generate. "That doesn't help the American beef farmers," he said. "We don't want to force the Europeans to buy our beef. We just want the right to sell to them."
Mr. Scher said his office considered comments from American retailers and the effect on American consumers in compiling the list of foods subject to the tariffs. Mr. Scher said he would rather see European exporters get discouraged and press the European Union to relent on United States beef than have Americans pay more at the grocery store.
Earlier this year, the Clinton Administration drew up a preliminary list of $900 million worth of European items that could be subjected to tariffs but cut the list to $116.8 million after the World Trade Organization estimated that was what the beef ban was costing United States beef producers. The United States beef industry has said its annual losses from the decade-old ban are much higher than that.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Selling City Guides to Ticketmaster for $240 Million

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Sidewalk series of Internet city guides to a rival, Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch, in a stock deal worth $240 million.
Microsoft confirmed that the deal, news of which had emerged during the weekend, would give it a 9 percent stake in Ticketmaster with the option to increase that eventually to 13 percent. Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch, which is controlled by USA Networks, will fold the Sidewalk sites into its network of Citysearch sites. 
 As it retreats from the city-guide business, Microsoft will retain two components of Sidewalk -- its buying guides and searchable business directories -- and fold them into a new local service on its MSN network. Ticketmaster Online will provide much of the content for that as-yet-unnamed MSN service, including ticketing, personal dating services and arts and entertainment reviews, company officials said.
Microsoft will also feature Ticketmaster's ticket-selling operation throughout the MSN network and on its WebTV service.
"In one fell swoop, Citysearch got rid of a rival and gained a distribution partner," said Lisa Allen, an analyst with Forrester Research, an Internet consulting firm. "It gives Citysearch an immediate presence in some big markets, and it gives Microsoft a graceful exit from its city-guide strategy."
Ticketmaster Online's chief executive, Charles Conn, said that the cross-marketing agreement included no restrictions, allowing Citysearch to continue providing content to MSN's rivals.
Sidewalk and the Citysearch service, which both offer on-line information about local entertainment, news and shopping in dozens of cities, have been rivals since Sidewalk opened its first site in early 1997, months after Citysearch started its service.
Microsoft initially hired experienced journalists to produce a kind of on-line magazine and event guide. But the company shifted Sidewalk from that emphasis as an anticipated boom in advertising from restaurants and theaters failed to materialize. Instead, it veered more toward electronic commerce and product information.
Citysearch, though, has cashed in on arts and entertainment content by selling tickets and offering a dating section and local auctions.
The deal, which is expected to close in the fall, will allow Citysearch to more than double the number of city sites it runs, from 33 to 77 worldwide. Citysearch, now the third-most- popular city guide network as measured by Media Metrix, a Internet research firm, would become the largest, attracting an estimated 7 million monthly visitors. Citysearch would reach nearly 11 percent of Internet users in the United States each month.
The Digital Cities service of America Online would remain in second place among city guides, with a 6.3 percent reach. New York Today, owned by The New York Times Company, competes with Sidewalk and Citysearch in the New York market.
Microsoft rarely sells businesses; moreover, the Sidewalk sale represents another step in the evolution of the company's Internet strategy away from entertainment and information.
By selling Sidewalk, the company sheds an unprofitable division, while keeping components that bolster its inventory of E-commerce offerings.

HEADLINE: Bank Earnings Increase; Wells Fargo Is Up 29%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Among the financial companies reporting higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, Wells Fargo & Company said its profit jumped 29 percent, and Bank of New York, the world's biggest processor of securities transactions, increased net income 9.5 percent.
The banks are reaping the benefits of the nation's longest-running peacetime economic expansion, with consumer spending the strongest in 11 years. Fees from credit cards and investment banking also helped fuel earnings growth. 
 "The stronger economy is clearly filtering into all of the banks," said Ned Riley, the chief investment officer at BankBoston, who oversees $30 billion. "Keeping costs under control shows the managements are clearly attuned to the marketplace and economy."
Wells Fargo shares fell 43.75 cents, to $42.6875, while Bank of New York rose 43.75 cents, to $38.
Net income at Wells Fargo rose to $931 million, or 55 cents a share, a penny above the consensus forecast of analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, from $719 million, or 43 cents, a year earlier. The bank said revenue from its consumer and small-business banking rose 46 percent, to $710 million, as its merger with Minneapolis-based Norwest Corporation started to pay off.
Norwest bought Wells Fargo in November, taking the Wells Fargo name and moving its headquarters to San Francisco. The Norwest Mortgage unit, the nation's largest originator of home mortgage loans and the second-largest mortgage servicer, said earnings rose 29 percent, to $70 million. Mortgage banking revenue rose 7 percent, to $324 million.
"They did a great mortgage business," said Joan Goodman, a bank analyst at the Pershing division of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in Chicago.
Earnings at Norwest Financial, which offers consumer finance and auto finance in 47 states, Canada, the Caribbean and Latin America, rose 22 percent, to $66 million.
Bank of New York's net income rose to $323 million, or 42 cents a share, in line with analysts' forecasts, from $295 million, or 38 cents, a year ago. Fees from securities processing rose 23 percent, to $372 million. The New York-based bank built its fee-based processing and trust businesses over the last five years through more than 30 acquisitions.

HEADLINE: Goodbye, Cowtown; Denver Enters the World Arena

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 19

 BODY:
Just after World War II, John Gunther wrote in "Inside U.S.A." that "the remarkable thing about Denver is its ineffable closedness," calling it "probably the most self-sufficient, isolated and complacent city in the world."
Half a century later, a modern-day visitor who arrives here clutching Gunther's book as a guide will feel like Rip van Winkle. 
 In January, Japan opened a consulate here. In April, China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, visited. This week, Air Canada inaugurated a daily flight to Winnipeg, its fifth Canadian destination from its mini-hub at Denver's airport.
In September, Mayor Wellington E. Webb plans to play host to African heads of state and government for a meeting here on development and democracy. In the fall, Britain plans to open its first new consulate in the United States in more than 20 years here.
"Denver was the brightest candidate," Sir Christopher Meyer, the British Ambassador to the United States, said from Washington. "We want to tap into a booming American economy, to get into those cities and those regions where economic power and cutting-edge technology have moved significantly ahead in recent years."
Experts say the rapid internationalization of this city, 1,000 miles from the nearest seaport, is perhaps the best example of a larger trend: the increasing integration of the nation's interior into the world economy.
"More and more international travel is taking place from nontraditional ports of entry -- Salt Lake City, Kansas City, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh -- but Denver is probably the one that has seen the most of it," said Thomas Nulty, president of Navigant Travel, a national network of travel agencies based here.
Over the last decade, Mr. Nulty said, his company's international business had increased 40 percent nationwide but almost 200 percent in Denver.
A strong economy and the boom in information technology are rapidly plugging interior cities into the wider world, said Jerry W. Leach, executive director of the World Affairs Councils of America, an association based in Washington with members from 83 American cities.
In Denver, globalization results from several factors, including the metropolitan area's emergence as a high-technology center, a cosmopolitan change in the area's population mix and the new airport, which opened in 1995 and cost $5 billion.
Fueled by these factors, almost 200 foreign companies from 22 nations have invested a total of nearly $500 million in Colorado, employing 30,000 people.
"It's the airport, the fax machine, the E-mail; 25, no 15 years ago, I could not do what I am doing out of Denver," said Gary Hart, who left Washington after his Senate term expired in 1986 to work here as an international lawyer for Coudert Brothers, a law firm based in New York.
Reflecting the growth in foreign ties here, the ranks of international lawyers in Colorado have grown to 200 from virtually none a few years ago.
In the 1990's, Colorado has recorded one of the nation's fastest growth rates in high-technology employment, 43 percent. Forty thousand jobs have been added in such areas as telecommunications, software and information technology. High-technology products account for about 70 percent of Colorado's $5 billion in annual overseas exports.
This new economy has drawn a more cosmopolitan migrant to a state historically populated by transplants. Long viewed as the place where the Midwest meets the mountains, Colorado has seen its migration from the Midwest drop by half since 1980. Today, more than half of Colorado's new residents come from the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts, historically areas with a more outward-looking world view.
The city is also becoming more ethnically diverse. Greater Denver now supports weekly newspapers in Chinese, Korean, Russian and Spanish. Besides dozens of Chinese and Mexican restaurants, Denver has restaurants specializing in the cuisines of Brazil, Ethiopia, Greece, Indonesia, Jamaica, Morocco, Nepal and Thailand.
"Colorado is a state that has an extraordinarily open attitude to integrating different cultures, races and origins," said Carlos Barros Horcasitas, the Mexican Consul here.
More and more, foreigners seeking to understand the United States or to influence policies place Denver on their itineraries. April's visitors included Ghana's President, Jerry J. Rawlings, who addressed a meeting of the National Conference of Black Mayors; Jose Ramos-Horta, the independence advocate for East Timor, and Julien Clerc, the French singer, who started his North American tour here.
Denver is now a stop for about 15 percent of the roughly 4,500 international visitors to whom the United States Information Agency is the host each year.
Most of these visitors come here through connecting flights. But with the start of Korean Airlines direct flights to Seoul, the South Korean capital, in 1997 and British Airways nonstop service to Gatwick Airport outside London in 1998, foreign trade officials say they believe that Denver's airport will gradually become a truly international hub. In addition to the airport's flights to five Canadian cities, it has direct flights to four Mexican beach resorts.
"At Denver's altitude, long-distance jets always had problem taking off fully loaded," said Marc L. Holtzman, Colorado Secretary for International Trade, Technology and Innovation, referring to the city's mile-high altitude. "But with the technology improving, the introduction of the Boeing 777's and the Airbus A-340's definitely favor a city like Denver for European and Asian flights."
From a small base, international passenger traffic through Denver is up 48 percent this year over last year, reaching 270,000 for the first four months of 1999.
As high-technology exports decline in weight and increase in value, air cargo is supplanting the need for an outlet to the sea for foreign trade.
"It used to be that the Dutch, the Portuguese, all these peoples from coastal nations were the traders," Mayor Webb observed. "Well, the air is our ocean. It allows us to move back and forth, east and west, to keep our economy strong. That is our port."
There are downsides to integrating into the world economy. Last year, the state's ski resort officials set an informal goal of selling 10 percent of all ski-lift tickets to foreigners, who spend heavily in mountain restaurants, hotels and shops. But officials had not calculated on the declining Canadian dollar, now trading at 68 American cents. As European skiers chose the Canadian Rockies over the American Rockies, ski ticket sales at Vail plunged by 16.5 percent last winter, while lift ticket sales at Vail's main Canadian rival, Whistler-Blackcomb, jumped by 25 percent.
And city and company officials here struggle to cope with the almost daily flood of foreign visitors.
Jim Reis, president of the World Trade Center Denver, a private company, said: "We told the Danish Consul General, 'Please don't come to Denver at the end of May. We are going to be inundated.' A Chinese delegation just showed up on our doorstep when I asked them not to. We knew we couldn't set up meetings for them."
Similar foreign interest is felt at the Denver World Affairs Council, said Karen de Bartolome, the group's executive director.
"We now could do all our programming simply by responding to people who want to come to Denver," Ms. de Bartolome said of the group's foreign affairs speakers series.
Mayor Webb, who led a delegation of 11 other American mayors on a 10-day trip to Senegal, Ghana and Nigeria in May, easily brushes off any criticism of his efforts to increase Denver's foreign trade and ties. The Mayor, who was overwhelmingly elected to a third term the week before his West Africa trip, said: "There will always be someone who will second-guess the trips, who will say, 'The Mayor doesn't need to be in Africa, the Mayor doesn't need to be in London -- that's a 1940's, myopic point of view.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Citigroup Profit Rises 21% As Nearly All Areas Grow
Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said that its second-quarter profit surged 21 percent, beating Wall Street expectations, as robust consumer spending and the resilient stock market bolstered earnings at several leading banks.
Nearly every area of activity at the Citigroup conglomerate, from underwriting insurance policies at Travelers to advising companies on mergers at Salomon Smith Barney, posted sharply improved results. Cost reductions, especially in the group's consumer division, helped the bottom line. Page C2. 

Microsoft Posts Solid Earnings
With its business surging on several fronts, Microsoft reported that its quarterly profits increased more than 60 percent, exceeding Wall Street's expectations. But the world's leading computer software maker also warned that the growth of its business is likely to slow during the next year. Shares of the company fell $1.0625, to $98.375, before the results were released. They fell to $97.5625 in after-hours trading. C6.
 
Microsoft agreed to sell its Sidewalk series of Internet city guides to Ticketmaster OnlineCitysearch in a deal worth $240 million. C6.
 
A Slight Decline in Stock Gauges
Stock prices retreated modestly after last week's climb despite glowing earnings reports. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 22.16 points, to 11,187.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 11.12 points, to 1,407.66, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 34.19 points, to 2,830.29. C12.
 
I.B.M. Profit Beats Expectations
I.B.M. said that its second-quarter profit beat expectations by 3 cents a share, bolstered by sales in its services business and a surge in computer revenue. C8.
 
Internet Not On-Line Pot of Gold
Although many people have founded Internet companies, offered stock and even created fortunes, not everyone is striking gold. For every 10 enterprises that receive financing, venture capitalists say, 2 will be stock market successes. That means a lot of entrepreneurs and employees end up disappointed. A1.
 
Tariffs Imposed on European Food
Reacting to a European Union ban on American beef treated with growth hormones, the United States imposed tariffs intended to double the price of $116.8 million in annual imports as familiar as Dijon mustard from France and as mysterious as the "guts, bladders and stomachs of animals (other than fish), whole and pieces thereof. Pork products make up the biggest category subject to the tariffs. Other foods include Roquefort cheese, truffles, chocolate and lingonberry and raspberry jams. C4.
 
South Korea Aids Daewoo Group
The South Korean Government intervened to prevent affiliates of the sprawling Daewoo Group from falling into bankruptcy and setting off a wave of bankruptcies. At the Government's urging, Daewoo's creditor banks agreed to delay by several months $5.9 billion of short-term loans that were due this week and lent an additional $3.4 billion. C4.
 
$21 Million Harassment Judgment
A jury in Detroit awarded $21 million to a woman who said that she had been sexually harassed at a DaimlerChrysler factory that builds the Jeep Grand Cherokee. The company vowed to appeal the verdict. C23.
 
I.R.S. Plans 'Safety Valve' Rules
The I.R.S. will issue regulations tomorrow allowing people with overdue taxes to keep their stocks, businesses and homes if they can show that they need them to pay for medical care or basic living expenses. C9.

HEADLINE: Profits Rise at Citigroup and Other Banks in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit surged 21 percent as robust consumer spending and the resilient stock market bolstered earnings at several leading banks.
Nearly every area of activity at the Citigroup conglomerate, from underwriting insurance policies at Travelers to advising companies on mergers at Salomon Smith Barney, posted sharply improved results. Cost reductions, especially in the group's consumer division, helped the bottom line. 
 Excluding a $29 million charge for reorganization, Citigroup earned $2.48 billion, or 71 cents a diluted share, compared with $2.05 billion, or 57 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected Citigroup to earn 65 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Revenue rose 12 percent, to $14.68 billion from $13.06 billion.
Nine of 25 banking analysts surveyed by First Call raised their projected estimates of Citigroup's profits after the quarterly results were released. For the full year, the consensus estimate was raised to $2.77 a share from $2.65.
J. P. Morgan & Company, the fourth-largest bank in the United States in terms of assets, also had a buoyant quarter, with profits rising 25 percent, to just more than $500 million. But the Bank of America Corporation, the nation's largest bank, eked out a modest profit gain of 2 percent.
Rarely have banks enjoyed a more favorable economic environment. Consumer spending has never been higher and is growing at the fastest rate since the last recession, with many of the new purchases being made on bank credit cards. The housing market, and the banks' mortgage business, has remained strong despite rising interest rates. And nearly all the leading banks now derive a chunk of their earnings from stock and bond markets, where underwriting and trading activity continues to grow quickly.
The only downside to the profit picture is wariness about whether banks can continue to expand their profits at a rate of more than 20 percent, a pace that not long ago was associated with the most successful small companies, some analysts said. Tempering those concerns are signs in the latest quarter that banks are streamlining their operations even as their revenue surges, helping to prepare them for an eventual economic slowdown.
"This is as good as it gets for the banking world," said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "They are working to make it sustainable. It depends on what happens to the economy, but we could see good numbers continue for a time."
One warning sign is that the traditional banking business of taking deposits and making loans has not expanded quickly. Instead, capital markets are lifting earnings at top New York banking conglomerates like Citigroup and J. P. Morgan, which are known as money center banks.
"The sun is shining on them right now," said David Berry, chief of research at Keefe, Bruyette and Woods. "The money center banks are doing very well, but the regular old banks are not growing anywhere near as fast."
Mr. Berry said he expected that the profit growth of 20 percent or more reported by some top banks this quarter would probably give way to a longer-term growth trend of 10 percent to 12 percent.
Since the merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group was finalized last fall, Citigroup has been the largest United States provider of financial services and the second largest in the world, after Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany. It has become a bellwether for financial companies because it is so diversified, serving both retail and corporate customers, in commercial and investment banking, in all major countries.
Citigroup said the consumer side of its business grew the fastest, with profits rising 40 percent, to $1.11 billion. Reducing expenses helped. The bank said it had cut $1.7 billion from operating costs companywide since the merger and was expecting to surpass its goal of reducing costs by $2 billion this year. On the consumer side, full-time jobs and other positions were cut by 5,500, mostly in North America.
"You have new managers looking at ways to make their businesses more efficient, and you also have prior restructurings coming into play," said Diane Glossman, an analyst at Lehman Brothers.
But the biggest surprise was in the corporate and investment banking operation, which had been subject to considerable turmoil after the merger. The division earned $1.26 billion, a 26 percent gain. The figure includes a 75 percent profit surge as the bank's Salomon Smith Barney subsidiary earned $610 million on the strength of trading and commission revenue.
Benefits from the merger have already helped the bottom line in corporate banking, Citigroup said. It cited 67 banking deals on which it earned fees that were made possible by combining the efforts of the old Travelers Group with the old Citibank corporate banking arm.
Sharp reductions in expenses helped Bank of America post a small gain in profit in the second quarter. It earned $2.06 billion, or $1.15 a diluted share, compared with $2.02 billion, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $16.05 billion from $16.46 billion.
Expenses fell 6.5 percent, to $4.57 billion. The number of employees dropped almost 10 percent, to 162,000. Those reductions were largely the result of combining the operations of the BankAmerica Corporation and the Nationsbank Corporation last year into Bank of America, which is based in Charlotte, N.C. The cost trims helped to offset declines in the combined bank's mortgage servicing and investment banking businesses.
J. P. Morgan's profit was $504 million, or $2.52 a share, compared with $4.02 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier. Revenue was $2.19 billion, up slightly from $2.15 billion.
The bank kept expenses steady, while revenue from investment banking grew 26 percent. Morgan turned in an especially strong performance in the highly competitive business of underwriting and trading stocks, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Camden Seeks Bankruptcy Protection, Angering State Officials

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 19

 BODY:
The city of Camden filed for bankruptcy protection today, a move that state officials denounced as an attempt to divert attention from the city's unwillingness to submit to fiscal reforms.
Camden officials could not be reached for comment late today on the filing in Federal District Court in Camden, which legal experts said was not only unprecedented but possibly illegal under state law. 
 The filing was the latest in a series of defiant actions by officials of the city of 87,000 who over the last decade have repeatedly sought state help in shoring up a sagging tax base and meeting the needs of an increasingly poor population, while blaming regressive state policies for their city's plight.
Officials of the state Division of Community Affairs, which oversees local finances and aid programs for municipalities, said that neither they nor the office of the state Attorney General had been given a copy of the filing.
"We learned about this when newspaper reporters called us asking for comment," said Jane M. Kenny, Commissioner of the Division of Community Affairs. "It seems that they would rather manufacture their own crisis than deal with the process that the state has set up to help."
The bankruptcy move comes as Camden was slated to receive a special aid package intended to close a $12 million budget gap. That aid was approved last month as part of the state budget.
Camden was one of five cities that were to receive the aid under the Distressed Cities Act. That assistance was to be provided on the condition that city officials sign an agreement under which they would submit to detailed audits of city spending and revenues, and commit themselves to implementing state-mandated reforms.
Ms. Kenny said that Camden was the only city of the five that refused late last week to sign the agreement.
In announcing the filing today, Camden's Mayor, Milton Milan, said in a statement reported by The Associated Press: "The State of New Jersey has singled Camden out -- and on behalf of its residents -- we're not going to take it anymore." The Mayor said that money from the Distressed Cities Act "is rightfully due to the City and its residents." Mayor Milan had threatened last week to file for bankruptcy protection if the city did not receive the aid payment.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, reacting to reports of today's action by Camden, said: "The state has an obligation to the citizens of Camden and to taxpayers across the state who are footing the city's bills to insure that tax dollars are being spent as wisely and efficiently as possible. Reaching this goal begins with accountability, a premise that has been roundly rejected by Camden City Hall."
The troubled city, which once boasted a vibrant manufacturing economy from soup to electronics, has been losing jobs and prosperity since the early 1980's. Its per capita income of $7,276 is the fifth lowest in the nation and unemployment is at 14 percent, nearly three times the state average. Adding to the problems of a shrinking tax base and a population increasingly dependent on services are charges of widespread corruption among some city officials
Last year the city, in exchange for some $15 million in state aid to close its budget gap, agreed to the creation of a state-dominated Financial Review Board to which it would submit its spending initiatives for review. But Ms. Kenny said that Camden never lived up to the agreement and review board members often found out about spending and revenue changes from second- and third-hand sources.
The provisions of this year's Distressed Cities Act were more stringent, she said, and intended to "make sure that the aid got them out of their financial problems." Not only did city officials refuse to comply with those provisions, Ms. Kenny said, they informed the state that Camden would need $24 million in additional aid next year while refusing to provide documentation for those projections.
Ms. Kenny said she knew of no other city in New Jersey that had filed for bankruptcy protection. She said that state law called for financially strapped cities to apply to her agency's State Finance Baord for help in meeting their obligations, and made no provisions for filing for bankruptcy protection.
Through the provisions of the Distressed Cities Act, Ms. Kenney said, the state was trying to avoid taking over Camden's daily operations, as it had done in 1981, when the city was on the verge of defaulting on debt payments and other obligations.
William Dressel Jr., the executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, said that there had been concerns among members of the group that the Distressed Cities Act imposed draconian measures on cities amid a decline in state and Federal assistance to urban areas. He said that the group's members were torn between whether the act was "assisting or strangling them," and planned to be vigilant about pointing out what state officials in Trenton were imposing on local voters.

HEADLINE: Freshman Senator Bucks His Billing, and the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, was not supposed to be like this.
He was supposed to be a creature of the far-right fringe of his party, at least according to the opponent he defeated in the Illinois Republican primary last year. He was supposed to be a lock-step soldier in the conservative brigade, at least according to his Democratic adversary in the general election, former Senator Carol Moseley-Braun. 
 And yet, on gun control and new regulations for managed health care, the two most hotly contested, bitterly partisan issues in the Senate so far this year, Mr. Fitzgerald broke party ranks to side with Democrats.
Only one other Republican Senator, John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, did likewise. But while Mr. Chafee had been giving party leaders angina for decades, Mr. Fitzgerald had not been expected to roil Republicans' blood pressure.
Mr. Fitzgerald's votes, especially his dissent late last week on managed care, raised questions about whether he was shaping up to be yet another Republican wild card whose support for the party's position could never be taken for granted.
In an interview in his Capitol Hill office, Mr. Fitzgerald said today that despite the extremist portraits painted by detractors during his campaign, "I'm voting the way I had suggested to the 12 million people of Illinois I would be voting."
"I represent 12 million people in Illinois, and that's a profound responsibility, and I don't intend to abdicate that responsibility by giving my proxy to other people," Mr. Fitzgerald said, referring to party leaders.
That attitude has taken people on all points of the political spectrum by surprise.
"There's been considerable chatter within conservative circles about these votes," said Marshall Wittmann of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative advocacy group.
"There's a general concern that he is, in the vernacular, growing in Washington -- moving to the left," Mr. Wittmann said. "People are wary of the early warning signs."
Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, said that he, too, had not anticipated Mr. Fitzgerald's votes.
"He has shown more independence than the overwhelming majority of his Republican colleagues," Mr. Durbin said. "There's more pragmatism there than I thought."
Indeed, Mr. Fitzgerald's deviations from the conservative orthodoxy can be seen in the context of his state, which teeters between the two political parties and prides itself on a centrist streak. The Congressional delegation from Illinois is evenly divided: 10 Republicans and 10 Democrats in the House, one Republican and one Democrat in the Senate.
Gun control has been a particularly popular cause in Illinois over the last five years, and several politicians cast as darlings of the National Rifle Association have paid the price of defeat at the polls.
Although Mr. Fitzgerald voted as a state legislator to allow some Illinois residents to carry concealed weapons, he said that he had always been amenable to reasonable gun control. He said that the Democratic proposal for mandatory background checks at gun shows, which he and five other Senate Republicans supported, was just such a measure.
As for his rejection of the Republican version of a patients' bill of rights, which nonetheless passed the Senate last week, Mr. Fitzgerald said that it lacked a Democratic provision that he favored: a removal of obstacles that prevent patients in health maintenance organizations from suing those insurers for malpractice.
Mr. Fitzgerald said that his position was wholly in line with his conservative views on the benefits of a free market.
"If there were a downside for H.M.O.'s to harm people, maybe they'd be more careful, so I think actually lifting their tort immunity would be a free-market way to improve their behavior," he said.
Mr. Fitzgerald, who was a classics major at Dartmouth College and graduated from law school at the University of Michigan, has an affable demeanor and a tendency to lapse into wonkish commentaries on policy.
At 38, he is the Senate's youngest member, a man who leapfrogged directly from the Illinois Senate to the United States Senate on the power of his intense ambition and his personal wealth, tied to his family's banking fortune. About $12 million of the $15 million he spent on the Senate primary and general election last year came from his own pocket.
Beyond gun control and H.M.O.'s, Mr. Fitzgerald, who is Roman Catholic, married and has a 7-year-old son, is among the Senate's most conservative members. He opposes abortion, making an exception only when pregnancy endangers a woman's life. His distaste for taxes is keen.
But his pet economic peeve is what he described as the flattering, deceptive way in which the Federal Government calculates surpluses, an arithmetic he would banish with his Truth in Budgeting Act.
"That act is encountering bipartisan resistance," he said with a mischievous laugh that suggested his days of ruffling feathers were just beginning.

HEADLINE: 2 Leaders: To Speed the Peace Effort

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of a news conference yesterday in the Old Executive Office Building by President Clinton and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel, as recorded by The New York Times.
 
PRESIDENT CLINTON -- Prime Minister Barak and I have had a very good series of meetings over the past few days. Of course we have focused primarily on the Middle East peace process. We strongly agree that a negotiated peace is the best way to make Israel more secure, the best path to lasting stability and prosperity for all the peoples of the Middle East.
The Prime Minister is determined to accelerate that process, to reach, with Chairman Arafat, a permanent-status agreement between Israel and the Palestinian people and to achieve a broader regional peace that includes Syria and Lebanon. As he has said, the objective now is to put the peace process back on all its tracks. 
 But we should have no illusions. The way ahead will be difficult. There are hard decisions to be made. Knowing his long record of accomplishment, both as soldier and civilian, and having spent a good deal of time with him these past few days, I believe the Prime Minister is ready to move forward decisively. And America is clearly ready to help in any way we can. As Israel takes calculated risks for peace, we will continue to support Israel's defense. Today we have agreed to strengthen our security assistance to Israel, so Israel can best meet the threats to its citizens, including terrorism and the growing threat of long-range missiles and weapons of mass destruction. We have also agreed to establish a high-level joint planning group to consult on security issues and to report back regularly. . . .
To enhance our scientific cooperation, we will create a working group between NASA and the Israel Space Agency to advance scientific research, educational activities and the peaceful uses of space. And an Israeli astronaut and a payload of Israeli instruments will fly on a space shuttle mission next year. . . .
 
PRIME MINISTER BARAK -- President Clinton and I have just concluded the last in our series of meetings. Those meetings were held in an atmosphere of deep friendship and understanding that characterizes the bilateral relationship between Israel and the United States. Our policy is based on the following.
We are committed to the renewal of the peace process. It is our intention to move the process forward simultaneously on all tracks: bilateral, the Palestinian, the Syrians and the Lebanese, as well as the multilateral. We will leave no stone unturned in our efforts to reinvigorate the process, which must be based upon direct talks between the parties themselves and conducted in an atmosphere of mutual trust. Any unilateral steps, acts or threats of terrorism, violence or other forms of aggression have no place in the process of peace. The peace we seek to establish is only the one that will enhance the security of Israel. Only a strong and secure Israel is capable of making the difficult choices that the process requires. I will not shy away from those difficult choices but I have responsibility to the people of Israel to do all that I possibly can to minimize the risks and dangers involved. . . .
 
Q. Mr. President, the Prime Minister has committed himself to implementing the West Bank pullback agreed on at Wye River. You just talked about accelerating the peace process. Realistically speaking, looking ahead, how long before the final-status talks get under way on the tough issues like Jerusalem, the Palestinian hopes for a homeland, refugees and what specific steps can the United States do to facilitate this process?
 
CLINTON . . . We should support the security of Israel, the stability of the region, the economic development of the region, and we should help to work out any of the particular problems as they arise. In terms of the timing, I don't think it's for the United States to set the timetables here. . . .
 
BARAK . . . I would suggest a kind of framework of about 15 months within which we will know whether we have a breakthrough and are really going to put an end to the conflict, or, alternatively, I hope this will not be the case, we are stuck once again.
I use the kind of framework of 15 months to signal to all publics and us, the players, that we are not talking about a magic solution that will drop upon us from heaven in three weeks. And we do not intend to drag our foot for another three years. . . .
 
Q. What is your reaction to the meeting of Syrian Vice President Abdel-Halim Khaddam in Damascus with the few Palestinian organizations that are opposing the peace process? Do you think that it's a significant step for peace?
 
BARAK . . . I did not get a real report about this meeting but if there was such a meeting and the Syrians really asked the terror organizations to reduce the level of activity, it is, of course, good news for all of us. . . .
 
Q. You've said that when Mrs. Clinton expresses her opinions publicly she's just doing something in public which you've done in private before, that is have disagreements. That's the American way. But when she talks about an opinion in which she takes the Israeli position on Jerusalem, doesn't this make it more difficult for you to be that honest broker?
 
CLINTON -- No, no. For one thing, let me say, that issue is not one. That's not the public-private distinction. The Government of the United States, the Executive Branch, the President, is a sponsor of the peace process and a facilitator of it. In that context, those of us with positions of official responsibility who are all the time asking Israel and the Palestinians were all the time asking both sides not to do anything which prejudices final-status issues. I have taken the position that my Government should not prejudice final-status issues. There are many American citizens who consider, for example, Jerusalem to be the capital of Israel. . . .
 
Q. Do you see, Mr. President, and you, Prime Minister Barak, a Palestinian state at the end of this period of time?
 
BARAK -- I think it's too early to think of the results of the negotiations about permanent status that were hardly begun. And I don't think that you should interpret this 15-month framework as a kind of a deadline where everything should be either fully concluded and implemented or the whole thing is blown apart. . . .

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO PRESS SYRIAN TO REOPEN TALKS WITH ISRAEL

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19

 BODY:
President Clinton pledged today that he would get in touch with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria to emphasize that a "golden opportunity" lay before him to complete a peace deal with Israel. Mr. Clinton spoke as he and Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel ended a series of meetings.
From their joint announcement at a news conference of plans to increase military assistance to Israel, to a plan to include Israeli astronauts on a NASA shuttle journey next year, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Barak appeared eager to show that the nations' relationship had been reinvigorated. Excerpts, page A8. 
 The two leaders also announced that Washington would provide financing for Israel's acquisition of additional Arrow antimissile systems, which could defend Israel against Iran or Iraq.
This is one of several measures planned for years but delayed during the tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The Arrow system was delayed for American budget reasons, other measures because of deterioration in relations over the lack of progress in peace talks.
Mr. Clinton said he would ask Congress to speed approval of economic assistance to Israel, the Palestinian Authority and Jordan that had been promised last fall on condition that the land-for-security deal completed at Wye, Md., moved ahead. That money was caught in the stalemate in carrying out the Wye agreement.
Mr. Clinton probably will contact President Assad by telephone in the coming days, a senior Administration official said. By reaching out to Mr. Assad, Mr. Clinton will be taking the first step in the process that Mr. Barak has said he hopes will result in a basis for a comprehensive Middle East settlement within 15 months.
Referring to his contacts over the years with Mr. Assad, Mr. Clinton said, "He knows very well that I am committed to the peace process between Israel and Syria and that I believe that he has a golden opportunity now." Mr. Clinton also said the United States "would like more normal relations with Syria." Syria is one of the last Arab states officially at war with Israel.
But the officials also said Mr. Clinton hopes to reduce the role of intermediary that the United States has played. There has been no direct contact between Israel and Syria. "If we proceed that way, nothing will get done in 15 months," a senior Administration official said. "We hope to see more direct contact."
In his meetings with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Barak said Israel would never agree to return to the borders that existed before the 1967 war, an Israeli official reported last week. But he added that Israel is willing to pull back partly from the Golan Heights, on the border with Syria, if the two countries can agree on other issues, like the status of Lebanon and ending terrorism.
Syria remains on the State Department's list of nations that it says support terrorism. But a report from the Middle East today said that Syria had called on guerrillas that it supports in Lebanon to "call off the armed struggle."
An official in Mr. Barak's delegation said the report could be an encouraging sign about the purposefulness of Mr. Assad's recent statements that he wanted to resume talks with Israel. But some guerrilla groups denied the report.
In announcing increased military assistance, which needs Congressional approval, the Administration was also outlining a plan under discussion for some time to restructure aid to Israel. Under a new formula, the United States would phase out economic assistance, now $1.2 billion a year, while increasing military aid. Israel now receives $1.8 billion a year in military assistance; over the next 10 years, this would be increased to $2.4 billion a year.
The aid package pledged to the participants in the Wye process includes $1.2 billion over three years to Israel, $400 million to the Palestinian Authority and $300 million to Jordan, which has already received one installment.
In another indication of their new confidence, the two leaders announced a strategic policy group composed of senior American and Israeli security officials that would report to them every four months.
Such a group was proposed at Wye but, Administration officials said, it lacked the authority to make meaningful recommendations or decisions on Israel's security needs. Under the new formula, the officials would consider ways to enhance Israel's security in the context of a comprehensive peace settlement.
In their communique, the two leaders said they would sign an accord allowing for "broad cooperation" between various agencies of both Governments on responding to the threat of weapons of mass destruction.
On the sensitive issue of Jonathan Jay Pollard, a former United States Navy intelligence analyst who is serving a life sentence for spying for Israel, Mr. Barak declined to comment, beyond saying he would like to see him released.
Mr. Pollard was arrested in 1985, pleaded guilty and was given a life sentence in 1987. Mr. Clinton has twice denied clemency to Mr. Pollard. But on the last day of the talks at Wye last year, Mr. Clinton pledged to Mr. Netanyahu that he would review the case after Mr. Netanyahu made it an issue and the director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, threatened to resign if he were released, senior American officials said at the time. Mr. Clinton asked Charles F. C. Ruff, the White House Counsel, to compile a report on whether Mr. Pollard should be released.
After the news conference the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said Mr. Barak, like all other Israeli Prime Ministers, had raised the issue. Mr. Berger said Mr. Clinton had not yet received the report from Mr. Ruff.
According to Mr. Berger's account, the Prime Minister said the Pollard case should not be part of the peace talks. At Wye, Mr. Netanyahu had threatened to walk out unless Mr. Pollard was released.
By accounts from American and Israeli officials, Mr. Barak and Mr. Clinton, who did not know each other well, developed a good rapport during two lengthy one-on-one sessions and then over meals and at other meetings.
But both leaders were short on details on what the unfolding peace efforts might look like. Mr. Barak said it was "too early" to talk about the results of what are termed permanent-status talks on such difficult questions as borders, refugees and the disposition of Jerusalem.
Still, Mr. Barak told the Administration that he would move forward with the Wye agreement and today in Israel, the Israeli Defense Forces began relocating its Jenin headquarters in anticipation of the next withdrawal from the West Bank.
Asked whether he saw a Palestinian state emerging by the end of the year, Mr. Barak said, "I am confident that the nature of the Palestinian entity will emerge quite naturally out of these permanent-status negotiations."
Mr. Barak had his last scheduled meeting with Mr. Clinton at the White House this afternoon. Earlier the Prime Minister met with officials of the American Israel Political Action Committee, which lobbies on behalf of Israeli issues, and this evening met with Mr. Tenet and attended a dinner at the home of the Israeli Ambassador, Zalman Shoval.
On Tuesday, his last day in the United States, Mr. Barak is to hold meetings on Capitol Hill and attend a lunch with Vice President Al Gore in his residence.

Syrian Approach to Militants
 JERUSALEM, July 19 (Reuters) -- Syria has asked militant Palestinian groups based in Damascus to end their armed struggle against Israel because it intends to make peace with the Jewish state, members of the groups said today.
Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam met with members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, the Saqa group and the Fatah Uprising, which is led by Col. Abu Musa, a Syrian official said. Mr. Khaddam held separate talks with the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.
 Other leading groups, including Hamas and the Islamic Holy War, were not involved in the meetings.
A spokesman for a Palestinian alliance in Damascus denied the report, and Hezbollah, the Party of God, dismissed it as "talk that does not merit a response."
 The Damascus-based groups oppose the peace accords with Israel signed by Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

HEADLINE: 'One China' Policy Ignores Reality

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re your July 17 front-page article on the Chinese Government's settlement and development program in the Xinjiang region: While it is true that some Uighurs have resorted to violence in order to resist Chinese colonization, thousands of Uighur political prisoners have been persecuted for peaceful protest. 
 Amnesty International released a report in April documenting human rights violations committed by the Chinese Government in the region, mainly against Uighurs. The violations included arbitrary and summary executions, systematic torture of political prisoners, arbitrary detention and unfair political trials.
While you suggest that Uighurs have benefited from development of the region, it appears that the main beneficiaries have been Han Chinese. According to the Amnesty report, unemployment is high among Uighurs because of the preferential treatment given to Han Chinese.
 
KATHY POLIAS
Washington, July 18, 1999

HEADLINE: There's Still Hope for Last-Minute Planners

BYLINE: By PAUL GRIMES; Paul Grimes writes the syndicated column "The Online Traveler."

 BODY:
UNEXPECTEDLY, you find that you can get away for a week or so in late summer or in early fall. But so late in the season, where can you go and what's the best way to get there? Where can you find transportation and rooms at reasonable prices and places that haven't nearly shut down because of foul weather or because they're not popular at that time of year?
Ask a travel agent? That can be fruitful if you know one who is familiar with your tastes and is an expert on the places and activities that interest you. 
 For example, if you're a wealthy outdoors-oriented client of Ray Kane, who runs Pisa Brothers Travel Service in New York, he might send you skiing in Chile or fishing in a remote Alaskan bay. For a cost-conscious couple who are Francophiles, he suggests Paris in September, when there are wonderful values in air-hotel packages.
Kay Brylawski of Flora Tours in Jenkintown, Pa., suggests that beach enthusiasts visit Aruba, which generally escapes the hurricane season that plagues other Caribbean isles. For fall foliage, she says popular tours often have late cancellations and smaller bus companies, operating from larger cities and selling through travel agents, often have last-minute room.
In the West, Myrna Ross of World Travel Partners in Phoenix lists Hawaii, Disneyland (near Los Angeles) and Catalina Island off the Southern California coast among her choices. "You can fly from Phoenix to Los Angeles right now for $88 round trip," she said. "There's always somebody at Disneyland in September, although it's less crowded than in summer. And Catalina is very relaxing, with a broad range of hotels but no cars and no crime."
These days, more vacationers are turning to cyberspace to do their own research if not complete travel planning. A good starting point on the Internet is the Great Outdoor Vacation Pages (www.gorp.com), where you can search by activity (camping, fishing), location (by state or country) or type of attraction (scenic drive, forest, beach, archeological site). Gorp will help plan a solo vacation as well as a group activity.
The Internet abounds in sites that sell vacation packages. They brim with so-called hot deals, some enticing. Be aware, though, that these are probably distress merchandise -- tours that have failed to sell. Typically, such sites embrace only tour companies that pay to be listed.
One that does better is the Online Vacation Mall (www.onlinevacationmall.com), which features packages from 13 major mass-market tour companies. Another exception is Vacation Packager (www.
vacpac.com). It is run by the Official Tour Directory, the travel industry's most comprehensive listing of tour companies, covering more than 800 destinations and 300 vacation interests and activities. The site has links to state tourist offices and lists of toll-free telephone numbers of airlines, hotel chains, auto-rental companies and the like.
Particularly useful for last-minute choices is TravelHUB (www.travelhub.com), a consolidated site for the package offerings of several hundred specialized travel agencies. An extensive directory of companies specializing in cruises can be found at dir.yahoo.com/Business-and-Economy/Companies/Travel/Cruises.
For the Caribbean, late summer and fall are bargain times. Yes, it is hurricane season, but, Liane Beck of The Travel Company's Miami office noted: "The captain doesn't want to go through a hurricane any more than you do, and he's going to use his sophisticated navigational equipment to circumvent it." There are also late-summer deals for Alaska, she said.
Sometimes, age can be a factor in planning a trip, at either end of the spectrum. Family Travel Times, a 15-year-old bimonthly newsletter devoted to travel with children, is developing www.familytraveltimes.com. The accent is on air-land packages, cruises and hotel specials. The catch: the best material is available only to newsletter subscribers for $39 a year.
Probably the broadest selection of learning vacations for older travelers is from Elderhostel, the Boston-based nonprofit organization with one- and two-week residential study programs around the world. Many programs fill up quickly months ahead, but others always have vacancies. The problem for last-minute decision-makers is to find out which ones.
One way is to call Elderhostel toll-free at (877) 426-8056. If you are specific -- asking, for example, about hiking in Montana or arts and crafts in West Virginia -- you should find vacancies. Obtain suggestions from the Web site, www.elderhostel.org, where you can do your booking.
Once you have decided where you want to go, the next issue is getting there. If you are traveling by air, your search for the lowest fare can be trying. Many Web sites profess to help, sharing a small selection of data bases. But few can provide senior fares or accommodate the discount and companion-flies-free coupons that stuff your mail. Sometimes prices differ among sites, because one includes taxes in its fare quotations and another does not.
Among the Web sites that can help is www.smarterliving.com, which will scan the Internet for the weekly specials of 20 airlines and E-mail you free-of-charge about those originating in the cities of your choice. It also scans for Internet-only specials of car-rental companies and hotels.
The new Farebeater feature at the discount site www.1travel.com promises to find the lowest fare on the days and routes you plan to fly. This can be useful for bookings too late to meet advance-purchase requirements for most discounts.
For rental cars, the smartest advice for do-it-yourselfers is to phone your travel agent or the car company. Then you can compare, with a real person, the many discounts, free days and upgrades for which you may be eligible through club memberships or coupons.
In popular areas at peak season, last-minute rooms can be hard to find. It is often easiest to look at weekend or weeklong packages that offer rooms alone, rooms plus meals or rooms, meals and transportation from and to home. If your destination is a large city in North America or Europe, a hotel consolidator, a company that contracts for large blocks of hotel rooms, can probably assist. It may not offer discounts at tight times, but it will have rooms at hotels that are otherwise sold out.
You could try the Hotel Reservations Network (www.hoteldiscounts.com or, by phone, 800-715-7666); Quikbook (www.quikbook.com or 800-789-9887) or Travelscape.com (www.travelscape.com or 888-335-0101). When asked about availability in New York for three days, Hotel Reservations Network produced 51 choices in Manhattan and five in the suburbs, from the modest to the Waldorf-Astoria.
For smaller cities or regions, the local convention and visitors' bureau or chamber of commerce may be able to direct you to accommodations at popular times. You'll find listings and contact at dir.yahoo.com/Recreation/Travel/Convention-and-Visitors-Bureaus. Or you can, of course, try a hotel Web site, a toll-free phone number or a travel agency in person, by phone or on line. It may take digging and time, however, to find the best deal for when you want to go.

HEADLINE: From California, Toasty, Mellow Nut Oils

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
EUROPEANS, especially the French, have always had a monopoly on good nut oils, which are a luxury in vinaigrettes and a fragrant substitute for butter on grilled fish. But now, a two-year-old company in California is making what are probably the best toasted nut oils on the market.
In Yountville, a town once better known for its groves of walnut trees than its vineyards, John Baritelle is producing five nut oils under the California Press label: walnut, pecan, almond, hazelnut and pistachio, each capturing the essence of the nut. They can add a flavorful finish to soup, salad or risotto or can even be drizzled on cheese. 
 Mr. Baritelle, a former professor of economics at the University of California at Riverside, is recapturing a childhood taste. "I grew up in Walnut Creek," he said, referring to a town near San Francisco. "We always had walnut oil and almond oil that one of our neighbors made. That led to a quest." In search of an intensely delicious walnut oil, he started in France three years ago and wound up importing walnut oil in ceramic jugs. The brand name was the French Press. "Then I asked my wife why we couldn't do it here," he said.
Mr. Baritelle bought an old sesame oil press and experimented with different kinds of walnuts at various levels of toasting. Once he was satisfied with the results, he changed his company's name and hired Chuck Schutte, an engineer, and his wife, Gayle, to run it.
Oils are easily pressed out of nuts, but their flavor blossoms only when the nuts are toasted first. Mr. Baritelle toasts his in what looks like a small coffee roaster. Then they are pressed in 15-pound batches. He grows some of his own walnuts and buys the almonds and pistachios from a California grower. The pecans are from Arizona, and the hazelnuts from Oregon.
The main difference between Mr. Baritelle's oils and most of the competition is that he uses whole nuts or halves, not the broken bits usually accepted by nut oil producers. The result is nuttier, deeper and more mellow oil, with no hint of rancidity or other off flavors. (They still should be stored in the refrigerator to keep them fresh.)
And there is a bonus. Because the California Press uses high-quality nuts, the cakelike residue from the pressing can then be ground and sifted and used as nut flour in baking and cooking. Mr. Baritelle is selling that, too, by mail for $17 a pound.
 California Press nut oils cost $15 to $18 for 8.4 ounces at markets including Dean & DeLuca, 560 Broadway (Prince Street), and Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street). They are also available by mail, (800) 736-6602. Shipping is extra.
 
FRISEE WITH MANCHEGO AND WALNUT OIL
Adapted from EQ
Time: 20 minutes
 
4 heads frisee, dark green leaves removed, torn in bite-size bits
 1/4 pound cremini mushrooms, very thinly sliced
1 tablespoon chopped shallot
1 tablespoon chopped chives
 1/4 pound manchego cheese, shaved thin
4 tablespoons rice vinegar
6 tablespoons walnut oil
Salt and freshly ground black pepper.
 1. Toss frisee, mushrooms, shallot, chives and half the manchego in a salad bowl. Drizzle vinegar and oil into bowl along one side. Gently combine. Season with salt and pepper.
2. Divide among four plates and top with remaining manchego.
Yield: 4 servings.
