SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 5; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1978 words

HEADLINE: A New Variety Of Flower Child In Full Bloom;
Music and the Internet Nourish a Counterculture

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS 

 BODY:
"I don't know what a hippie was," said Benjy Eisen as he stood near a sink filled with dishes in a Winnebago parked at the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., on Thursday. "I'm a kid of the 90's. In our generation we don't have Vietnam stories, we have Lollapalooza tales. Our war stories are about the car breaking down on the way to a show."
Mr. Eisen and 10 friends, none older than 26, had rented the camper to follow the band Phish on its six-week summer tour, stopping in Holmdel that evening and the next. Most of the friends were from New York or Pennsylvania, although one had come all the way from Bakersfield, Calif. They had driven hundreds of miles to see shows from Kansas to Georgia, sleeping alongside one another on increasingly dingy foam beds, selling fruit smoothies to earn spending money, taking time off to play music in state parks, and meeting other travelers at every turn. 
 "There's kids in these parking lots who have seen more of the country than their parents or their grandparents," said Kevin Schoenecker, who is from Rochester. "Some people find religion in it, and other people find just a good time and a new city every night."
Such counterculture scenes are springing up like weedy flower beds all over the country, and not just in the wake of Phish.
The "jam band" community is a major underground force in pop, with thousands of fans meeting over the Internet, teaming up to tour with Phish or other bands like Moe and the Disco Biscuits, disseminating hundreds of bootleg tapes and supporting myriad local scenes.
"Seems like every city in America has at least one band to represent," said Chris Zahn, who books the Wetlands Preserve, Manhattan's premier jam-band club, when asked later about the phenomenon. Phish shows can attract up to 70,000. Festivals staged by smaller bands draw thousands.
This outpouring seems similar to the one being commemorated at this weekend's 30th-anniversary celebration of the Woodstock festival in Rome, N.Y. Many of its adherents appear to have stepped from photographs of that historic event, in their calico clothes and tangled hair, with their stashes of glass pipes for smoking marijuana and their fondness for group hugs. But they insist they're not trying to get back to the garden.
"The term hippie is such a convoluted stereotype," said Matthew Rudnicki, a 20-year-old student at Clark University in Worcester, Mass. "It's an explosive cliche. You jump on tour, and you think there will be people massaging you and feeding you, and it's this bubble of love, and things are a lot grittier than that."
 
Old Trappings, New Groove
In the parking lot on Thursday the mood of celebration was underpinned by one of practicality. A "green crew" of volunteers organized by Phish employees met to discuss how to clean the lot and recycle cans and bottles after the show. A women's group called the "Phunky Bitches," which formed through an Internet mailing list, distributed bags containing condoms, tampons, antacids, sanitizing gel and other necessities, and made themselves available to answer the needs of female fans.
"It's used as a safe haven for women if they go on tour," said 24-year-old Randy Schwartz. "They know they can come to us for supplies or a safe ride to the next show. We felt like women were a minority on tour, and that it was a male-dominated scene."
These inheritors of counterculture chic strongly resist romanticizing their life style. They don't want to be social dropouts; most refer to the Phish tour as merely a vacation.
"I work hard, three jobs," said Brad Kluttz, 22, from Atlanta, who was about to drop off the tour because he was fighting a bronchial infection. "This is fun for me, and I love it. They put on a great show for me every night." He added, "but I've got responsibilities at home."
There are divisions in this subculture between the young professionals who take time off to join the tour for a while and fans who scramble to survive.
"Kids with coolers full of beer, they have the money," said Matt Iarrobino, 24, a television cameraman by day and the lighting director at the Wetlands by night. "And there are kids who sell grilled cheeses after the show just to get to the next one." These differences aren't discussed, Mr. Iarrobino said. "When you're at a Phish show, everyone is equal."
Even as they revel in the Phish tour's open and loving atmosphere, these enthusiasts know that its security is not guaranteed and its pleasures are ephemeral. But they take its lessons with them after the tour ends.
"This microcosm -- the lot economy, the relationships here, the social dynamics, the travel dynamics, everything -- carries over into a real-world application," said John Frattalone, 19, a Long Island native and another of the Winnebago renters. "You see businessmen who were involved with the Grateful Dead scene who have completely different ways of approaching business, where no one gets hurt. That's what I want to carry out for myself."
With their natural-fiber clothing, vegetarian diets and predilection for trippy music, the members of the jam-bands scene seem to be carrying on the legacy of their hippie forebears.
But they are not dreaming of a new Woodstock nation. They belong to one subculture among many thriving today, and as the saying goes, they may think globally, but they act locally.
They learned their methods from the Grateful Dead, a band that embodied the hippie stereotype. The ritual of the road trip originated with Deadheads, the group's patchouli-wearing camp followers.
The custom of trading tapes and communicating over the Internet, vital to sustaining a scene that thrives largely without the help of the mainstream music industry, also originated with them. And the band pioneered the diverse, improvisational approach to rock that keeps fans so deeply engaged.
Yet observers agree that not until the Grateful Dead disbanded after the death in 1995 of its leader, Jerry Garcia, did the jam-band scene solidify. "People started to look to the clubs, where you could have that immediacy with the bands and with one another," said Dean Budnick, author of the book "Jam Bands" (ECW Press) and editor of the Web site www.jambands.com. The older people didn't care, and all of a sudden these young people saw themselves."
Members of popular bands like Moe, the Slip, Galactic and the Disco Biscuits are in their 20's. "You've got a generation of parents listening to their Woodstock CD's, and kids are like, yuck," said Mr. Zahn of the Wetlands. "The kids are looking to groove to great music, indulge in drinking and partying. That hasn't changed. But the fashions have changed. Kids are realizing that rave and hip-hop fashion and music is way cooler than this tired, boring classic rock."
At the same time some find the source of their rebellion in reviving the values of the counterculture. "Kids wanting to be more like hippies is definitely counterculture now," said Chuck Garvey, a guitarist in Moe. "After hard-core yuppiedom, kids think this is the alternative."
 
Road Trips And Street Politics
Some taking this road make the step into street politics. Larry Bloch opened the Wetlands in 1989 as a center for activism as well as a nightclub. He sold the club in 1997, but its Environmental and Social Justice Center is still open, now coordinated by Adam Weissman, 21.
Every Tuesday evening at 7, the couch-filled basement lounge of the Wetlands is the site of informal political forums. Last week about 30 people gathered as Bre Reiber, a 22-year-old executive assistant at the peace group Physicians for Social Responsibility discussed the effects of United States policies toward Iraq.
The issues that most inspire the young people at such gatherings are different from the ones their parents embraced. Environmentalism is their main cause, and they support animal rights, a nascent movement in the 1960's. They say their approach also differs.
"We're going to do this and get it done," said Karen Benezra. "We're not going to just commune. A lot of it is finding yourself through ethics and direct action and not wastes of time and peyote."
Ms. Benezra's flippant put-down of psychedelic drugs reflected a certain defensiveness among these young activists. Although casual drug use is commonplace, many young people disassociate themselves from the image of the stoned hippie living in a hazy fantasy. They also rejected the idea, so important in the 60's, of generational unity.
"I don't think we're trying to build a generational movement," said Mr. Weissman. "Less than a generation gap, there's a cultural gap between people who feel that going along with a society bent on self-destruction through massive overconsumption and global exploitation and fundamental injustice is an acceptable thing, and those of us who don't."
Clara Kramer-Wheeler, 17, gave a personal spin to Mr. Weissman's rhetoric. "If I was the only young person in a group of activists, I'd feel left out," she said. "But I go to demos with my parents all the time. Me and my sister got them back into activism."
Rather than dreaming of a mass movement, these self-styled counterculture kids take a do-it-yourself approach to relatively small corners of the culture, whether that means staging guerrilla protests or trading tapes of their favorite shows.
"It's beyond the music-industry hype, beyond the machine," said Mr. Garvey. "Now people go to dance, to meet these other folks. Tapers support that because they're disseminating the music and getting people interested in becoming part of a community."
 
Deliberately On the Fringe
Few of the jam bands are on major labels, and those who are, like Phish (and, briefly, Moe, before it parted ways with Sony), stay credible by maintaining some distance from the mainstream pop world. Phish has never had a hit single; most of its songs are too long and complicated for the radio.
Although the band plays standard concert sites, it sells most tickets through a self-maintained mail-order service and holds some special events, like last weekend's festival in Oswego County, N.Y., at places where the band, not a promoter, makes the rules.
Their fans make such activities possible. The presence of the jam bands on the Internet is extraordinary. The most popular bands have elaborate networks of Web sites and mailing lists, and there is even a database, www.jambase.com, that tracks concert dates throughout the country. Well-equipped insiders bring laptop computers and cellular modems to shows, transmitting instant set lists and reviews on the Internet.
Fans and artists also organize their own festivals, reasonably priced alternatives to corporate events like Woodstock, throughout the summer. The Finger Lakes Grass-Roots Festival, running tomorrow through Sunday at the Trumansburg Fairgrounds, near Ithaca, N.Y., is one example. Founded by the jam band Donna the Buffalo in 1991, the charity event has expanded to embrace a world of music -- this year's performers include the venerable African singer Thomas Mapfumo, the reggae veteran Justin Hinds and the Irish-American supergroup Solas.
Moe can't make it to this weekend's Grass-Roots Festival partly because the band is playing on Friday afternoon at the Woodstock concert. Mr. Garvey said that he was happy to perform for the 250,000 people expected at the Rome blowout, but that he hoped to make it over to Trumansburg afterward to hang out among 10,000 more like-minded folks.
He said he did not expect to run into many "moe.rons," as his band's devotees are called, at Woodstock. The gathering is too expensive, too big, and besides, the Grass-Roots Festival and three Midwestern Phish shows are that weekend. The children of the counterculture will be scattered as usual, pursuing their subcultural way of life.

HEADLINE: Profit Higher For Bank One And Mellon

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Bank One Corporation and the Mellon Bank Corporation reported higher second-quarter profits yesterday based on the rising stock market and increasing consumer spending.
Bank One, the nation's fifth-largest bank, said earnings before a one-time charge rose 22 percent, while Mellon, the second-largest bank in Pennsylvania, said earnings gained 9.8 percent. 
 The banks are benefiting from "nine years of uninterrupted growth with low inflation," said Anthony Gray, chief financial officer of STI Capital Management, which oversees $15 billion. "Some of the businesses that the real big banks are in happen to be doing well right now."
Bank One, based in Chicago. said second-quarter operating profit rose to $1.11 billion, or 93 cents a diluted share, compared with $915 million, or 77 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The results met analysts' estimates, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Revenue rose to $4.56 billion from $4.47 billion.
Noninterest income rose 6.4 percent, to $2.22 billion, as credit card fees jumped 46 percent, to $920 million.
Bank One is starting to see savings from its merger last year with the First Chicago NBD Corporation, having reduced noninterest expense for two consecutive quarters.
Net income rose 11 percent, to $992 million, or 83 cents a share, compared with $895 million, or 75 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, including charges this year for the merger with First Chicago and gains a year ago from branch sales.
Shares of Bank One fell $1.0625 yesterday, to $59.375.
Second-quarter earnings at Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, rose to a record $236 million, or 45 cents a diluted share, compared with $215 million, or 40 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier, also meeting Wall Street estimates.
At Mellon, which owns the Dreyfus family of mutual funds, fees from mutual funds, investment management and other services rose 25 percent, to $284 million.
Fee revenue rose 11 percent, to $787 million.
In the latest quarter, net interest revenue fell 2.9 percent, to $363 million.
Shares of Mellon fell $1.75, to $34.875 yesterday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Trade Group Agrees On Split Term for Director

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 20

 BODY:
Members of the World Trade Organization resolved a prolonged and bitter dispute over who would be its next leader today by agreeing that the two finalists will share the job in consecutive three-year terms, with the New Zealand candidate going first, followed by his Thai rival.
The compromise, which had been gathering support in the last few weeks, was introduced today at the organization's decision-making General Council. It is likely to be formally approved on Friday, representatives said. 
 If approved, it would end a struggle that had pitted Mike Moore, a former New Zealand Prime Minister, against Supachai Panitchpakdi, a Deputy Prime Minister of Thailand, to head the 134-nation organization that sets the rules of global commerce.
And, though the dividing lines were not always neat or clearly drawn, the leadership struggle also pitted Western economic powers, many of whom supported Mr. Moore, against Asians and others in the third world, who saw Mr. Supachai's candidacy as a way of gaining some equality in international councils.
Supporters of each candidate agreed that the trade organization had worked its way out of an embarrassing and potentially crippling episode in its young history. "No one pretends that this is an ideal solution, but it is certainly the most practicable," said Iftekhar Chowdhury, the representative from Bangladesh, which first proposed the idea of a divided term.
The previous Director General, Renato Ruggiero of Italy, who left the post at the end of April, served a four-year term, though after an initial fight over his appointment.
The United States, which had supported Mr. Moore and was privately accused by some countries of trying to sabotage Mr. Supachai's candidacy, said it was satisfied with the outcome. "We accept this knowing that we have to move forward with the trade agenda," said Rita Hayes, the American representative at the trade organization. "These are two very qualified individuals."
A formal announcement of the sharing arrangement was partly dependent on negotiations over who would become the deputy directors general in various world regions. But even if disagreements arose over these posts, representatives said, the split-term arrangement for director general would not be derailed.
The failure to fill the top post had been threatening the smooth functioning of the Geneva-based group. The Director General oversees a staff of 500 and can appoint arbitration panels in trade disputes.
The main question surrounding the split-term compromise was on who would go first. Last week, the Thai Government helped expedite a solution by announcing that Mr. Supachai could take the second term, and that broke the last significant obstacle to the deal.
"I am delighted that the meeting today reached a conclusion on term-sharing," Mr. Supachai said in a statement today.
Under the compromise, Mr. Moore will take over on Sept. 1 and serve through Aug. 31, 2002. Mr. Supachai's term would start the following day and finish on Aug. 31, 2005.
Mr. Moore's first priority will be to guide negotiations for the coming round of global trade talks scheduled in Seattle at the end of November.
In an interview, Mr. Moore quipped that his best qualification for the job "is that I look like Rocky" -- the nickname of Mr. Ruggiero. But at 50, Mr. Moore is 19 years younger than his predecessor.
He has held a number of New Zealand Government posts, notably a brief tenure as Prime Minister in 1990. "I was there such a short time it made Gerald Ford look like Franklin Roosevelt," Mr. Moore remarked.
Negotiations on how the deputy director general posts will be filled remain a potential source of conflict in the trade organization, the successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Under the old GATT structure, there were two deputies, one from the United States and the other from India. Another deputy position was added and filled by a Latin American -- from Mexico -- in 1993. Two years later, when Mr. Ruggiero was named Director General of the new World Trade Organization, the number of deputies grew again when a South Korean was named a deputy.
With the Europeans relinquishing the top slot, which they held throughout the history of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, they are anxious for a deputy post. But many developing nations are similarly intent on getting deputy posts for Asia, Africa and Latin America. The United States also wants a deputy.
The math adds up to five deputies, three more than the trade organization had planned. For now, the proposed compromise indicates the need for "equitable geographical balance" in the deputy selection, but interpreting that phrase is certain to lead to a lot of hard bargaining.
"The question is how to deal them out," said Pakistan's trade envoy, Munir Akram. "They're important because it's like having a sympathetic ear in the court. It's somebody you can pick up the phone and talk to if there's a problem."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Passengers on Jetblue will be able to watch live satellite-television programming from their seats.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
JETBLUE AIRWAYS plans to offer its passengers live satellite-television programming, a feature that experts say could revolutionize in-flight entertainment throughout the aviation industry.
The new discount airline, which is scheduled to begin domestic flights out of Kennedy International Airport early next year, will use Airbus A320 planes equipped with special antennas that are part of a system developed by Live TV, a joint venture between the Harris Corporation and Sextant In-flight Systems. The antennas will receive programming from three satellites that broadcast the satellite-television service offered in the continental United States by DirecTV, a unit of Hughes Electronics, which is itself owned by General Motors. 
 Five-inch, high-resolution television screens will be installed on the back of all Jetblue seats, while armrests will be equipped with plugs for headsets as well as volume and channel controls.
Tom Anderson, Jetblue's director of aircraft programs, said the carrier would offer 24 channels of live programming from DirecTV, plus one channel that will track the plane's route and another that will be used for promotional purposes. With the exception of the safety briefing, all programs will be available from the minute a passenger sits down until the plane arrives at its destination gate.
No decisions have been made yet about what channels Jetblue will offer; by Federal law, DirecTV can broadcast only cable, not network, television programming in flight. Mr. Anderson also said Jetblue would not censor programming. For example, if a plane crash occurs, Jetblue will not suspend news programs dealing with that. Commercials also will be the same as they are on the ground.
Jetblue will charge $3 to $5 for its TV service, depending on the length of the flight; payment will be by credit card only.
Jetblue will be among the first carriers to feature live satellite-television programming. Delta Air Lines used DirecTV on one flight in October 1996 to broadcast the fourth game of the World Series between the Atlanta Braves and New York Yankees. John Kennedy, a Delta spokesman, said the airline had no plans to reintroduce the service now or in the immediate future. DirecTV has also been selling its service to private jet owners since last year.
Mr. Anderson said Jetblue's new system would give travelers more choice in and greater control over entertainment options than they now have. He also said the system occupied less room in an aircraft cabin than others, freeing space both in overhead bins and beneath seats.
Glenn Latta, Live TV's vice president of operations and corporate development, said his company had signed an agreement with a second United States airline, which he declined to identify, to also offer 24 channels of programming from DirecTV.
Terry Wiseman, publisher of Airfax, a Seattle-based newsletter on in-flight entertainment, suggested that Jetblue's service would be a test case for the airline industry of live in-flight TV.
"If it works in the U.S., you might see it go on international routings when international satellite systems are put up," he said.
He also predicted that air travelers who track stocks on in-flight television would call their brokers from their airplane seats to make trades. And he said they would even be able to conduct such transactions on line once planes are equipped, also by satellite, with E-mail and Internet capabilities.
 
New Service to Italy
Air Europe, which is based in Milan, Italy, and 49.9% owned by SAir Group, the parent of Swissair, will begin service on the Pisa-Venice-New York (Kennedy) route July 26. Flights, which will operate every day but Wednesday, will serve fresh pasta, espresso, Italian pastries and ice cream in both economy and business classes. The carrier is offering an introductory round-trip economy-class fare to either Venice or Pisa for $425, with some restrictions, through Sept. 30.
 
For What Can Ail You
Cadogan Guides has published the second edition of "Bugs, Bites and Bowels," a medical book for travelers by Dr. Jane Wilson-Howarth, an expedition doctor and parasitologist. It covers everything from food-related illnesses to skin infections and motion sickness, and contains charts on tropical diseases and data on immunizations. Distributed in the United States by Globe Pequot Press, it costs $9.95.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Food Business Offsets Soft Tobacco Sales

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest tobacco company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings, excluding charges, rose nearly 3 percent as its Kraft food unit increased sales and cut costs, softening declines in cigarette profits.
The company, which makes Marlboro cigarettes, Maxwell House coffee and Miller beer, said profit excluding charges was $2.06 billion, or 85 cents a diluted share, compared with $2 billion, or 82 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. The results met analysts' expectations, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. 
 Revenue rose 4.3 percent, to $19.81 billion from $18.99 billion. Net earnings, including one-time items, were up 16.7 percent, to $2.03 billion, or 84 cents a share, from $1.74 billion, or 71 cents a share, a year ago.
Kraft, with a product line that includes Velveeta and Miracle Whip, surged on higher sales from new products and a cost-cutting push begun in 1997. Its North America profit rose 7 percent in the quarter. Kraft accounts for almost a third of Philip Morris's annual profit.
"Kraft has terrific brand franchises, and they've been very effective in reducing costs," said Marc Cohen, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Philip Morris's earnings were dragged down by its flagship tobacco business, where sales and profits fell because of higher prices in the United States and falling currencies and weakened economies in Eastern Europe and Latin America.
The company, based in New York, warned three weeks ago that its profit this year would be less than some analysts had forecast because of falling cigarette sales abroad and currency effects.
Shares of Philip Morris fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $37.3125. Its shares have fallen 30 percent this year after two big jury awards in smoking-related cases against the company and an expected suit from the Federal Government.
Cigarette unit sales in the United States fell 9.6 percent because of higher prices to pay for a $206 billion legal settlement with states. Still, that was less than the 10.4 percent decline in industrywide unit sales.
Domestic tobacco profit fell 3.9 percent on a $1.1 billion payment for the settlement and a promotion offering a 35-cent-a-pack discount during a five-week period in the quarter.
Foreign tobacco unit sales fell 6.1 percent, as sales dropped an aggregate 32 percent in Russia, the rest of Eastern Europe, Venezuela, Brazil and in its worldwide duty-free business. The declines offset a 6.7 percent rise in more profitable markets in Western Europe and Japan.
Philip Morris also benefited from a 13 percent rise in profit at its Miller beer unit on newly acquired brands and increased profit margins.

HEADLINE: Arthur Katz, 91, the Maker Of Corgi Toy Cars, Is Dead

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Arthur Katz, whose Corgi brand of miniature cars thrilled a generation of children, many of whom became collectors as adults, died on June 25 near his home in London. He was 91.
Before Mr. Katz introduced the Corgi line in 1956, most die-cast metal toy cars were fairly crude. Many companies simply painted the zinc-alloy forms that were pressed from molds and added wheels. But Mr. Katz's engineers and designers added details like plastic windshields and diamond-crystal headlights as well as gadgets and gimmicks like spring-mounted wheels and doors and hoods and trunks that opened. 
 Corgi's best seller was a model of the Aston Martin DB5 sports car, the auto driven by James Bond in the 1964 film "Goldfinger." As in the movie, the Corgi model had rotating license plates, a steel screen that sprang up to protect the back windshield from bullets fired by hostile pursuers, hub caps with Ben Hur-style tire slashers, machine gun turrets that popped out from behind the headlights, and best of all, an ejection seat that sent a tiny plastic passenger hurtling skyward through the car's roof.
At its peak in the early 1970's, Mr. Katz's company, Mettoy Ltd., employed 3,500 workers.
"I remember going to the factory in Swansea in South Wales," said Eugene McKeown, the director of sales at Reeves International Inc. in Pequannock, N.J., which is the United States distributor for Corgi. "It was like General Motors. There were people creating thousands and thousands of cars."
Mr. Katz retired in the mid-1970's. By the end of the decade, Mettoy was in trouble. Britain's high inflation and the soaring value of its currency had made the company's toys much more expensive than those of Asian rivals. "There was no way you could cut your costs fast enough," said Peter Katz, Arthur Katz's son, who was Mettoy's managing director.
Mettoy declared bankruptcy in 1983, as had several other famous British toy makers, including a rival, Matchbox. A group of its managers tried to resurrect the company, moving production to China. They later sold the company to Mattel Inc., which, in turn, sold it to another management group in 1995. It is now a private company based in Britain called Corgi Classics.
Since the 1970's, the demand for toy cars has shrunk, as children's tastes have switched to action figures and video games. Corgi cars are now sold primarily in specialty shops. But there has been a resurgence in demand among baby boomers the last five years.
Corgi cars that sold for $5 and $6 in the 1970's now retail for $30 to $40 new, while originals from the 1960's and 70's in mint condition can sell for several hundred dollars. "Die cast is among the hottest categories of collectibles right now," said Chris Byrne, editor of Toy Report, a weekly newsletter.
Mr. Katz was born in Johannesburg to German parents in 1908. When he was 12, he and his mother moved to Nuremberg, then the center of the German toy industry, after his father's death.
Upon completing his schooling and serving an apprenticeship at one of the city's toy export companies, Mr. Katz joined Tipp & Company, a maker of pressed-tin toys that was owned by Philip Ullmann, who was his mother's cousin.
In 1933, after Hitler came to power, Mr. Katz, who was Jewish and held a British passport, having been born in South Africa, emigrated to England. Mr. Ullmann joined him there, and together they founded Mettoy.
The company had a quick start but was soon diverted to war production. After World War II, Mr. Katz began focusing on the export market. "He was an extremely good negotiator," Peter Katz said, "which means that he was good at reaching agreements with people whereby they felt comfortable with it, and the company felt comfortable with it."
Besides his son, Mr. Katz is survived by his third wife, Agnes, and a daughter, Susan Wolff, all of London.
Although Mettoy was never the largest British toy manufacturer, Mr. Katz became the industry's leader, serving as head of the British Toy Manufacturers' Association in the 1950's and 1970's.
He showed his devotion to his adopted country by naming the Corgi brand after the breed of dog most favored by the British royal family. In turn, he was awarded the Order of the British Empire in 1961 and was made a Commander of the British Empire in 1973.
In one of the more curious episodes in Mr. Katz's life, he was appointed a colonel in the British Army in 1946 and dispatched to Germany to see if there was anything that Britain could salvage from what remained of the German toy industry.
He found little of value but did get the chance to return to Tipp, which had been expropriated by the Nazis after Mr. Ullmann fled.
"He had the pleasure," his son recalled, "of dismissing the man appointed by the Nazis to run it."

HEADLINE: Camden Officials Ask State to Take Over Daily Operations of City

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Noting that Camden's increasing dependence on state aid had effectively destroyed local political control, the City Council voted yesterday to press the state to take over day-to-day operations of the city.
Meeting in an extraordinary session yesterday afternoon, the City Council approved, by a 5-to-1 vote with a single member absent, a resolution introduced by Mayor Milton Milan calling for a state takeover. 
 The dramatic step by the elected officials of the city of 87,000 people came just a day after they had taken the equally dramatic step of filing for Federal bankruptcy protection under Chapter 9. That filing was an attempt to hold creditors at bay and to highlight the city's plight as it tries to close a $12 million gap in its current $110 million budget.
"What the Mayor is saying is that he will step aside and let the state take over because if they are fiscally responsible then they ought to be held politically responsible as well," said John Misci, the city attorney, who was preparing to move yesterday afternoon or today in state court to request the takeover. "Let them draw up the budget and defend it to voters and tell them why there isn't enough money to clean streets, repair sidewalks and demolish buildings."
While state officials had no immediate reaction to the latest city move in the escalating war of words, Jane M. Kenny, Commissioner of State Department of Community Affairs, did say that the Monday bankruptcy filing by the city was not only reckless but illegal because it first required that it get state permission. Consequently, she said, the State Attorney General will file a motion today in Federal Bankruptcy Court to have the city petition dismissed.
"Really?" Mr. Misci said simply in response.
Both the bankruptcy filing and the challenge to the state come a week after Mayor Milan and other city officials declined to grant the state sweeping powers to audit their spending and impose fiscal and management changes in exchange for granting them the additional budget balancing funds they need. The conditions, Mr. Misci said, would hamstring Mayor Milan and any elected official who followed him.
The funds were part of the Distressed Cities Act passed by the State Legislature last month and intended to aid five financially strapped cities in New Jersey: Camden, Jersey City, Paterson, East Orange and Irvington. All of the cities with the exception of Camden agreed to the auditing and revamping conditions. When Camden declined, the state not only withdrew the $12 million but withheld $50 million more in funds scheduled to be deposited into city bank accounts. About 70 percent of the city's budget comes from various state and Federal sources.
City officials said that there was no threat of immediate service disruptions or layoffs. Mr. Misci said that the city had enough cash on hand to operate most services at current levels for the next 30 days.
The increasingly acrimonious tone of the exchanges between Camden and state officials hinted at hard feelings that have accumulated over the years as the city has watched its tax base and manufacturing-based economy erode. It has become increasingly dependent on state aid as its population has grown poorer. And there were management problems and occasional corruption charges.
But in the last two decades, said Robert Bailey, a professor of public administration at the Camden campus of Rutgers University, the city has had to give over areas of control to meet conditions for state or Federal aid: its parking authority went to the state, its housing and development programs went to the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, its Empowerment Zone went to independent bodies and its police department went to the county prosecutor.
"This is the capstone of the slow teasing away of the managerial authority of the city," said Mr. Bailey, referring to the auditing and revamping requirements of the Distressed Cities Act. "There is some disingenuousness on the part of the state, which could have upgraded City Hall management skills and given them some breathing space to instill fiscal discipline. But the whole sense of the state's role over the years has been punitive."
Angel Fuentes, a three-term member of the Council, echoed the frustration felt by officials and some residents of the city, calling recent state actions "politics as usual at the expense of our constituents." He added, "We just don't see a light at the end of this tunnel."

HEADLINE: Euro, Braking Its Slide, Rises On the Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Europe's single currency rallied sharply against the dollar yesterday after a key economic report showed business confidence in Germany growing much more than expected. In contrast, the dollar climbed against the Japanese yen after the Bank of Japan sold yen for dollars through the Federal Reserve.
For the beleaguered euro, the new currency that has dropped as much as 13 percent since its introduction in January, the rally may signal that it has reached a bottom. But what kind of rebound may be ahead is unclear. 
 For the yen, the Japanese intervention was aimed at preventing the currency's value from rising too quickly. This year's rally in the Japanese stock market, and signs that the economy may be turning around, have led many investors to jump back into stocks and into the yen needed to buy them. But a big rally in the yen would make Japanese exporters less competitive abroad and put a drag on an economic rebound.
The euro, in trading yesterday, was worth $1.04130, up from $1.02940 Monday. Its low for the year was $1.0136 last Wednesday. Against the yen, the dollar climbed to 118.95 yen, from 117.80 on Monday.
The spark for yesterday's rally by the euro, which represents the currencies of 11 nations, was a report by the Ifo economic research institute of Munich that put its business confidence index for Germany, the largest economy in Europe, at 92.9 in June, up from a revised 90.5 in May. The rise was much sharper than analysts expected.
In addition, interest rates in Europe have recently been rising. While interest rates are still higher in the United States, the narrowing of the gap increases the euro's attractiveness to investors. And in recent comments, leaders of the European Central Bank have hinted that their next move will be to raise interest rates.
But it will take further confirmation that the economies of Germany and other European nations are turning around before many analysts will be ready to declare that the euro can climb back to its January level of $1.17, and higher.
Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston, said he expected the euro to rally in the short term. But he has not changed his long-term outlook. In fact, BankBoston is still predicting that the euro will drop below $1.00 by the end of the year.
The intervention to weaken the yen against the dollar yesterday was prompted in part by the yen's sharp rise on Monday, when it jumped 2.3 percent against the dollar. That rally, analysts said, was started by speculation, which no official confirmed, that American officials had told the Japanese that the United States would not help them slow the appreciation of their currency.
To some that meant that the new Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, did not support the strong-dollar policy of his predecessor, Robert E. Rubin. After the intervention yesterday, Mr. Summers said the United States' policy favoring a strong dollar had not changed.
But analysts do not think that the intervention by the Bank of Japan alone can keep the yen from getting stronger. Yesterday's yen selling was the sixth time that Japan has intervened since June 10, when the yen was 118.96 to the dollar, according to Bloomberg News.
"This slows down the recovery of the yen against the dollar," said Karen E. Parker, currency strategist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. She predicts that the yen will rally to a range of 110 to 115 to the dollar in the next 6 to 12 months.
It is not unusual for one central bank to intervene in the currency markets on behalf of another central bank, and usually such a move does not signal any policy change by the central bank that is asked to intervene. The Bank of Japan probably used the Federal Reserve yesterday because Japanese markets were closed for a holiday and on Monday the yen jumped back to the 118 level, where the intervention process began on June 10.
The intervention would have been more significant if the Fed were doing it for its own policy reasons in conjunction with the Bank of Japan, as it had in June 1998. Then, the Fed joined the Japanese by intervening to support the yen when it was falling sharply, threatening to worsen a global economic crisis.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Deficit Set a Record During May

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
A surge of imports driven by the continued strength of the American economy pushed the United States trade deficit to another record in May, more than $21 billion, fueled both by rising oil prices and growing evidence that China is using exports to support its lagging economy.
The China deficit comes at a politically inopportune time for the Clinton Administration: Next week, the House of Representatives is expected to vote on a one-year renewal of China's preferential trade status. While the House is expected to approve the measure, the rising deficit with China -- it totaled more than $23 billion in the first five months of 1999 -- further complicates a relationship already deeply strained by the accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and China's renewed threats to use force if necessary to keep Taiwan from declaring itself an independent state. 
 The trade deficit is also one of the few economic indicators that Republican Presidential candidates can seize on to argue that not all is well with the American economy. But it is, in fact, a byproduct of American economic health; with unemployment at record lows, low-cost imports have helped keep inflation near zero.
"The May trade figures reflect the continuing large gap between the strong growth in the United States and weaker conditions in many foreign countries," Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said today. He estimated that the deficit was running at an annual rate of $224.8 billion, which would be nearly 37 percent higher than last year's record, $164.3 billion. China is not the only cause. The trade deficit with Japan remains large, though it dropped slightly in May, and there is a rising deficit with Canada and Mexico, the two other members of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The size of the May deficit surprised many economists and led a few today to lower their predictions for American economic growth in the second quarter a bit. But perhaps more important, it was a strong indication that the American consumer spending binge is moving ahead unabated, which is bound to worry the Federal Reserve.
"Five years ago if we had seen numbers like this, what you would have heard on Capitol Hill was politicians blaming the Japanese and the Chinese," said Richard Medley, who heads Medley Global Advisors, an international investment firm in New York. "Now what you hear more often is that this proves we are spending too much and saving too little."
In fact, a number of economists and American officials are increasingly concerned that the accumulating current account deficit could ultimately hurt the value of the dollar -- and that, in turn, could set off an international exodus from the stock market.
The Japanese, meanwhile, are clearly worried about the effects of a weakening dollar -- not on the United States but on their own hobbled economy. They intervened Monday night to weaken the yen and prop up the dollar, in hopes of making their own exports cheaper on world markets. While the purchase was carried out through the New York Federal Reserve, acting as Japan's agent, there are increasing signs that the United States and Japan are at odds on exchange rate policy. A stronger dollar would further hurt declining American exports.
Today's report suggested that the decline is modest, but is made worse by the growing demand for foreign-made cars, crude oil and medium-technology electronics. Oil prices increased in May to an average of $14.54 a barrel, the Commerce Department said, from $12.71 a barrel in April.
Exports decreased to $77.6 billion from $78.2 billion in April, but they were up fractionally from May 1998. Imports increased to $98.9 billion from $96.8 billion in April and $92 billion in May 1998.
The latest figures suggest that some of the areas that the Clinton Administration concentrated the hardest on bolstering during Mr. Clinton's first term in office -- autos, auto parts and machinery -- are the exports now in greatest decline. They are also the products that are being imported in increasing numbers. Administration officials who once boasted of the auto and auto parts agreement they reached with Japan in 1995, after a trade dispute that nearly resulted in an embargo on Japanese luxury cars, now rarely discuss the subject.
Nor is there much discussion from the White House about how to deal with the complex trade problems with China. Over all, Chinese exports to the world are in decline. But their continued rise here suggests that the United States, now more than ever, has become the market of last resort for the Chinese.
The politics of the trade deficit with China are messy. Opponents of President Clinton's China policy -- on both the left and the right -- say the trade figures show that the President's decision to delink human rights and the annual renewal of China's trade status has helped neither dissidents nor American companies. Arrests by Chinese authorities continue -- there was a major crackdown today -- and exports to China are clearly not increasing.
Yet there has been little real resistance to the renewal of what was once called "most favored nation" trade status, and which has been delicately renamed "normal trade relations." American companies have argued annually on Capitol Hill that unless China has the benefit of low tariffs on their imports here, the Chinese market will gradually be shut down for them.
If China and the United States reach an agreement this year on Beijing's entry to the World Trade Organization, the terms of its move to join the group should, in theory at least, open more markets to American goods. But opponents on Capitol Hill, both those on the left who are concerned with China's human rights record and those on the right who see China as a growing threat, view its admission as a favor to the Chinese, and not one that will necessarily benefit American workers.

HEADLINE: Beijing Detains Leaders of Sect, Watchdog Says

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 20

 BODY:
In what could be the start of a broad crackdown, dozens of leaders of the Buddhist Law spiritual movement were detained by the police today in 14 Chinese cities, according to a Hong Kong-based human rights group.
At least 70 leaders of the group, which stunned authorities last April when 10,000 adherents silently materialized in a protest outside the Communist leaders' compound here, were picked up in a sweep that began Monday night, the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said. Arrests were reported in Beijing, Tianjin, Dalian and 11 other cities. 
 The rights group said the police searched the homes of the detainees, confiscating books about the rapidly growing movement and addresses of people who attended meetings.
The Chinese police would not confirm the reported detentions.
The group, known in Chinese as Falun Gong, combines traditional Chinese breathing and meditation exercises with the idiosyncratic blend of Buddhism and Taoism of its founder, Li Hongzhi, who lives in self-imposed exile in New York.
Falun Gong has posed a ticklish problem for the authorities since the demonstration on April 25. The group was protesting local officials' treatment of its members and demanding official recognition, which has not been granted.
The Government normally keeps a tight leash on mass organizations. But Falun Gong, whose rapidly increasing members are devoted to its mixture of martial arts and mysticism, could be a potent force in a country that faces dislocating social and economic changes.
Most alarming about the April demonstration -- the largest protest in Beijing since the 1989 democracy movement -- was that in a country where where public gatherings are tightly regulated, Falun Gong was able to mobilize thousands of followers without warning, leaving the authorities struggling to understand the extent of the group's reach.
Falun Gong insists it is apolitical, but the role of quasi-religious groups in fomenting political rebellion throughout Chinese history leave officials wary of its intentions.
Although the official news media did not report this week's detentions, officials in Beijing seemed well aware of the ramifications.
At Zhongnanhai, the sprawling walled compound where President Jiang Zemin and other leaders live, a huge police contingent patrolled the streets tonight on a sultry summer evening. The western edge of the compound, where the Falun Gong members massed in April, was closed to motor traffic.
Rumors of a crackdown against the group have circulated widely in recent weeks, despite assurances by Chinese officials that it would be left alone. In a meeting with Falun Gong members last month, a senior Government official warned the group not to "promote superstition" or "destroy social order."
Beijing appears to have been laying the groundwork for a crackdown. Over the past two weeks, state-controlled newspapers and television have carried a steady stream of commentaries about the dangers of superstition, particularly among Communist Party members.
In a front-page commentary on Monday -- its fifth on the topic since the April demonstration -- the Communist Party newspaper, People's Daily, blamed lax officials for the rampant spread of superstition. Newspapers and television reports have also begun celebrating people who they say overcame "feudal superstition" -- for example, a rural village where residents gave up rituals like hanging mirrors over doors.
Fears of harassment prompted Mr. Li, the founder and leader of Falun Gong, to move to the United States last year. On June 2 he said in a letter posted on the Internet that his followers were being treated unjustly. He suggested that China was negotiating to have him extradited in return for a $500 million reduction in China's trade surplus with the United States.
Although there were no signs of protest in Beijing today, several hundred Falun Gong members demonstrated in Dalian and two smaller cities, the Hong Kong rights group said. And in Hong Kong this afternoon about 150 people marched to the local branch of the official New China News Agency, where they delivered a letter appealing to the Chinese Government to release the detained Falun Gong leaders.
"We wanted to express our shock and concern on this matter," said Sophie Xiao, a spokeswoman for the group in Hong Kong.
Ms. Xiao said she spoke today with Falun Gong members in Beijing who were worried that the Government might declare the group illegal. While not officially recognized, Falun Gong has existed in a kind of gray area, as the Government has tried to avoid a confrontation.
"We're not trying to threaten anybody," Ms. Xiao said. "People who don't understand us may feel threatened because of the number of people who are doing it, and because of how quickly we have grown."
Indeed, from a standing start seven years ago, Falun Gong now claims 100 million members worldwide, though this cannot be confirmed.
Mr. Li, 48, a former grain bureau clerk in northeastern China, began his metamorphosis into a spiritual leader in the late 1980's, when he discovered the ancient practice of qigong (pronounced chee-gong), in which people seek to channel their vital energies to improve their health and even heal others.
By combining qigong with his own mystical ideas, Mr. Li fashioned an all-embracing philosophy that preaches clean living. Eschewing politics, followers of Falun Gong work hard to portray themselves simply as good people.
The detentions, and the heavy police presence in Beijing tonight, suggest that the authorities fear otherwise.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. LEADERS TRY TO STEM A REVOLT OVER BIG TAX CUT

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Republican leaders in the House scrambled today to head off a revolt by party moderates and avert a humiliating defeat on their signature issue of tax cuts.
With a vote on the biggest tax cut since 1981 scheduled for Wednesday on the House floor, Republicans said it was unclear whether enough of the 20 or so moderates would break with the leadership to defeat or block passage of the bill, the centerpiece of the party's domestic agenda. 
 The moderates have been pressing Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and his deputies to scale back the 10-year, $864 billion tax-cutting package approved last week by the Ways and Means Committee, saying the bill leaves none of the projected Federal budget surplus to help reduce the national debt or address issues like education.
The leadership agreed to cut the package to $792 billion, the size of a corresponding bill taken up today by the Senate Finance Committee, both to mollify the moderates and to sidestep a procedural problem. But the Republican moderates, led by Representative Michael N. Castle of Delaware, insisted today on a package of no more than $514 billion.
At a lunchtime meeting, the moderates listened to pleas for support from Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the Budget Committee. Tonight, the moderates were summoned to a meeting with Mr. Hastert, who also urged their support.
But afterward, Mr. Castle repeated that he would not vote for the $792 billion package, and that enough other moderates shared his view to block its passage.
"As of right now, clearly they would not be able to pass the bill," Mr. Castle said.
Republican aides said a preliminary count today showed that the leadership remained short of the 218 votes need to insure passage, and that intensive horse trading was under way. But such jockeying is common before high-stakes votes, and senior Republicans said they were confident of getting enough votes to pass the bill.
"We will have the votes," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. "We're talking with all of our members and listening to all of our members."
The situation is the latest illustration of the difficulty that Republicans are having maintaining a working majority in the House, where the party is tugged constantly between factions, each of which is capable of blocking legislation. The leadership's situation has been made more difficult by the defection from the party last week of Representative Michael P. Forbes of Long Island, who abruptly announced on Friday that he was joining the Democrats.
Republicans have 222 members in the House. There are 211 Democrats, plus one independent, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont, who almost always votes with the Democrats. There is one vacancy.
As a result, the votes of as few as five Republicans can deprive the party of a majority, assuming all Democrats and the independent stick together. Mr. Castle said there were at least a half-dozen moderates intent on voting against the $792 billion Republican package.
Emboldened by projections of rapidly growing Federal budget surpluses, Republican leaders had planned for this year's tax bill to be the vehicle for an ideologically charged showdown with Democrats and President Clinton over the size of the Government and the nation's priorities in an era of prosperity.
Although Mr. Clinton has signaled a willingness to discuss a compromise, he sent his top aides to Capitol Hill today to underscore his opposition to any plan approaching the size of the $792 billion package contemplated by the Republicans.
"The tax cuts that have been put on the table will represent a reversal of course that would put the economic strategy we have been pursuing and the prosperity it has brought us at risk," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary.
In the Senate, Republicans reached out to Democrats by writing a bill geared more to the middle class than the House version is. Democrats have responded with compromise overtures of their own, with a few centrist Democrats saying today that they would support a tax cut of around $500 billion.
But there has been no effort at bipartisanship in the House, where issues tend to be more polarized. The problem for Republicans in the House has been almost completely from within their own ranks.
Already Mr. Archer has had to rework the bill that passed the Ways and Means Committee to bring its cost down to $792 billion over 10 years. He said today that he had done so primarily by phasing in the bill's main components, its 10 percent reduction in income tax rates and its repeal of the inheritance tax on large estates, more slowly than he had originally contemplated. Mr. Archer was forced to make the changes because a larger bill would have been subject to parliamentary rules that would allow a filibuster in the Senate, further complicating the prospects for a tax cut.
But several moderates said the reduction to $792 billion from $864 billion was not enough to deal with their objections.
Many of the moderates are from the Northeast and from districts where voters are more centrist than those from Republican districts in other regions, particularly the South.
Representative Marge Roukema, a Republican from New Jersey, said she was opposed to the $792 billion tax package because it was too big and because it was based on projections of Federal budget surpluses that were likely to prove inaccurate.
"What I strongly recommended is that we postpone action until we get to a position where we have consensus on this and get a more realistic bill," she said. "I think the leadership has been somewhat surprised at the definitive nature of the criticism and the number of people willing to speak up. I want Denny Hastert and the Republican leadership to succeed, but we can't have only a minority from the South and West setting policy."
The moderates are not the only headache for the leadership. A group of social conservatives is pressing for the tax package to be changed to reflect their No. 1 tax issue, the repeal of the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that hurts many two-income couples. But the conservatives said they were unlikely to withhold their support for the main bill over the issue.

HEADLINE: The Empty U.S. Seat at Mideast Talks: A Boon for All

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
One of the enduring images of the late and unlamented period in American-Israeli relations that ended with Ehud Barak's victory over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is that of a senior State Department envoy with a tape measure marking off the width of Shuhadah Road in Hebron, in the West Bank.
Such was the depth of United States involvement in relations between Israelis and Palestinians that an official from Washington was flown in to determine the exact distance, to the inch, that should separate Jewish settlers from Palestinians in the divided town. 
 If anything changed as a result of Mr. Barak's visit to Washington, which ended today, it was this conception of the American role in Israel's dealings with its neighbors.
No longer, Mr. Barak and President Clinton pledged, will the United States serve as full-time intermediary, referee and highway engineer in relations between Israel and Syria, the Palestinians or other Arabs. The United States -- at least in the early stages -- is prepared to serve the same function as the father of the bride: It will provide the hall, toast the newlyweds and pick up the tab.
Important roles, to be sure, but far different from the parts Mr. Clinton and his aides played last October at the Wye Plantation talks, which ranged from drafting language for Israeli-Palestinian agreements to providing Central Intelligence Agency officers to enforce the deal. The new arrangement foresees a more active role for Washington only if the talks break down, as they almost certainly will at some point, Administration officials said this week.
"The United States should not come up with its own decisions how to resolve these issues," Vice President Al Gore said today after meeting with Mr. Barak. "In terms of trying to spell out the terms, that is not our role."
There are risks in this approach, which is a return to the style that guided United States efforts at Mideast peacemaking during the Government of Yitzhak Rabin, Mr. Barak's mentor and Mr. Clinton's friend, who was assassinated in 1995.
There is no guarantee that Israel can make peace on its own with Syria -- with which it has technically been at war for more than 30 years -- or with the Palestinians, who have very different views from most Israelis on sovereignty, Jerusalem and refugee issues.
But the rewards of a less intrusive American role are great as well, for Israel and its negotiating partners, and for Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Barak has indicated a desire to engage directly with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat without day-to-day American intervention.
Mr. Clinton, for his part, says he is happy to serve as host and caterer, providing the peace table at which the parties can dine alone. The catering bill will run to hundreds of millions of dollars -- to finance the prospective Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and the Golan Heights, to subsidize improvements in Israel's military, to build housing, roads and ports for Palestinians, and perhaps one day, to bring Syria into the 21st-century economy.
But the economic benefits for the United States are considerable, too. Israel just this week announced its biggest arms deal ever, a $2.5 billion order for 50 new F-16E fighters and an option to buy 60 more warplanes for $2 billion. That will preserve thousands of jobs at Lockheed Martin and underwrite refinements in American aircraft development at a time when the Pentagon is cutting back on its fighter purchases.
It is expected that American companies will also have a role in the big-dollar improvements in Palestinian territories. In addition, peace could lower the American military costs of monitoring the region, though Iran and Iraq continue to pose threats.
And that is not to mention Mr. Clinton's interest in establishing a legacy as a peacemaker in his remaining months in office and maybe winning that coveted Nobel Prize.
Mr. Clinton said last week that "everyone knows what the big issues are" in Middle East negotiations. Progress stalled under Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Clinton acknowledged, but he said Mr. Barak's election "gives the United States the opportunity to facilitate the process, something we've been trying to do for well over two decades."
At the same time, he said, any lasting agreement must come from mutual trust and not under the duress of threats or inducements from outside.
A senior Administration official who handles Middle East affairs said the American role in regional affairs is "evolving" and will depend on Mr. Barak's success in winning the faith of his negotiating partners.
"The key determinant is the amount of trust between the parties so that we don't have to do the tedious job of intermediating between the sides," the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
"If they aren't talking, they'll come to us and say, 'We need you.' But our preference is to encourage them to speak directly, and we are the safety net, to propose bridging proposals and to provide enormous political, economic and diplomatic assistance to put the whole process in shape."
As eager as Mr. Clinton is for a dramatic peace deal, and as eager as Mr. Barak appears to restart the process, it is unlikely that the coming weeks or months will yield a a garlanded flight of doves.
Mr. Barak has said he will be able to judge the likelihood of success 15 months from now, just in time for the final lap of the American Presidential campaign. But he has cautioned against expectations of a miracle.
A senior Administration Middle East adviser said: "Forget any notion of major breakthroughs in the next few months. I don't think people should be expecting White House signing ceremonies any time soon."

HEADLINE: Israeli Tries to Assure Arafat On West Bank Withdrawals

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 20

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ehud Barak tried to reassure Yasir Arafat today that Israel will move more quickly to complete withdrawals from the West Bank than the 15-month target he set for an overall Middle East peace settlement.
On the last day of his maiden voyage to Washington as the Israeli leader, Mr. Barak was replying to complaints today by Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, that the 15-month timetable was unacceptable for carrying out the accords signed in Wye, Md. last fall. 
 "I fully agree with him," Mr. Barak said. "There is no reason to wait. We do intend to implement the Wye accords. I will check with him."
The Wye accords called for Israel to withdraw from another 13.1 percent of the West Bank. But that was stalled under the last Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and it has been a major concern of the Palestinian leader.
As a sign of the pressure on Mr. Arafat to get Israel to complete the withdrawals, the Palestine Liberation Organization's Executive Council said in Ramallah Sunday night that the Wye accords should be carried out in their entirety before negotiations begin on so-called final status talks. Those talks will address the boundaries of a Palestinian entity, the disposition of Jerusalem and the return of refugees.
Mr. Barak spent most of today visiting members of Congress, where he delivered one of the messages of his visit: that he intends to stand firm in negotiations he hopes to have with the Palestinians and Syrians on not returning to the borders before the 1967 war and that Jerusalem will remain the capital of Israel.
The Republicans in Congress, who were a bulwark of support for Mr. Netanyahu, are key to the passage of the Administration's requests for financial aid to Israel -- including $1.2 billion tied to the Wye accords that President Clinton said this week he wanted expedited.
Some outspoken supporters of Mr. Netanyahu said today that they were impressed with the new Israeli leader. Representative Tom DeLay, the Texas Republican who is majority whip, said after meeting Mr. Barak that he liked what he heard.
The Speaker of the House, Representative Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, released a statement that echoed some of Mr. Barak's recent remarks, saying that Israel -- not the United States -- should be the final decision-maker about its future.
"As you pursue your policies of economic and political security for Israel, we in Congress firmly believe that in the final analysis, Israel must determine its own destiny," Mr. Hastert said.
Mr. Barak's first encounter on Capitol Hill this morning was with 30 Jewish members of Congress, many of whom support legislation that calls for moving the American Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem in the near future. Congress enacted a law in 1995 that called on the Administration to move the embassy by May 31 of this year, but President Clinton used a waiver provision in the law to delay the move.
Some members of Congress support legislation that would repeal Mr. Clinton's waiver. But at his meeting with Congressmen today, Mr. Barak gave a muted response to a question about the proposal, a participant said. The Prime Minister said the legislation should not be pushed now, but he added that he would not openly oppose it.
Israeli officials have said that mandating the move of the embassy before negotiations are completed with the Palestinians on the final status of Jerusalem would make the negotiations almost impossibly difficult.
Mr. Barak was also asked about the transfer of nuclear technology from Russia to Iran, a congressman said. The Prime Minister, a former chief of staff of the Israel Defense Forces, gave a detailed analysis of the seriousness of the problem and was supportive of the Clinton Administration's efforts to discourage the Russians, the congressman said.
At the State Department, Mr. Barak met with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright for the second time during his visit. They discussed her scheduled trip to the Middle East, which is expected to help set the stage for the opening of negotiations between Israel and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.
Ms. Albright's trip, originally scheduled for the first week of August, was moved back to the middle of the month to give the Israelis more time to consult with the Palestinians and the Syrians and among themselves on how negotiations on an overall settlement might proceed, Administration officials said.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Jets' Johnson Brings His Skills to a New Field

BYLINE: By KEN GURNICK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 20

 BODY:
Helping revitalize an offense is one thing. Keyshawn Johnson's off-season task is to help revitalize the decaying neighborhood of his youth.
Johnson, a Pro Bowl receiver for the Jets, is part of a team of developers planning to turn a 23-acre site in the South-Central neighborhood, abandoned since the city's 1992 riots, into a $53 million shopping center and commercial project. 
 "This will allow me to better understand who I am and where I came from," Johnson said today. "This will also give people a better idea that there's more to me than just football."
Taking a cue from Magic Johnson, the former Los Angeles Lakers star who has become a prominent urban developer, Keyshawn Johnson not only lent his name to the project, but also made what he calls a substantial investment. He would not say how much, but it is believed to be in the $250,000 to $500,000 range.
Johnson, who led Jets receivers in catches (83), yards (1,131) and touchdowns (10) last season, said he would be active as a developer only until July 29, when he reports to the Jets' summer training camp for his fourth season. He is working under a six-year, $16.5 million contract he signed after being the first player taken in the 1996 draft.
Johnson, 26, has been a proponent of City Councilman Mark Ridley-Thomas's pet project: returning professional football to Memorial Coliseum, where Johnson played for the University of Southern California. Johnson's agent and sports lawyer, Jerome Stanley, is also active in that drive. Ridley-Thomas presented the development proposal to Johnson and Stanley as a business and civic opportunity.
"This is a man who has done well professionally and returned to help revitalize his neighborhood that supported him and loved him," Ridley-Thomas said. "He is one of the emerging sports figures that is community-minded and sets an example for others with the capacity to invest."
Johnson said that there was nothing like this proposed development in the South-Central community, and that when he was approached to participate he made one demand.
"I just didn't want to be a token name, a celebrity from football," Johnson said. "I wanted to be involved from start to finish. I see what Magic has done. He's been a huge plus in me getting involved."
Magic Johnson has invested in movie theaters in several big cities, typically in underserved, black communities. He has expanded his efforts and, for example, is part owner of a Starbucks in Harlem.
Chris Hammond, one of Keyshawn Johnson's partners in the South-Central project, said the name recognition was critical to the project's success.
"It's difficult to attract tenants to a tough part of the inner city, there's a phobia for a long time here," said Hammond, the chairman of Capital Vision Equities and a partner with Katell Properties. "Keyshawn has given the project the notoriety it needs to get people to take a fresh look at the community. And he's got real money in this deal. I couldn't do this without him."
The development, which will be called Chesterfield Square, will be anchored by a 150,000-square-foot Home Depot and will include a major grocery store and a pharmacy, with a target date for opening of Christmas 2000.
It will be one and a half miles from the flash point of the 1992 riots and is the largest project to date of a $292 million economic redevelopment that followed the riots.
"I lived a half-mile from here," Johnson said, looking past a graffiti-lined fence along a railroad track that borders the property. "My aunt lives a couple blocks that way, right by that palm tree over there. This community is desperate for this type of center. We have a chance to bring jobs here.
"I could have invested in any community, but why not the one where I was born and raised? Why wouldn't I?"
Stanley said Johnson's involvement fit with a strategy to position Johnson as more than a football player. That includes the controversial book Johnson wrote after his rookie season, "Just Give Me the Damn Ball," as well as an upscale restaurant that Johnson and some partners opened six weeks ago in Beverly Hills called Reign.
"He pulled himself up by the bootstraps from urban America," Stanley said, adding: "He's seen his neighborhood burned and scarred by riots. It would have been easy for him to invest in high-tech mutual funds, but it makes more sense to invest in his community."
Johnson insisted that business demands would not interfere with football.
"My life now is like two acts, football and nonfootball, and at the end of the month I go back to football," he said. "My focus will shift to New York and football takes over until, let's say, February. Then it's back to this business."
