HEADLINE: Cubans Now Choosing Smugglers Over Rafts

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 20

 BODY:
They used to be called balseros Spanish for "rafters" -- after the rickety crafts of plywood, inner tubes and empty oil drums they launched from the beaches of Cuba, praying that the homemade boats would hold together long enough to cross the treacherous Florida Straits.
They struggled ashore in the Florida Keys, at Palm Beach and on barrier islands in between, sunburned, half starved, dehydrated, telling stories of circling sharks and loved ones who vanished when their crafts came apart in the waves. In Miami, there are monuments to the ones who just disappeared. 
 Others, like Ray Dieppa, piled into fishing boats crowded with sick, terrified adults and sobbing children, and pushed off into uncertainty. Mr. Dieppa remembers gazing into the pitch-black night, almost 20 years ago, and wondering if he would ever see the United States.
"I am against the communist regime," he said, when asked why he had risked that passage.
It has not been that simple for a long time.
In the heaviest exodus since President Fidel Castro allowed 33,000 people to leave Cuba in 1994, more than 1,500 Cubans have made it ashore in South Florida so far this year. But increasingly, United States Coast Guard officials say, the Cubans are making their passage not on rafts or in fishing vessels but in the boats of smugglers, who bring them in close enough to swim ashore or launch a small dinghy.
The cost: as much as $8,000 per person.
In the same period, more than 1,000 Cubans have been stopped at sea and forced to return to their homeland in compliance with the so-called "wet-foot, dry-foot" policy that President Clinton put in place after the 1994 exodus. That policy allows Cubans who make it to United States shores to apply, ultimately, for asylum, but sends those picked up at sea back to Cuba. In all of 1998, 1,047 Cubans were stopped by the Coast Guard.
The policy, part of an agreement with President Castro to halt the 1994 exodus, has led to high drama at sea and on the beaches of South Florida, as Cubans try almost anything, including threatened self-immolation and suicide, to hold off the Coast Guard long enough to put at least a foot on dry sand.
"We had an incident a month ago in which a woman threatened to drown her baby if the Coast Guard crew members came closer," said Glenn Rosenholm, assistant district public affairs officer for the Coast Guard.
"This is not normal, not usual," Mr. Rosenholm said. "These are very, very volatile situations."

Increasing Poverty And Desperation
Life in Cuba has become increasingly difficult, because of both poverty and politics, recent arrivals say, so people are more desperate to flee.
Jose Martinez, 34, was one of the lucky ones. He reluctantly conceded that he was smuggled into South Florida in October with six others, for $8,000 each. But he does not apologize for doing anything that he could to leave Cuba.
Mr. Martinez said he and his relatives lived in a deteriorating house, without running water, in a neighborhood where, he said, informants turned in people who spoke against the Government, and sometimes even those who did not.
The story is well-worn in Cuban Miami, repeated with every boatload.
When he recalls life in Cuba, Mr. Martinez said, "I feel like crying."
It is no wonder, he and Cuban-Americans here say, that people will do almost anything to leave their island and cannot meekly accept being sent back, especially when they are in sight of land.
In the past few weeks, confrontations between the Coast Guard and the people they stop at sea and turn back have turned ugly.
Earlier this month, a Cuban doused himself, his boat and others in it with gasoline and threatened to set everyone on fire if the Coast Guard did not let him reach shore.
In the past two weeks, two groups of Cubans in small boats have jumped into the water, some miles from shore, instead of giving up to the Coast Guard.
On Friday, several men jumped into the water off Islamorada in the Florida Keys, saying they would rather drown than be sent back. They had to be rescued by Coast Guardsmen.
"They know they have to make it to land," said Cheryl Little, executive director of the Florida Immigrant Advocacy Center. "When they're getting this close, they're desperate. We can expect desperate people to do desperate things."
In just one day this past weekend, 56 Cubans made it ashore, some posing for photographs before heading to what has usually been a temporary detention with the immigration service. In the same 24-hour period, 24 Cubans were stopped at sea, some in sight of land, and sent home.
The most publicized landfall came on June 29 just off Surfside, north of Miami Beach, when six Cubans on a small boat were blasted by a Coast Guard water cannon as news helicopter thundered overhead, broadcasting live footage of the drama to Miami television stations, which interrupted afternoon soap operas with the story.
As the men tried to swim the 200 yards to shore, Coast Guardsmen shot pepper spray into their faces, as the cameras rolled and hundreds gathered on the beach, cheering the swimmers on. Two Cubans made it ashore, one running between the police before diving onto the sand.
A demonstration soon blocked a main causeway from Miami to Miami Beach, and more than 1,000 demonstrators marched on the adjacent Coast Guard office, chanting "Assassins!." As traffic jammed, Coast Guard officials relented, allowing the four other Cubans, who had been picked up in the water, to seek political asylum.
Less than a day later, all six were released from custody and were on the streets of Miami, being feted. On Independence Day, they shared a seafood dinner with Miami's Mayor, Joe Carollo.
 
Sympathy Still Won Despite New Method
As the six were being greeted as heroes against communism, the United States Border Patrol questioned why the men, who said they had rowed all the way from Cuba on a 14-foot boat, had shown no signs of dehydration or exposure, and their hands had no splinters or calluses.
Less than a week after they landed, a Miami artist fashioned a sculpture of a man diving for the sand and freedom as two police officers closed in. It was erected on the site of the Surfside confrontation.
"People are more sympathetic to the Cubans that arrive by themselves, struggling with a raft, than Cubans who arrive with a suntan and well-fed," said Jaime Suchlicki, director of the Institute for Cuban and Cuban-American Studies at the University of Miami.
But that is not a major issue in a Cuban American-dominated Miami, Mr. Suchlicki said.
Some, including a Cuban doctor who recently made it to Florida grimy and exhausted, are still coming the old-fashioned way, on their own boats. But while the ones who pay smugglers to deliver them are not regarded with quite the same hero status as those who made it on their own, there is little condemnation of them here in the Cuban community, where the hatred of Mr. Castro colors everything.
In fact, immigration officials say, the one-time rafters who came here years ago are largely financing the new wave of migrants.
Elena Freyre, executive director of the Miami office of the Cuban Committee for Democracy, said Cuban-Americans in Miami were largely footing the bill for this new migration, paying the smugglers to bring their relatives from Cuba. Most of the smugglers are probably of Cuban descent, Ms. Freyre said.
Some new arrivals have said they paid their own way, having saved for years.
And while many Cuban-Americans may still refer to them as balseros, they sometimes do so with a smile.
Mr. Dieppa said that it was wrong for the smugglers to make money off such suffering, but that he, like many others here, would accept what they saw as a lesser evil.
"If my family could afford it, I would want them to try," said Mr. Dieppa, now an editor at a South Florida television station, who still has family in Cuba.
Just because smugglers are bringing them in, it is no guarantee of a safe trip, Mr. Martinez said.
While some here in Miami wonder if the steady trickle of Cubans is a sign of another exodus like in 1994, experts on Cuban immigration say they doubt if it will get that large.
"This will die," Mr. Suchlicki said. "I don't think it's a permanent situation. It has to do with the toughening political situation."
 
A Growing Reaction To Lost Freedoms
The present exodus is also attributed to a general feeling that small freedoms won after Pope John Paul II's visit to Cuba last year have been taken away. Small business, vendors and even prostitutes have been forced to close up shop and every boat of refugees brings another story of increasing punishment and tightening Government control.
Another mass exodus can only come with Mr. Castro's blessing, said Steve Schnably, professor of International Law at the University of Miami. "If he makes it clear at any time that people can just leave the island, then you will have an exodus," Mr. Schnably said.
Cuba has already moved to quash the exodus, according to the state-controlled newspaper Granma, which said in an editorial: "Every desire to leave the country by safe and legal means will be permitted. Attempts by illegal means will categorically not be allowed."
Experts on immigration say the United States policy almost guarantees future altercations at sea, not only with the Cubans but also with Haitians who are still trying to make the sea passage to Florida. The Haitian economy is in shambles, and people there are, if anything, worse off than the Cubans, Haitian advocates said.
As for Cuban advocates in Miami, the once white-hot reaction to the Coast Guard's actions has cooled in the past few weeks.
"The Coast Guard is trapped in a difficult situation," said Ramon Saul Sanchez, a delegate with Movimiento Democracia in Miami, an anti-Castro group. But, Mr. Sanchez said, "the politics of applying migration laws have to be revised to become more humane."
In Miami, though, all the blame for most things sad and Cuban ultimately ends up at Mr. Castro's foot.
As long as he rules, said Ninoska Perez, a spokeswoman for the Cuban American National Foundation, the balseros will keep coming.
"A dictator of 40 years," she said, "does not change."

HEADLINE: Living the 8-Bit Dream in a 32-Bit World

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
AS a mathematician at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Steve Judd harnesses the power of Unix work stations and Cray supercomputers to detect and prevent the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons.
When he goes home, he basks in the light of his 15-year-old Commodore computer, a one-megahertz machine with 64 kilobytes of RAM. It can move chunks of data in the same size packages as a Nintendo Game Boy and has 3 percent of the memory capacity of a Palm III organizer. 
 Mr. Judd creates three-dimensional graphics on his obsolete Commodore and calls it a real programming challenge. "It's like building a radio from scratch," he said. "You are designing from the most fundamental level. You have to take advantage of every ounce of the computer."
Fender Tucker, who runs a Commodore software company called Loadstar, said, "Commodores are for people who aren't all that sure that the computer revolution has made our lives better."
Thousands of people appear to have turned to old computers (or stuck with them) out of a feeling of nostalgia, a desire for simplicity and an appreciation for classic design. In the realm of digital machines, where today's computer is out of date tomorrow, there can be great satisfaction in taking a digital Model T out for a spin.
Douglas Cotton, editor of Commodore World magazine, estimates that a million Commodores are still in service around the world. Their owners include people who remember their first computers more fondly than their first girlfriends (most users are men), as well as people who have handed them down to their children or have set up miniature computer museums in their basements, much to the dismay of their wives.
And it's not only the Commodore. Old Apple computers and Sinclair Spectrums are also popular.
"Some people like to drive classic cars, like the 60's-era Mustang or the original Beetle," said Scott Gamon, 24, who still uses an Apple II GS. "I think the main reason is that the cars are classic vehicles that made history. The Apple II computer is the same in the computer world."
Some owners are active users of the old computers, and some participate in international programming competitions. These are not people who can't afford a new computer or don't know how to use them. Many actually own up-to-date computers that are hundreds of times as fast and much more powerful than their old ones, but they keep their eight-bit machines around to remind them how they started with computers.
"If I didn't buy that machine with my paper-route money when I was 11, I likely wouldn't have gotten into computers, a university scholarship and a decent-paying job," said Robyn Harbron of Thunder Bay, Ontario.
Mr. Cotton, who is also technical director of Creative Micro Designs, a Commodore hardware company, said, "We have a number of people who have called us up saying, 'Windows is nice for work, but I miss that old Commodore.' "
A number of fans of eight-bit machines are sophisticated programmers who praise the computers' timeless elegance and efficiency. "You don't say Mozart, Shakespeare or van Gogh are good for their time," Mr. Judd said. "They are just plain good. I make the claim for the Commodore 64."
All software, whether Windows 98 or Lotus Notes or Doom, is based on simple mathematical calculations like addition and multiplication. Computers express information in binary numbers; each digit is a 0 or a 1, and each place is a power of 2. Eight-bit computers handle data in binary numbers that have eight digits. For large calculations, an eight-bit computer has to break down the problem into simpler pieces, and that is one factor that makes eight-bit computers slow, compared with modern 32-bit machines.
But the biggest reason for the sluggishness is that those old computer chips did not have many transistors, or switches, and the transistors they did have were far apart, lengthening the paths signals had to travel. Modern chips pack transistors tightly together to speed up processing times. In addition, internal clocks, which provide the heartbeat for computer instructions, are several hundred times faster in today's PCs than in yesterday's eight-bit computers.
Many users insist that the eight-bit classics are on the verge of becoming collectibles. Searches on auction sites like Ebay unearth hundreds of items in the classic realm, like floppy disks, printers and actual computers, for generally low prices.
Proponents of trailing-edge technology have their own magazines, conventions, weekly on-line discussions, Web sites and newsletters. In Europe, dozens of programmers meet regularly for competition parties, where they see who can stretch the capacities of the eight-bit computers the furthest. Some are on a crusade, contending that the old computers should be preserved for posterity. The Vintage Technology Center, a computer nostalgia group in Santa Clara, Calif., recently announced plans to build a supercomputer out of Commodore 64's. "Sixty-four 64's" is its motto.
All of that would be mere nostalgia, or a hobby like collecting Pez memorabilia, except that the eight-bit die-hards actually use their computers. In a sense, their devotion to the simple machines is an active refutation of the Wintel world of quick obsolescence that frustrates many computer users.
In the early days, programmers looked for creative software solutions instead of glitzier hardware. "In a way it was simpler back then," said Lane Denson, a Nashville farmer who has set up a computer museum in his basement. "You didn't have 20 or 30 sound cards and you didn't have to worry about upgrading every other week."
At a time when mega, giga and tetra are the popular prefixes, the software available for the kilobyte clunkers is surprisingly sophisticated. Commodore users can send faxes via modems, use laser printers and use a mouse to maneuver through an operating system that looks a lot like Windows. And their computers can act as hosts for Web pages. Accessories that increase the capacities of the old machines are also available, including one that speeds them up by a factor of 20.
Maurice Randall, who has an auto repair shop in Charlotte, Mich., uses his Commodore for all facets of daily computing, for things like designing newsletters and writing HTML pages. "If you don't need to do a lot of high-powered graphical work, they're perfect," Mr. Randall said. "They don't crash. They don't have viruses, and they don't break down as often."
The most popular eight-bit computers are the Commodore 64, of which 20 million units were sold from 1982 to 1992; the Sinclair ZX Spectrum, which was the most popular computer in Britain in the mid-1980's, and the Apple II line, which went on the market in 1977 and became immensely popular for its educational software. Production had stopped for all these models by the early 1990's because of pressure from the I.B.M. compatibles.
Now as then, the various computer camps are fierce rivals. European Spectrum fans periodically invade on-line discussion groups of Commodore users, and vice versa -- each group engaging in the electronic equivalent of nose-thumbing.
"You can talk about my mom all you want, but don't insult my computer," Mr. Judd said.
Many programmers insist that the limits of the old machines force programmers to be more resourceful. Many of them, like Mr. Randall, who spends 40 to 50 hours each week programming, write in assembly code, the most fundamental programming language, because it takes up less space than higher-level languages.
"Using assembly language, I can make the code real tight and small on a Commodore," Mr. Randall said. The program he uses to send faxes via modem is only 56 kilobytes in size. His software releases, including a fax program and an updated operating system that looks much like Windows, earn him more than $20,000 a year.
For some, eight-bit programming represents a return to computing as a personal experience and a move away from being a technodrone in an information economy. "Before, it was very much discovering and experimenting for your own benefit," said Mark Lair, 40, of Dallas. "Now we're in a service industry. Most of us programmers are providing for other people rather than ourselves."
But others acknowledge that there is not a high demand for eight-bit programmers. "Yes, I'm a Sinclair fan, but to earn a living, I need to remain up to date in a rapidly evolving industry," said Richard Jordan, 26, a programmer in Britain who owns several Spectrums.
Eight-bit computers draw their biggest chunk of fans because of the classic video games they play. Fans say the older games, unadorned by fancy graphics and sound effects, focused more on game play. The result, they contend, was games that transcend their technological simplicity.
A few times each month, Jeff Lewis, 35, goes into his basement to play some of the hundreds of Commodore 64 games he has accumulated. His wife, Dianna, refers to the computer, which is still connected to a working dot-matrix printer, as a "Commodore shrine." "She actually thinks I'm kind of nuts for keeping it up," said Mr. Lewis, who lives in a suburb of Cleveland. "I just tell her it's part of my childhood."
For all those who actually own old computers, there are hundreds of thousands more who pretend that they do by using a generation of emulators, which allow the 32-bit PC's to imitate primitive Commodores, Spectrums and Apples. Thousands of old games are available for downloading on the Web.
Despite the number of eight-bit admirers, the most dedicated enthusiasts sometimes bemoan the skewed demographics of their ranks. Oyvind Vevang, 20, of Haugesund, Norway, meets many friends though a common interest in classic video games, but they are almost all male. Mr. Vevang lamented, "If more girls were interested in this, I'd have one hell of a pickup trick!"

HEADLINE: SCREEN GRAB;
'Fearful Symmetry' Now in Pixels Bright

BYLINE: By SALLY McGRANE 

 BODY:
WILLIAM BLAKE, the British poet, painter, engraver and printmaker who died in 1827, has been called the first multimedia artist for his hand-produced books of elaborately illustrated poems. Students who study Blake in high school or college, however, seldom fully experience his work, reading texts that are accompanied by poor-quality reproductions of his artwork.
"You'll read Blake in an anthology and you'll get a typeset version of 'The Tyger' or 'The Lamb' that looks nothing like the original gorgeous, illuminated plates," said Matthew Kirschenbaum, a doctoral candidate at the University of Virginia. 
 Mr. Kirschenbaum and other scholars are out to change that, giving Blake's work a transfusion from the Internet. Two centuries after he printed them, Blake's illustrated poems are coming to life, in full color, in the on-line William Blake Archive (jefferson.village.virginia.edu /blake).
Blake is best known for his lyrical collection of short poems, "Songs of Innocence and of Experience." As with his other works, he printed each copy by hand and painted each individually using watercolors.
He called these books of poetry "illuminations" and produced in all 175 copies of 19 books, each with different colors, details and in some cases, different orderings of the poems. The actual books are often prohibitively expensive to reproduce.
The Web, however, is changing all that. The William Blake Archive has completed its first-phase goal of posting at least one copy of each of the first 18 of Blake's 19 books (the last book, "Jerusalem," has more than 100 plates and should be posted later this year).
The archivists plan to make a standard printed edition of Blake's works (with notes on the text) available on line before the end of the summer and will continue posting other copies of illuminated books through 2002, when the second phase of the project is to end. Plans for phase two also include posting 3,000 images that form the remaining one-third of Blake's body of work -- paintings, drawings, engravings, manuscripts and typographical works.
The William Blake Archive was born in 1995 when three of the country's top Blake scholars -- Morris Eaves of the University of Rochester, Robert Essick of the University of California at Riverside and Joseph Viscomi of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, along with John Unsworth, the director of the University of Virginia's Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities -- decided that Blake scholarship and electronic technology were each mature enough to create an electronic Blake resource.
The three editors had recently completed work on two printed volumes of Blake's work and had been frustrated by the limitations that the print medium imposed.
"There were economic constraints on print versions of Blake that the electronic medium would let us get around," Dr. Unsworth said.
With a grant for $250,000 for the first three years from the Getty Grant Program, the project got off the ground (it has since received support from Sun Microsystems, the Inso Corporation, the Paul Mellon Center for Studies in British Art and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill).
The Web is uniquely suited to dealing with the problems that Blake scholars have encountered in the past. The Internet is not subject to the space considerations that print books are, so it is possible to post as many different copies of a poem as exist.
"Because of the electronic editing, we can afford to reproduce 30 different versions of 'The Tyger,' " Dr. Eaves said.
Blake researchers can easily compare versions of the same poem, something that previously would have required trips to collections all over the United States and Britain. And the Web gives scholars a chance to compare them simultaneously.
Another remarkable feature of the archive is the ease with which textual or bibliographic searches can be conducted. Thanks to a special Java applet that the institute programmed for this project, it is also possible to search the archive for images. "Everything is searchable," said Mr. Viscomi. "You could look for sunflowers, lambs and birds that all appear on a plate."
The site, according to Mr. Kirschenbaum, receives between 425 and 450 visitors every day. "The site statistics spike for the first week of September and the first week of January," he said. "That's when Blake is usually taught in Romantics period courses. He's one of the early Romantics."
Mr. Kirschenbaum paused, then added, "He's also a good way to scare people off if your class is overenrolled."

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Cherubic Commando

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The new Prime Minister of Israel, Ehud Barak, stopped moving through a welcoming throng to ask me: "Do you remember what you told me after Bibi defeated Peres?"
Here it comes, I thought, another politician afflicted with total recall, rubbing my nose in one of those cockamamie predictions I make just to be provocative. 
 "You said it was good news for me. That if Peres had won, when my time came the Israeli voters would be tired of Labor. But with Bibi winning, I could be in a better position of challenging him in a few years. I never forgot that."
Yeah. I remember now. After the Likud's Bibi Netanyahu scored a stunning upset victory over Labor's Shimon Peres three years ago, I thought it would be good to buy some Ehud Barak stock at the low. So I interviewed him in his unbusy Foreign Ministry office and then gave him this cheer-up scenario:
If Labor had won in 1996, as Bill Clinton had fervently hoped, the dovish Peres would never have been able to persuade half of the Israelis that his dreamy deal with the Palestinians would provide security. With the right resolutely opposed, the peace process would founder.
But the victorious Netanyahu, I figured, would slow down the Oslo rush to give away almost all the West Bank before final-settlement talks. Then he would bring along the right, Nixon-to-China style, to buy a deal for a Palestinian state on half the West Bank. If Yasir Arafat balked, Bibi's hard-ish line would at least put the next Israeli government in position to negotiate a fairly secure peace.
That's how it seems to be working out. With "bad cop" Bibi gone, a large majority of Israelis can accept the risks that "good cop" Ehud is prepared to recommend.
What does this remembrance of predictions past reveal about the new Prime Minister? First, he sure knows how to butter up a right-wing American columnist. More important, he can get from a softened-up Clinton what his predecessor was denied.
Thus, we see him going home with a long-term switch of economic aid to military aid -- money to keep American arms production lines rolling and the Israeli armed forces with their qualitative edge. Obstruction to financing the Arrow anti-missile system will be removed. (The decision to choose F-16 fighters was Barak's; the more sophisticated F-15 costs too much to fly.)
And the same suggestion that Bibi made to fold the next salami slice of the West Bank into the final talks was no longer opposed by Clinton. It was for Arafat to reject, which he promptly did, making him look negative at a positive moment.
Barak also arranged for Clinton to be less of a buttinsky. The future U.S. role is to be facilitator, not mediator. Israel needs an ally more than a broker.
In that spirit, the White House is willing to help reopen talks with Syria, long a hotbed of terrorism and importer of missiles. Last time, a too-eager American Secretary of State was repeatedly insulted; if Hafez al-Assad makes Madeleine Albright cool her heels, she should return to a Damascus hotel and tell him to call her from the lobby.
Barak appears not to be making Yitzhak Rabin's mistake, which was to seek American troops on the Golan Heights. His idea seems to be a Syrian-Israeli arrangement of mutual monitoring joined by a team of international observers. If the aging Assad says, "Get off the Golan or else," Israel should choose else.
The new Prime Minister, a former commando who looks remarkably cherubic, made two mistakes in his debut. One was saying "We do not intend to drag our feet for another three years," which sounded like a gratuitous shot at a predecessor whose necessary corrective made possible Barak's current lionization in Washington. He disclaims any such intent, but it delighted doves and mars his unity pitch.
The other mistake was to select 15 months as his deadline for final agreement. Why the odd number? Why not a year, or 18 months, or no deadline at all? It puts all the pressure on an agreement made two weeks before the U.S. election, presumably when campaigning Democrats -- most of all Hillary Clinton -- will be panting for peacemaking handshakes on the White House lawn. Scheduling an "October surprise" is too clever by half.
Otherwise, his debut as P.M. here went well. Fancy his remembering that sage cheering-up.

HEADLINE: Rebels Without a Cause

BYLINE: By David Brooks; David Brooks is a senior editor at The Weekly Standard.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Some days it is impossible to understand American politics unless you remember that while most politicians are lovable, they are also breathtakingly self-absorbed. The people who choose such a miserable life style in the first place tend to have an insatiable desire to dominate every room they enter. And when they come to Washington, they enter a work environment that only further magnifies their self-importance.
All day people come to them ladling flattery. Lobbyists come looking for favors. Television cameras come looking for bon mots. Constituents come looking for celebrity. Politicians walk around Capitol Hill surrounded by aides who hover so solicitously that they look like a Motown group: Look, there go Senator Jones and the Deference Brothers. 
 The politician's task is to absorb infinite amounts of praise and to talk about his or her own wonderful attributes without shame. It's no wonder so many come to regard themselves as queen bees. And it's always thrilling to find a politician who thinks and talks like a normal human being -- who can go five minutes without steering the conversation back to the ever-fascinating subject of his or her grand career.
Washington's culture of political aggrandizement helps explain two recent defections from the Republican Party. Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire has announced that he is dropping out of the Republican Presidential race in order to mount an independent bid for the White House. Representative Michael Forbes of New York has left the party to become a Democrat.
Now, there is such a thing as an honorable defection. This happens to people who gradually change their views or who come to find their own opinions are utterly alien to those on their side of the aisle. In 1971, John Lindsay, Mayor of New York, left the Republican Party for the Democratic Party. And he was right to do so, because his ideas were genuinely Democratic. But the defections by Mr. Smith and Mr. Forbes were not defections of conviction. They were defections of monumental vanity.
Mr. Smith is pro-life. He wants to cut taxes and Federal spending. He opposes most gun-control legislation. These are all orthodox Republican positions. His third-party run will scarcely advance any ideas that will not also be found in the Republican platform.
Mr. Smith isn't quitting because his ideas are anathema to the Republicans. He is quitting because few Republican voters -- including those in his home state -- take his Presidential bid seriously, so he's trying to dress up this personal repudiation as some heroic rift over principle.
Mr. Smith has defended himself by saying the Republican establishment doesn't push conservative ideas as vigorously as he would like. But it has tried. If there is one thing that recent elections -- and Mr. Smith's own subatomic poll ratings -- prove, it is that candidates as aggressively conservative as Bob Smith do not win national elections. Does he really think a major party should commit political suicide simply so it can be more like him?
Now consider Michael Forbes. If Mr. Smith's pretext for defecting was that the Republican Party had become too moderate, Mr. Forbes's was that it had become too conservative. To the extent that his beliefs can be pinned down at all, Mr. Forbes is a moderate Republican. He voted to impeach President Clinton. He is anti-abortion (for now). According to an analysis done by the National Journal magazine, Mr. Forbes is in the center on economic matters, slightly right of center on social matters and solidly conservative on defense spending and other national security issues.
Remember, this is a man who rode into office on the great Republican tide of 1994. When people like Newt Gingrich were leading the party, he was a loyal champion of the Contract With America. He ran for Congress vowing to cut the Federal Government by 10 percent, which is more radical than anything the Republican leadership now proposes. But now that the party's leaders include people like Dennis Hastert and George W. Bush, suddenly the party is, in his words, "angry, narrow-minded, intolerant, uncaring."
Please. The moderate Republicans are riding higher now that at any time in the past two decades. If ever there was a time when Mr. Forbes could pull the party in his direction, this is it.
Instead, both Mr. Smith and Mr. Forbes have manipulated minor political differences in order to thrust themselves center stage. But then, this is the era of the self-absorbed. For some, traits like party loyalty and gratitude are never allowed to get in the way of the epic personal drama that exists in a politician's own mind.

HEADLINE: New-Home Construction Dropped 5.6% in June

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments, pinched by rising mortgage rates and shortages of skilled workers and some building materials, plunged in June to the lowest level in more than a year, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department reported that work began on 1.57 million units last month at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, a drop of 5.6 percent from May. June's activity, while still brisk, was the lowest since 1.54 million units in May 1998. 
 The overall decline in June reflected an 8.7 percent drop in the construction of single-family homes, offsetting a 10 percent rise in apartment construction. New-home construction was down or flat in most parts of the country.
The report comes as home builders are voicing concerns about rising interest rates and shortages of skilled construction workers and building materials, said Michael Carliner, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders.
Mortgage rates have been creeping up for two months. This year, the rate for a 30-year mortgage hit a low of 6.74 percent at the end of January and a high of 7.71 percent earlier this month.
"Higher mortgage rates have curbed the housing sector," said Karen Dexter, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Looking forward, she said: "We believe housing activity will stabilize at about current levels in the second half of the year. For overall economic growth, housing, which has been a strong contributor, will be neutral."
At the end of last year and the beginning of this year, new-home construction was at levels too high to be sustained, Mr. Carliner said. He said that he expected activity to slow and that housing starts would remain at or below 1.5 million units by the end of the year, which would still be considered a healthy level.
Economists said the new-home construction report could be seen as further evidence that one of the economy's strongest sectors is beginning to slow, reducing the chances that the Federal Reserve will again raise interest rates next month.

HEADLINE: Let's Not Get Too Wired

BYLINE: By Edward Tenner; Edward Tenner is a visiting researcher in the geosciences department at Princeton and the author of "Why Things Bite Back."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The Commerce Department has just reported that 67 percent of Americans still do not use the Internet. Even 38 percent of households with personal computers don't have an Internet connection.
Is this bad news? It certainly can look that way. African-American and Hispanic households are much less likely to have access to the World Wide Web than white or Asian-American households. The big cities in the Northeast are significantly less connected than those in the West. The report concludes that the gap between the already-wired haves and the less-connected have-nots is turning a "digital divide" into a "racial ravine."
Few will argue with the report's concern about this gap, and with the call for expanded access to the Web in schools, libraries and other public places. (It may be time to throw in some new books, too.) But the document implies more. It suggests -- though it never quite says directly -- that everybody should be on the Web, just as nearly everybody is on the telephone network. 
 But does everybody want to be? Nonusers and occasional users have rational grounds for skepticism. A survey included in the report found that 40 percent of all respondents were "very concerned" about confidentiality on the Internet. People regularly give up Internet connections because of expense or disappointment -- "temporary" files accumulate on hard drives if not removed, innocuous search queries land the user at a pornographic link, malicious programs are outpacing anti-virus software, and so on.
In fact, there are hints that users of public terminals may actually enjoy computing most. Douglas Rushkoff, the cyberculture journalist, has reported that a survey by some of his students at New York University found that only half of the children at private elementary schools (students who were required to have their own laptop computers) were happy about computing, while their public school counterparts (who mostly used school equipment) were uniformly enthusiastic about it. For these public school students, computer sessions are treats, not encumbrances. Somebody else maintains the hardware and software.
Regular users of the Web should heed this and learn to appreciate the nonwired and occasional user, for several reasons. For example, these holdouts prod the computer industry into cutting profit margins and lowering prices for connections. If a personal Internet link really became as ubiquitous and as necessary as the telephone, the drive for new business would stop, and providers might seek growth in higher charges or more intrusive on-line advertising instead.
Also, if everyone were on the Web, the rest of cultural life, although it would not evaporate, could certainly be impaired. Book sales have already slumped even though the economy has surged and on-line bookselling has exploded. Independent and small-chain bookstores are folding. Compressed on-line music formats may displace some higher-quality CD's. Internet holdouts help protect intellectual variety and choice in such areas.
Paradoxically, the unconnected also benefit on-line shoppers. They help maintain the retail outlets and catalogues that are valued as alternatives (and as printed and physical showrooms) even by many of those who would rather fill electronic shopping carts. You might order your new car on line, but you'd probably swing by the local showroom to get a look first. And the sales taxes paid by patrons of local retailers are helping to buy more time for the exemption still enjoyed by on-line buyers. Universal service would almost surely mean farewell to the free ride.
But the biggest benefit from the Internet holdouts is not what they consume but what they save: energy. In "Earth in the Balance," Al Gore celebrated the potential of a future national computer network to help spare the environment through telecommuting. Now we have wide access to the Internet, yet consumption of electricity continues to rise as electronic devices multiply. Some scientists, unconvinced that reserves are growing as reported, predict new petroleum shortages within a decade. If so, the Web's contribution to the energy load will compound them.
Today's personal computers are thermally as well as metaphorically hot. My now-antique 1993 P.C. is rated at 150 watts; its 1999 Pentium III successor has a power supply for 200 watts.
And that's without the monitor. Add another 120 to 140 watts for a 17-inch screen. (By the way, Windows 98 supports two active monitors with one computer.) A deluxe speaker system may have its own power supply, plus a powered subwoofer. A laser printer is increasingly a must. High-speed connections, riveting action games and fixed-rate service also encourage users to keep their computers fired up longer than in pre-Internet days. As in a casino, time can lose meaning on the Web.
Thanks to all that cruising, the servers and routers that harbor Web sites and distribute data -- and the factories that make the chips -- use energy prodigiously. Writing recently in Forbes, Peter Huber has estimated that it takes "about 1 pound of coal to create, package, store and move 2 megabytes of data" and that computer-related demand already consumes 13 percent of America's electricity.
Internet enthusiasts should consider what would happen to their utility bills if most nonusers jumped onto the Internet just as new generations of chips arrive, running hotter than ever. During the summer, the extra heat would be pumped into city streets by air-conditioners, supercharging the local microclimate as well as contributing to global greenhouse gases; we would demand still more cooling, until cities and even regions faced the likelihood of blackouts.
So Web users ought to count their blessings, think of the money they're saving with their on-line purchases, support a balanced program of information access for all Americans -- and take a Luddite to lunch.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
The CasinoEffect in Asian Stock Markets

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 21

 BODY:
In one of Southeast Asia's perplexing riddles, investors keep plowing money into the region's stock markets even as governments dither over the urgent financial and regulatory overhauls many of them promised in the wake of the economic crisis that began two years ago.
Asian markets are soaring despite a widely held view among financial experts that the collusion, corruption and financial bungling that contributed to Asia's troubles have merely been diluted, not eradicated. 
 Many of the same economists, bankers and investors say that the market recovery has helped lull the region into complacency about the need for more politically distasteful economic medicine.
But a closer look at which investors are driving the recovery in Asian stocks and what kind of markets they have created suggests that the rally is not as unlikely as it seems. Some say that the soaring Asian equity markets are not a vote of economic confidence, but rather a symptom of continuing financial gridlock that has turned these markets into corporate casinos for skeptical Asian savers and skittish Asian banks.
While higher stock prices may ultimately help companies raise cash and strengthen their balance sheets, some economists say that the rally represents a false dawn -- one that has yet to convince foreign investors.
Reorganization is crucial to having a long-term recovery, says Bernhard Eschweiler, head of economic research at Morgan Guaranty Trust.
And the big gains in Asian stock indexes are helping to obscure just how much value corporate Asia has lost. Indonesia's benchmark stock index, for example, has risen by 61 percent so far this year, almost back to where it was before the crisis began late in 1997. That sounds terrific until the decline in Indonesia's currency is factored in, which makes the stock market there worth only about half as much in United States dollars as it was two years ago.
The same goes for Malaysia -- despite a 43 percent rise by its benchmark stock index this year.
Economic considerations aside, some say that the latest rally makes sense if only from the standpoint of accounting for currency devaluations -- a sort of inflation adjustment by fund managers rejiggering their global portfolios so they more closely mimic the relative size and growth potential of economies. Others assume that new wealth being created in United States stock markets is finding its way to Asia as investors seek to diversify their holdings.
But data suggest that the opposite has been taking place. Since the crisis started, investors have withdrawn an estimated $1.77 billion from American mutual funds investing in Asian markets other than Japan, according to Lipper Inc. And while those funds have grown by 44 percent so far this year as markets swelled, they have only half as much money invested in the region as they did when the crisis started. The world's biggest pool of capital -- the United States -- does not appear to be unambiguously behind the Asian rally.
That may be changing. Lipper says investors pumped an estimated $380 million into those Asian funds last month, the biggest monthly inflow in more than two years. And Asia's economies, reforming or not, are showing signs that they are recovering. Inflation is under control, interest rates are falling, exports are rising, and Asians are saving more than they spend.
So why haven't foreign investors been moving into the region more aggressively? Analysts and fund managers say it is largely because United States stocks are doing too well to risk putting money into economies that are still under renovation.
"It's still not fashionable yet to be looking at opportunities offshore," says Dominic Armstrong, head of Malaysia and Singapore research at ABN Amro Asia Ltd.
At the same time, however, Asia's savers are giving banks a growing pile of deposits that they either cannot afford to lend or that companies are too indebted to borrow. Brokers say that a lot of that money is ending up in regional stock markets for lack of a better place to go. Joining it are small, local investors eager to make a quick profit on the surge in stocks.
"It's the old-fashioned gambling mentality," says Hugh Young, managing director at Aberdeen Asset Management. "The consumer is still quite nervous, but is quite happy to pump the market."
Brokers and economists point to Malaysia as a prime illustration. Foreigners are reluctant to put money into a market where the Government will tax them up to 30 percent for funds they withdraw within a year of investing them. Instead, the market's gains are being driven primarily by local investors, they say -- in some ways the very type of short-term "hot money" that Malaysia had hoped to discourage by imposing currency controls last September.
"The casino element is taking over," said William Belchere, head of fixed-income research and strategy at Merrill Lynch International Bank Ltd.
That much is evident from statistics measuring the volatility of Asia's markets. Trading in Kuala Lumpur has nearly quadrupled, compared with its level at the start of the crisis. At the same time, the market is twice as volatile as it was two years ago. Bangkok's stock market is almost as turbulent now as it was in the uncertain days before the Thai baht was devalued in July 1997. And Jakarta's stock market yo-yo's more than any of the others.
Asian markets are, of course, minuscule compared with the New York Stock Exchange, so it takes a lot less money to move them. Nevertheless, the amount of local money pouring into these markets has important implications for economic recovery, experts say, since it demonstrates that despite Asia's difficulties, the region is sitting on sizable amounts of investor capital.
"It's a frightening indication of how much cash there is in Asia," Mr. Armstrong of ABN Amro said.

HEADLINE: Bear Stearns Income Is Up, As Fees GrowFrom Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that profit in its most recent quarter rose 56 percent, to a record, as a stock market rally and a comeback in mortgage bonds lifted trading and commission revenue.
Net income rose to $269.1 million, or $1.85 a diluted share, in the period, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of the company's fiscal year. Analysts expected the company to earn $1.44 a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. 
 A year earlier, Bear Stearns earned $172.3 million, or $1.18 a share. The period a year earlier included a pretax charge of $108 million related to litigation involving the defunct brokerage firm A. R. Baron. The special charge amounted to 42 cents a share, and taking that into account profit was up 15.6 percent in the 1999 quarter.
Revenue net of interest expense rose 24 percent, to $1.5 billion.
Shares of Bear Stearns fell 6.25 cents yesterday, to $43.6875.
The profit at Bear Stearns mirrored that of its Wall Street rivals as rising stocks and relatively low interest rates in the quarter encouraged investors to buy securities and supported a boom in mergers.
Return on equity, an important measure of profitability, was 29 percent in the quarter, among the highest on Wall Street and topping the 25.4 percent posted by Merrill Lynch & Company. The Bear Stearns figure was 21.8 percent a year earlier and 23.7 percent in the third quarter, which ended March 31.
Trading revenue rose 45 percent, to a record $712.8 million, helped by activity in the derivatives and mortgage-backed and high-yield bond markets.
Commissions rose 18 percent, to $273.3 million, amid a 31 percent surge in average daily trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange. The more active trading also helped the securities-processing business of Bear Stearns, the largest such operation in the United States.
The firm arranged $1.63 billion of stock offerings during the quarter, up 58 percent from a year earlier. Fees for stock issues are double those of bond offerings.
Bear Stearns also advised on $29.5 billion of mergers during the quarter, up from $24 billion in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley's Own Work Threatens ItsDomination

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., July 21

 BODY:
"Don't look back," the legendary baseball pitcher Satchel Paige once said. "Something might be gaining on you."
The truth of that warning was driven home today to a group of Silicon Valley business and civic leaders when a survey they had commissioned showed that the booming Internet economy is decentralizing technology industries and threatening Silicon Valley's domination of all things digital. 
 The group, Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network, said its survey showed that Internet companies -- and the economic growth they reap -- are expanding rapidly in seven regions outside of the Valley: Seattle; Los Angeles; Austin, Tex.; Boston; New York; the District of Columbia, and San Francisco's "Multimedia Gulch."
The survey was conducted for Joint Venture by A. T. Kearney, a business consulting firm. Its findings were based on surveys and interviews with 125 executives of Internet companies in an effort to provide a portrait of an industry that, according to a study by the University of Texas Center for Research in Electronic Commerce, accounted for 1.2 million jobs and $300 billion in revenue in 1998.
The paradox is that the Internet -- which has largely been the offspring of networking and software technologies that were commercialized and invented in Silicon Valley -- is making it possible for new economic activity to spread rapidly beyond the Valley. As a loosely defined geographic region, Silicon Valley now describes an area bordered by San Mateo on the north to far past San Jose on the south.
"We cannot expect the past dominance in high-tech will insure future dominance of the emerging Internet industry," said Ruben Barrales, president and chief executive of Joint Venture. The challenge for Silicon Valley, he said, was "how to remain the geographic center of an inherently locationless medium."
To be sure, each new industry that has emerged based on the increasing power of the integrated circuit has eventually spilled over the Valley's borders into areas that quickly donned imitative names like Silicon Mountains, Silicon Desert and Silicon Alley. Outside the United States, it has generated vast manufacturing and design outposts in Asia and elsewhere.
There is, however, a growing concern that increasing quality-of-life concerns as well as the rapid depletion of skilled workers relative to demand is encouraging companies that would have come to the Valley to look elsewhere.
More than 85 percent of the executives surveyed reported access to talent as a factor in determining the site of their Internet companies. In the Valley, the shortfall in the skilled work force is estimated to be as high as 160,000 workers, equivalent to almost 33 percent of the regional labor demand for skilled employees, according to A. T. Kearney.
Against that background, a number of technology executives and government officials spoke defensively today about the strengths the region still offered as a result of its entrepreneurial culture.
"There is an extremely strong work ethic here," said Arife Janjua, vice president and general manager of Saraide.com, a wireless Internet services company. "People are willing to go the distance for the cause."
And other executives gave examples of the hypergrowth that continues to set the Valley apart. Rod Schrock, president and chief executive of the Altavista Company, said that his Valley-based business had grown from 55 employees to more than 500 in the last six months and was now hiring 8 to 10 new employees a week.
 "You could not achieve this kind of growth anywhere but in Silicon Valley," he said.
At the same time, there is growing concern that congestion in the Valley is reaching historic proportions and that housing costs, which once required that a household have two breadwinners, are now so high that each home will instead soon require two instant-millionaire beneficiaries of initial public offerings.
"We can no longer see ourselves as a suburban community," said Richard Gordon, a San Mateo County Supervisor. "We have to see ourselves as an urban environment."
Despite the growing anxiety that the Valley's best days may be behind it, there was a general consensus among those who spoke at a news conference here today that the Valley's culture, built largely by entrepreneurs and based on meritocracy, was still unmatched anywhere in the world.
The report can be obtained on line at http://www.jointventure.org. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Helps Shares Make First Advance of Week

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday for the first time this week, led by computer-related shares like Microsoft, as Internet companies reported better-than-expected results.
But Goodyear Tire and Rubber fell after reporting a profit that missed estimates, limiting the gain of the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 "The market is becoming more selective and rewarding companies that come through with good results and penalizing those that come through with negative results," said Joseph Stocke of Meridian Investment in Valley Forge, Pa.
The Dow rose 6.65 points, or 0.06 percent, to 11,002.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.19, or 0.2 percent, to 1,379.29. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 29.59, or 1.1 percent, to 2,761.77, after falling 3.5 percent on Tuesday. All three indexes had slumped since Friday, when they touched records.
Advancing and declining stocks were about even on the New York Stock Exchange.
While Microsoft rose 1 3/8 yesterday, to 94 11/16, on Tuesday stocks had slumped after the company warned that business might slow later this year because of Year 2000 computer problems.
UAL, Chase Manhattan and Internet companies, including Real Networks and Excite@Home led a parade of companies beating or matching analysts' forecasts. Goodyear and the insurers Allstate and Progressive fell short of estimates. This is the busiest week for earnings reports, with more than 1,000 companies reporting.
Goodyear fell 2 7/8, to 54 3/4 after the company, the biggest tire maker, reported profit that was lower than the recently reduced Wall Street estimates. Allstate fell 1 11/16, to 34 15/16, and Progressive lost 7 1/8, to 133 7/8.
Chase Manhattan, which posted a 25 percent rise in earnings from operations, gained 7/16, to 81 5/16. It had strong results in all areas of business.
Real Networks, a maker of software used to distribute audio and video on line, rose 10 1/8, to 87 15/16, after it reported a smaller-than-expected second-quarter loss as revenue surged 86 percent compared with that of the 1998 quarter.
Excite@Home rose 11 5/16, to 47. The company, which provides high-speed Internet access through cable television lines, said its second-quarter loss had widened in line with estimates as revenue more than doubled and subscriptions grew 35 percent. Excite@Home also said it was in talks with rivals regarding possible transactions, though it declined to elaborate.
America Online rose 1 7/8, to 115 1/16, and Amazon.com advanced 5 5/16, to 125 7/16. After the market closed, America Online posted earnings that beat forecasts, while Amazon.com's results matched expectations.
Airline stocks rose for the second time in three days after UAL and AMR beat profit forecasts. UAL, parent of United Airlines, rallied 1 9/16, to 64 1/16. AMR, parent of American Airlines, gained 1/8, to 69 5/8.
Mergers lifted shares of Centocor and IXC Communications.
Centocor, a biotechnology company, surged 7 7/8, to 57 3/8, after Johnson & Johnson agreed to buy it for $61 a share, or $4.9 billion, in stock.
IXC jumped 3 1/2, to 39 3/4, after the company agreed to be acquired by Cincinnati Bell for $49.42 a share, or $3.2 billion in stock and assumed debt. IXC is building an 18,000-mile network that will provide services to phone and Internet companies.
In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as investors and traders sold bonds before Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, testifies before Congress today on the economy.
A falling dollar and expected sales of more than $10 billion of corporate debt by borrowers, including Wal-Mart Stores, also kept bonds in check.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond slipped 8/32, to 90 31/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.90 percent from 5.88 percent on Tuesday.
Concern about what Mr. Greenspan will tell Congress at his twice-yearly Humphrey-Hawkins testimony kept traders from buying Treasuries, especially as 30-year yields have already fallen more than a quarter-point the last month.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Regulators Seize Documents From Coca-Cola in Europe

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
In the latest twist to the Coca-Cola Company's fortunes -- or misfortunes -- in Europe, its offices in four European countries have been raided by regulators who seized company documents that may lead to an investigation of the company's competitive practices with big customers like supermarkets.
A spokesman for Coca-Cola confirmed yesterday that officials from the European Commission, which has tangled with Coke several times in recent months, appeared without warning as the business day was beginning Tuesday and asked for access to company files. 
 The offices of Coke and its bottling companies were entered in Austria, Denmark and Germany. Coke's bottling office in London also received a surprise visit from regulators.
"Their purpose was to review internal files with respect to commercial practices with retailers and other customers," said the spokesman, Rob Baskin. "We're cooperating fully with them. We believe we are within full compliance of all competition laws and regulations."
An investigation into whether Coke abused its position as the market leader in Italy has been going on for nearly a year. The investigation began after a complaint from Pepsi, Coca-Cola's chief rival.
The action comes less than six weeks after the biggest recall of Coke products in company history because of a contamination scare in Belgium and France. The recall hurt Coke's image in Europe, one of its most important markets.
It also had a significant impact on Coca-Cola's bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, costing the bottler $103 million, or most of its earnings for the year.
Coke has faced other problems in Europe, notably regulatory opposition to its plan to acquire most of the overseas rights to Cadbury Schweppes brands like Dr Pepper and Canada Dry. Coke announced the $1.85 billion plan in December, but by May had scaled it back to $1.1 billion, leaving out most of the countries in the European Union after antitrust regulators said Coke would hold too much market share if the acquisition were approved.
Neither the Cadbury deal nor the product recall seems to have any connection to the European Commission action. Coke and its bottlers have disagreed with the regulators over various company strategies, including whether the company abuses its "dominant position" in certain markets.
The three bottlers examined in the raid Tuesday are Coca-Cola Beverages, which is in the middle of merger talks with Hellenic Bottling and in which Coke holds a 50.1 percent stake; Coca-Cola Nordic Beverages, a joint venture with Carlsberg A.S. in which Coke has a 49 percent stake, and Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetranke A.G., Coke's German bottler in which Coke holds a 40 percent stake.
Analysts in New York seemed shocked by what they viewed as the latest setback for the company, which has been suffering through one of its worst years in recent memory, with economic distress around the world cutting into volume and profit growth.
"It looks like the E.U. is becoming a government unto itself," said Emanuel Goldman, a consumer-products analyst for Merrill Lynch. "It's gotten out of hand."
Andrew Conway, a beverage analyst for Morgan Stanley, said, "The very nature of a dawn raid is to give the E.C. unfettered accesss to Coke's files."
Coca-Cola stock slipped 31.25 cents yesterday, closing at $62.625.
Top Coke executives are expected to lead a meeting in New York today with analysts and investors, at which they will discuss the strategic outlook as well as the recall in Europe last month.

HEADLINE: Belgrade Presents Schedule For Reservists' Back Pay

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 21

 BODY:
In an unusual open meeting of the Government intended to help assuage popular grievances after the Kosovo conflict, the Yugoslav Defense Minister announced today that army reservists would be paid overdue wages in installments over the next six months.
Angry reservists have protested around central and southern Serbia, including again today in Kragujevac. The protesters have blocked roads and railroad tracks and marched on city halls, demanding to be paid for their service in Kosovo. 
 The Defense Minister, Pavle Bulatovic, told the Cabinet that paying the reservists was a "top priority" and that the bill would be 1 billion dinars, or $100 million at the official exchange rate.
With Yugoslavia foreign exchange reserves estimated at $150 million before the war -- the figure is a carefully kept secret -- paying the soldiers is bound to mean printing money and new inflation.
There is much more to be spent to try to restore electrical stations and transformers, roads, bridges and factories, many of which were heavily damaged in the NATO bombing.
But the reservists come first. The Government of President Slobodan Milosevic cannot afford the potential for a popular explosion led by armed former soldiers who were mobilized for Kosovo, with 8,000 from Krusevac alone.
The protests in many areas include Krusevac, Nis, Prokuplje, Pirot, Smederovo and Leskovac. In Kragujevac today, 250 protesters rallied in the town center, marched two miles and blocked traffic along the road to Kraljevo, letting only the old and the sick through their barricades.
But the protesters typically spoke less about fundamental politics than about obtaining their money. One protester, Dusan Danjanovic, told a local journalist: "This is nothing to do with politics. This is a question about money. If they hadn't promised the money, we wouldn't have asked for it."
"If I trusted the Yugoslav Army," Dragan Radovic said, "I would go back to the army again. But it depends on whether they pay us or not."
Ljubica Markovic, editor in chief of the independent Beta news agency, noted in an interview that the Government "is not fighting back, but clearly hoping that the demonstrators will get tired."
Already, she said, daily demonstrations by reservists and opposition supporters in Leskovac and Valjevo are dwindling. One main opposition grouping, the Alliance for Change, has been organizing daily protests in Leskovac for 16 days, and Valjevo has had eight days of rallies.
The rallies are demanding Mr. Milosevic's resignation and the release of those arrested for organizing the protests.
"If the Government doesn't keep its promises to pay the reservists," Ms. Markovic said, "there will be more trouble. But there doesn't seem to be much belief or real energy in the demonstrations so far. Just deprivation and depression. The protests in southern Serbia are about social problems and lack of money, not about politics, at all."
If the region experiences social explosions as winter approaches, she said, "they could take all the politicians right along with them."
The Milosevic era is ending, "and there will be hard days for everyone," Ms. Markovic said. But she predicted that Mr. Milosevic would "be here for another year or 18 months, losing little by little, until the threshold is crossed, and people will abandon him."
Such discussions are beginning among figures on the outskirts of the Government, she said, but the moment for defection is not yet.
Mirosinka Dinkic, an economist at the Belgrade Economics Institute, said Yugoslavia's gross domestic product for this year would be $13 billion, 30 percent smaller than last year's. Average salaries, she added, are down 50 percent from Jan. 1, at least as measured by the black-market exchange rate for the German mark. The salaries are running 75 marks, or $45 a month.
Mr. Bulatovic said the Government would pay each soldier who served in Kosovo $180, and $120 a month to those who served outside the province. He said he was convinced that the plan would satisfy the reservists, because professional soldiers were paid just this week for the first half of May.
The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Dragoljub Ojdanic, said in his report that 62 Yugoslav soldiers had been killed in Kosovo Liberation Army attacks after the accord signed with NATO on June 10, during the withdrawal of Yugoslav security forces from the province. He said the army's equipment losses in the war were minor.

Rebels Said to Comply With Pact
PRISTINA, Kosovo, July 21 (Agence France-Presse) -- NATO-led forces said today that they were encouraged by how rebels in the province were complying with the disarmament pact. The Kosovo Liberation Army has handed over a significant number of weapons ahead of a midnight deadline, said a spokesman for NATO, Maj. Jan Joosten.
Under the accord, signed on June 21, by rebel leaders and the commander of the NATO force, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Jackson, the rebels were to turn over all heavy weapons and nearly one-third of automatic arms by tonight.
Two later phases will see all the rebels' weapons, aside from small nonautomatic weapons like pistols and hunting rifles, placed in controlled depots by Sept. 21.

HEADLINE: Chase Manhattan Earnings Show Strengthin All Areas

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose a greater-than-expected 25 percent partly because of strength in Internet investments, trading, investment banking and credit cards.
Profit from operations rose to $1.35 billion, or $1.55 a diluted share, compared with $1.08 billion, or $1.21 a share, in the 1998 quarter. Analysts had expected Chase to earn $1.37 a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings. 
 Net income rose nearly 30 percent, to $1.39 billion, or $1.60 a share, from $1.07 billion, or $1.20, in 1998. The net figure included one-time gains from the sale of branches in Texas, the sale of One New York Plaza and a one-time expense for a contribution to the Chase Foundation.
Shares of Chase rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $81.3125.
In the quarter, Chase benefited from an expanding economy and surging equity markets, which fueled demand for loans and bolstered trading revenue. Chase also profited from its investment in Starmedia Network, Latin America's biggest on-line service company;its shares have more than tripled since it went public last month.
"It was an excellent report across the board," said Diane Glossman, a bank analyst at Lehman Brothers. "All areas contributed."
Revenue grew 20 percent or more in three main businesses: investment banking and trading, consumer services and investor services.
Noninterest revenue rose 28 percent, to $3.47 billion, as trading revenue surged 63 percent, to $526 million, lifted by gains in the trading of equities and commodities and in debt products. Gains in private equity, or venture capital, climbed 39 percent, to $513 million.
Chase said last month that its investment in Starmedia would add at least $240 million in revenue, plus an additional $60 million for every $10 change in Starmedia's stock price above $48.
Starmedia, based in New York, went public last month at $15. On June 30, the stock closed at $64.125, giving Chase an apparent revenue gain from the investment of about $336 million. Shares of Starmedia fell 18.75 cents yesterday, to $48.1875.
Dina Dublon, Chase's chief financial officer, said the bank's Internet investments were worth about $1.2 billion and that the bank had reported about $500 million of those gains.
Fees from investment banking, which includes loan syndications, high-yield underwriting and mergers and advisory services, rose 34 percent, to a record $585 million.
"Investment banking was off the charts," said David Berry, a bank analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
Chase was the largest provider of syndicated loans in the second quarter, according to the Securities Data Company. The bank also increased its ranking in advising on mergers to 10th, with an 8.3 percent market share, from 19th, with a 2.2 percent share in the period a year earlier, Securities Data said.
Chase said it expected investor services revenue to slow in the fourth quarter because corporate clients might cut back on financial transactions because of potential Year 2000 problems.
Chase, the fourth-largest provider of Visa and Mastercard credit cards, said credit card revenue rose 20 percent, to $438 million. Ms. Dublon said the bank was able to increase credit card profit by 15 percent.
Noninterest expense rose 13 percent, to $3.07 billion.
Chase's net interest income rose 5.4 percent, to $2.15 billion. The provision for loan losses rose 18 percent, to $388 million.
The bank also benefited from a strong domestic economy, as consumer banking revenue grew. Regional consumer banking revenue gained 9 percent, to $593 million.
