HEADLINE: Economic Scene: Cream in Labor Market'sChurn;
Why Job Losses Are Rising Amid Job Hunters' Nirvana

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
At a time when joblessness has fallen to just 4.3 percent of the work force and employers are loudly complaining about labor shortages, companies are also announcing record numbers of layoffs. It doesn't seem to make sense, does it?
Yesterday, for example, Eastman Kodak disclosed plans to cut up to 2,500 more jobs on top of the 17,700 it had already planned to eliminate by the end of the year. Not long ago, Procter & Gamble announced a mass layoff of about 15,000, with 2,400 in North America, as it reorganizes its worldwide operations. 
 And Levi Strauss, fighting off competition from makers of cheaper jeans, said this year that it would close half of its manufacturing plants in the United States and Canada, moving work overseas and laying off 5,900 workers.
Indeed, according to the widely followed monthly surveys by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an international outplacement firm, layoff announcements in the first half of this year are running about 40 percent higher than 1998, which was a record year.
Why are the Challenger surveys picking up rising layoffs at a time that unemployment hovers near a 30-year low? On the surface, it seems paradoxical.
But economists and labor market analysts, including those at Challenger itself, say it is not contradictory at all.
"Job creation will far outdistance automation and job destruction," explained John Challenger, the firm's chief executive. "Sometimes a company must take a step backward by cutting part of its labor force in one area in an effort to move two steps forward into more profitable areas of development."
So, though layoffs tend to attract more attention during periods of economic stress, they can often signal economic vitality and long-term willingness to create jobs, even as they temporarily victimize some workers.
Take the case of AT&T, which announced in early 1996 that it would lay off 40,000 workers. Not long afterward, the company ended up hiring enough new people -- in providing wireless and local telephone services and running telecommunications systems for major corporations -- that by the end of 1996 its total employment had hardly budged. AT&T continues to lay off workers in some of its divisions even as its adds workers to others, like its new cable operations.
A tip that layoffs are not necessarily sinister or a sign of weakness comes from looking at the industries that have been hit hardest. In April, the computer industry -- hardly anyone's candidate as a troubled sector -- announced the most job cuts that month, more than 10,000. Electronics, another high-technology star, was second, with 8,900. According to the Challenger survey, between 1993 and 1998 the computer industry announced almost 273,000 job cuts, about the same as retail trade and second only to the aerospace-military industry.
More broadly, the Challenger data need to be put into the context of a labor market that is constantly churning.
Challenger says announced layoffs are running at about 60,000 a month. That might seem like a lot. But set it against another, truly startling, number: 13 million workers change their employment status in a typical month, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
On average, that means that 13 million Americans leave home or school to enter the labor force, exit the labor force without looking for new work, find new work after a spell of unemployment or search for work after they quit or are dismissed or laid off -- every month. Seen in the context of that enormous number of job changes that take place every month, the Challenger numbers barely register as a blip.
Actually, the 13 million figure is an underestimate of labor market churning. For it takes no account of workers who manage to change employers within a month. Nor does it include workers who change jobs within the same company.
Officials at the Labor Department estimate that 40 percent of the work force, or roughly 50 million workers, changes jobs within a year. In manufacturing alone, Prof. Steven Davis, a labor economist at the University of Chicago, estimates that 10 percent to 12 percent of jobs disappear in a typical year, a number that has not changed in decades.
Finally, careful scrutiny of Government data suggests that Challenger's surveys might not accurately track the number of actual layoffs taking place throughout the economy.
The Challenger surveys draw rapt attention because they are the only data available monthly, providing the only instant barometer of corporate layoffs. The question is how representative the announcements of layoffs are of actual layoffs.
For one thing, the surveys might be biased toward large companies, since they are the only ones that are required by law to announce plant closings and large layoffs ahead of time. Further, some job cuts are achieved through attrition rather than through actual layoffs.
The Labor Department does collect data every two years on displaced workers -- workers who lose their jobs because plants close or move, or because sales fall. Once collected and analyzed, the Government's data, drawn from the entire economy, have shown that the actual number of job losses was significantly greater than those picked up by Challenger's more limited surveys. That is unsurprising.
But the Government data also show that job losses have been steadily falling over the last few years, the opposite of the trend in the Challenger data. Professor Davis says the Government's data differ from Challenger's because Challenger appears to capture "only the tip of an iceberg."
According to the Labor Department, the portion of nonagricultural private workers with at least three years' tenure who were displaced during 1995 and 1996 fell to 3.8 percent. The figure for 1993 and 1994 was 4.4 percent. The 14 percent drop indicates job cuts were falling at least through 1996.
Another indication of the trend in job losses comes from Government surveys of unemployed workers who report they lost their jobs. The number has been falling -- to 2.7 million last month from 2.8 million in June 1998, and 3.1 million in June 1997 -- even though the size of the labor force grew by about 4 million during that two-year period.
Layoffs fuel fears, expressed throughout the 1990's, that corporate downsizing has been ripping workers from the security of long-term employment relationships. But a careful sifting of the numbers does not lend support to that anxiety.
Prof. Henry Farber, an economist at Princeton University, calculates that about 13 percent of the work force was displaced from jobs between 1991 and 1993. That compares with 15 percent between 1993 and 1995 and 12 percent between 1995 and 1997. His estimates are far higher than the Government's in part because he does not limit his sample to workers who have been working at least three years for their current employers.
Professor Farber says his data suggest that "somewhat more jobs were lost in the recent expansion than at similar points in the expansion of the late 1980's."
"The reasons are unclear," he added in a recent interview. "But the evidence is that workers are now coping better, and a higher fraction can find jobs. Also, the average wage loss by displaced workers is smaller than it used to be."
Of the workers who lost jobs between 1995 and 1997, about 75 percent were employed as of February 1998, compared with 65 percent for the 1993-1995 period. "None of these changes, however, is dramatic," Professor Farber said.
He says that despite the public focus on downsizing, there has been no substantial decline in job security in the 1990's. "Long-term employment is still an important phenomenon in the U.S. economy," he added.
He says that 35 percent to 40 percent of workers at least 35 years old have been with their current employers more than 10 years. These long-term relationships exist alongside the tremendous churning that characterizes the rest of the labor force.
Some workers, especially the young, change jobs rapidly -- at least until they find the occupations and employers they want for the long haul. Some industries, like fast-food restaurants, foster short-term employment. So the economy creates substantial numbers of long-term and short-term jobs.
The upshot is that layoffs remain high by historical standards. But job creation remains far higher.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.P.S. Plans to Go Public, Raising at Least $3 Billion
United Parcel Service has resisted the persistent entreaties of investment bankers and remained private for 92 years. But now it has decided to sell 10 percent of itself to the public.
The package delivery company, which earned $1.7 billion last year on sales of $24.8 billion, plans to raise $3 billion to $5 billion in the offering. Page A1. 

Profits as Expected on the Internet
America Online said its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, topping estimates, as it signed up 755,000 new subscribers and ad revenue surged. Amazon.com said its second-quarter loss widened because of increased spending to promote and expand its Web site, but its results matched expectations. Both companies reported after the market closed, and both stocks had gained. C8.
 
Johnson & Johnson to Buy Centocor
Johnson & Johnson has agreed to acquire Centocor, a biotechnology company, for $4.9 billion in stock. C2.
 
Schering-Plough, Eli Lilly and Bristol-Myers Squibb reported higher second-quarter profits as advertising increased sales of medicines for allergies, depression and diabetes. C2.
 
Silicon Valley Faces Competition
A survey conducted by the business consulting firm A. T. Kearney shows that the booming Internet economy is decentralizing technology industries and threatening Silicon Valley's domination of all things digital. C2.
 
Stocks Reverse Slide and Edge Up
Stocks rose for the first time this week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.65 points, to 11,002.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.19 points, to 1,379.29, and the Nasdaq composite index climbed 29.59 points, to 2,761.77. C9.
 
Kodak Plans Closings and Job Cuts
Eastman Kodak said that it would close some manufacturing operations, cutting as many as 2,500 jobs. Analysts applauded the move, which will entail a $300 million charge in the third quarter, but the mood was somber in Rochester, where Kodak is already cutting 7,500 jobs. Kodak also reported a 9 percent quarterly earnings rise to $491 million. C11.
 
New Packages for Familiar Brands
In the beverage industry, some companies are trying to win consumers over to their products by putting the usual brew in an unusual package, using substances like aluminum, glass and clear plastic and the opportunities those offer for industrial-strength decorative arts like embossing and surface printing. The new packaging ranges from a can for Heineken beer to plastic bottles for Miller Beer brands to a glass fruit-drink bottle with a label that changes as the contents decrease. Advertising. C6.
 
Europeans Raid Coca-Cola Offices
Coca-Cola offices in Austria, Britain, Denmark and Germany have been raided by European Commission regulators. They seized company documents that may lead to an investigation of competitive practices with big customers like supermarkets. The company said it believed it was in compliance with all laws. C3.
 
G.M. Admits Antilock Brake Faults
After a five-year Federal investigation, General Motors acknowledged that antilock brakes on 3.6 million sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and full-size vans may be slow to stop the vehicles in some cases. A10.
 
Chase Manhattan Profit Up 25%
Chase Manhattan said that its second-quarter earnings rose a greater-than-expected 25 percent, in part because of strength in Internet investments, trading, investment banking and credit cards. C23.
 
Bear Stearns said that profit in its most recent quarter rose 56 percent. C2.
 
Times Mirror Results Increase 6%
Buoyed by a turnaround at The Los Angeles Times, where national advertising volume increased by 33.5 percent, Times Mirror posted a 6 percent gain in second-quarter profit. C6.

HEADLINE: Bank Dips Its Toe in South Bronx;
Commerce Gingerly Follows Housing in Ex-Wasteland

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Hilda Hernandez stared, stepped back, stepped up. She stared some more. The look on her face suggested that a flying saucer had just landed in her neighborhood.
In fact, only a bank had, but for Ms. Hernandez, who has lived through her neighborhood's seesawing fortunes for 30 years, that was news enough. Last week, the European American Bank, or E.A.B., officially opened its first branch in the South Bronx, making it the first bank in the area served by the borough's Community Board 3 in more than a decade. 
 "It's very nice, very nice," Ms. Hernandez said over and over, her eyes glued to the automatic teller machine.
In the early 1980's, the building of the ranch homes on Charlotte Street, a block away from the bank, helped start the borough's huge housing renaissance, in which 57,000 apartments and houses have been built or rehabilitated. That a suburb -- today complete with satellite dishes and lawn sprinklers -- could be built on the rubble that Presidents Carter and Reagan toured as an example of urban ruin suggested that revival was possible.
But even as the Charlotte Street homes were followed by dozens and dozens of new multifamily homes on nearby streets, stores and services were slow to follow. The perception that poverty and crime were more abundant than customers kept businesses away.
Today, though, commercial life is slowly creeping back to areas that became retail wastelands as the Bronx burned.
The smart brick bank is embedded in a new mini-mall on Southern Boulevard at Jennings Street, and health and day care centers, a pharmacy, a community room and other enterprises plan to move in, with 6,000 square feet still to be rented.
Across the street is a video store, three years old, run by two sisters from the Dominican Republic, and up the block is a Western Beef store, a veritable graybeard with six years in the neighborhood. Around the corner from the bank is a fruit, vegetable and fish market, opened eight months ago by a Korean couple. A few blocks north is a large, sparkling new doughnut shop.
And north of the doughnut shop, on 174th Street, a 137,000-square-foot shopping center long in the planning stages is, its developers say, close to construction. Its tenants are to include a Pathmark supermarket, a Payless shoe store and an Ashley Stewart clothing store.
"It's the beginnings," said Bill Traylor, a senior program director at the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a national nonprofit group that assists local development. "There's a nascent commercial and economic revival, and it's happening not just because the economy's good but because we've rebuilt the market."
And "the market" -- the people living in the neighborhood -- is delighted. "When I moved here, there was nothing," said Abdullah Sabuur, a neighborhood resident since 1987, and a new account holder at E.A.B. Now, he said, "I don't think I can get a better neighborhood, with what they're bringing here."
There is, of course, still a long way to go. Most of this stretch of Southern Boulevard, for example, is still ghostly, with most stores boarded up or vacant. And there are those who worry that the airy new South Bronx -- where single-, two- or three-family homes have often replaced giant apartment buildings -- may not have a high enough concentration of free-spending customers to sustain much retail business, particularly when welfare revision has also reduced the cash flowing to the area.
But there is no question that there has been progress in trying to recapture the era when "Southern Boulevard was Southern Boulevard," in the words of Marcella Brown, the chairwoman of Community Board 3. That was before the fires and the exodus of residents in the 1960's and 70's. As buildings burned and people fled, the remaining businesses slowly closed.
Wanda Santiago, the 38-year-old manager of the new E.A.B. branch, remembers it well. She grew up not far away, at Fox and 163d Streets. As apartment buildings burned, until her family's was the only one left on her block, the businesses on her street, whether the pharmacy or the discount store, left too.
"The only thing that survived was the bodega," she said.
Even as shiny new homes filled Ms. Santiago's old street and the streets around her new employer, few businesses leapt into the breach to serve the new residents.
"There's always a lag between housing and services," said John Roberts, the district manager of the adjacent Community Board 2, which covers the Longwood and Hunts Point areas. "It's very slow."
But Mr. Traylor said a study two years ago by his organization confirmed that a retail comeback had been particularly slow in the South Bronx. "A negative image was literally burnt into retailers' minds," he said. "Overcoming that has been a long process."
Bodegas and other small businesses run by immigrant entrepreneurs were among the first to return. A sampling by the Local Initiatives Support Corporation two years ago noted a 16 percent increase in the number of retail businesses over what the South Bronx had in 1989, but said that most of those seeking to lease empty storefronts were bodegas.
But gradually, the businesses coming in are diversifying, both in their nature and in their size. There is a growing sector of insurers and realtors serving the healthy real estate market in the Bronx. National chains, from Rite-Aid to Blockbuster, are coming in, too, particularly to commercial strips, like the one farther south on Southern Boulevard, just below Westchester Avenue, that survived the hard years. There is even a new Starbucks on Fordham Road, generally considered the northern border of the South Bronx, and a Gap store is coming, too.
But business at the Starbucks, as at many of the new businesses, is slow, a reminder that the question of whether the South Bronx has enough customers with enough money to sustain all its new businesses has yet to be answered.
The businesses on or around Southern Boulevard say they are not sure yet. Tan Il Nam, a Korean immigrant who opened the neighborhood's only fruit, vegetable and fish market with her husband eight months ago, said that she loved her customers but that business was slow. She is counting on more customers from three buildings at the corner of Southern Boulevard and Jennings Street that have just been rehabilitated and are being reoccupied, and a new residence for the elderly across Jennings Street.
E.A.B.'s statistics show an average annual household income of $18,000 for the 19,000 households around the bank, and a home ownership rate of 8 percent. The bank decided to build a branch there in 1995; the long delay in completion was due to the defaulting of the initial contractor.
At the time, government regulators were leaning on banks to serve the South Bronx, but Richard Roberto, the president of E.A.B.'s community development corporation, said pressure did not motivate the bank. "Pure and simple, we went there to make money," he said, pointing out that the bank has no competition in the area served by Community Board 3. "We think we're taking a prudent risk."
Since its unofficial opening in mid-June, the bank has taken in just under $1 million from 359 depositors -- an average of $2,700 per depositor -- plus $8 million in community development funds from a single depositor, said Ms. Santiago, the manager.
"It doesn't make a market for us, but everyone needs banking," Eugene Brody, the bank's manager of market research, said. He added: "It is an extraordinarily underserved community. We'll do well. We'll provide a community service and have a warm fuzzy feeling as well."
Armin Krauss, a butcher who kept his business going on Jennings Street for 41 years, said he was skeptical that the bank or the new businesses would do well. Welfare cutbacks, he said, have taken a big bite out of the neighborhood's cash flow.
But the bigger problem, Mr. Krauss said -- and many planning officials agree -- is that while the Charlotte Street houses are beautiful, far fewer people live in them than lived in the apartment buildings that once shadowed the street. There are now about 6 families per acre in Charlotte Gardens, as the suburban tract is known, where there were once close to 200.
Fewer homes mean fewer customers. And that, said Mr. Krauss, who was born in Hungary and describes himself as "the only concentration camp survivor in the South Bronx," is why "the neighborhood has come back, but not businesswise."
Charlotte Street, with its suburban feel, is extreme -- no other area in the Bronx is so spread out. But particularly in the southeast, the borough has been rebuilt with many single- , two- or three-family homes where large apartment buildings once stood.
And so in some cases, community development groups that once focused exclusively on housing are now turning their attention to bringing retail and services to the areas they serve. M.B.D. Community Housing Corporation, for example, the neighborhood group that has renovated much of the housing in the Charlotte Gardens area, is the developer of the new mall that will house the Pathmark.
"Once you get the neighborhood settled, and establish a renters' and homeowners' base, you're able to go and attract businesses," said Ralph Porter, the president of M.B.D.
Without a commercial revival, he and other community leaders said, the South Bronx's rebuilding would be incomplete. Harold DeRienzo, president of the Parodneck Foundation for Self-Help Housing and Community Development, said that without local retailing, the South Bronx had become a two-tier society, in which those with cars went outside for goods and services, while those with few options were trapped.
"We need to build one overall community with diverse choices," he said, and added, as did other planners, that that meant making sure stores have sufficient parking. The new bank branch has a drive-through window.

HEADLINE: Council Votes Big Raises for Top Officials

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
The City Council voted yesterday to approve pay increases of 10 percent to 28 percent for the city's top officials, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and the Council's own 51 members. The raises had been recommended by a panel of three private citizens that is convened every four years to consider the pay levels of the city's top elected leaders.
With scant debate yesterday, the Council voted, 38 to 5, to approve the panel's recommendations. The largest percentage increases will go to the Council members themselves. Their base annual pay, for what is considered part-time legislative work, will rise almost 28 percent, to $90,000, from $70,500. 
 The raise does not affect the stipends 36 Council members get for heading committees and holding leadership positions. The stipends range from $3,000 for the minority whip to $39,500 for the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
Mr. Giuliani, who has said he will sign the raises into law, will get an increase of slightly more than 18 percent, bringing his annual salary to $195,000 from $165,000. The raises would be retroactive to July 1. At his daily news conference yesterday, Mr. Giuliani defended the raises when asked about complaints from some labor officials that they were too large.
The Mayor noted that by law, the panel of three citizens, called the Quadrennial Advisory Commission for the Review of Compensation of Elected Officials, is convened only once every four years.
"When the commission recommends raises, they recommend them with the anticipation that that will be the only raise for four or six years," he said. "So it makes it look as if the percentage is very high in a given year. I think they made a fair objective analysis of salaries throughout the country and they took into account that it's the only raise for a four-year period."
Asked if he would accept the raise, Mr. Giuliani replied: "Sure, if it's voted, absolutely. I am not a fool."
The members of the panel were Richard L. Gelb, chairman emeritus of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company; Stanley Brezenoff, president of Maimonides Medical Center, and Robert Kaufman, a partner in the law firm of Proskauer Rose. The panel recommends specific salary increases, which the Mayor and the Council can approve or reject but not change.
The Council also approved raises of more than 20 percent for the City Comptroller, to $160,000, from $133,000; 20 percent for the Public Advocate, to $150,000, from $125,000; more than 18 percent for the borough presidents, to $135,000, from $114,000, and almost 10 percent for the city's five district attorneys, to $150,000, from $136,700.
Mark Green, the Public Advocate, who refused to accept a raise four years ago because of the city's poor fiscal condition, said he would accept the increase this time in a healthy economy.
The Council members to vote against the raises were Stephen J. Fiala, of Staten Island; Kenneth K. Fisher, of Brooklyn; Martin J. Golden, of Brooklyn; Sheldon S. Leffler, of Queens, and James S. Oddo of Staten Island. During the debate yesterday, no one said he or she would refuse the raise.
Mr. Leffler said that the increases were too large because they far exceeded the rate of inflation. Mr. Oddo and Mr. Fiala said later that they wished the raises had been tied to legislation making Council positions full-time jobs with limits on outside income.
But on the chamber floor, other Council members were quick to defend themselves as overworked and deserving of raises. "It's not a merit raise," Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge of Manhattan said. "It's based on the responsibility that this body has."

HEADLINE: U.P.S. Going Public And Its Employees Hope for Windfall

BYLINE: By By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Ever since two Seattle teen-agers started a telephone message service in 1907 that grew to become United Parcel Service of America Inc., the company, now the world's largest package delivery service, has been a rarity in corporate America.
It is owned by its employees, and many spend their entire working lives there. The company's top 15 executives all began their careers sorting packages. 
 Even more unusual, for 92 years U.P.S. has resisted the entreaties of investment bankers and remained private. But yesterday, in the latest sign that the siren song of Wall Street is too hard to resist in an age of instant riches and the Internet, U.P.S. said it would sell 10 percent of itself to the public later this year.
The stock offering will very likely be one of the biggest in history, raising $3 billion to $5 billion. And in today's overheated stock market, analysts think U.P.S. shares will soar because of the company's link to the Internet -- as a prime deliverer of goods bought on line -- creating a windfall for tens of thousands of the company's managers, employees and retirees. That means that the local U.P.S. deliveryman in his chocolate brown uniform and matching truck could see his net worth soar.
"For years that's the thing everybody has been hoping for," said Jason Vines, a driver who was picking up packages yesterday in Manhattan and received the news from the company through its cellular network. "Now it's going to happen."
James P. Kelly, the chairman and chief executive of U.P.S., said the company, which estimates that it ships 6 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, had taken care to structure the deal so that it would preserve the company's culture. Though 10 percent of the company will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange, 99 percent of the voting rights will remain with the current employees and managers.
"In designing our plan," Mr. Kelly said, "we've insured that this fundamental element of our success will continue as an essential part of our future."
But once its stock begins trading, U.P.S., which is based in Atlanta, will come under the kind of pressure for short-term profits felt by other large corporations. Though in the past it could invest in new technology or expansion in Europe without worrying about the effect on its stock price, that luxury might be lost.
"This was an internally fed culture with an unusual sense of purpose," said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, the president of the nonprofit Chief Executive Leadership Institute in Atlanta, who worked as a consultant to U.P.S. for 12 years. "There is a hometown flavor to them. It is very meritocratic."
The formula has been a success. U.P.S. posted profit of $1.7 billion last year on sales of $24.8 billion, making it larger and more profitable than its rival, Fedex. Its 330,000 employees delivered more than 3 billion packages to 1.6 million customers in more than 200 countries. U.P.S. trucks and planes ply routes in virtually every corner of the world, making it one of the most recognizable brands.
Mr. Kelly said that U.P.S. needed to issue stock to the public to maintain its competitiveness against rivals like the FDX Corporation, which owns Fedex; DHL and several increasingly aggressive foreign postal services that are also planning to issue stock soon.
As the package delivery service has become global in recent years, U.P.S. has expanded into Europe, Asia and Latin America. It has also moved into the fast-growing logistics business, taking charge of the delivery of all parts and components for large manufacturers.
U.P.S. has more than $3 billion in cash and can borrow billions more, but it does not have publicly traded stock to use as a currency for deals. "We think we need this flexibility," Mr. Kelly said, "to provide ourselves with another tool should we decide to do the kind of strategic acquisitions we are talking about."
But analysts also said that it was becoming increasingly difficult for U.P.S. to continue to turn its back on the soaring values investors are giving an Internet-related company. Last year, FDX shares soared 47 percent after investors identified it as a so-called Internet play.
U.P.S. executives think they have an even better story to tell. They point to a report by Zona Research of San Francisco that concluded that U.P.S. delivers 55 percent of all the goods bought on the Internet. While $80 billion worth of merchandise was bought on line last year, Forrester Research in Boston estimated that the figure will balloon to $3.2 trillion by 2003.
That sort of talk should play well to investors when U.P.S. shares begin trading. "Their timing is excellent," said Edward M. Wolfe, an air freight and logistics analyst at Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown in New York.
There is also a strong reservoir of demand for U.P.S. stock from employees, their families and friends. The company now issues private stock to managers as part of their annual compensation and lets employees set aside part of their paychecks to buy shares.
The U.P.S. board sets the price of the stock each quarter based on the company's performance and future prospects. But it retains the right to buy back shares when employees retire to reissue them to others.
In the last 50 years, the shares have risen in value every quarter except one, in 1997, when they fell 25 cents after the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents 202,000 U.P.S. workers, struck the company. Yesterday, Chip Roth, a teamster spokesman, said the union was "analyzing the I.P.O. for its potential impact on employees."
Mr. Sonnenfeld said, "U.P.S. family members and friends that have seen the performance of U.P.S. stock have always wished they could buy some." Still, in place of a stock known for stability, they will have shares subject to the wild swings of the overall stock market.
Under the plan, U.P.S. will create two types of stock: A shares held by insiders and B shares held by the public. Each A share will have 10 votes compared with one for every B share. But instead of having to sell shares to the company, holders of A shares can convert them to B shares and sell them on the open market.
Today its internal stock is priced at $47 a share, giving the company a value of about $26 billion. But most analysts think that figure is extremely conservative, based on the valuations given to FDX and others. Some said it could go as high as $50 billion, which would mean that the company would raise $5 billion.
U.P.S. said it would use the cash to buy shares from employees who wish to sell. About 125,000 employees are shareholders. Still, no employee interviewed yesterday said he would sell. "It's a pot of gold for when I retire," said David Arroyo, 32, a driver who has worked at U.P.S. nine years and holds 500 shares.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From President Clinton's Wide-Ranging News Conference

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the news conference by President Clinton yesterday at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times: 

Prepared Statement
Today I want to make a brief statement about the choice we face here in Washington and in our country about how best to move forward into the new century and what to do with the surplus. When we look toward the future, it is helpful to remember at least the recent past.
Six and half years ago the budget deficit was $290 billion and rising, wages were stagnant, inequality was growing, social conditions were worsening. In the 12 years before I took office, unemployment averaged more than 7 percent. It's almost difficult to remember what it was like. No one really thought we could turn it around, let alone bring unemployment to a 29-year low or turn decades of deficits, during which time the debt of our country was quadrupled in only 12 years, into a surplus of $99 billion.
Our nation has made a seismic shift in the last six years from recession to recovery, from a crisis of confidence to a renewal of resolve, from economic disorder to a fiscal house finally in order.
Now as we debate what to do with our prosperity, we face a critical choice, whether to move forward with the fiscal discipline that got us to where we are today, or return to the kind of risk-taking that got us into recessions and deficits before. We must decide whether to invest the surplus, to strengthen America over the long term or to squander it for the short term.
I think the right course is clear and a bigger surplus only means that the mistake could be bigger and the missed opportunity greater if we take the wrong course.
I have proposed a balanced budget that puts first things first. I believe we must maintain our sound economic strategy and invest the surplus in long-term goals, saving Social Security, saving and strengthening Medicare, modernizing it by providing a long overdue drug benefit and continuing to meet our basic responsibilities in education, defense, the environment, biomedical research.
Tomorrow I will release a report that shows a great and growing need for prescription drug coverage. What the study shows is that 75 percent of our older Americans lack decent, dependable private-sector coverage of prescription drugs. That's three out of every four seniors. Clearly, America needs a prescription drug plan that is simple, universal and voluntary. Anyone who says we don't, I believe, is out of date and out of touch.
As I've described, my plan meets these national priorities, while paying off the debt by 2015, while investing in America's new markets, the places that have not yet felt our prosperity, and while providing substantial tax relief, $250 billion of it targeted to help families save for retirement, pay for child care, long-term care, for modern schools.
So let's be clear about something. We're not debating whether to have tax cuts or not. We should have tax cuts, but tax cuts that provide for us first to save Social Security and Medicare, not undermine them. Tax cuts we can afford, not ones that would demand drastic cuts in defense, education, agriculture or the environment. Tax cuts in the national interest, not special interest.
Now, these are the risks that are posed by the Republican tax plan that the House is about to vote on. Let me tell you what their plan would do. It would pile up $3 trillion in debt over the next two decades, right when the baby boomers start to retire -- that's what it costs -- right when Social Security and Medicare feel the crunch.
Because of the cost of the tax plan over the next two decades, I should say what it doesn't do. It doesn't do anything to extend the solvency of Social Security, to extend the solvency of Medicare to provide the prescription drug benefits, and it would require significant, significant cuts from where we are today in education, defense, biomedical research, the environment and other critical areas. If we don't save Social Security, it's not because we can't. If we don't strengthen Medicare and add the prescription drug benefit, it's not because we can't. If we don't meet these clear national needs, it's because we choose not to do so. It will be because instead we choose to reward ourselves today by risking our prosperity tomorrow.
I hope Congress will make the right choice. When members cast their ballots on the Republican tax plan, they're really voting also on whether to save Social Security and Medicare. They're voting on whether to pay off the national debt for the first time in over 150 years, something that would guarantee us lower interest rates, higher investment, more jobs, higher incomes and for average citizens, lower home mortgage payments, car payments, credit card payments, college loan payments. They're voting whether to meet our most pressing national priorities in education, defense, nearly every other domain in our people's lives.
I think the choice is clear between the plan the Republican leadership has outlined and the national priorities of the American people. I hope we can still work together across party lines to save Social Security and Medicare, to safeguard our priorities and have the right kind of tax cut. If Congress passes the wrong kind, of course I will not sign it. I will not allow a risky plan to become law. And as I said, we now have six and a half years of evidence. This is not really a debate that's just about ideas without any evidence. We clearly know what works now, and we ought to stay with it.
As I said, I will work with any member of either party willing to put first things first. We can't have a tax cut and do the right thing for the long term in America. That is my commitment and I hope that together we can fulfill it for our people.
 
Questions and Answers
Q. Mr. President, in U.S. treaty relations, is it obligated to defend Taiwan militarily if it abandons the one-China policy, and would the U.S. continue military aid if it pursues separatism?
MR. CLINTON. Well let me say first of all, a lot of those questions are governed by the Taiwan Relations Act, which we intend to honor. Our policy is clear. We favor the one-China policy. We favor the cross-straight dialogues.
The understanding we have had all along with both China and Taiwan is that the difference between them would be resolved peacefully. If that were not to be the case under the Taiwan Relations Act, we would be required to view it with the gravest concern. But I believe that both China and Taiwan understand this. I believe that they want to stay on a path to prosperity and dialogue and we have dispatched people today as the morning press reports to do what we can to press that case to all sides.
This is something that we don't want to see escalate, and I believe that what Mr. Lee said yesterday was trying to move in that direction. We all understand how difficult this is, but I think that the pillars of the policy are still the right ones. The one-China policy is right, the cross-straight dialogue is right, the peaceful approach is right and neither side, in my judgment should depart from any of those elements.
Q. But we would still have to go to war with China if it decided to break away.
A. I will say what I've already said. The Taiwan Relations Act governs our policy. We made it clear and I have, as you remember. A few years ago we had a physical expression of that, that we don't believe there should be any violent attempts to resolve this. We would view it very seriously. But I don't believe there will be. I think that both sides understand what needs to be done. . . .
Q. Economists have been calling on you to indicate now whether you intend to reappoint Alan Greenspan in order to avoid having the issue become mired in election year politics and upsetting financial markets next year. Would you like to see the chairman stay on? And has he given you any indication of his plans?
A. I have, as you know, enjoyed a very good relationship, both personally and professionally, with Mr. Greenspan. I think he has done a terrific job. I have no idea whether he would even be willing to serve another term. I will make the decision in a timely fashion. I do not expect it to become embroiled in election year politics. . . .
Q. Sir, you talk about how expensive the Republican tax cuts would be. But the Congressional Budget Office has now just come out with a report saying that even with their tax cuts, almost $800 billion in tax cuts, they would save about $277 billion over a 10-year period where by your program would save only about $50 billion. That's about a $227 billion difference. How do you reconcile that and, you know, people on the Hill listen to the C.B.O.
A. They listen to the C.B.O. except where it's inconvenient for them, like the Patients' Bill of Rights. The Republicans have freed us all now to question the C.B.O. since they ignored the C.B.O. on the Patients' Bill of Rights. They have discredited their own C.B.O. Let me say, I haven't seen that C.B.O. accounting.
All I can tell you is that all of our budget people were rolling their eyes and saying that it was a very creative study. Let me just say this: You have six and a half years of experience with the numbers we have given you and the estimates we have made. And every single year our numbers have not only been accurate, but we have done better than we said we would do. Every single year for six and a half years now. Our studies show that their tax cut, over the next two decades, will cost, first a trillion dollars and then three trillion in the second decade. And that then the enormous loss to the American people in interest savings. That is, we'll have to keep spending more and more of our tax money paying interest on the debt, and it will require huge cuts in education and defense and other things. . . .
Q. The C.B.O. says it estimates the cost of your Medicare reforms are more than twice what you say they are.
A. Well, again, you have evidence. Let me just say this: In the 1997 balanced budget agreement, we agreed to a Medicare savings figure. O.K. And we -- and this is the reason all these teaching hospitals are in trouble today. We agreed to a Medicare savings figure. And we said O.K., here is our health information. This is what we do in the executive branch, we deal with these hospitals. Here are the changes you need to make in the Medicare program to achieve the savings that the Republicans and the Democrats in Congress and the White House agreed on. And the C.B.O. said no, no, no, no. That won't come close. You need these changes plus these changes. And we said O.K., we're following the C.B.O. We put it in there.
What happened? That's one of the reasons the surplus is somewhat bigger than it otherwise would be, the cuts in Medicare were far more severe, our numbers were right, their numbers were wrong and that's why you've got all these hospitals all over America, every place I go, talking about how they're threatened with bankruptcy.
So when it comes to estimating Medicare costs, again we have evidence and whenever there's been a difference between us and the C.B.O., we've been right and they've been wrong. That's all I can tell you. No serious person -- and so what are they going to do about Medicare? They say our drug program will cost more. They don't put a red cent into it. What are they going to do about it? Even if you don't have a drug program, if you adopt their tax-cut program they won't be able to do anything to extend the solvency of Medicare and they will have to have huge cuts.
For them to produce those savings, they are going to -- they can't even fund my defense budget, much less the one they say they want. They're going to have cuts in defense, cuts in education, cuts in the environment. That's all their savings assumed that there going to stay with the present budget levels, which they themselves are trying to get out of even as we speak here today. . . .
Q. Sir, in your conversation with Chairman Arafat this morning, did you ask him to take any specific steps to advance what you believe is new momentum toward peace? And did you discuss with him his complaints yesterday that he found Prime Minister Barak's 15-month timetable unacceptable?
A. Well, I told him only this. I said that, I generally described my meetings with Prime Minister Barak to him. I told him that he was committed to working in partnership with Chairman Arafat and honoring any agreements that had been made to this point and that any, any modifications they make going forward to the benefit of either or both sides would have to be done by mutual agreement, that I thought he was completely committed to resolve the, all the issues outstanding in the peace process in an expeditious manner.
And what I urged him to do was to have this one-on-one meeting. Hear him out, think it through and if he wanted to talk to me again after the meeting occurred, that I would be happy to talk to him. So I went out of my way not to describe the Prime Minister's proposals or to advocate or not advocate, but simply to say that I was convinced they were being made in complete good faith and that they would, that the peace process would be revitalized and whatever they did from here on out is something that they would do together. And I think he felt good about that. . . .
Q. The House of Representatives appears to be on the verge of terminating funding for the F-22 fighter. Will the White House fight hard for full funding for that program, even if it means sacrificing other Pentagon airplane programs, or even pay for servicemen?
A. Well, I don't think we should sacrifice the pay for our service personnel because we now are getting back in the ball game in recruitment. The good economy and the increased deployments and the low pay all combined, making it hard for us to both recruit and retain people. And the people are still the most important part of our military, their quality and their training and their morale and their commitment and the condition of their families.
So I don't think that. Now the Congress every year puts other things into the defense budget which are not priority for the Pentagon and are priorities for the Congress. We can fund the F-22, we can fund the plane without compromising the basic priorities of our national defense, within the funds set aside, and that is what I will fight to do.
I think it will be a mistake to abandon the project. I think it has real potential to add to our national defense. I have always supported it. And I hope that it can be preserved.
Q. You had some fun recently with George W. Bush and his slogan of compassionate conservatism, but you went beyond the notion that he's not offering many details of his policy and seemed to ridicule his slogan and even question his sincerity. Were you just trying to help Mr. Gore's candidacy or were you taking the opportunity maybe to just needle the leading Republican candidate?
A. No, I was just having a little fun. I, you know, this is such a long time, if we don't have any laughs, this is going to be a very tedious struggle between now and November of 2000. Let me say this, I think that you know every, every person struggles to find a phrase, or something that will sort of stand for what he or she is trying to do.
So, I was really just having a little fun. I think the most important thing is that all the candidates make their positions clear on the great debates going on now. And make their positions clear on what they would do if they got the job. To me, that's the most important thing.
You know, I am not involved in this campaign as a candidate. And I have a full-time job so I'm not involved in any sort of full-time consulting role. So I look at this, I look at this more from the point of view of the average American voter.
What will change the lives of America? For example, every candidate should tell us, you know, are you for the Patients' Bill of Rights? Are you for closing the gun-show loophole? Are you for raising the minimum wage? Are you for the House Republican tax plan or do you favor our plan on Social Security and saving Social Security and Medicare and making America debt free and having a smaller tax cut that enables us to continue to fund education and defense and these other things? What are going to do if you get elected?
I mean, to me the best thing the Vice President's done is to talk about, you know, dramatically intensifying the war on cancer, making preschool universal, increasing access to college by helping people save without tax consequences, what he would do to make America a safer country, what he would do in communities to have faith-based organizations cooperate with governments more.
I think these are interesting ideas about how you build on the progress the country's made the last six and a half years. So I would say to everyone, use whatever slogans you want, but tell us where you stand. I think that's the most important thing.
Q. Mr. President, the economy is going great, and in a new USA Today/CNN poll this week your approval rating was at a very healthy 58 percent. But that same poll showed that by 50 percent to 38 percent Americans said they wanted to see a change from Clinton Administration policies, not a continuation of them. What do you think accounts for that sentiment for change? And do you think it means that you present something of a mixed blessing to Mrs. Clinton and Vice President Gore in their campaigns next year?
A. No. I think what that means is people think things are going well, but they want to change a policy. So I think that's right. If you ask me, if you ask me that question and you word it in that way, I'd be in the 50 percent because I think that my own view is that in a -- particularly in a dynamic time when things are changing, you should want continued change. But is -- the question is should we change in a way that builds on what has been done and goes beyond it, which is what I would argue.
Or should you change and go back to the policies we were following when we had $290 billion deficits and we averaged over 7 percent employment for 12 years? I mean, I think that's really the question the American people have to ask themselves. Is -- I think change is good.
The great thing about this country is that it works best when it's sort of in a perpetual stage of renewal. So I would, myself, as a citizen, I would vote against somebody who said, 'Vote for me and I'll keep it just like it is, everything that Bill Clinton did is exactly what I'll do.' I would vote against that candidate because I do not believe that is the right thing to do. But what I think we should do is we should build on what the progress of the last six years, and go beyond it. And not adopt a completely different approach which has been proven not to work.
So all I want the American people to do is to remember what it was like before, think what it's like now, recognize that ideas and policies have consequences, and you know, the American people usually get it right. That's why we're all still around here after more than 200 years.
Q. In your last press conference, sir, with Prime Minister Ehud Barak, you mentioned you wanted better normalized relations with Syria. Now have you received any response, positive response or indication from Syria toward that? And on Iran, can you share with us the Administration views of the last events and administrations in Iran?
A. Well, on Syria let me say I -- the only thing I can tell you is that the statements, at least, that have been coming out of Syria have been quite encouraging in terms of the regard that President Assad seems to have for the Prime Minister and the willingness, the openness that there is to negotiating and moving toward peace, so I'm encouraged by that.
And on Iran, frankly I'm reluctant to say anything for fear that it will be used in a way that's not hopeful to the forces of openness and reform. I think that people everywhere, particularly younger people, hope that they will be able to pursue their religious convictions and their personal dreams in an atmosphere of greater freedom that still allows them to be deeply loyal to their nation. And I think the Iranian people obviously love their country and are proud of its history and have enormous potential. And I just hope they find a way to work through all this, and I believe they will.
Q. You mentioned the Patients' Bill of Rights. It seems like that was an argument by both parties over providing more for people who already are lucky enough to have health insurance. And in fact neither party dealt with some very fundamental issues that energized you and the First Lady five and six years ago. My question is, with such a robust economy and the budget surpluses, if not now, when? And if not you, who would provide the leadership to provide for those folks?
A. Yes, but I think the bigger question is how. That is, it is true that just as we predicted in 1993 and 1994, that the percentage of people who have health insurance on the job is going down. Just as we said it would, if nothing was done.
So what we have tried to do is to isolate discrete populations that seem to be most in need and try to offer them help. In the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, we reached bipartisan agreement on a proposal that would fund providing health insurance for up to five million more children through state-designed programs.
Now, I've been a little disappointed, and I'm not being critical of any of the states either here, but I've been a little disappointed that the uptake on the program has been a little slow. That is, I would have thought by now we'd have almost three million of those five million children enrolled already, because we've got the money there. And we're well behind that.
So we are looking at whether there are things we can do at the national level to work with the states to simplify access to the children's health insurance programs that the states have set up. But I also had a talk with Senator Kennedy the other day who believes that for little or no more extra money we could actually adjust the program and take in several million more children. So the children are the biggest group.
Then I have a proposal, as you know, that's part of my Medicare reform proposal that I didn't mention today but I want to reiterate it, that would allow the most vulnerable group of people without health insurance, people between the ages of 55 and 65, to buy into the Medicare system in a way that would not compromise the integrity of the system. So I think that is quite important. In addition to that, there are a lot of states, or excuse me, there are some states -- Tennessee was the first state to do this -- which are allowing lower-income working families to buy into their Medicaid programs on a sliding scale.
So if all these things were done, we would dramatically reduce the number of people without health insurance, and will eventually probably get down to the -- . . . if we keep pushing in this direction, getting down to the point where the largest group of people without health insurance are young, single people who believe that they're going to live forever and be healthy forever and don't want to bear the cost. And we'll have to think about them, what to do, but what I think the best thing to do is to try to get as many kids as we can covered and then try to get these people who are out of the work force, who are older, but they're not old enough to get Medicare, to get them at least where they can all afford on the sliding scale to buy into the Medicare program. . . .
Q. Sir, you've stressed that you have plenty and yet for some time your political career has enjoyed the benefits of support from two people in particular: the Vice President and the First Lady, two people who are now in a position to expect some support from you. I'm wondering what you feel you owe those two people in terms of political support and as you plan your schedule in the weeks and months ahead, how you'll balance that assistance against your job as President and, finally, how you personally are adjusting to what people might think is an interesting shift in role.
A. Well, I will do whatever I'm asked to do, basically. I'll try to be helpful. And if I can be helpful, I will be. But I think it's -- the best thing I can do for anyone who is -- generally shares our ideas, part of our party, trying to move the country forward, is to continue to be a good President and take care of our country.
But I don't mind hard work and I don't mind long hours -- and I find myself apparently unlike some of my predecessors -- but I just read what you all say about it, but I don't feel myself winding down. I feel myself keying up. I want to do more. I want to try to make sure that I give the American people as much as I can every day. So I've got plenty of energy and I'll do whatever I'm asked to do. I owe them a great deal.
I mean I think Al Gore -- everybody in this room knows that he's had far more responsibility, and gotten more done, than any Vice President in history. Nobody's ever had a role that even approximates that. I don't think the American people know that yet. But I know that. And he deserves a lot of credit for what he's done. And he has my friendship and my support. . . .
And of course I did an interview and I talked about Hillary and this road. If she decides to do this, I will do whatever I can do and if she's successful I will happily go to the Senate spouse's meeting if that's part of the job. I think the -- I have never known anybody who didn't run for office who was a more effective, more consistently committed, completely passionate public citizen than her. . . .
Q. Mr. President, in that same vein sir, as the spotlight shifts from you to your Vice President and to your wife, are you likely to be content drifting slowly off stage? Or do you think that someday you will want to run for office, some office, again? . . .
A. I don't have any idea. I really, I don't -- let me just say, I love this job. I love it. Even on the bad days, all of a sudden you can do something good for the country, you can do something good for the future. I have loved doing this. And I have given it every ounce of my energy and ability and judgment and I have -- I feel very fortunate.
But we have a system that I frankly agree with, even though I'm in pretty good shape, we have a system that says the President gets two terms and then the President has to go find something else to do with his life. And there are lots of other worthy things to do. And I was a very happy person before I became President. I've never had any trouble finding something interesting to do that I believed in, and I will do my best to use the opportunity and the gift the American people gave me to serve in this position, to be a useful citizen of my country and the world for the rest of my life.
And I have no doubt that they'll be some way that I can do that. And I'm frankly kind of excited about it. I mean it's a new challenge. I'll have to think in a different way and do a different way. Will I miss a lot of the things about this job? Yes, I'll even miss all of you, believe it or not. But, and then -- but I'm just grateful that I've had the chance to serve and that the results have been good for our people and for our country and I think for the world. . . .

HEADLINE: Barak on Europe's Role

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 21

 BODY:
The Israeli leader, Ehud Barak, told Prime Minister Tony Blair today that the allied effort to halt tyranny in Kosovo showed that Britain and the European Union could play a significant role in providing conditions for peacemaking in the Middle East.
"The Kosovo crisis and the way it was led by President Clinton and Tony Blair provide an excellent example of how free-world leadership should act in the global arena," the Israeli said after a breakfast meeting with Mr. Blair en route home from Washington. 
 Speaking in the garden of 10 Downing Street, Mr. Barak praised the Europeans and Americans for defining "a clear line" that a tyrant could not cross without international retaliation.
"I believe this is important for the back yard of Europe, the Balkans," he said, "but it is maybe more important for any potential future despots anywhere around the world."
Mr. Blair left no doubt that he saw the Israeli succession, with Mr. Barak replacing Benjamin Netanyahu as Prime Minister, as a plus for the peace effort.
"There are a whole set of circumstances which have come together, not least with the election of the new Government in Israel, which allows us to move forward," Mr. Blair said.
He pledged full British backing, saying, "I just wanted to put on record our admiration for what he has achieved so far and my 101 percent support for all that he is doing for Israel and the Middle East peace process."
Asked about the Barak visit during a later appearance in the House of Commons, Mr. Blair said he was "very impressed" by the new Israeli leader and "pleased that he felt that Britain and indeed the E.U. could play a part in trying to bring about peace in the Middle East." He added, "And we will certainly be willing to do so."
In his maiden voyage to Washington as Israel's Prime Minister, Mr. Barak had extensive talks with President Clinton, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and members of Congress.
He said he had set a target of 15 months for achieving a comprehensive framework for peace in the Middle East that would encompass the Wye accord, "final status" arrangements with the Palestinians that would decide the borders of a Palestinian entity, the withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon and an agreement with Syria.
Today he said he highly appreciated the "positive signs" from Syria since he took office earlier this month, and promised to negotiate with the Palestinians in good faith.
"I think I can deliver," he said. "I think the time is right for achieving a peace of the brave between Israel and all its neighbors, including Syria. Time is of the essence for the whole process. We cannot sit idly and wait for the whole process to be solved somehow magically."
He cautioned that his hope of major progress toward a comprehensive peace within 15 months was more a goal than a rigid deadline.
"I won't ask for a medal if it takes nine months," he said. "But nor will I jump from a tower if it takes 24."

HEADLINE: A Speaker Under Pressure Beseeches His Party's Members

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
One after another, all afternoon, House Republican dissidents were summoned to the office of Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, who sought their votes to pass a $792 billion tax cut, the centerpiece of the leadership's agenda.
Mr. Hastert asked what problems they had with the bill. He discussed economics. He talked about the importance of tax cutting to the Republican Party. He told skeptics that the bill was only an opening step, a bargaining position in the negotiations yet to come with President Clinton. 
 Still, some Republican moderates held out throughout the long afternoon and into the evening, until many were satisifed by a concession linking part of the tax cut to a reduction in the national debt.
The one-on-one sessions were just one element of an intense lobbying campaign waged by Mr. Hastert and his leadership team as they tried to keep an assortment of Republican moderates and conservatives from jeopardizing a piece of legislation that was supposed to be the crown jewel of the Republican program.
At stake was not just the Republican agenda but also the credibility of Mr. Hastert as Speaker. And he came close to pointedly telling his colleagues just that. Republicans said that on Tuesday, at the party's morning caucus, he told them in unusually personal terms that he needed their votes for the tax bill.
One Republican involved in the vote-gathering said House leaders had also turned to officials of the Republican National Committee and to party donors, asking them to telephone members. The message was implicit: that campaign support for the holdouts could be in jeopardy.
And on Tuesday, when the 40 or so moderate Republicans who call themselves the Tuesday Group emerged from their weekly lunch, they found lobbyists from the National Association of Manufacturers and the National Association of Homebuilders waiting for them, to argue in favor of the tax cut.
Part of the difficulty for the leaders was the pure arithmetic of pushing anything through a House in which the Republicans hold one of the smallest majorities of this century. Their edge is only five seats after Representative Michael P. Forbes defected to the Democrats on Saturday, charging that his party was run by extremists. Uncertain whether they would draw any Democratic votes over to their tax bill, the Republicans could afford to lose only four votes of their own.
The day was made more difficult by the fact that tax cuts, which once served as the glue holding together the various elements of the Republican Party, no longer work like cement. In the new age of surplus politics, some moderates say they are determined not to do anything that might cause renewed budget deficits.
"This is where the rubber hits the road," declared Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, who had been pushing for assurances that the tax cut would not relegate debt reduction to second place and risk deficits' return. "These are real decisions on budget strategy and tax changes, and we need to be honest with the American people about where this debate is headed."
On the other side of the Republican spectrum, some conservatives as well were threatening to vote against the bill. Their problem was that it would not fully eliminate the so-called marriage penalty, which results in some married couples' paying more in taxes than they together would pay if they were single.
But Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, insisted that the leadership would yet prevail. "You always know how many horses are in the herd," Mr. Armey said as he went off to another meeting in early evening. "It's just a question of how long it takes to get them into the barn."

HEADLINE: Government Seeks an Ad Ban and Label Warning for Cigars

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21

 BODY:
Responding to the rapidly growing popularity of cigars, the Federal Trade Commission recommended today that Congress impose restrictions on them like those already on cigarettes, including health warning labels and a ban on television and radio advertising.
Congress has been reluctant to toughen restrictions on tobacco products, and there is little broadcast advertising for cigars. 
 But industry executives and Government officials said today that the agency's call for uniform health labels might be adopted, particularly as some states have begun to impose a variety of warning labels, a patchwork approach that the cigar industry considers burdensome.
In 1989, California became the first state to require health warnings on cigars, and earlier this year Massachusetts became the second. But critics have said the California warnings are not strong enough, and the two states require different labels. Moreover, some industry executives fear that if other states try to impose their own warnings, cigar boxes could begin to resemble a well-traveled suitcase covered with unsightly labels.
Federal officials also said the requirements in Massachusetts were only for machine-made cigars, not hand-rolled ones, and since there are often no requirements on placement of warnings, they have been put where they cannot be easily read.
The Federal Trade Commission's recommendations were approved 4 to 0. Robert Pitofsky, the chairman of the commission, said the agency had the authority to order the industry to post health warnings but decided instead to make the recommendations to Congress as the agency had done in the case of cigarettes.
The commission recommended that Congress consider rotating three warning labels to be put conspicuously on cigars, boxes and advertising:
*Warning: Regular cigar smoking can cause cancers of the mouth and throat, even if you do not inhale.
*Warning: Inhaling cigar smoke can cause lung cancer. The more deeply you inhale, the greater your risk.
*Warning: Cigars are not a safe alternative to cigarettes.
The recommendations follow a sharp rise in cigar sales from 1993 to 1997, when consumption increased by almost 50 percent to more than five billion cigars. The trend reversed a 20-year slump.
The largest increase in cigar consumption has been among relatively well-to-do young and middle-aged men, but there have also been significant increases among teen-agers and women, according to a study on the health effects of cigar smoking, which appeared last month in The New England Journal of Medicine.
That article, a study of 17,774 men of whom 1,546 smoked cigars, attributed the resurgence of cigar smoking to a widespread misperception that cigars are safer than cigarettes.
Studies by the National Cancer Institute and others have shown that cigar smoking can cause several forms of cancer and that cigar smoke contains the same toxic and carcinogenic constituents as cigarette smoke. The studies have also shown that cigar smokers face increased risks of heart and lung diseases and that cigars are therefore not safer than cigarettes.
The journal article also concluded that cigars had become more popular because they had been glamorized in advertisements and in movies and television shows. The trade commission called for health warnings to appear in print advertisements for cigars as they do for cigarettes.
Total marketing expenses of the five largest cigar makers, which constitute almost 90 percent of the national industry, grew by 32 percent to $41 million in 1997. Less than 1 percent of that marketing budget went for television and radio advertising, and today Mr. Pitofsky, the trade agency's chairman, said that the heart of the report was not the ban on such advertising but the new proposed labeling requirements.
While representatives of the cigar industry said a standard warning label could ease the problems associated with different state rules, they criticized the commission's report and others that have tied advertising to the rising popularity of cigars.
Norman F. Sharp, president of the Cigar Association of America, said that cigar consumption had been relatively stagnant over the last year and that the industry's marketing expenditures were a pittance compared to cigarette marketing. As a result of the California labeling law, Mr. Sharp said, health warnings already appear on about 96 percent of cigar packages.
Mr. Sharp said the increase in cigar consumption was largely a reflection of economic prosperity and renewed attention from the media.
"Cigars are now seen as one of life's little affordable luxuries, like beers from microbreweries and fine wine," he said.

HEADLINE: Soup Line to the Left, Armanis to the Right

To the Editor:
Re "Prosperity Builds Mounds of Cast-Off Clothes" (front page, July 19): No doubt there are many people in rural areas in the United States who would be more than happy to take some of the surplus clothing donated to charities, much of which is being shipped overseas.  Perhaps, as President Clinton suggested in his recent "poverty tour," we should refocus and intensify our efforts to assist those in need in these areas so that they may reap the benefits of our booming economy.

HEADLINE: Soup Line to the Left, Armanis to the Right

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A July 19 front-page article on the rise in clothing donations to charities mentions the decrease in the price of women's clothes as a contributing factor. This price reduction is likely made possible by the use of sweatshop labor in the United States and abroad. 
 If companies were forced to disclose the conditions under which our clothing is made, consumers could make better informed choices. And if workers were paid a living wage, clothing prices would rise to reflect their real value, forcing consumers to make more conservative purchasing decisions.
Meanwhile, retail clothing racks are bulging with inexpensive clothing, making it difficult to resist the urge to stock up on garments that become virtually disposable.
It is paradoxical that much of the donated clothing produced by exploited workers ends up being shipped back to its country of origin.
 
FREDRICA RUDELL
New Rochelle, N.Y., July 19, 1999
 
The writer is chairwoman of the department of marketing and international business, Iona College.
