HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"THE AMERICAN CENTURY: ART AND CULTURE, 1900-1950," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Aug. 22). This is the first half of a marathon end-of-an-era survey. (Part 2, covering 1950-2000, opens on Sept. 26.) It flows chronologically through four floors of the museum's galleries, resulting in a show of substantial if circumscribed pleasures. Most of the 600 paintings, drawings and sculptures are familiar icons from a canonical art history, one in need of shaking up. But if what is here is short on fresh insights, there are wonderful things to look at. By the time you've worked your way from Gilded Age society portraits on the top floor to Jackson Pollock below, you've had a genuine time-travel experience: exhausting, diverting, sometimes moving, even pride-inspiring. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $12.50; $10.50, students and the elderly (Holland Cotter). 

* "AMERICAN FOLK ART IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Sept. 5). One of the museum's less visible collections, this group of folk art portraits, views, genre scenes, marine paintings, religious works and so on has been assembled for its first overall showing, and high time. The best are the portraits, which include a masterpiece or two by the great Ammi Phillips, along with the work of Joshua Johnston, Erastus Salisbury Field, Rufus Hathaway and other greats. A very appealing section of watercolors and drawings includes mourning pictures, a Victorian convention in which relatives of the dead are shown weeping by tombstones; tributes to heroes like George Washington and General Lafayette, calligraphic endeavors and many lively renditions of family groups and trees. Not to be missed are some wonderful New York views, like William H. Schenck's "Third Avenue Railroad Depot" (1859-1860), a handsome red brick building that served as a trolley turnaround and station between 65th and 66th Streets. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 P.M. Admission: $8; $4, children and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
"FAME AFTER PHOTOGRAPHY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Oct. 5). Not the usual Modern exhibition, this breezily entertaining summer extravaganza includes hundreds of publicity stills, movie trailers, supermarket glossies and television excerpts that chart a trajectory from the world of Queen Victoria to that of Kato Kaelin. The subject is celebrity as a phenomenon redefined by photography. You'll leave it wondering whether something that has become so commonplace is still meaningful beyond its value as a marketable commodity. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:15 P.M. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
"IMPRESSIONISTS IN WINTER: EFFETS DE NEIGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 29). Think of the Impressionists, and chances are you think green: lawns, hedges and fertile fields of a deciduous nature caught at full leaf. But these artists were year-round workers, and winter landscapes, rendered in the frosty open air or through the glass of a studio window, figured in their repertory. Here are some 60 such paintings. And if ever a show were tailor-made for summer viewing, this one is. Its size is untaxing, and its deep-freeze images of snow-covered fields and ice-caked trees are the visual equivalent of air-conditioning. Of course, much of the work by Monet, Pissarro, Sisley and their colleagues is extremely beautiful in that immediate, you-have-to-be-there Impressionist way. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. (to 11 P.M. on the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $9.50; $7.50, students over 10 and the elderly (Cotter).
 
* "POMO INDIAN BASKET WEAVERS, THEIR BASKETS AND THE ART MARKET," National Museum of the American Indian, 1 Bowling Green, lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3712 (through Aug. 15). Baskets made by the Pomo Indians of northern California around the turn of the century were notable for the strength of their design and artistry, and when white settlers new to the territory discovered them a market began to develop. The baskets, in earth colors of black, tan and deep brown with subtle geometric designs, were often covered or accented with tiny colored feathers, clam shell disks (which once served the Pomo as money), abalone pendants and stones. They ranged in size from feast bowls that could feed a tribal gathering to miniatures so tiny they could be mistaken for seeds. This is a knockout presentation of the work of 47 early 20th-century Pomo basket makers. Organized by the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, it vividly tells the story of the weavers (mostly women), their patrons and collectors. Hours: Daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M. Free (Glueck).
 
* "PRAYER BOOK FOR A QUEEN: THE HOURS OF JEANNE D'EVREUX" AND "DEVOTIONS AND DIVERSIONS: PRINTS AND BOOKS FROM THE LATE MIDDLE AGES IN NORTHERN EUROPE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 29). The 14th-century book called "The Hours of Jeanne d'Evereux" is only three and a half inches high. But in the story of Western culture it looms large as a wellspring of a northern European painting that stretches from van Eyck to Bruegel. Recently the binding was removed to make a facsimile, and all the full-page illuminations are on temporary display. They are exquisite. The Met has organized a survey of medieval books and prints for the occasion, ranging from hand-colored block prints with a bumptious folk-art charm to polished designs from urban workshops. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
* "SURREALISM: TWO PRIVATE EYES," the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi Collections, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 12). The Surrealist collections formed by two friends fill the museum from lobby to ceiling. Although it has more than 700 objects, this powerful show is by no means a comprehensive survey but an intense, close-up experience of Surrealism that might be imparted by two obsessed acquisitors taking you on a personal tour of their treasures. Highlights include clusters of paintings by Dali, Victor Brauner, Magritte, Andre Masson and Yves Tanguy; a splendid group of boxes by Joseph Cornell; a brilliant selection of photographs rife with portraits by Man Ray; dozens of beautifully bound books, and remarkable drawings by Hans Bellmer and Masson. The show has notable omissions and a few surprising inclusions, but by and large the menu is high quality. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"PATTERN," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Aug. 27). This well-selected show presents two dozen artists for whom patterning is a compelling motive. Julia Jacquette neatly paints rows of penny candy and Nina Bovasso produces wacky agglomerations of cartoon motifs inspired by Philip Guston and R. Crumb. Donna Sharrett's lacy quasi-Victorian mandala woven from synthetic hair and Mary Judge's Minimalistic block of gray concrete bricks bearing a radiating pattern of fine charcoal lines each convey a ritualized spirituality (Johnson).
 
* "STAMPED WITH A NATIONAL CHARACTER: 19TH-CENTURY AMERICAN COLOR PLATE BOOKS," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through July 31). Color in books is a commonplace today, but 200 years ago it was a rarity in American volumes and affordable only by upscale readers. With more than 100 examples, this thoroughly absorbing show traces the evolution of the American color plate book from 1800 to the end of the century when machine production ended laborious hand operations. Assembled from the collection of William S. Reese, a New Haven dealer and collector, its objects range from John James Audubon's giant portfolio "The Birds of America" to fashion books and medical texts with gruesome illustrations. Worthy of special note is the earliest color plate book produced in the United States, "The City of Philadelphia, in the State of Pennsylvania, North America, as It Appeared in the Year 1800," a handsome offering that might be called the first American coffee table book (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
"LINEAR IMPULSE," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Aug. 13). This crowded presentation of variously linear paintings and sculptures includes famous artists like David Smith, Mark Tobey and Lee Krasner. There are works in outmoded Modernist styles, like the Surrealistic Cubist paintings of Jimmy Ernst, but there are things that still look fresh, including richly layered paintings by Alfonso Ossorio and a dense ball of wire and glass by Claire Falkenstein (Johnson).
 
ODD NERDRUM, "Self-Portraits," Forum, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 355-4545, (through July 30). These self-portraits don't deliver the sort of weird storytelling for which the Norwegian humanist is revered by his fans, but the most startling picture, in which the artist holds up the hem of his golden, pearl-studded robe to expose a swelling, marmoreal paunch and upsweeping erection, is not to be missed (Johnson).
 
JUDITH JOY ROSS, Pace Wildenstein MacGill, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999 (through Aug. 27). Ms. Ross makes understated, uncommonly sensitive photographic portraits, especially of children. Among her lovely gold-toned 8-by-10-inch works are pictures of a blond, messy-haired urchin slouched at his elementary school desk, gazing at the camera with a look of heartbreaking ennui, and of a 10- or 11-year-old girl standing by a hazy lake with a Band-Aid on her knee and an ethereal aura (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
"THE BUREAU OF INVERSE TECHNOLOGY," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323 (through July 31). The Bureau of Inverse Technology is a group of Neo-Dadaists who think up perverse applications for new technology. Though visually uninteresting, their most intriguing projects operate like chillingly plausible ideas in a dark science-fiction novel. "Suicide Box" proposes to correlate a real-time tracked suicide rate (people leaping from Golden Gate Bridge) with the Dow Jones Industrial Average to generate "a new economic indicator" called the "Despondency Index" (Johnson).
 
"CAUGHT," 303 Gallery, 525 West 22d Street, (212) 255-1121 (through July 30). The diverse works in this five-artist show are linked by oblique humor and formal lucidity. Jason Meadows scrambles an aluminum stepladder; Evan Holloway constructs a plywood stealth bomber; Shannon Okasana copies a dozen portraits of the singer Nana Mouskouri from different album covers; Samara Caughey makes biomorphically perforated wooden platforms, and Dexter Dalwood paints a circular view of a futuristic command console (Johnson).
 
"THE CONVERSATION," Jack Shainman, 513 West 20th Street, (212) 645-1701 (through July 31). No two works in this 11-artist show look alike, yet somehow they all hang congenially together. The exhibition includes an optically mesmerizing spinning machine by David Ireland; a colossal watercolor head by Till Freiwald; a small, dense swatch of alphabetically embroidered fabric by Alighiero Boetti, and a goofy Minimalist foot painting by Carl Ostendarp. A 14th-century granite Indian deity presides (Johnson).
 
"EUROPE ON A SHOESTRING," Weber, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 691-5711 (through July 31). This roundup of European avant-gardists ranges from the amusing to the oblique. Highlights include a Roman Olpalka number painting; Alghiero E. Boetti's enormous steel-framed window with the delightful title, "Nothing to See, Nothing to Hide," and Hans Haacke's "Photo Opportunity," which pairs a portrait of George and Barbara Bush at a storm disaster site with a portrait of a poor Alabama farm family by Walker Evans (Johnson).
 
WADE GUYTON, Andrew Kreps, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-8849 (through July 30). Mr. Guyton has removed everything from the gallery's office and storage space and installed a puzzling, roughly made abstract sculpture of slotted Plexiglas units, two oblique architectural photographs and a piece of dark plywood. This stark and harsh environment contrasts sharply with the crowded, anarchic installation of Kreps's complete inventory in the main exhibition space (Johnson).
 
ERIK HANSON, Derek Eller, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through July 30). Mr. Hanson draws on his background as a Minneapolis punk rock D.J. to make pencil doodles in which elements are systematically labeled with song titles by famous rock groups. For a series of Donald Judd-style "caves," the artist installed colored plaster stalagmites and stalactites between plywood boards. This work is pretty slight but charming nevertheless (Johnson).
 
"KILL ALL LIES," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9100 (through July 30). This motley group show is held together by language, subversive intent and different kinds of static. Jean-Michel Basquiat's early graffiti wall writings are recorded in Henry Flynt's handsome color photographs; the 1998 United States bombing of Iraq is the subject of a sound piece by Dara Birnbaum, and Steve DiBennedetto's bright, fragmented abstract paintings are little exploding worlds unto themselves (Smith).
 
"LOST AND FOUND," Audiello Fine Art, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 675-9082 (Through July 30). This modest summer show of gallery regulars and guests has the slightly forlorn look suggested by its title. Most of the work feels physically vulnerable and secretive, as if it were in the process of coming or going, with melting snowmen, hand-painted dolls in corners and a suitcase with family photos that may be something new to be discovered or something old best left behind (Cotter).
 
RITA McBRIDE AND SYLVIA PLIMACK MANGOLD, Alexander and Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through July 30). Ms. McBride's installation focuses obliquely on the concept of the art exhibition. Three sets of curvy wooden bleachers invite viewers to sit and look at a picture on the wall, which periodically changes. (First up was a Cindy Sherman self-portrait as a secretary from 1978.) Ms. Mangold's Precisionist painting of a ruler on a wooden floor reflected in a wood-framed mirror and a more recent Cezannesque portrait of a tree echo the woodiness of the bleachers (Johnson).
 
MICHAEL PAHA AND SKEET MCAULEY, Feigen Contemporary, 535 West 20th Street, (212) 929-0500 (through July 30). A nice double feature here, the pairing of two artists whose work is based on human tinkering with nature. Bringing landscape indoors with gratifying results, Michael Paha has created a miniature garden of many levels, an ingenious orchestration of plants, terrariums, carved wooden troughs, sand, rocks, guppies and even a kitchen sink, nourished by a recycling river that runs through a loop of pipes connected to a pump. Skeet McAuley shows big color photographs of golf courses along with close-ups of bonsai trees and desert stones. The golf courses, in the American Southwest and Hawaii, lie in manicured splendor against rougher natural backgrounds of mountains and scrub vegetation. His very formal views of bonsais and groomed rocks emphasize the artificiality of these objects, whose cultivation arose from a Taoist bent for taming nature (Glueck).
 
"THE SEA, THE SEA," Murray Guy, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7372 (through July 30). Among the attractions in this smart, understated selection of works related to oceanic themes are Kay Rosen's bouncy painting of the words "nausea" and "seasick"; deft painterly miniatures by James Sheehan and Pamela Golden; a lush seascape made of cut paper by David Thorpe, and dark, dense, postcard-size pictures of watery surfaces by Michael Blodget (Johnson).
 
"STARS AND STRIPES," Ricco/Maresca, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4819 (through Aug. 14). In this absorbing exhibition of photographs and folk art America's star-spangled banner exerts iconic resonance. In Philip Jones Griffith's photograph "Vietnam," the flag flies in the distance while a soldier washes up in a crater; Jayne Hinds Bidaut's shadowy, contemporary tintypes depict full-bodied nude women wrapped in the flag and a funky, flag-waving goddess of liberty weather vane made in 1865 points the way (Johnson).
 
KRZYSZTOF ZAREBSKI, "Water Nymphs," Pardo Sheehan Gallery, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 242-8523 (through July 31). A Polish-born assemblagist and performance artist, Mr. Zarebski has a grab-bag of ideas, many of them far from fabulous. He is preoccupied with leeches, the fat worms once used for bloodletting. Live ones appear on his back in a number of photographs; painted ones in the glass jars that form part of works here and there. Other exhibits range from a battery-operated toy water nymph that swims aimlessly up and down in a plastic trough to the muzzle of his dog, acquired after the animal bit a dog owned by a neighbor (together with the neighbor's complaint, taped from an answering machine). The show recalls somewhat the antics of the 1960's Fluxus group, but they were better editors of their own work (Glueck).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
PEDRO BARBEITO, Basilico, 26 Wooster Street, (212) 966-1831 (through July 30). A young Spanish-born painter who lives in Brooklyn presents four absorbing paintings that look like complicated computer-generated diagrams. Mr. Barbeito applies layers of thick paint, following underlying grid patterns. At certain points, small-scale gridded structures made of layered paint project several inches from the surface. There is a nice tension between disembodied rationalism and quirky materialism (Johnson).
 
"FOREVER IS A HELL OF A LONG TIME," Bronwyn Keenan, 3 Crosby Street, (212) 431-5083 (through July 30). This engrossing works-on-paper exhibition shows how anarchically entertaining pluralism can be. It includes neatly lettered self-help titles by Brian Block; small deft Surrealistic doodles about animals by Adam Raymont; Jonathan Herder's collages in which Abe Lincoln fills in for Frank Sinatra; liquor stores in Detroit listed by Valaire Van Slyck, and a wonderful dragon head painted with the intensity of an Old World miniaturist by Robert Medvedz (Johnson).
 
CHIP HOOPER, "California Dreamin,' " Edward Carter Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-1933 (through Sept. 11). The Big Sur coast of northern California and the Southwest desert are explored in these contemplative black-and-white photographs, with a bow to the work of Ansel Adams. Viewing the daily moods and changes of the Big Sur territory, Mr. Hooper captures events ranging from the flaming eruption of dawn over the sea to the milky dusk that settles on Soberanes Beach. In his studies of ancient cliff dwellings in the desert, you can almost sense the spirits of the long-gone occupants. No affectations mar this work; the photography is robust, if on the traditional side (Glueck).
 
"MIXUP," Lehmann Maupin, 39 Greene Street, (212) 965-0753 (through July 30). This interesting, albeit disconnected, show of artworks by seven designers and one fine artist includes a gel-filled talking punching bag by Natasha Makowski and Alexandros Psychoulis; a hypnotically percussive sound installation by Tobias Frere-Jones, and clever mock commodities by Daniel Jasper, who has invented an agency called Daddy to market to young Neo-Marxist revolutionaries things like oven-fired bricks and an "Auto Critique Pistola," a beautiful silver pistol that fires backward (Johnson).
 
ANTOINE PEVSNER, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through July 31). This remarkable exhibition presents 120 drawings done from 1912 to 1956 by one of the original Russian Constructivists. Made in graphite in an elasticized Cubist style, they realize Pevsner's fantasy of Machine Age dynamism more persuasively than do his sculptures, which today look clunky and dated. Artists who continue to explore the possibilities of abstraction might find this collection a rich source of ideas (Johnson).
 
JOAQUIN TORRES-GARCIA, Cecilia de Torres, 140 Greene Street, (212) 431-5869 (through July 31). This show of small paintings and drawings on paper commemorates the 50th anniversary of the Uruguayan-born modernist's death. Torres-Garcia's gridded, pictographic works, by which he articulated a comprehensive cosmic philosophy with an unassuming comic touch, are especially engaging (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"THE CATHEDRAL PROJECT: LIZ DESCHENES, KEVIN LARMON, DONALD MOFFETT," Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (through Aug. 29). Constantly being worked on, ceaselessly eroding with time, the cathedral is a Gothic ruin under construction and worth a visit any time. Its spirit of uphill optimism finds a counterpart in this uneven three-artist show that commemorates both the 30th anniversary of the Gay Liberation movement and the realities of AIDS. Ms. Deschenes's photos of a hots springs in Japan have a Heaven and Hell look: billowing steam could be clouds or smoke. Donald Moffett's shots of the sky over New York are mute, abstract versions of a wild blue yonder. Kevin Larmon's paintings, done on wood panels that belonged to a fellow artist, Tom Brazelton, who died of AIDS last year, are beauties (Cotter).
 
"HANG TIME," White Columns, 320 West 13th Street, West Village, (212) 924-4212 (through Aug. 1). This amusing show of works relating to sports and leisure includes George Raggett's "Weiner Island," a kidney-shape wooden deck equipped with a grill; Eric Porter's Minimalistic beer cooler; Sylvan Lionni's pristine simulation of a Ping Pong table; Cristian Alexa's photographic documentation of a day in a hammock; ridiculous competitions staged and videotaped by a team called Type A; baseball numerology by Janet Cohen; soaring footballs photographed by Pamela Lins, and videos about tennis and roller coasters by Andrea Ray and Neil Goldberg, respectively (Johnson).
 
"HOLY ART OF IMPERIAL RUSSIA," American Bible Society, 1865 Broadway, at 66th Street, (212) 408-1200 (through Oct. 2). The icons in this show are a long way from the great Russian icons produced from medieval times through the 17th century, most of which are firmly ensconced in Russian churches and museums. The objects here, collected by a Florida-based art restorer, Gary Hollingsworth, are from the 18th to the 20th centuries, when icon painting had by and large declined into a stale fustian enterprise of copying and embellishment. But like Latin American retablos, these were made mostly for private devotion or humble parish churches, and many have a folk quality that energizes them. Some are clumsily painted, some are slick with sweetened colors, but others carry their religious imagery in artistically appealing ways. Collectively, they give a colorful hand-me-down account of the many styles, personages and events of the great icon heritage (Glueck).
 
Last Chance
 
"CLARA GUTSCHE: THE CONVENT SERIES," Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through Sunday). At once matter-of-fact and quietly radiant, these 54 photographs taken in 20 Canadian convents include pristine interiors and pictures of nuns, shown in prayer, lined up outside their rooms, reading in the library, playing cards in the community room. They document a life of devotion, selflessness, unwavering daily routines and restrained joy, while also insinuating themselves into the history of portraiture, religious art and contemporary set-up photography (Roberta Smith).
 
"FOR MYLES," Five Myles, 558 St. Johns Place, Brooklyn, (718) 783-4438 (through tomorrow). A new exhibition space opens in Brooklyn with a six-artist show selected by Marian Griffiths, the former Sculpture Center director. Included are a snaky, 27-foot cast-iron spinal column by Jack Pospisil; Michael Lee Poy's globular, cosmically split "Crystal City"; poetic boxed works about hair by Cathleen Lewis; a meditative grid of padded paper and pins by Veronica Ryan; Terry Boddie's mixed-media essays on the martial art Capoelra, and ceremonial tiled stools by Maria Elena Gonzalez (Johnson).
 
* LIZA LOU, "American Glamorama," Grand Central Terminal, (212) 878-7178 (through Monday). The extreme beader Liza Lou followed up her unforgettable "Kitchen" (1995) with the spectacular "Backyard" (1997), on view along with other works in the Main Waiting Room. A life-size tableau of twinkling grass and goofy flowers surrounding a loaded picnic table, a ruby barbecue grill, a glittering lawn mower and more, all realized in zillions of glass beads, "Backyard" is not only a marvel of crafty industry but also a funky, transcendental transfiguration of an iconic American scene (Johnson).
 
* "THE MEDIEVAL HOUSEBOOK: A VIEW OF 15TH-CENTURY LIFE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sunday). Mystery still surrounds the vivacious 15th-century German manuscript known as the Medieval Housebook -- who the artists were, for example. Part idyll, part real-life manual for the landed gentry, the housebook touches on such miscellaneous matters as astronomy, astrology, courtly love, chivalry, mining, metallurgy, jousting, warfare, recipes, medications, castle defense, animal husbandry and the trapping of men by female predators. In its exquisitely detailed drawings, a mischievous mix of the elegant and the bawdy, men and women conduct lofty amours and earthy functions, the raffish mingle with the raffine, and sybarites are far more evident than saints. A secular sanctuary in a religious era, the manuscript captures, for an enchanted moment, the spirit of a world that's bygone yet very much a prologue to our own. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
"WHEN TIME BEGAN TO RANT AND RAVE: FIGURATIVE PAINTING FROM 20TH-CENTURY IRELAND," Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through tomorrow). This begins with works influenced by Impressionism and Post-Impressionism and ends with routine versions of 80's Neo-Expressionism. Rife with derivative, overearnest work, it is most valuable as a reflection of Ireland's painful history and its effect on its art. It makes palpable the tensions between artists who wanted to keep abreast of international (mostly French) developments in art and those who disdained modernism and celebrated Irish rural life or the struggle for independence. Its high points are few, but include the work of Jack B. Yeats, whose thickly painted Expressionist works succeed in fusing distinctly Irish predicaments and states of mind with an original, contemporary style (Smith).

HEADLINE: SPARE TIMES;
FOR CHILDREN

 BODY:

Theater
 
"GOLLY GEE WHIZ!," a musical set in 1939 in a town called Happyville, where the teen-agers decide to boost the economy by putting on a show, could have been pure saccharin. Instead, the show is a funny spoof, thanks to the authors, Eric Rockwell and Joanne Bogart, the director and choreographer, Cynthia Thole, and the spirited performances by Tada's 8- to 17-year-old thespians. Tada, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea. Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays at noon and 2 P.M.; Saturdays and Aug. 1 at 1 and 3 P.M.; through Aug. 1. Tickets: $12; $6 for ages 15 and under. Reservations advised: (212) 627-1732.
 
Events 

AT&T LATINO ARTS FESTIVAL, celebrating the diversity of Latino art and culture, runs through Aug. 8 at the Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows Corona Park, off Exit 9E of the Grand Central Parkway, near Shea Stadium, Queens. Shows this weekend that may interest youngsters include Teatro Circulo's "Los Titingos de Juan Bobo," short stories intermingled with music, songs and traditional Puerto Rican folk tales (tomorrow at 3 P.M.) and a performance by the Spanish dance troupe Noche Flamenca (Sunday at 3 P.M.). Tickets: Teatro Circulo, $15; $10 for children. Tickets: Noche Flamenca, $20 and $25. There is also a free performance Sunday at 1 P.M. of "Smiles and Wisdom," three short bilingual fables from Latin America featuring animals, plants and animated objects. Information: (718) 760-0064, English; (718) 760-0686, Spanish.
 
CARNAVAL EN EL YUNQUE. The tropical forest plants of Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, will inspire youngsters to create colorful masks and costumes, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M. in the Kerlin Learning Center. Afterward the dancer Yvette Martinez and the musician Nancy Friedman will lead youngsters in a carnival like the one that takes place in July in Loiza, Puerto Rico, celebrating the rain forest, or Yunque. Free with garden admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Tuesdays, free all day; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.
 
THE CLYDE BEATTY-COLE BROTHERS CIRCUS comes to Brooklyn. The three-ring circus presents a two-hour show of traditional aerial, acrobatic and animal acts. It pitches its tent in Brooklyn's Marine Park, Avenue U west of Flatbush, tonight at 5 and 8 and tomorrow and Sunday at 1:30, 5 and 8 P.M. Tickets: reserved seating, $14; for children 12 and under and the elderly, $9; general admission is $2 less. The circus then moves its red-and-gold big top to Staten Island, Midland Beach Park, at Father Capodanno Boulevard, Monday through Thursday, with performances at 5 and 8 P.M. Information: (718) 441-0080.
 
FAMILY ARTS FESTIVAL at the Theater of Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, at 120th Street, will take place weekends through Aug. 1. This weekend's performances include the Godino Opera Ballet (tonight at 7 and Sunday at 2 P.M.), the Leela Puppet Theater (tomorrow at 2 and Tuesday at 7 P.M.) and the music troupe O'Samba Brazilian Capoeira tomorrow and Sunday at 7 P.M.). Call for ticket price. Information: (212) 870-6784.
 
GEOLOGY 101, a workshop for children 7 and older with Scott Chessman, a geologist with the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, who will demonstrate how rocks are mined and how to identify minerals, tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue. Free. Ages 7 and older. Information: (212) 860-1370.
 
"STORY CORNER: ADVENTURES AT SEA." LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: Focusing a Green Eye on Car Plants

BYLINE: By JIM MOTAVALLI 

 BODY:
HOW green is your Volvo? Its manufacturer is happy to tell you, in its recently published Environmental Product Declaration, a cradle-to-grave look at the pollution generated by the manufacturing, use and eventual dismantling of its S80 luxury sedan.
"It's our judgment that consumers have a right to this kind of information," said Hans-Olov Olsson, president and chief executive of Volvo Cars of North America. "It lets people know about the environmental processes that are ongoing within the company." 
 Some of Volvo's categories are familiar, like exhaust emissions (the company gives itself various scores from 9 to 90 percent, depending on pollutant) and parts recyclability (50 to 100 percent). But the product declaration also looks at a process not often discussed -- the actual manufacturing of the car in Torslanda, Sweden -- and it admits there is room for improvement.
Although Volvo has made big gains in cleaning up emissions from the paint shop, generally the dirtiest part of any car plant (Volvo gave itself a 91 percent score), and has little material waste (86 percent), it scolds itself for using too much energy to build the S80 (46 percent).
No other auto company offers such a holistic look at the environmental impact of its operations, but all of them care about the image they project. So they promote everything from air-conditioning refrigerants free of chlorofluorocarbons to brake pedals made from recycled tires.
It is not surprising, then, that there was an outcry from the car makers that scored poorly in the environmental ratings of 56 United States car plants by the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research institution in New York that advocates what it calls responsible corporate behavior. Mitsubishi came in last of eight manufacturers in the council's reckoning, with Honda next to last. The top scorer in the weighted ratings was DaimlerChrysler, followed, in descending order, by General Motors, BMW, Ford, Nissan and Toyota.
Honda was particularly wounded, since it plans to introduce soon the Insight, a very clean, fuel-efficient hybrid-power car, and its president, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, said last year that the company was willing to put "everything on the table" to fight global warming and reduce greenhouse gases. Mitsubishi offers several cars with excellent fuel economy, and it recently successfully negotiated an end to a long-running boycott organized by the Rainforest Action Network over the company's forestry operations. It saw the bad publicity as not only unfair, but also particularly ill-timed.
Not surprisingly, the mood was more sanguine at DaimlerChrysler, the top-scoring company. James A. Carlson, director of pollution prevention and remediation, said that the results were "a positive acknowledgment that we've been pro-active in dealing with plant environmental issues."
Both Honda and Mitsubishi questioned the process by which the Council on Economic Priorities had scored the companies. Only 70 percent of the score was derived from the companies' actual environmental performance; 10 percent was based on an evaluation of their annual environmental reports. (Only Nissan failed to publish one.) The other 20 percent came from a ranking of environmental management systems. Honda and Mitsubishi were penalized for failing to return the council's detailed questionnaire.
"We fundamentally disagree with C.E.P.'s conclusions, which are, frankly, unsupportable," said Roger Lambert, senior manager of company communications for Honda. "They said they downgraded us because we didn't complete their survey form, but we shared with them extensive information that showed that even as our plants in Marysville and East Liberty, Ohio, were increasing production by 30 percent from 1994 to 1997, they were also decreasing per-unit chemical emissions by 71 percent."
Mr. Lambert said that starting in 1990, Honda was an "aggressive" participant in an Environmental Protection Agency program to reduce emissions of 33 chemicals by 50 percent over five years. The East Liberty plant, he said, was the first in the nation to switch to cleaner water-based paint, in 1989, and was the first to use returnable containers for parts delivery. Honda also pioneered the salvage of auto-body stamping scrap for use in brake and engine parts.
At the Council on Economic Priorities, Romi Gottfrid, an environmental research associate who was a principal author of the report, disagreed with Honda about the data the company provided. "They sent us nothing," she said. "We didn't even get the glossy public relations handouts."
Mitsubishi accused the council of misreading toxic-emissions data that manufacturers report annually. A spokeswoman, Gael O'Brien, said: "Mitsubishi performs all functions such as stamping, welding, painting and assembly in one facility, while most other auto makers have separate sites for these operations. And those other facilities report their emissions separately." She added that the council had failed to give the company full credit for recycling. "Less than 6 percent of the emissions we generate are actually released," she said.
Judged solely on its generation of pollutants, as measured by 1996 toxic-emissions data, the Mitsubishi plant in Normal, Ill., is unquestionably the nation's dirtiest, producing 21.6 pounds of toxic chemicals per vehicle. But E.P.A. data indicate that Mitsubishi has an 85 percent recycling and recovery rate. And the agency offers caveats about drawing conclusions from raw data.
In response to Mitsubishi's complaints, Ms. Gottfrid said the council stressed reducing pollution at the source. In response to a letter from Mitsubishi, the council said, "Controlling pollution is the old way of looking at the problem, versus the new way, which is pollution prevention."
If reports like the Council on Economic Priorities' are a stick to goad corporations into building cleaner plants, the voluntary principles outlined by another group, the Council for Environmentally Responsible Economies, are a carrot to move them forward gently. Among auto companies, only General Motors is a signatory, but corporations outside the industry, including Polaroid and the Body Shop, have signed on. The nonspecific principles call on manufacturers to, among other things, "reduce and where possible eliminate waste through source reduction and recycling."
Does the public care about dirty auto plants? The 1999 edition of "The Green Guide to Cars and Trucks" by John DeCicco and Martin Thomas (American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, $8.95) notes, "Most of the environmental impact associated with motor vehicles occurs when they are used." Manufacturing accounts for 9 percent of the energy eventually used by a typical car, the book says.
The Council on Economic Priorities has tried to bring plant emissions to the forefront by enlisting a public relations firm and providing bulk copies of postcards that are pre-addressed to the president of Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing, Michino Yamashita. "Your Normal facility yields four times the toxic emissions of the best auto manufacturer in the U.S.A.," the cards say.
Bad publicity hurts, but do cleaner companies benefit from high scores? "Consumers aren't yet demanding environmentally friendly products, and they're definitely not prepared to pay for them," Mr. Olsson of Volvo acknowledged.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush's Speech on Goals

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt from a speech delivered yesterday in Indianapolis by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner for the Republican Party's Presidential nomination, as provided by Mr. Bush's Presidential exploratory committee:
 Today I want to propose a different role for Government, a fresh start, a bold new approach. 
 In every instance where my Administration sees a responsibility to help people, we will look first to faith-based organizations, charities and community groups that have shown their ability to save and change lives. We will make a determined attack on need, by promoting the compassionate acts of others. We will rally the armies of compassion in our communities to fight a very different war against poverty and hopelessness, a daily battle waged house to house and heart by heart.
This will not be the failed compassion of towering, distant bureaucracies. On the contrary, it will be Government that serves those who are serving their neighbors. It will be Government that directs help to the inspired and the effective. It will be Government that both knows its limits and shows its heart. And it will be Government truly by the people and for the people.
We will take this path, first and foremost, because private and religious groups are effective, because they have clear advantages over government.
Sometimes the idea of compassion is dismissed as soft or sentimental. But those who believe this have not visited these programs. Compassion is not one of the easy virtues.

SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1276 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A blitz by new media helps old media foil forecasts of doom.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE boom in the new media of the Internet is supposed to portend the beginning of the end for traditional media along with a similar fate for the traditional advertising agency. But don't waste time trying to tell those purported dinosaurs about their impending doom: They're too busy counting the money pouring in from, of all places, the very companies that are supposedly going to put them out of business.
The rush among Internet companies to promote their brands to computer users is turning into a gold rush for television, radio, newspapers, magazines and outdoor advertising, not to mention the mainstay Madison Avenue agencies. 
 "The economy is strong and advertising is good anyway," said Stephen B. Shepard, editor in chief of Business Week magazine in New York, published by the McGraw-Hill Companies. "But because of technology and E-commerce, we're blowing the doors off."
"Our summer issues are like April or October fat," he added. "There are tons of ads from companies you didn't know a few months ago -- and in some cases, you hadn't heard of till you see the ad."
How robust is the growth for the traditional media from the on-line media? While spending among all advertisers in traditional media in the first quarter of 1999 rose 4.6 percent from figures in the period a year earlier -- according to Competitive Media Reporting, a research unit of VNU N.V. -- the largest gain by far came in the category of new media: up 183.1 percent, to $284.2 million from $100.4 million.
"It's just like when the medium of TV got turned on, and ad budgets escalated geometrically," said Jonathan Bond, co-chairman at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, an agency that works for cyberspace clients like the DLJ Direct on-line brokerage firm and Theglobe.com at its New York and San Francisco offices.
"It's a race," Mr. Bond said. "The first one to become a brand wins."
To become a brand, a product must gain awareness among consumers. But the new media still lag behind the traditional media in how many consumers they reach; for instance, about 37 million households have Internet access while about 100 million have TV sets.
"Especially for businesses that are trying to target people who are on the fence about going on line, the traditional media are obviously the best place to reach an audience not quite there yet," said Patrick Keane, director for on-line advertising strategies at the consulting company Jupiter Communications in New York.
So in addition to the hefty sums spent by the new media in the new media to advertise themselves, they must also turn to the old media, at least for the moment, to reach mass audiences to advertise their wares.
"Right now, it's a feeding frenzy," said O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the industry trade association in New York.
"It's ironic that all the 'dot coms' are using off-line media to attract people to their sites," he added. "But you cannot do on the Net what you can do in a 30-second television commercial or a strong newspaper ad."
Indeed, newspapers are scrambling to keep up with the additional demand for ad space.
"The one word I would use is explosive," said Jyll F. Holzman, senior vice president for advertising at The New York Times. "It's triple-digit growth."
"An account that wanted to spend $2 million in eight weeks came in yesterday," she added, "and it was 35 minutes from 'We're interested' to 'We'll commit.' That does not happen every day."
The Times plans to run a special news section about E-commerce on Sept. 22, Ms. Holzman said, and "it could have the most advertising of any special section ever to appear in our pages."
The sibling print medium of magazines is reporting similar strength. For the first six months of 1999, new- media companies spent $111.5 million to advertise in magazines. That was 154 percent above the $44 million spent in the period a year earlier -- and almost as much as the $117 million spent during all of 1998.
"The reports of our demise are premature," said Chris Miller, executive vice president for marketing at the Magazine Publishers of America, the trade association.
"Nobody is going to kill anybody," she added. "The media are all being married to each other."
Even the most prosaic media are benefiting.
"If you sit on the beach as I did last weekend," said F. Stone Roberts, co-chairman and chief executive at Gotham Inc. in New York, an agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies that handles cyberclients like America Online and WebMD, "half the banners you see planes towing are for 'dot com' businesses."
"They had a little something different in mind when they used to talk about 'banner ads,' " he added.
Another form of outdoor advertising, billboards, is also thriving, particularly in what Tom Bedecarre, chairman at Citron Haligman Bedecarre/Euro RSCG in San Francisco, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, described as "the top wired markets." Those are cities like Boston, Denver and San Francisco in addition to the giants like Los Angeles and New York.
"Billboards along Highway 101 near the San Francisco airport and in Silicon Valley go for $15,000 to $25,000 a month," said Neil Cohen, senior vice president for business affairs at Adauction.com in San Francisco. Last week, his company auctioned several sites for an average of 35 percent more than the already high prevailing prices.
"We started in remnant, distressed media," Mr. Cohen said. "But an auction also works when something is scarce, in demand."
The demand in traditional media is keeping traditional agencies busy.
"We must get five calls a day saying, 'We've got $2 million to spend and we like your E*Trade advertising,' " said Rich Silverstein, co-chairman and creative director at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. "I can't even keep track of it."
"The reason they seem to need us is that we have to give them a brand, a soul," said Mr. Silverstein, whose agency, a unit of Omnicom Group, recently landed big "dot com" accounts like E*Trade, the on-line brokerage firm, and Ebay, the auction Web site. "There isn't a lot of soul on the Internet."
San Francisco is a hotbed of account activity because of its proximity to Silicon Valley.
"We went from no 'dot com' accounts to five in the last six months," said Mr. Bedecarre, referring to new clients like Cnet and Women.com. "And it will be six tomorrow; we were just hired by someone else."
"We love working with these clients," he added, "because there's a greater conviction in the on-line world that advertising works than in the off-line world."
That feeling is fueled by cash raised in initial public offerings and from venture capitalists, who encourage ad spending to build businesses and market valuations by building brands.
"In the old days, ad spending was funded by profits," Mr. Bond said, "and no profits meant no ad spending. But now there's a paradigm shift. It's O.K. to spend money on advertising without profits; your financial strategy and your marketing strategy are intertwined."
Still, Madison Avenue is less than exuberant about all the new new-media work.
"This is the time you have to be very careful," Mr. Silverstein said. "Not all these companies are going to make it."
"Tell me where is Tucker, Hudson, Studebaker?" he asked, referring to defunct car brands. "It all sorted out to the Big Three."
Mr. Bond agreed.
"It's all risky," Mr. Bond said. "I'm not bragging about our Internet assignments."
"I'll be honest with you," he added. "I've got to find some boring old bricks-and-mortar clients."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Pepsi Acknowledges Role in Putting Coca-Cola Under Inquiry

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The European Commission's raid this week on Coca-Cola offices in four countries followed complaints from competitors, including Pepsico, that had accused Coke of unfair business practices intended to keep rival products off store shelves.
Pepsico acknowledged yesterday that it had informed European Commission officials that it believed Coca-Cola was abusing its dominant position in the European market. The acknowledgment indicates that the cola wars have moved to a fresh international arena. While Pepsi executives had said they would not exploit Coke's problems that arose from a recall in Europe earlier this month, they appeared less constrained over Coke's already difficult relationship with the European Commission. 
 "Late last year, we expressed our concern about certain Coca-Cola practices that we believe are unlawful, and this year we filed a formal complaint with the commission," a Pepsi spokesman, Richard Detwiler, said yesterday. He would not elaborate on what those practices were. But the European Union's competition commissioner, Karel van Miert, said yesterday that the inquiry centered on whether Coke had used its power as the biggestseller of soft drinks to dissuade retailers from stocking rival products.
Mr. van Miert said European regulators suspected Coke had used illegal incentives in Denmark, Austria and Hungary. They included rebates for meeting growth targets and for offering a full range of Coke products, and payments for exclusivity.
He also said there were "indications that Coca-Cola is granting very significant promotional rebates in the form of price reductions or free products, which are sold by participating buyers, like supermarkets, during promotions."
A Coca-Cola spokesman denied the accusations, saying, "We are confident that at the conclusion of this process, the Coca-Cola Company's business practices will be found to be within all laws and regulations."
Earlier this year, Mr. van Miert castigated Coca-Cola executives over plans to acquire most of the overseas rights to Cadbury Schweppes brands, accusing the soft-drink giant of trying to sidestep European Union antitrust rules. Coke maintains that it and the European officials interpreted the requirements differently.
Investigators from Mr. van Miert's office swooped into Coke offices in Austria, Hungary and Denmark early Monday and Tuesday, seizing documents from company files. They also seized papers from company offices in London.
At a meeting with analysts in New York yesterday, Coke's chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, played down what had happened. "It's a pretty routine thing," he said. "It happens. It's not the first time. It's been happening in other industries." He added: "I sort of expected it, that as this wave was going through, someone in the E.U. would say, 'Oops, we forgot Coca-Cola.' "

HEADLINE: 'Gimmick' Eased Passage Of Tax Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
All day on Wednesday, Republican leaders negotiated with a small band of moderate Republicans who were threatening to bring down the party's cherished tax-cut bill on the ground that Congress might be risking money the Government did not have.
Finally, a compromise was contrived that satisfied both sides. The incremental reductions in income-tax rates would not go into effect, they agreed, in any year when there was not a budget surplus. 
 At first, the Republicans decided to measure whether a surplus existed by determining each year whether the national debt was lower than the previous year.
Then, shortly before midnight, they changed plans and decided that the gauge triggering tax cuts would be whether Government interest payments were lower than they were in the previous year.
The apparent reason for the change is that counting tax cuts, gross Government debt can be expected to rise slightly over the next 10 years because of transfers between Government accounts. That would mean tax cuts could not go into effect. But total interest payments are projected to fall because the Congressional Budget Office is forecasting lower interest rates.
When the vote was taken early today to put the restrictions into the tax bill, hardly any of the legislators knew what they were voting for.
In the light of day, when outside policy experts on both sides of the tax-cut debate had a chance to read the measure, they pronounced it absurd.
"It's just a dumb idea," said Stephen Entin, an economist at the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, who was a Treasury official in the Reagan Administration and is a devotee of deep tax reductions.
Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now an economist at the Brookings Institution and who opposes tax cuts, said, "It doesn't make a whole lot of sense."
But the experts can take solace in one point: Hardly anyone in Congress thinks the contrivance will become law.
"It was a gimmick, a smear of grease to get us past a sticky spot last night," said a senior Republican Congressman who spoke on condition of anonymity.
A top staff member on the Senate Finance Committee said there was no chance this would become part of a companion bill that will go before the Senate as early as next week.
The moderate Republicans in the House who agreed to the deal were breathing easier today after all the pressure they faced from their leaders on Wednesday.
"I didn't want to be part of killing a significant tax bill," said Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey, adding that she could not have voted for the bill without the trigger mechanism.
What if the bill comes back from the conference with the Senate without the mechanism?
"We'll have to face that when we come to it," Ms. Roukema replied.
Another moderate, Representative Nick Smith of Michigan, who was one of the main authors of the compromise, said, "If this doesn't come back from conference, 40 Republicans will have to be convinced that our conferees really tried and couldn't do it. And even then some of us will be quite wary."
Here is how the mechanism would work: Each July, the budget office would determine whether total Government interest payments, to the public and to Government trust funds, were lower in the previous 12 months than they had been in the 12-month period before that.
If they were lower, then the cut in income-tax rates scheduled to go into effect the following Jan. 1 could be put into place. Otherwise, the tax cut would be postponed for a year. Then it would be subject to the same test of lower interest payments.
Under the bill, tax rates would fall by one percentage point in 2003 and continue to fall in annual increments until the reduction reached 10 percentage points in 2009.
The other tax cuts in the bill, like the reduction in capital gains rates and the abolition of inheritance taxes, would not be affected.
The worst problem cited by the policy experts is that interest payments, which depend not only on the size of the debt but also the level of interest rates, are not always a good measure of debt reduction.
Another problem is that if interest payments rise sharply from one year to the next and then fall slightly in the following year, a tax reduction would be allowed even though more interest was paid in the third year than in the first.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Aides Seek Alternatives To an I.M.F. Sale of Some Gold

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Faced with mounting opposition in Congress, the Clinton Administration began backing away today from plans to have the International Monetary Fund sell a portion of its gold reserves to finance debt relief for some of the world's poorest nations.
The Administration's plan, a legacy of former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, calls for the I.M.F. to sell up to 10 million ounces of gold on the open market. But gold prices have been falling, in part because of the I.M.F. plan and a sale by the Bank of England, and mining companies and gold-producing countries have lobbied to kill the plan. 
 A senior Treasury official, briefing reporters today, gave the first public acknowledgment that Congress was unlikely to approve the plan.
"We are exploring whether there are alternative ways of mobilizing I.M.F. gold reserves that would avoid any impact on the gold market and would be acceptable to the I.M.F.'s membership -- would command the support of Congress," he said. But the official declined to specify what kinds of alternatives the Treasury was considering.
On Wednesday, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, said he opposed the plan to sell the gold. He said he feared that the sale would hurt many of the same countries that the United States was trying to help, including nations like South Africa that rely heavily on gold sales.
The initial logic of the sale was to turn a nonproductive I.M.F. asset, a portion of the gold that the international lending agency was given after it was created more than 50 years ago, into an income-producing asset. The money from the sale would be invested, with the proceeds used to help pay off the debts of the most indebted countries. Leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations approved the plan in June.
But under the rules of the I.M.F., sale of the gold requires the approval of 85 percent of the monetary fund's members. Washington controls an 18 percent share of the fund, and Congress determines how the United States' vote is cast. Approval by the banking committee would be necessary, and Mr. Leach said today that he had determined that would not happen.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Large Luxury Condominiums Sell Steadily at East Side Tower

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
With 76 family-size apartments and amenities that include a screening room and personal wine-storage units, the Empire is the latest entry to Manhattan's luxury condominium market. The 32-story, $75 million building is rising on a site on the Upper East Side that was once home to the so-called Cottages, a row of 1930's stores topped by apartments overlooking an interior garden that supporters spent more than a year unsuccessfully trying to save.
Most of the apartments at the Empire will have two to four bedrooms, though there will be two one-bedroom models. The apartments range from 1,273 to 3,205 square feet, and many can be combined to create larger spaces. 
 Though the building, at 188 East 78th Street and Third Avenue, is still a year away from completion, contracts have been signed for 23 apartments since sales began six weeks ago. Prices, which have already been raised an average of almost 4 percent, range from $665,000 to $3.87 million, with penthouses going to $4.15 million, said Adrienne Albert, president of the Marketing Directors of Manhattan, the project's sales agent.
It is being developed by a joint venture of Davis & Partners and RFR Holding, developers of luxury rental buildings in the neighborhood. The Empire, the partners' first condominium project in Manhattan, joins a spate of similar projects developed in the last year as builders capitalize on what they say is a continuing demand for family-size condominiums.
The supply-demand imbalance has pushed the construction of luxury condominiums into new locations. "It used to be that buyers of luxury apartments needed to be on Fifth or Park Avenues," said Sachiko Goodman, managing director at Sumitomo Real Estate of Manhattan. These days, the buyers are different -- younger, with new money made on Wall Street, or overseas buyers -- and they prefer new buildings with large apartments and more amenities, she said.
But with each new project, said Louise Sunshine, president of the Sunshine Group, another Manhattan brokerage, developers are forced to come up with new services and amenities to make their buildings stand out. "Its like a game of one-upmanship," she said.
In turn, prices have risen to an average of $1,000 per square foot, or $1.6 million for a typical 1,600-square-foot, two-bedroom unit and $2.4 million for a 2,400-square-foot, three-bedroom apartment, Ms. Albert said. The average price per square foot rises to $1,100 on the Upper East Side and is 20 percent higher still for new units, she said. So far, the average sales price per square foot at the Empire is almost $1,100 and "we are contemplating raising prices again at the end of the summer," she said.
Ms. Sunshine said that as long as the economy remains strong and families continue to remain in Manhattan, demand will be steady.
Indicative of that is the pace of sales at the Empire. "If 200 to 300 condominiums were being developed, I would be very cautious, but I don't see that kind of production happening on the Upper East Side in the years to come," said Trevor Davis, one of the development partners.
"The demand is there for large apartments in this location." Mr. Davis added that since he and his partners control the entire blockfront on the west side of Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets, they "have preserved a corridor of light and air" and insured that another building could not be built next door.
The Empire project met with spirited opposition. A local group, the Coalition to Save the Cottages and Garden, unsuccessfully rallied to preserve the Cottages site, with its lush courtyard garden and eight apartments. After more than a year of legal wrangling, the remaining five tenants accepted a settlement from Mr. Davis and his partners to move, and the coalition lost its last attempt to have the site landmarked.
Last fall, the partners closed on the purchase of the site and began building the new tower. Mr. Davis said there would be a new interior garden, designed by Thomas Balsley Associates of Manhattan, as well as landscaped rooftop and terrace areas. The building's design also aims to maintain the character of the Cottages, he said.
The building, a 26-story tower topped by a gabled roof over a six-story base, will fill half the Third Avenue blockfront, with the tower portion at the northwest corner of 78th Street. Its base becomes two stories from the midblock to the 77th Street corner to incorporate the portion of the commercial and residential row that has been retained.
The design of the building, by Hartman-Cox Architects of Washington, also calls for refacing the Third Avenue facades of the old storefronts with the same rose-colored brick and precast stone simulating limestone that will be on the new tower. And the red brick exterior of four former Cottage apartments will be also be cleaned and restored or recreated, as will some of their architectural details, including their peaked roofed vestibules.
The Manhattan firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron designed the apartments, all of which will have features like nine-foot ceilings on average and washers and dryers, and many will have terraces or balconies. Other building amenities include a private dining salon and children's playroom as well as an underground parking garage for 25 cars. There will also be 36 storage areas and 36 personal wine storage units available for purchase by residents.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
How the Racial Literacy Gap First Opened

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
My great-grandfather John Wesley Staples (1865-1940) was vain about writing and scribbled even grocery lists theatrically, gesturing grandly with the pencil and pausing between words to lick its point. A fuss over a shopping list seems ridiculous -- until you consider that John Wesley was born in the slaveholding South, where educating black people was illegal until after the Civil War and where aggressively literate blacks were seen as subversive and even dangerous well into the 20th century. Modern writing on the role of race in academic achievement generally discounts this history. But the only way to grasp the extent of the problem is to acknowledge that black literacy was obstructed as a matter of law for more than a century.
John Wesley's father, also named John, was enslaved in Virginia in 1831, when the black Baptist firebrand Nat Turner led the bloody slave rebellion that terrified the whole of the plantation South. Slave owners blamed black literacy for the plot, and pursued what historians have since described as a program of "compulsory ignorance" to prevent slaves from colluding through written material. A Virginia state law passed in the year of the rebellion forbade schooling not just for slaves but for free Negroes as well -- forcing parents to exile their children into Northern states in order to educate them. 
 When free Negroes petitioned for relief, the legislature passed a deliberately vindictive statute, banishing from the state any child who left Virginia for the purpose of learning to read and write. Similar laws were passed quickly throughout the South and took an enormous toll. By the time John Wesley was born, only 1 in 10 Negro adults were literate.
"Compulsory ignorance" created a legacy of alienation from books and reading that has had a lingering effect on African-American achievement. The most pernicious fallout was a set of preconceptions -- often held by both blacks and whites -- that defined brawn work as black and brain work as an exclusively white activity. Of the many obstacles to academic excellence, expectations based in race have proved to be one of the most important -- and least-studied -- factors.
This could change with a forthcoming report from the National Task Force on Minority High Achievement, sponsored by the College Board. Many studies have scrutinized academic achievement among impoverished black students. But the task force study, one of the first of its kind, has ventured into affluent areas like Evanston, Ill., and Berkeley, Calif., to examine a disturbingly persistent achievement gap between blacks and whites who are essentially of the same class and economic backgrounds.
A recent article by The Times's Pam Belluck examining the task force's work in Evanston shows that the fallout of enforced illiteracy is still evident not just among the black poor but in the black middle class.
Black students who excel at school typically struggle with racial stereotypes and conflicted notions of ethnic identity. Some students absorb the broader society's view that they can never be first-rate students and give up trying. Those who excel are routinely attacked by their friends for "selling out" and becoming "white." Still others find themselves confronted by teachers and counselors who cannot conceive of them as academically inclined and discourage them from taking advanced courses.
Black families that urge their children on are historically less well equipped than whites to provide necessary supports. For one thing, the black parents are most often first-generation college graduates -- who grew up in households without books or systems that could support first-rate academic achievement. The current crop of black high achievers, then, is battling hostile cultural conditions -- and traveling a course that no one in the family has traveled before.
The National Task Force on Minority High Achievement will study these students at school, at home and among their peers -- in an attempt to produce more of them, more quickly. But what is already clear is that the leap from averageness to excellence for children of the black middle class will require discarding attitudes and preconceptions that were hundreds of years in the making. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
MajorIndexes Close Lower After Fed Chief's Testimony

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday as Wall Street gave a bearish reading to comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, about the economy and the stock market.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.56 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 10,969.22, while the Nasdaq composite index slumped 77.33 points, or 2.8 percent, to 2,684.44. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 18.32 points, or 1.33 percent, to 1,360.97. 
 In his twice-yearly testimony to Congress, Mr. Greenspan said the surge in stock prices could be overdone.
"We do know that a significant part of the rise in prices reflects rising expected earnings and a goodly part of that is a very major change in the view of where productivity is going," Mr. Greenspan said.
"What we do not know is whether it is being overdone, or to what extent it is being overdone," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has repeatedly warned about the stock market's high valuation over the last few years. The most famous instance was in December 1996, when he questioned investors' "irrational exuberance" as the Dow hovered at 6,000.
As recently as last Friday, all of the major stock market indexes rocketed to new highs, with the Dow jumping to a record 11,209.84, propelled by strong corporate earnings.
Amazon.com plunged 18 1/4, to 107 3/16, yesterday after analysts predicted that the on-line retailer would keep losing money as it continued to spend heavily to expand into new businesses. Late Wednesday, the company, which is the Internet's biggest retailer, reported a loss of $82.8 million, compared with a loss of $17 million a year earlier.
The stock of the Internet service provider America Online ended 4 9/16 lower at 110 1/2 even though it posted revenue and earnings that topped Wall Street forecasts.
Also, a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter analyst, Mary Meeker, raised her earnings estimate for America Online for the fiscal years 2000 and 2001. Ms. Meeker said the company's lineup of branded product offerings was becoming more powerful, with 17.6 million paying subscribers.

Bond Prices Suffer Loss
 By Bloomberg News
Bond prices suffered their biggest loss in a month after the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said yesterday that the economy might be growing fast enough to prompt the Fed's second interest rate increase this year.
"The Fed is still very much in the picture," said Steven Bohlin, who helps manage $1.9 billion of bonds at the Thornburg Management Company in Santa Fe, N.M. Mr. Bohlin expects the Fed to increase rates at its next meeting, which will be held Aug. 24, and possibly again after that. He is holding new cash that comes into his funds instead of investing it, for now, as protection in case bonds fall more.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 2 7/32, to 90 4/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.96 percent from 5.9 percent on Wednesday.
Bonds fell as Mr. Greenspan delivered his twice-yearly testimony to Congress. "If new data suggest it is likely that the pace of cost and price increases will be picking up, the Federal Reserve will have to act promptly and forcefully," he said.
The Fed raised its target for overnight lending between banks, the Federal funds rate, to 5 percent from 4.75 percent last month to try to cool economic expansion, now in its ninth year, and head off inflation.

HEADLINE: Ernst & Young Gets Breaks To Stay in New York City

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In a deal that marks the first time the city has granted tax breaks to keep an accounting firm from leaving, the Giuliani administration and the state have agreed to provide Ernst & Young with a $20 million incentive package to build a skyscraper in Times Square.
Ernst & Young, one of the largest accounting firms in the world, would move to a new 37-story office tower at the southwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, next door to the New Amsterdam Theater, from its current headquarters on Seventh Avenue at 52d Street. The new site sits across the street from one office tower nearing completion, 4 Times Square, and another tower just starting construction, the Reuters Building. Five blocks to the north, a hotel is under construction. 
 On Wednesday night, Ernst & Young signed a deal for its new headquarters with Boston Properties, the real estate company that controls the development site , according to executives and officials involved in the negotiations. City and state officials said yesterday that they were completing the details of an incentive package for the company that would include $10 million in tax breaks on the purchase of equipment and machinery, a $2 million training grant and a discount on electrical power worth $5.5 million. City officials said the deal would not be formally approved until Aug. 10.
The Ernst & Young deal amounts to a second subsidy for the building. Under the 42d Street redevelopment project, the site itself has property tax breaks worth $236.4 million over 20 years.
The city has long provided tax breaks to banks, media companies and other large corporations that threatened to leave New York. But until now it had refused to grant subsidies to law firms, architects and accountants on the theory that those kinds of services would not leave the city because they need to be close to their corporate clients.
Randy Levine, deputy mayor for economic development, said the city would reap many benefits from the Ernst & Young deal, which is principally tied to job growth. The accounting firm would get the full value of the package only if it adds 6,000 employees to its current workforce of 4,000 over the next 20 years, he said.
"We look at things on a case-by-case basis," Mr. Levine said. "They're creating an extraordinary number of jobs and there's going to be a new building. I think it's one of the better transactions the city has done."
But urban planners, economists and budget watchdogs who describe these deals as corporate welfare said the Giuliani administration was setting the stage for other accounting firms to demand the same kind of incentives.
"This is totally unnecessary given the strength of the city's economy," said James Parrott, an economist with the Fiscal Policy Institute. "Unfortunately, it opens the door for yet another industry dominated by large profitable corporations to start lining up for these subsidies."
Indeed, PricewaterhouseCoopers, another large accounting firm, is negotiating to build an office tower at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas and plans to ask the city for tax breaks, according to executives working with the company.
"It would be a lot better to devote those tax revenues to improving the overall business climate for economic development and jobs," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission.
The Ernst & Young deal has also dismayed some executives at both the city and state economic development agencies.
"The economy gets better and we give out more and more money," one executive said. "How does that make sense?"
Last spring, Ernst & Young had threatened to move some employees to Jersey City if it did not receive a $65 million tax break, a sum that both city and state officials said they thought was ludicrous. The state agreed to provide a small training grant and a $4.5 million sales tax exemption, but the city initially balked at granting any additional subsidies at such a desireable site.
Robert E. Selsam, senior vice president of Boston Properties, declined to comment other than to say the company was completing the acquisition of the site. Leslie C. Zuke, a spokesman for Ernst & Young, said, "There's no final deal."
