HEADLINE: Fed Chief Warns About Stocks and Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned anew about euphoric stock markets today and pledged to act "promptly and forcefully" to prevent any revival of inflation.
He then infuriated some House Republicans by characterizing their drive for a huge, immediate tax cut as premature and economically unwise. 
 Wall Street quickly interpreted Mr. Greenspan's testimony to the House Banking Committee as a warning that the Fed's Open Market Committee is more likely to raise interest rates, possibly as early as its next meeting in August but almost certainly by October unless the economy slows from its current robust pace.
Mr. Greenspan's comments "left little doubt that he is nervous about inflation risks in the United States," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America in New York.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which plunged from its high for the day by more than 100 points after Mr. Greenspan began talking, rallied a bit before the close, ending down 33.56 points at 10,969.22. But the broader market -- especially growth-oriented technology stocks -- fell much more sharply.
And the bond market, which is extremely sensitive to the potential for Fed action, tumbled as the rate on the 30-year Treasury, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, climbed to 5.96 percent from its close of 5.90 percent on Wednesday.
In answering questions from lawmakers, Mr. Greenspan hedged his comments, acknowledging that there is no evidence yet of inflation's imminent return. But his prepared remarks, which express the views of the entire group of Fed policy makers, were more hawkish than many had expected and suggested that the Fed's recent modest rise in short-term interest rates will not necessarily be its last.
When the Fed nudged rates higher by a quarter of a percentage point on June 30, it said it had taken a "neutral stance" on the future direction of interest rates. But that position, Mr. Greenspan made clear today, did not preclude acting as soon as the Fed sees imbalances emerging in the economy.
"If new data suggest it is likely that the pace of cost and price increases will be picking up," Mr. Greenspan said, "the Federal Reserve will have to act promptly and forcefully."
He also expressed concerns about an overheated stock market. In a more muted version of his famous 1996 comments about "irrational exuberance," he discussed the risks of a euphoria that exceeds any reasonable assessement of returns.
"The danger is that in these circumstances, an unwarranted, perhaps euphoric, extension of recent developments can drive equity prices to levels that are unsupportable even if risks in the future become relatively small," he said.
 While Wall Street focused on Mr. Greenspan's comments on the likelihood of another rise in short-term interest rates, Washington focused on his unusually clear warning to Republicans about their plan to cut taxes by $792 billion in the next 10 years. The subject came up several times, and Mr. Greenspan's message was stern: Don't do it.
"I'm saying hold off for a while," Mr. Greenspan said just two hours before the House approved the tax bill. "And I'm saying that because the timing is not right."
Mr. Greenspan urged Congress to pay down the debt and delay any tax cut until the economy begins to turn down. "The business cycle is not dead," he warned, telling lawmakers that whenever an economic slowdown hits, "a significant tax cut" may be needed to ward off recession.
Mr. Greenspan was quick to add, as he has many times before, that tax cuts are preferable to increased spending. Republicans have often cited this in support of their plan.
But the Fed chairman openly disagreed with Republicans like Rep. Merril A. Cook of Utah, who asked, "What's wrong with moving down that path simultaneously?" -- that is, paying down the $5.6 trillion national debt and cutting taxes.
Mr. Greenspan responded that tax cuts should wait until the debt is clearly shrinking. "Once we know we really have got it locked in place," he said, and "if we are not being confronted with a large number of spending programs, which try to eat up the surplus, I think at that point we can basically focus on getting important tax cuts in place."
Effectively, Mr. Greenspan was siding with the White House, Democrats in the House and a small number of moderate Republicans who have argued that the tax cut passed today is too big and too soon. No sooner had he spoken than some Democrats were repeating his words on the House floor in last-minute, unsuccessful arguments against the tax-cut bill.
"At some point -- I don't know when that is going to be -- this economy is going to slow down and perhaps slow down quite significantly," Mr. Greenspan said.
"At that point, I would suspect that a significant tax cut, mainly of marginal tax rates and capital gains tax rates, might be a very useful and timely vehicle to sustain an economy which is otherwise weakening."
The markets shrugged off Mr. Greenspan's longer-term predictions of a slowdown and focused on his assessment of whether the Fed would act pre-emptively to slow the economy. "Most of the time we can't be pre-emptive because, as I point out in my remarks, the future is opaque," said Mr. Greenspan, who is widely considered an expert on opacity.
On monetary policy, he ran through the familiar litany of potential problems that could fuel inflation: A slowdown in the growth of productivity improvements, continued labor shortages, rising oil prices. But he stopped short of saying that he saw an immediate threat.
Mr. Greenspan said he would be paying particularly close attention to the next report on job growth in the economy, due in early August, and to changes in commodity prices, which can be a useful indicator of early price pressures and the strength of industrial activity.
He also played down the risks of weakness in the global economy, saying that the fears last year that prompted the Fed to cut rates in the fall have eased considerably.
"Greenspan's testimony," said Tim O'Neill, chief economist at Harris Bank/Bank of Montreal, "suggests that he believes there is a high probability that interest rates will need to rise further to contain future inflation."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Fed Chairman's Testimony to Panel

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, presented his semiannual report on the economy to the House Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts:
Last fall, the Federal Open Market Committee eased monetary policy to counter a seizing-up of financial markets that threatened to disrupt economic activity significantly. As those markets recovered, the F.O.M.C. had to assess whether that policy stance remained appropriate. By late last month, when it became apparent that much of the financial strain of last fall had eased, that foreign economies were firming, and that demand in the United States was growing at an unsustainable pace, the F.O.M.C. raised its intended Federal funds rate one-quarter percentage point, to 5 percent. To have refrained from doing so in our judgment would have put the U.S. economy's expansion at risk. . . . 
 The already shrunken pool of job-seekers and considerable strength of aggregate demand suggest that the Federal Reserve will need to be especially alert to inflation risks. Should productivity fail to continue to accelerate and demand growth persist or strengthen, the economy could overheat. That would engender inflationary pressures and put the sustainability of this unprecedented period of remarkable growth in jeopardy. One indication that inflation risks were rising would be a tendency for labor markets to tighten further. But the F.O.M.C. also needs to continue to assess whether the existing degree of pressure in these markets is consistent with sustaining our low-inflation environment. If new data suggest it is likely that the pace of cost and price increases will be picking up, the Federal Reserve will have to act promptly and forcefully so as to preclude imbalances from arising that would only require a more disruptive adjustment later -- one that could impair the expansion and bring into question whether the many gains already made can be sustained. . . .
By themselves, surges in economic growth are not necessarily unsustainable -- provided they do not exceed the sum of the rate of growth in the labor force and productivity for a protracted period. However, when productivity is accelerating, it is very difficult to gauge when an economy is in the process of overheating.
In such circumstances, assessing conditions in the labor market can be helpful in forming those judgments. Employment growth has exceeded the growth in working-age population this past year by almost one-half percentage point. While somewhat less than the spread between these growth rates over much of the past few years, this excess is still large enough to continue the further tightening of labor markets. It implies that real G.D.P. is growing faster than its potential. To an important extent, this excess of the growth of demand over supply owes to the wealth effect as consumers increasingly perceive their capital gains in the stock and housing markets as permanent and, evidently as a consequence, spend part of them. . . .
In its deliberations this year, the F.O.M.C. has had to wrestle with the issue of what policy setting has the capacity to sustain this remarkable expansion, now in its ninth year. For monetary policy to foster maximum sustainable economic growth, it is useful to pre-empt forces of imbalance before they threaten economic stability. But this may not always be possible -- the future at times can be too opaque to penetrate. When we can be pre-emptive, we should be, because modest pre-emptive actions can obviate more drastic actions at a later date that could destabilize the economy. I should emphasize that pre-emptive policy making is equally applicable in both directions, as has been evident over the years both in our inclination to raise interest rates when the potential for inflationary pressures emerged, as in the spring of 1994, or to lower rates when the more palpable risk was economic weakness, as in the fall of last year. This even-handedness is necessary because emerging adverse trends may fall on either side of our long-run objective of price stability. Stable prices allow households and firms to concentrate their efforts on what they do best: consuming, producing, saving, and investing. . . .
By itself, the interpretation that we are currently enjoying productivity acceleration does not insure that equity prices are not overextended. There can be little doubt that if the nation's productivity growth has stepped up, the level of profits and their future potential would be elevated. That prospect has supported higher stock prices. The danger is that in these circumstances, an unwarranted, perhaps euphoric, extension of recent developments can drive equity prices to levels that are unsupportable even if risks in the future become relatively small. Such straying above fundamentals could create problems for our economy when the inevitable adjustment occurs. It is the job of economic policy makers to mitigate the fallout when it occurs and, hopefully, ease the transition to the next expansion.

HEADLINE: Hastert Triumphs, but Faces a Long High-Stakes Negotiation

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
By narrowly securing passage of a $792 billion tax cut today, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert won a sweet victory and avoided a precipitous collapse of his party's bargaining position for budget talks with President Clinton. But there is still a long road ahead in a high-stakes negotiation that is likely to set down many of the themes of the 2000 campaign.
Once again, Republicans are staking their identity and their majority on vast tax cuts, even though the tax rebellion that propelled Ronald Reagan into office nearly two decades ago has subsided as the economy has boomed. A $792 billion reduction would be the largest since Mr. Reagan pushed through a reduction in income tax rates in 1981. 
 "We should not miss the purpose of the Republican Party and conservative philosophy," Representative John Kasich, Republican of Ohio, said today, arguing for the tax cut. "It is our mission in this city to shift power and influence from this city back to the people who sit in the gallery and watch on television and pull the wagon."
Democrats, too, see this looming confrontation as a defining moment for the 2000 campaign. President Clinton this week repeatedly showcased his party's stance, with his threats to veto the Republican bill.
"We face a critical choice," Mr. Clinton said, "whether to move forward with the fiscal discipline that got us to where we are today or return to the kind of risk-taking that got us into recessions and deficits before."
The head-to-head confrontation between Mr. Clinton and the Republicans is still weeks off.
First, Republicans have to agree among themselves. Though Mr. Hastert survived another near-death experience by pushing through the tax cut, the effort he had to exert to earn the last votes from Republican moderates showed that even tax cuts no longer serve as glue for the Republican Party. And from the right, the Presidential candidate Steve Forbes complained that the House's tax cut was too timid.
House and Senate Republicans are promoting separate bills that cut taxes by $792 billion, and share common goals of having broad-based tax cuts, spurring savings and investment and reducing the so-called marriage penalty, which causes some couples to pay more taxes once they marry.
Their approaches, however, are at times sharply different and will have to be resolved in a House-Senate conference committee. The House bill, for example, is tilted more toward the wealthy. It includes a 10 percent across-the-board cut in income taxes phased in across a decade. The Senate bill would reduce the lowest income tax rate to 14 percent from 15 percent and increase the number of Americans who pay at the lowest rate.
Whatever bill comes out of conference will be vetoed by President Clinton as too large; then the battle for public opinion will begin in earnest.
The stirrings could be heard on the House floor today as Republicans argued just as they had in the Reagan years that tax cuts would stimulate the economy, while Democrats remembered how the tax cut of 1981 contributed to the deficits that were a persistent problem for the next decade.
But the nation's economic picture has changed since Mr. Reagan swept into office riding discontent with high inflation and high taxes. And it is not at all clear that the political climate favors Republican tax-cutters at a time of low unemployment and a booming economy.
A poll released today by the Pew Research Center for the People & the Press, showed that when Americans were asked which issue they would like to hear discussed in the Presidential campaign, health care, Social security and Medicare all drew more interest than tax cuts, which was listed by just 9 percent of the public.
The poll showed that the public could be open to tax cuts, for the part of the surplus that is not attributable to Social Security payroll taxes -- which explains why the Republican budget makes a point of setting aside the Social Security funds so they can not be used for other spending programs or for tax cuts. But even that support seemed to depend on how poll questions were phrased.
When asked what should be done with the surplus after reserving two-thirds for Social Security, support for tax cuts was relatively high when people were not given specific spending alternatives. Sixty percent of those polled supported a tax cut, while only 25 percent wanted "new federal programs."
Support for tax cuts fell off significantly, however, when people were asked whether they preferred tax cuts or spending on education, the environment, health care, crime-fighting and military defense. Sixty-nine percent of the public wanted the remaining surplus spent on those programs while only 22 percent favored a tax cut.
The Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, told a House hearing today that it is more important to pay down the national debt than cut taxes. Debt reduction, he said, would lower interest rates and put the Government in better shape for the retirement of the Baby Boom generation.
Despite the heated debate the outlines of a budget and tax cut compromise are already visible if the two parties decide they want accomplishments over campaign issues. Mr. Clinton's own budget proposed $250 billion in tax cuts. And a handful of Senate Democrats have already signaled their willingness to go along with a $500 billion tax cut. A grand deal would involve Mr. Clinton's agreeing to a larger tax cut perhaps in exchange for support of the new Medicare prescription drug benefit he has proposed.
But for now neither the White House or Congressional Democrats are making an effort to help Republicans out of the problem they have created for themselves by their pledges to protect Social Security and to provide the near-$1 trillion tax cut.
With little money left for other needs, Republicans have not been able to find a way to pass the crucial spending bills for labor, health, veterans and education programs because the cuts required would be too deep to be politically viable.
And that only increases Mr. Clinton's own negotiating position come the end of September, when the new fiscal year begins. The last thing the Republicans want is to be accused again of shutting down the Government.

HEADLINE: Let New Moms Leave the Office

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a scholar of work-family policies and the mother of a 2-year-old, I was dismayed to read Danielle Crittenden's critique of paid family and medical leave proposals (Op-Ed, July 21). 
 It is true that children need their parents throughout their lives, and ideally our country's family policy would include things like child subsidies and incentives for businesses to create good part-time jobs, to help parents who want to scale back or stop working. But it is doubtful that such a policy could pass under a Republican Congress, even with the enormous budget surpluses we are experiencing right now.
While paid family and medical leave would not solve the problem of parental time, it would be an important first step. It would allow parents to be relatively free of economic worry at those critical times when their children are very young or very ill.
 
ANYA BERNSTEIN
Newton, Mass., July 21, 1999
 
The writer is a lecturer in social studies at Harvard University.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (77%); 

COMPANY: HARVARD UNIVERSITY PRESS (55%); HARVARD UNIVERSITY (55%); HARVARD UNIVERSITY (55%);

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS PASS BIG TAX CUT TO SET STAGE FOR DEBATE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22

 BODY:
Republicans in the House put down their marker today in the debate over how to allocate projected Federal budget surpluses, passing the largest tax cut in nearly two decades despite a veto threat from President Clinton.
The Republican plan, which would cut taxes by $792 billion over the next decade, passed on a largely party line vote of 223 to 208. Four Republicans voted against it and six Democrats voted in favor. 
 The outcome averted a major defeat for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and the rest of the Republican leaders, who scrambled throughout Wednesday to keep the bill from being derailed by objections from a dozen or so moderates within their own party.
The moderates said the tax cut was too big and left none of the surplus for debt reduction and needed spending, but most of them voted for the bill in the end after adding a complex and hastily written provision that makes a portion of the tax cut contingent on reducing the interest payments on the national debt.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, infuriated some House Republicans today by characterizing their drive for a huge tax cut as premature and economically unwise. Page C1.
The Republicans' bill calls for personal income tax rates to be cut gradually by 10 percent over the next decade, and for the top rate on capital gains to be reduced to 15 percent from 20 percent immediately.
It would also phase in a repeal of the tax on large inheritances, create a deduction for health insurance expenses, cut a variety of business taxes and reduce the so-called marriage penalty, which leaves many two-income couples paying a bigger tax bill than if they were single.
"So Mr. President, we say, what's wrong in letting American taxpayers keep more of their hard-earned money," Mr. Hastert said at a Republican pep rally after the vote. "We trust them to spend it right, and we think you should, too."
The House bill stands almost no chance of becoming law. But it represents the opening bid by conservatives as they head toward negotiations with the Senate, which is moving toward passage of its own, somewhat less partisan tax cut, and with Mr. Clinton, who despite his veto threat has opened the door to a smaller tax reduction.
The issue is among the most ideologically charged and politically potent facing Congress and the Clinton Administration this year.
Not since the 1920's has the Federal Government had a realistic prospect of taking in more money than it spends over a sustained period. Current estimates show the Government running a surplus of $2.9 trillion over the next 10 years, permitting both parties the luxury of setting out wish lists that reflect their basic philosophies about the size and role of the Federal Government, their approaches to long-term challenges like assuring the solvency of Social Security and their strategies for the 2000 elections.
Beyond ideology and politics, there is also economics. Mr. Greenspan, usually one of Washington's most outspoken proponents of tax cuts, suggested that Congress should concentrate instead on paring the national debt. Big tax cuts typically stimulate economic growth, and the Federal Reserve is already concerned that the economy is overheating.
"The timing is not right," Mr. Greenspan said in response to a question at the House Banking Committee a few hours before the vote on the tax bill.
"I think we will need a very important reduction in marginal tax rates," Mr. Greenspan said, "and in the capital gains tax rate at some point in the future when this economy inevitably falters."
On the House floor, Republicans swept aside criticism of their tax-cutting plan. Sending excess revenues back to the taxpayer, they said, was the best way to advance their goals of reducing the power of the Federal Government and increasing prosperity.
If the surplus is not used for tax cuts, they said, Democrats would inevitably use it for new spending programs. Even with a big tax cut, Republicans said there is already more than enough Federal money to pay for domestic and military spending and deal with the long-term problems in Medicare and Social Security.
Despite polls showing that most voters rank tax cuts behind Social Security, Medicare and debt reduction as the best use for the surplus, Republicans said a broad-based tax reduction would help the party recapture the conservative fervor of Ronald Reagan's first term as President, when Democrats in Congress acceded to an even bigger tax reduction.
"The Democrats believe they know best how to spend money by spending it with government," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the author of the Republican bill. "We believe the people know best how to spend their own money. And what this debate is really all about is downsizing the power of Washington and upsizing the power of people."
Democrats replied that the Republican plan was built on assumptions about future surpluses that might never materialize, risking the return of budget deficits and higher interest rates.
They said that by allocating to tax cuts nearly all of the portion of the surplus available for that purpose -- the $996 billion over the next decade that does not come from excess Social Security revenue -- Republicans were missing the country's best chance to do more to shore up Social Security and Medicare and to invest in education, health care, the environment and the military.
Moreover, Democrats said, the Republican tax cut is disproportionately tilted toward the wealthy.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee, said the Republicans were pandering to their conservative base with an irresponsible bill that they knew would never be signed into law. The Republicans' intention, Mr. Rangel said, is to create a "Christmas tree" and cast Mr. Clinton in the role of Scrooge.
"Your bill is what we call in Harlem a trip to nowhere," Mr. Rangel said.
Mr. Clinton also kept up the pressure on the Republicans, repeating his veto threat for a second straight day.
"I believe that this plan that's being voted on in Washington will not enable us to pay off our debt," Mr. Clinton said today on a trip to Lansing, Mich. "It will not do anything to add to the life of Social Security and Medicare. It will require huge cuts in our other investments and taking care of our kids. And I will veto it if it passes."
After the frantic bargaining between House Republican leaders and party moderates on Wednesday, there was relatively little drama in today's vote. Most of the moderates who had threatened to defect said they were satisfied that the leadership had taken their concerns seriously and had agreed to their demand that the largest component of the tax cut -- the phased-in reduction in personal income tax rates -- take effect only if regular progress is made in bringing down the national debt.
But there was considerable confusion on both sides of the aisle about just how the contingency would work in practice, and whether it was anything more than an expedient way of holding the fractious Republican majority together for a few hours to get the tax bill passed. Even some of the moderates said they did not expect the provision to survive when the House and the Senate reconcile their tax-cut bills in coming weeks.
The four Republicans who voted against the bill were Representatives Michael N. Castle of Delaware, who had led the moderate revolt; Jack Quinn of New York; Greg Ganske of Iowa, and Constance A. Morella of Maryland.
The six Democrats who voted in favor of the bill were Representatives Sanford D. Bishop Jr. of Georgia; Virgil H. Goode Jr. of Virginia; Ralph M. Hall of Texas; Gary A. Condit of California; Pat Danner of Missouri, and Ken Lucas of Kentucky.
Three members of the House did not vote. They were Representatives Patrick J. Kennedy, the Rhode Island Democrat, who was attending services for his cousin, John F. Kennedy Jr.; Jim McDermott of Washington, a Democrat, and John E. Peterson of Pennsylvania, a Republican. There is one vacancy among the 435 seats in the House.

HEADLINE: Filter Aid to Poor Through Churches, Bush Urges

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, July 22

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said today that the Federal Government should "rally the armies of compassion in our communities" by providing tax incentives and Federal funds to churches and neighborhood groups to help the needy.
"Government can spend money," the Republican Presidential hopeful said. "But it cannot put hope in our hearts or a sense of purpose in our lives. That is done in churches and synagogues and mosques and charities that warm the cold of life." In his speech and in a news conference that followed, Mr. Bush spoke of the "transforming power of faith," a phrase nearly identical to that used by Vice President Gore when he called in May for a collaboration between Government and grass-roots groups to help those in need. 
 Campaigning at a Methodist church here, Mr. Bush gave the first major policy speech of a Presidential campaign that until today has been more notable for spectacular fund-raising, and the slogan "compassionate conservatism," than for any detailed discussion of issues. On this potentially sensitive issue of the role of religious institutions, Mr. Bush provided many of the specifics that his critics, including President Clinton at Wednesday's news conference, have chided him for neglecting.
Mr. Bush proposed spending $8 billion in Federal money, a sum he described as 10 percent of the budget surplus not derived from Social Security, "to encourage an outpouring of giving in America."
"In every instance when my Administration sees a responsibility to help people," he said, "we will look first to faith-based institutions, to charities and to community groups that have shown their ability to save and change lives."
Asked if his proposal would violate the constitutional separation of church and state, Mr. Bush said, "I'm told by the legal experts that my initiative will pass constitutional muster. We will send money to fund services. But the money does not go fund the religious programs within the institution."
The question that should be asked about a Federal program, he said, is not who implemented it but "does it work?"
A central part of his plan would permit lower-income taxpayers who do not itemize their deductions -- the great majority of filers -- to deduct their charitable donations. He also proposed bigger tax breaks for corporate giving, limiting the civil liability of businesses that donate equipment or cars to charitable groups and allowing people to make charitable contributions with money from Individual Retirement Accounts without penalty.
Mr. Bush said he would seek changes in laws and regulations so that individuals could direct some of their state taxes "directly to private and religious institutions fighting poverty."
In addition, Mr. Bush proposed Federal grants to ministries and mentoring programs to help the 1.3 million children he said had parents who were in prison. He said he wanted to try InnerChange, a Texas prison program that "teaches inmates to rely on faith to transform their lives," in four Federal prisons to test its effectiveness.
Mr. Bush spoke at a meeting hosted by the Front Porch Alliance, an Indianapolis program that uses church and neighborhood organizations to fight crime and poverty. Church choirs prepared the audience for his address.
In it Mr. Bush promised to "change the laws and regulation that hamper the cooperation of government and private institutions" in order to "allow private and religious groups to compete to provide services in every Federal, state and local social program."
Mr. Bush insisted that his "faith-based" approach would not be sectarian. "We will keep a commitment to pluralism, not discriminating for or against Methodist or Mormons or Muslims, or good people with no faith at all." And he said he would insure there were "secular alternatives" to faith-based programs.
Faith-based organizations can and do receive Federal grants for a variety of social welfare programs.
Melissa T. Skolfield, assistant secretary for public affairs at the Department of Health and Human Services, said that "the welfare reform bill specifically allows faith-based organizations to receive Federal funds to help move people from welfare to work." Moreover, she said, "we've used the bully pulpit" to make the case for even greater involvement by such groups.
Constitutional scholars generally agree that the government may use churches, synagogues and mosques to help administer social-service programs as long as the programs do not promote religious beliefs.
Professor Ira C. Lupu of the George Washington University Law School, an authority on the subject, said the Supreme Court had upheld the use of government funds by religious institutions as part of a social-service program if there was no proselytizing. "You can't, for example, give food to hungry people while transmitting a religious message," he said. "As long as they are acting as social-service agencies and not as religious agencies, it's acceptable."
In 1988, the Supreme Court in Bowen v. Kendrick upheld the Adolescent Family Life Act enacted by Congress to promote chastity. The Court ruled that the law did not violate the Constitution's prohibition against mingling church and state even though it required that some funds be funneled through religious organizations.
Mr. Bush told the audience that his message was not directed only to Washington bureaucrats but also to his own party:
"We must apply our conservative and free-market ideas to the job of helping real human beings, because any ideology, no matter how right in theory, is sterile and empty without that goal."
Mr. Bush said the attitude that governments should only "leave us alone" was a "destructive mindset." Asked at his news conference if that comment meant he was repudiating the approach of a Republican Congress first elected in 1994 with a great promise to reduce Federal programs and regulations, he declined to answer.
Mr. Bush also said, "It is not enough to call for volunteerism," a hallmark of his father's term as President. "Without more support and resources -- both public and private, we are asking them to make bricks without straw."
Mr. Bush said he wanted to work with institutions that shared a belief "in the transforming power of faith, a belief no one is finally a failure or a victim, because everyone is the child of a loving and merciful God -- a God who counts our tears and lifts our heads."

HEADLINE: China Steps Up Its Drive to Halt Dissident Sect

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 22

 BODY:
China stepped up its offensive against the Buddhist Law movement today, announcing a ban on the organization and unleashing a barrage of charges against its founder that revealed how seriously the Government takes the sect as a challenge to its control.
The Government's ban on the group, known in Chinese as Falun Gong, had been rumored since the police rounded up more than 100 leaders of the sect in several Chinese cities this week. 
 But the ferocity of Beijing's campaign -- aimed at a group of mainly middle-aged people who practice a form of Chinese breathing exercises and meditation -- suggests that it regards Falun Gong as more than a movement of physical and moral uplift. At a time when China's economy is slowing and social unrest is rising, officials here view this amorphous but fast-growing sect as a dangerous political force.
After Beijing handed down its edict this afternoon, it began an extraordinary public-relations assault on the group and its founder, Li Hongzhi, through state-run television and newspapers.
The Ministry of Civil Affairs accused Falun Gong of "inciting and creating disturbances, and jeopardizing social stability." In an editorial scheduled for publication on Friday, the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said Mr. Li was pursuing a hidden political agenda that posed a "massive threat" to Chinese society.
State media also accused Mr. Li of misleading followers about his birth date, so that he could claim to be a reincarnation of Siddhartha Gautama, the founder of Buddhism, and of accepting payments for supposedly miraculous cures. Falun Gong followers, displaying the reach that has so alarmed the Chinese authorities, immediately posted rebuttals of the charges over the Internet.
Mr. Li, 48, a former grain bureau clerk who is now based in New York, fashioned his sect from an eclectic blend of qigong -- traditional breathing exercises -- as well as elements of Buddhism and Taoism. His followers say they disavow politics and embrace Mr. Li's teachings for their physical and spiritual health.
But Falun Gong deeply unsettled China's rulers when 10,000 of its adherents materialized on April 25, a warm spring Sunday, in front of the compound that houses President Jiang Zemin and other leaders.
The rally, held to demand official recognition of the group, demonstrated that this obscure spiritual sect was in fact a highly organized movement with an international network capable of mobilizing thousands of people and putting them under the noses of China's top leaders without a whisper of warning.
As word of the detentions spread this week, thousands of Falun Gong followers massed in front of government offices in Dalian, Guangzhou and 28 other cities to protest the Government's crackdown, according to members of the group and a Hong Kong human rights organization.
The wall-to-wall coverage in the state-run media of the ban -- which prohibits the public practice of the exercises and meditation as well as the distribution of the group's literature -- underscores that the Government is determined to stamp out Falun Gong.
But the group could prove an elusive quarry for Beijing. It has a large and rapidly growing membership -- estimates run from the Chinese Government's figure of 2 million to the group's number of 100 million in more than 30 countries -- as well as a fluid structure and an appreciation of the power of the Internet to pass information and organize activities.
"I think this is going to make us stronger," said Sophie Xiao, a spokeswoman for Falun Gong in Hong Kong, where the ban does not apply. "People are not simple-minded. Educated people will hear about this group, and check it out."
A former Chinese official said the police in Beijing had released several hundred people who had been detained as they massed near Zhongnanhai on Tuesday and Wednesday.
 On Friday morning, about 200 people gathered in Tiananmen Square and began a sitting protest, the Reuters news service reported. They were arrested and the square was cordoned off.
Chinese officials were clearly concerned about how the ban would be received abroad. Shortly before the announcement, a high-ranking official briefed foreign correspondents here on why the Government felt it necessary to take such draconian action.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Beijing had moved against Falun Gong because of "the danger it posed to our country and our people" and that "any responsible government would do the same."
He said members of the group had harassed government offices and pro-Beijing news organizations. He said the Government had evidence that Mr. Li had been in Beijing for the three days before the April rally at Zhongnanhai had helped plan it.
In Washington, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said the United States was disturbed by China's decision to ban Falun Gong, and was urging China to abide by international human rights conventions.
Here as well, the strident tone and sheer volume of the denunciations of Falun Gong baffled some experts in Chinese politics. Why, they asked, would the Government pour so much energy into fighting a group that it says has only 2 million members.
"After all, a few months ago hardly anyone had heard of it, and no one was saying it was a threat to the state," said one political scholar in Beijing, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I think the party leaders felt personally insulted by the Falun Gong protest. It made them look like fools."
A former government official said today that the unexpected demonstration in April particularly unnerved President Jiang. In briefings with Government officials earlier this week, this person said, a senior leader quoted Mr. Jiang as harshly criticizing Mr. Li and the movement.
Experts said there were plenty of reasons for Beijing to worry about this kind of group. With its mixture of martial arts and mysticism, Falun Gong appeals to people who have felt adrift in the last two decades of economic restructuring and relaxed social controls.
Quasi-religious groups played a profoundly disruptive role in the final decades of the last imperial dynasty. The Taiping Rebellion (1851-63), led by Hong Xiuquan, who claimed to be the younger son of Jesus Christ and strove to replace what he called corrupt Manchu rulers with a "heavenly kingdom," cost millions of lives and devastated much of southern China. At the turn of the century, the Fists of Righteous Harmony, or "Boxers," mixed martial arts and mysticism in their campaign to expel foreigners, which ended with a Western and Japanese expeditionary force occupying Beijing.
And Communist officials are well aware that the Communist Party, in its early years, was an underground organization with ties to other secret societies and that it owed much of its own rise to power to disaffected elements of society.
But now as the Communist Government approaches the 50th anniversary of its rule, on Oct. 1, China's economic engine is sputtering. With Beijing embarking on an ambitious campaign to overhaul its state sector -- one that has already resulted in huge layoffs -- the Government is bracing itself for widespread unrest.
Signs that the Government may feel vulnerable abounded in the flood of official denunciations today. In a 70-minute documentary that has been rerun almost nonstop today on state television, Falun Gong was portrayed as a pernicious cult that leads members to mental instability, madness and even murder.

HEADLINE: BREAK IN LOGJAM ON ALBANY BUDGET

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 22

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders removed the last major obstacle to a new state budget today, reaching agreement on a plan to spend more than $700 million on school repairs, new housing for the mentally ill, highway projects and a smattering of tax cuts.
The deal ends a bitter and protracted stalemate and clears the way for the adoption of a new $73 billion budget that rejects many of the cuts Mr. Pataki had sought in education and health care. It keeps $1.8 billion in a reserve fund to hedge against a downturn in the economy and to make up for revenue lost to future tax cuts. Mr. Pataki had insisted on the reserve fund as part of any final budget agreement. 
 The budget was due on April 1, but for the 15th straight year, state leaders failed to meet that deadline. The record for a state budget delay came in 1997, when it was 122 days past the deadline. As of Friday, the budget is 114 days overdue. The Legislature is expected to begin the final work next week, according to aides to Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders.
"This is a very happy occasion," Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, said this morning during a hearing with members of both houses of the Legislature. "We are making progress."
The deal reached today by Mr. Pataki, Mr. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, resolves the most difficult issues that had held up a final budget agreement. But aides to Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders cautioned that some details still had to be worked out before the final budget is submitted for the approval of rank-and-file members. The process could also be slowed by the arduous task of translating the deal into the arcane and complex language of legislation, something that often leads to blow-ups that can derail a deal, if only momentarily.
The additional spending that the leaders agreed on today, totaling $710 million, is not expected to have a significant impact on this year's final budget, largely because it is based on borrowing and tax cuts that will take effect in future budget years, legislative aides said.
The plan sets aside $250 million to pay for new tax cuts, most of them having been sought by Mr. Pataki and his Republican allies in the Senate. The majority of those tax cuts, about $150 million, would apply to banks and insurance companies, legislative aides in both parties said. The remaining $100 million in tax cuts is still being negotiated.
Under the agreement, $145 million would be spent to repair schools; $50 million to build housing for the mentally ill; $15 million to add new publicly financed day care slots for low-income families, and $15 million to provide affordable housing for the poor. Those proposals are supported, for the most part, by Democrats.
The deal also includes about $235 million to pay for programs championed by the Republican majority in the Senate: $160 million for highway projects, mostly outside New York City, and $75 million for a job development plan to help beleaguered upstate communities.
"Barring any unforeseen problems, we expect the budget to be resolved relatively soon," said Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for the Governor. "Hopefully, the entire budget will be done within the next 10 days."
The negotiations over this year's budget were thwarted by the deep level of mistrust that has grown between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver. Last year, both houses of the Legislature passed a spending plan that provided large election-year increases to all sorts of constituencies. But Mr. Pataki vetoed $1.6 billion in programs, mostly those supported by Mr. Silver and other Democrats.
Mr. Silver sought to prevent that from happening again this year, but had no assurances until last week, when Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed on the broad outlines of a $73 billion plan.
The deal spends about $1.1 billion more than Mr. Pataki had proposed in January but allows the Governor to achieve one of his main objectives in the budget: saving $1.8 billion from the budget surplus that accumulated in the fiscal year that ended March 31. Mr. Pataki wanted the savings to pay for tax cuts that have been enacted into law but take effect in future years.
But Mr. Pataki's Democratic rivals have some things to cheer about in the final budget deal.
Democrats saved one of their most cherished programs: one that pays for prekindergarten classes, all-day kindergarten and smaller class sizes in the early grades. Mr. Pataki had proposed eliminating the program and replacing it with a smaller block grant that school districts could use as they wanted.
But the future of the program is unclear, because Mr. Pataki has refused to make it a permanent program, as Democrats have demanded. The budget will also increase overall aid to school districts by $910 million, an 8 percent increase over last year. That is the largest year-to-year increase ever for education.
As it now stands, the budget deal also calls for restoring $134 million to the program that provides tuition assistance for low-income college students.
Mr. Pataki had proposed eliminating that much from the program, known as the Tuition Assistance Program, which provides money to eligible full-time students who attend any private or public college in the state.
Word of today's deal came as members of the Legislature began winding up a series of budget conference committees that began on Monday. The committees were convened to allow rank-and-file lawmakers to determine in public how to spend the additional $1.1 billion that Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed to add to the Governor's original proposal.
The hearings were instituted last year in an effort to break with the much-maligned practice in which the Governor and legislative leaders hammered out budget deals behind closed doors without the benefit of public hearings.
But as with much of the budget this year, the agreement reached today was hammered out in secret negotiations among Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno, making the conference committees largely irrelevant. The committees are scheduled to end their work on Friday morning.

 BODY:

 Under the law, state aid to local governments will automatically increase each year to offset inflation in the cost of providing municipal services, according to a statement from the Governor's office. The increases will cost the state about $11.5 million in the current fiscal year, which has a total budget of $19.5 billion. HEADLINE: China Steps Up Its Drive to Halt Dissident Sect

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 22

 BODY:
China stepped up its offensive against the Buddhist Law movement today, announcing a ban on the organization and unleashing a barrage of charges against its founder that revealed how seriously the Government takes the sect as a challenge to its control.
The Government's ban on the group, known in Chinese as Falun Gong, had been rumored since the police rounded up more than 100 leaders of the sect in several Chinese cities this week. 
 But the ferocity of Beijing's campaign -- aimed at a group of mainly middle-aged people who practice a form of Chinese breathing exercises and meditation -- suggests that it regards Falun Gong as more than a movement of physical and moral uplift. At a time when China's economy is slowing and social unrest is rising, officials here view this amorphous but fast-growing sect as a dangerous political force.
After Beijing handed down its edict this afternoon, it began an extraordinary public-relations assault on the group and its founder, Li Hongzhi, through state-run television and newspapers.
The Ministry of Civil Affairs accused Falun Gong of "inciting and creating disturbances, and jeopardizing social stability." In an editorial scheduled for publication on Friday, the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said Mr. Li was pursuing a hidden political agenda that posed a "massive threat" to Chinese society.
State media also accused Mr. Li of misleading followers about his birth date, so that he could claim to be a reincarnation of Siddhartha Gautama, the founder of Buddhism, and of accepting payments for supposedly miraculous cures. Falun Gong followers, displaying the reach that has so alarmed the Chinese authorities, immediately posted rebuttals of the charges over the Internet.
Mr. Li, 48, a former grain bureau clerk who is now based in New York, fashioned his sect from an eclectic blend of qigong -- traditional breathing exercises -- as well as elements of Buddhism and Taoism. His followers say they disavow politics and embrace Mr. Li's teachings for their physical and spiritual health.
But Falun Gong deeply unsettled China's rulers when 10,000 of its adherents materialized on April 25, a warm spring Sunday, in front of the compound that houses President Jiang Zemin and other leaders.
The rally, held to demand official recognition of the group, demonstrated that this obscure spiritual sect was in fact a highly organized movement with an international network capable of mobilizing thousands of people and putting them under the noses of China's top leaders without a whisper of warning.
As word of the detentions spread this week, thousands of Falun Gong followers massed in front of government offices in Dalian, Guangzhou and 28 other cities to protest the Government's crackdown, according to members of the group and a Hong Kong human rights organization.
The wall-to-wall coverage in the state-run media of the ban -- which prohibits the public practice of the exercises and meditation as well as the distribution of the group's literature -- underscores that the Government is determined to stamp out Falun Gong.
But the group could prove an elusive quarry for Beijing. It has a large and rapidly growing membership -- estimates run from the Chinese Government's figure of 2 million to the group's number of 100 million in more than 30 countries -- as well as a fluid structure and an appreciation of the power of the Internet to pass information and organize activities.
"I think this is going to make us stronger," said Sophie Xiao, a spokeswoman for Falun Gong in Hong Kong, where the ban does not apply. "People are not simple-minded. Educated people will hear about this group, and check it out."
A former Chinese official said the police in Beijing had released several hundred people who had been detained as they massed near Zhongnanhai on Tuesday and Wednesday.
 On Friday morning, about 200 people gathered in Tiananmen Square and began a sitting protest, the Reuters news service reported. They were arrested and the square was cordoned off.
Chinese officials were clearly concerned about how the ban would be received abroad. Shortly before the announcement, a high-ranking official briefed foreign correspondents here on why the Government felt it necessary to take such draconian action.
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Beijing had moved against Falun Gong because of "the danger it posed to our country and our people" and that "any responsible government would do the same."
He said members of the group had harassed government offices and pro-Beijing news organizations. He said the Government had evidence that Mr. Li had been in Beijing for the three days before the April rally at Zhongnanhai had helped plan it.
In Washington, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said the United States was disturbed by China's decision to ban Falun Gong, and was urging China to abide by international human rights conventions.
Here as well, the strident tone and sheer volume of the denunciations of Falun Gong baffled some experts in Chinese politics. Why, they asked, would the Government pour so much energy into fighting a group that it says has only 2 million members.
"After all, a few months ago hardly anyone had heard of it, and no one was saying it was a threat to the state," said one political scholar in Beijing, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "I think the party leaders felt personally insulted by the Falun Gong protest. It made them look like fools."
A former government official said today that the unexpected demonstration in April particularly unnerved President Jiang. In briefings with Government officials earlier this week, this person said, a senior leader quoted Mr. Jiang as harshly criticizing Mr. Li and the movement.
Experts said there were plenty of reasons for Beijing to worry about this kind of group. With its mixture of martial arts and mysticism, Falun Gong appeals to people who have felt adrift in the last two decades of economic restructuring and relaxed social controls.
Quasi-religious groups played a profoundly disruptive role in the final decades of the last imperial dynasty. The Taiping Rebellion (1851-63), led by Hong Xiuquan, who claimed to be the younger son of Jesus Christ and strove to replace what he called corrupt Manchu rulers with a "heavenly kingdom," cost millions of lives and devastated much of southern China. At the turn of the century, the Fists of Righteous Harmony, or "Boxers," mixed martial arts and mysticism in their campaign to expel foreigners, which ended with a Western and Japanese expeditionary force occupying Beijing.
And Communist officials are well aware that the Communist Party, in its early years, was an underground organization with ties to other secret societies and that it owed much of its own rise to power to disaffected elements of society.
But now as the Communist Government approaches the 50th anniversary of its rule, on Oct. 1, China's economic engine is sputtering. With Beijing embarking on an ambitious campaign to overhaul its state sector -- one that has already resulted in huge layoffs -- the Government is bracing itself for widespread unrest.
Signs that the Government may feel vulnerable abounded in the flood of official denunciations today. In a 70-minute documentary that has been rerun almost nonstop today on state television, Falun Gong was portrayed as a pernicious cult that leads members to mental instability, madness and even murder.

HEADLINE: CONNECTIONS;
Even for Death's Escapees, the Myth Says, There Are Rules

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
Resurrection from the dead may be the most universal of mythic ideas: a devoted savior descends to the netherworld to restore a loved one to life. But there is always a price to be paid: natural law is rarely overturned without penalty and pain. Persephone must return to Hades. Lot's wife, insufficiently awed by her rescue from her death-ridden home, glances back and turns into a pillar of evaporated tears. And the Christian story of resurrection leaves the final transformation incomplete, pending the spiritual perfection of mankind.
This myth is also at the heart of two 400-year-old operas. In the Chinese opera "The Peony Pavilion," which is being performed in complete 19-hour form as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99 (its last marathon performance is this weekend), the slightly cocky young scholar Liu Mengmei brings his beloved back to life. And in Monteverdi's "Orfeo," which was given an exquisite performance last month in a production by Trisha Brown at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Orpheus, whose playing of the lyre could wring tears from stones, uses his music to rescue his Eurydice from Hades. 
 This operatic coincidence is unusually resonant. Both works were written around the same time ("Peony" in 1598, "L'Orfeo" in 1607). Both became models for their respective styles of music drama. And both, in their resurrection myths, invoke the dreamy powers of art while alluding to its dangers.
Consider first "Peony," which, when seen in full, has the force of a revelation. However strange the initial impression is on Western eyes or ears -- the formal hand gestures, the eye movements, the sweeping, sighing melismas, the percussive punctuation -- the opera is a grand picaresque comedy. Liu's rescue of his beloved from the Underworld is more earthy than heroic: he has to shovel dirt out of the grave, worry about foul smells and flee with his newly disinterred wife as a suspected grave robber. It is as if the 17th-century author, Tang Xianzu, were winking slightly at the very idea of resurrection. Liu has more to worry about from earthly authorities who would behead him for plundering tombs than from any supernal force.
And how pompous those earthly authorities and their minions are! Liu never fails to boast of his scholarly superiority ("I am stuffed full of knowledge"); his beloved, Du Liniang, pities the mirror that can capture only part of her beauty; the Prefect self-importantly quotes ancient poetry to prove his points. There is constant deflation of pretense. Even images of natural beauty -- so central to the work's effects -- are turned into bawdy allusions. It is as if Shakespeare's gravediggers had been set free in the Ming dynasty.
This seems extraordinarily mischievous given that "Peony" is a "kunqu" opera -- an elite, learned genre -- with a text peppered with literary citations. What is also surprising is that the penalty we expect for Liu's violation of natural law never comes. The work seems to proclaim that anything is possible if one dreams well enough and is willing to challenge convention.
But the opera is also so subtle that no sooner is this impulse celebrated than it is resisted. Everything is pomposity? Not quite. Everything is possible? Barely. Du's resurrection always remains somewhat creepy; her father never fully accepts her return to life. In addition, the ritualistic performance style keeps circumscribing desire in melancholic ceremony. The director, Chen Shi-Zheng, uses a variety of popular and vernacular ideas in his staging -- very little authentic kunqu material survives -- but he retains a controlled, stylistic foundation that keeps the mischief in check. The impression is not of unbounded freedom but of bounded accommodation. Art may break boundaries but it also must answer to them.
Monteverdi may have had something similar in mind. In the myth, Orpheus has such mastery over his art that he can use it to suspend natural law and descend into Hades. But Monteverdi's attitude toward Orpheus' musical powers is more ambiguous. The composer wrote this opera at a moment of heated debate in Italy about the nature of music: should music or text take priority? Monteverdi believed that music had already gone too far in eclipsing its texts. It had become overly introverted, intricate, indulgent. In creating one of the first modern operas based on his understanding of classical ideals, Monteverdi wanted music to serve the text, not dominate it. It would have to acknowledge an external authority.
But this is just what Orpheus is unable to do. He treats music as a law unto itself, answerable to no constraints. He can't even control his own impulses -- he ultimately glances back at Eurydice, violating a strict edict, and so condemns her to eternal death. Nor is Orpheus the master musician he seems. He succeeds in passing into Hades not by seducing the ferryman, Charon, with his music, but by inadvertently putting him to sleep. And while Orpheus credits his music with winning over the Lord of the Underworld, Persephone's plea is what makes the difference. Orpheus may sing the praises of his own song, but he does not take its proper measure; he prefers elaborate effects to simple communication. In both his actions and his style, Orpheus acknowledges no external authority; he insists on his absolute freedom, and ends up losing it.
So in the end, "L'Orfeo" is not a celebration of music's seductive powers to undo death and rescue love, but an exploration of music's limits. This is the opera's tragedy: not that Orpheus's powers fail, but that, in their self-absorbed form, they cannot possibly succeed. "Peony" ultimately sides with Monteverdi as well. Both operas suggest that in art, as in death, there is no escape from rules and limits. But the struggle against them ends up becoming one of the great recurring myths of Western opera.

HEADLINE: Looking for Happiness? It May Be Very Near;
When the Heart Sings, Part of the Cortex Gets Busy

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The secret to happiness, it turns out, may not be wealth or power. Or love or success or faithful friendship. Or Ray Charles crooning "Georgia on My Mind" or even chocolate mousse.
Finding happiness may mean going no further than your very own forehead -- the left prefrontal cortex of your brain, to be exact. The more the sparks fly from this sliver of gray matter, the more electrical impulses it generates, the happier you are. 
 That is the conclusion of Richard J. Davidson, a professor of psychology and psychiatry at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, and others who have examined adults, children, infants, even Rhesus monkeys. Over the last several years, they have tested perky, enthusiastic people and pessimistic, morose ones. The results are always the same. People blessed with effervescent left prefrontal cortices are much more likely to be smiling.
Dr. Davidson is part of a small band of pioneers who have set out over the last decade to discover what many philosophers but few scientific researchers have bothered to ask: What is it, exactly, that makes us happy?
They are marshaling all the most sophisticated scientific techniques: searching for a genetic basis for happiness, brain imaging to pinpoint the spot on the brain where happiness resides, and in-the-field surveys to try to understand which activities or stimuli make people more or less happy. And they are interested in a range of possible applications. How does happiness affect physiological symptoms like stress and heart disease? Can drugs be used effectively to make unhappy people happy? Are our brains coded from birth for a certain level of happiness, or can they be altered by experiences when we are young, or even as adults?
This is revolutionary stuff, not only for biologists but also for psychologists, who have concentrated much of this century on pathology, obsession, melancholy and angst.
"Look in a psychology textbook," said Daniel Kahneman, a professor of psychology and public affairs at Princeton University and another happiness sleuth. "There are a lot of pages devoted to anxiety and depression. Happiness might not even be there."
Norbert Schwarz, a professor of psychology at the University of Michigan, said it had historically been tough to get grants to study what tickles people's fancy.
"When you're deciding whether to fund research," Dr. Schwarz said, "it seems much more important to say you want to help people not to get depressed than to say you want to help people enjoy their dinner more."
But these days, happiness research is on the upswing. Chock it up to the Don't Sweat the Small Stuff movement, experts say, or to the emphasis on physical health and "wellness" that has people smoking less and Stairmastering more. But even the current president of the American Psychological Association, Martin E. P. Seligman, has been making speeches over the past year urging researchers to study a new "positive" psychology.
Happiness, it goes without saying, is highly subjective and some researchers are trying to better define and measure this squishy subject.
Edward F. Diener, a University of Illinois psychologist who conducts happiness research, said in an interview: "We're trying not to just ask people how happy they are in general, but to document it at specific points. Happiness is how frequently you're happy, not how intensely you're happy. Having some peaks in there is nice -- it's certainly not bad -- but if you have a peak, it could be because you're unhappy and then you had something happen to make you superhappy. Then you have to go back to the normal thing."
Michael Argyle, a psychologist at Oxford University, has found some common threads. Money, he says, makes little difference to happiness, except for people who are very poor. People on the job are happiest when they have good relationships with co-workers and when part of their day is spent "wasting time, fooling around, and sharing gossip and jokes," he said. And for some reason, watching soap operas on television makes people happy ("I think they've got imaginary friends there," he said.)
Increasingly, though, most happiness researchers are convinced that a healthy part of happiness is physiological and genetic.
Tests on twins have found that "identical twins separated from birth are more similar in how happy they are than fraternal twins who grew up together," Dr. Diener said.
The research of Dr. Davidson and others provides some of the most compelling evidence yet.
People who describe themselves as optimistic, engaged, "the kind of people who jump out of bed in the morning and are ready to tackle the world," as he put it, have consistently higher levels of left prefrontal lobe activity. Physiologically, they also have "higher levels of natural antibody activity -- antigens against everything from colds and flu to cancers."
By contrast, people who are depressed have greater activity in their right prefrontal lobe. And children with more active right prefrontal lobes show "excessive wariness in response to unfamiliar situations," Dr. Davidson said.
To see whether anticipation of something good or bad makes a difference, Dr. Davidson tested heavy smokers who were deprived of cigarettes for a day and then shown a lighted cigarette and told they would be able to smoke in two minutes. During those two minutes, the smokers showed a strong increase in left prefrontal lobe activity.
On the other hand, a group of people with intense fear of making public speeches were told they would be required to do just that. Their right prefrontal lobes went ballistic as they got closer to making the speech.
Naturally, drug companies have been banging on Dr. Davidson's door. He says that some studies have found that antidepression drugs increase left prefrontal cortex activity, although there is no research yet on how long that effect lasts.
Yet drawing the line between the physical and the psychological is not easy. What is cause and what is effect? Are people with more prefrontal cortex activity happier or do happier people have more prefrontal cortex activity?
Dr. Davidson, for example, is studying whether experiences -- meditation, for example -- can produce changes in prefrontal brain activity "to more definitively answer the question on nature versus nurture," he said. "Data suggest there's a lot of plasticity that appears to be present up until the time of puberty. But brain function might be malleable even in adults."
He assisted in a recent study conducted with Jon Kabat-Zinn, a meditation expert at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester, in which stressed executives of a high-powered biotechnology company were given an eight-week course in meditation -- one three-hour class a week and an assignment to practice 45 minutes a day. The results are not yet in, Dr. Davidson said.
With the blessing of the Dalai Lama, Dr. Davidson is also studying Buddhist monks, both in Tibet and Wisconsin, to see whether their lives of meditation show up on their prefrontal lobes. "To get these people to do the research is very difficult," he added. "They tell us if we really want to learn about meditation they could give us instruction, and if we like it we can teach it to other people."
Whatever this research will ultimately show, happiness is clearly more than the sum of brain circuits. Researchers have noticed, for example, that people's responses to questions about happiness change depending on the context in which they are asked. If asked about their lives on a sunny day, people are likely to express more contentment than on a rainy day.
Dr. Schwarz, a co-editor of "Well-Being: Foundations of Hedonic Psychology," published this month by the Russell Sage Foundation, has conducted an experiment in which some people who used a University of Michigan copying machine found a dime that researchers planted, while others were not given a dime to find.
After using the copier, people were asked how happy they were about life, and those who found a dime were consistently more upbeat about "their lives as a whole, the economy, that kind of thing," Dr. Schwarz said. "We've found that a dime can make you happy for about 20 minutes. Then your mood wears off."
People tested in a study at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana are given Palm Pilot handheld computers, which beep randomly several times in a day. After each beep, subjects fill out a questionnaire rating their happiness at that moment on a scale of one to seven. They are also asked what they were doing when they were beeped.
Dr. Kahneman, another co-editor of the "Well-Being" book, said research on moment-to-moment happiness could help scientists figure out all sorts of things. "What is the mood of people when they ride in a Washington subway versus a New York subway?" he asked, making a comparison between a subway that's new, clean and punctual and one that often is not. "What is the effect on mood of having trees, of looking at water?"
Last year, Dr. Kahneman and a colleague published a paper on whether people are happier in California or the Midwest. "We found not a particle of difference," he said. "But everyone in California and the Midwest thinks that people are happier in California."
Dr. Kahneman concluded that people asked about happiness often focus on one particular point, like the climate in California. But when it comes right down to it, Dr. Kahneman said, "climate is just not very important to well-being."
There do appear to be cultural differences across countries though.
Hamlet, it seems, was the rarest of creatures: an unhappy Dane. Surveys have found that "Danes appear to be frightfully happy," said Mr. Argyle, citing a study in which 65 percent of the Danes interviewed said they were satisfied with life. By contrast, "Italians and French seem miserable," he said, with only 10 percent giving life a thumb's up.
Americans tend to be a pretty positive bunch, while Asians are less sanguine.
"People in Japan report being less happy -- probably because they focus on the negative," said Dr. Diener, referring to several cross-cultural surveys that have been done. "They think about their own shortcomings. Americans have bad points, but they don't tend to look at them too much."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

 BODY:

THE YEN RISES. The dollar fell as traders scooped up the Japanese currency, which has become more attractive on a brightening outlook for the Japanese economy. The dollar closed at 116.55 yen, down from 116.70 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Are We Ready to Lose the Next Air War?

BYLINE: By F. Whitten Peters; F. Whitten Peters is Acting Secretary of the Air Force.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With little debate and without a hearing, the full House voted this week to effectively kill the F-22 Raptor aircraft, the linchpin of the Air Force's modernization program. Fortunately, the final word is not in, and the F-22 still has strong support in Congress and from Defense Secretary William Cohen and President Clinton.
Killing the F-22 is simply not acceptable. It is wrong for national security. It is bad economics. And it would put American service members at unnecessary and unacceptable risk. 
 Operation Allied Force in the skies over Kosovo illustrated that air superiority is the foundation for victory on land, at sea and in the air. As we rapidly deploy decisive combat forces from the United States to the scene of hostilities, fighter jets will be the first to arrive. They will help us deter an adversary from attacking and, if deterrence fails, to fight on the ground and in the air, and win. The F-22 would guarantee success in these vital missions for decades to come.
Some critics of the F-22 contend that our country's relatively easy victories in the last 10 years prove that we don't need a new fighter. They insist that our air power is already far superior to that of any potential enemy.
Today, though, at least six other aircraft -- the Russian MIG-29, SU-27 and SU-35, the French Mirage 2000 and Rafael and the European Consortium's Eurofighter -- threaten to surpass the aging F-15, our current top-of-the-line air-to-air fighter.
These aircraft are marketed aggressively around the world to our allies and potential adversaries. Without the F-22, the United States runs the risk of allowing our air superiority to atrophy to the point that an adversary could inflict great harm on our previously superior Air Force.
Already many nations, among them Iran, Iraq and North Korea, are constructing sophisticated air defenses built around surface-to-air missile systems like the Russian SA-10, SA-12 and SA-20. All these missile systems are available on the market today. Our current aircraft, like the F-15 and F-16, lack the F-22's stealth and supercruise abilities and will be unable to evade or destroy these air defenses without risking heavy losses.
Other weapons that might be used against these air defenses are also extremely expensive. The Air Force's conventional air-launched cruise missile and the Navy's Tomahawk cruise missile cost $1.4 million each. Even with these weapons, we would still need an upgraded F-15, which could cost some $40 billion -- essentially the same as the cost of completing the F-22 program, but the F-15 would have only one-third of the ability.
Using a combination of cruise missiles and upgraded F-15's does not, therefore, reflect the best stewardship of taxpayer dollars. More important, our young men and women would be at greater risk in future wars.
Not only does the F-22 meet the military threats on the horizon, it is also affordable as a part of a well-conceived modernization strategy the Air Force has used over the last three decades. By consistently investing about 10 to 12 percent of our total budget on new aircraft, we have been able to upgrade all our aircraft over a period of years.
In the 1970's, we bought new fighters. In the 1980's, we added new bombers. During the 1990's, we fielded the C-17, our newest transport jet. Now, our attention returns to the fighter force. The Congressional Budget Office has applauded this cyclical strategy; we have maintained the world's best air force while avoiding overlaps in aircraft purchases.
No question, the F-22 is expensive, but it is worth every penny. Each Raptor will cost on average about $84 million to produce. The $200 million price tag discussed recently is a figure that charges all past F-22 program costs -- including research and development, testing, procurement and military construction -- to the planned purchase of 339 aircraft.
This is an unfair comparison because the $23 billion we've already spent on the F-22 would be lost if the program were canceled. The key question is, What will it cost from today forward?
At peak production, the Air Force would spend about 6 percent of our budget on the F-22. This is about the same percentage of our budget that went toward developing and buying the F-15 nearly 30 years ago. This equates to less than 2 percent of America's national security budget. Our cost containment on the F-22 is a success story; it is within Congressionally mandated caps for both development and production.
The threat is real, and the F-22 program is well within our budget. The air superiority provided by the Raptor would insure victory in future battles and preserve the lives of countless Americans soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines. The F-22 is an investment America cannot pass up.

HEADLINE: A Worthy Tax Credit for New York

 BODY:
The Albany budget process consists of a long stalemate followed by the hasty negotiation of a deal between the Governor, Senate majority leader and Speaker of the Assembly. This year's scramble is running true to form, leaving the possibility that a valuable tax break for low-income workers -- some of whom are former welfare recipients -- might fall by the wayside.
The bill would let workers who earn less than $30,000 keep more of their earnings, and it would give a cash refund to working families making less than $14,000, who pay no income tax at all. The payment, known as an earned income tax credit, has proved successful at the Federal level. The state proposal would be financed by savings that have resulted from the shrinkage of welfare rolls. 
 This is made possible by the Federal welfare reform act, which converted matching payments to the state into a block grant that has kept level since 1997. The decline in welfare rolls means that $500 million in Federal matching funds has not been spent, a sum expected to rise to $1.4 billion in a year. The Government stipulates that surpluses be spent only to help the poor through day care, drug assistance or other programs designed to help them hold down jobs. But at least a dozen states have decided to bolster low-income wage earners by enacting the tax credit into law.
New York State has been slow to spend its surplus, in part because of a desire to save in case there is a recession and the welfare rolls expand again. But using as much money as possible for a tax credit will create more of an incentive for people to get off welfare -- and make it easier for the state to meet Federal targets, which require the rolls to grow smaller with each passing year.
