SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2703 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
A Worldly Getaway 2 Hours From Manhattan

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE

 BODY:
AHA! Another weekend warrior up from the big city," Paul Cavaccini, the manager of Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, N.Y., said with a chuckle when he saw me walk in the door. I certainly looked the part of a New York City runaway -- my dark linen pants ensemble hinted of brunches in SoHo, while the North Face backpack I hoisted smelled of sweat and insect repellent.
Mixed signals, certainly. But I was experiencing simultaneous cravings for urban sophistication and rural idyll. I wanted to lose myself in sylvan woods and babbling brooks, but only if they were within shouting range of a good wine store, an interesting restaurant and, perhaps, a purveyor of prosciutto di Parma. 
 I've never been much of a weekender. When faced with the choice of spending several thousand dollars on a summer rental on, say, Fire Island versus spending the same or less on a month's sojourn living extremely well in Mexico, the Caribbean, or Asia, I've always opted for the faraway trip.
Still, there are those Fridays in June when the sky is so blue, the air so fresh and warm, the smell of blooming wisteria drifting in the air from Prospect Park so lush, that it seems almost a misdemeanor to spend Saturday and Sunday in Brooklyn. Could I stage a swift, brief getaway that wouldn't upset my notions of travel economy?
On a weekend like this in early June, I decided to try. I took a subway to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan and hopped on an Adirondack Trailways bus headed to New Paltz, about 85 miles north, in Ulster County.
Southern Ulster, where New Paltz is, isn't as hip and well-trodden as Woodstock (in northern Ulster), nor as fashionable as celebrity-studded Columbia County. So I figured that accommodations would be a bit cheaper. I'd been there before, to visit my friend Annie, and we had spent a day wandering through almost-empty, gorgeous wooded trails in Minnewaska State Park, where the Shawangunk Mountain range drops, in a dramatic series of bare rock cliffs, down to the Hudson Valley -- an amazing vista that I wanted to see again.
There's a good Web site for the Hudson Valley region (www.hvnet.com), and a local magazine with lots of bed-and-breakfast listings called Ulster Magazine. Between these two sources, I was able to arrange my travel plans in less than an hour.
I decided to stretch my getaway, and stay four nights instead of two, from Friday to Tuesday. I booked a single room without bath for the first two nights at the Kripplebush Bed-and-Breakfast, not too far from Annie's cabin in the town of Stone Ridge, for $50 a night. Then, I'd splurge on a two-night stay ($80 a night) at Ujjala's B & B, near New Paltz.
Abby Johnnes, the owner of Kripplebush, gave me the number of Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, a short walk from the Trailways depot. Paul set me up with an economy car for $29 a day, including all insurance, and gave me the inside dope on local sources of Italian ham.
Abby, a sweet petite grandmother who once ran a bookstore in Greenwich Village, bought her house in the country after her children went off to college. Her house sits on a country road across the street from the Methodist church, a 12-mile drive northwest of New Paltz. My room was one of six that she rents out in the large wood-frame house that dates to the mid-1800's.
The room was tiny, but had a window with a view of her inviting back garden, where pink peonies and stalks of foxglove were blooming. The decor ran to Oriental prints, Abby's own paintings and shelf after shelf of interesting books, artifacts of a downtown literary life, circa 1960.
It was already dinnertime. I'd figured there would be little diversion available, but soon Annie called. "You're right near me," she said. "We're going to the film festival tonight. Pick you up in a half hour."
The Hudson Valley Film Festival was in its last week in Rhinebeck, about a half-hour drive from Stone Ridge across the Hudson River. We hurried over, just in time to catch a screening of a documentary on the photographer Walker Evans ($5). Afterward, I was pleased to find that the enthusiastic festival organizers had arranged a reception for the participants -- free wine and excellent and abundant canapes of smoked salmon, vegetables, and cheese.
I munched away at "dinner," amused that I'd run off from New York City only to bump into it upstate, as strains of movie conversation floated through the room: "You know I told Marty that he needed to talk to Bobby about this." Annie explained that the Stone Ridge-High Falls area of Ulster was a weekend hideaway for the independent film industry. Harvey Keitel and Willem Dafoe, among others, had houses along the same road as Kripplebush -- hadn't I noticed Dafoe's house, made of rubber?
I hadn't. I bit into another canape and savored the weekend warrior experience.
Breakfast was ready when I stumbled down at 8:30 the next morning: crepes with fruit and cream, bagels and superb coffee.
Braced and well-fed, I set out for Minnewaska -- with a detour, first, for provisions. In High Falls, a picturesque village three miles from Kripplebush, I bought a big bag of date bars ($3.99) and a bag of organic almonds ($3.99) at the local food co-op. At a deli closer to the park, Stone Ridge Specialty Foods, I picked up some homemade crab cakes ($3.75 each), for the rest of my trail lunch.
Crab cakes, a crisp blue sky, no bugs in sight and a nearly deserted trail stretching ahead -- hiking doesn't get much better than this, I thought to myself. My feet hit a nice walking rhythm along the carriage road. Until the mid-80's, this area was the grounds and preserve of a grand hotel (owned by the brother of the owner of the nearby Mohonk Mountain House). After the hotel burned down, the property became part of the state park system.
At one end of the park, Lake Minnewaska draws crowds, but the vast network of foot trails isn't much used. With the free map that the guard had handed me as I pulled into the parking lot (the fee is $5), I charted a course that I figured would lead me about four miles to the far end of the park, to a high bluff with a panoramic view of the valley and of Lake Awosting. The map was not very detailed, so I stuck to the carriage road. Then I bumped into a park ranger who had some good news: today, the park was inaugurating a hiking path that wasn't on the map yet but that led in the direction I was headed. The ranger pointed out the trail blazes, and I was off.
I followed a riverbed for a while, then took a turn and headed over high bare rocks. Suddenly, I was on a bluff covered with gnarled, ancient looking pitch pines. I was alone, and in the midst of a natural setting as remote and wild as any I've experienced. That this pristine place is but a short drive from Manhattan seemed almost a miracle. The wind up here howled -- some of the pines were bent almost horizontal. I continued, stopping to take pictures and have lunch.
Scrambling up another little ridge, I came down the other side and gasped. Below the mountain that dropped several hundred feet, Hudson Valley farmland spread out like a tablecloth checkered in shades of green. Lake Awosting shimmered at the other side. It was a lot of view, considering how little climbing I had to do. (I'd say my hike was moderately easy, with a bit of rock scrambling.)
Still, I'd come about four miles, and my return route to the parking lot, which skirted the ridge and passed the park's other lake, Minnewaska, was about another four and a half miles. By the time I got my sweaty self back to Kripplebush, I was ready for a nice dinner.
The Clove Cafe in High Falls is designed to please a city slicker out for a meal in the country -- dim lights, comfy wooden booths, not overly formal. The menu looked ambitious (the new owners , I found out, are graduates of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, across the Hudson), and was filled with wild things like venison and rabbit.
I had rabbit stew in a hearty Mediterranean-style sauce, polenta and steamed arugula. On the chef's recommendation, I tried a glass of a South African red wine called Pinotage, delicious, richly oaky and fruity, perfect for the end of a full day of tramping. With dessert and tip, dinner came to $48 -- pricey, but worth it, and my repast the night before had been free, after all.
Ujjala's Bed-and-Breakfast is about a 15-mile drive from Kripplebush, on the other side of the Shawangunk ridge, just south of New Paltz. I set out early, stopping for a bit to poke among old books and kitchen appliances at the Sunday morning flea market in High Falls.
At Ujjala Schwartz's lilac-colored Victorian house on a quiet small-town road, my room was larger than the one at Kripplebush, with antique bed and desk, lacy comforter and a puffy featherbed over the mattress. Wind chimes tinkled outside the kitchen, which opened to a little deck, sauna and pocket-sized garden. In the back was a meditation lodge, and two sweat lodges, where Indian purification rituals are sometimes held.
My friend Mark arrived from Westchester, to join me for a day of wine tasting. This part of the Hudson Valley was settled by the French Huguenots in the 1600's, and the Gallic farmers planted some of the first vineyards in the Americas. Viniculture in the region has waxed and waned through the centuries, but has recently hit its stride again: there are now enough vineyards in the area to support two wine trails, organized by local tourist organizations. We set out to visit the six vineyards on the Shawangunk Wine Trail.
The winding county roads ran through picturesque farmlands where cows lazed beside big red barns and young deer occasionally darted across our path. We tasted about four wines each at three vineyards; Mark, the connoisseur, was underwhelmed. Just when we'd decided that the scenery, rather than Hudson Valley wines, was the main attraction of the wine trail, we came upon Baldwin Vineyards in far southern Ulster. There, we sampled some unusual and subtly sweet dessert wines, intense with essences of local strawberries and raspberries. Even Mark was impressed, and we bought five bottles between us ($7 to $10).
I awoke early my last day because I wanted to go sightseeing in New Paltz before hiking again. To my dismay, I found that on Mondays, the town's old stone Huguenot houses are closed. But I enjoyed a walk in the cool of the morning down Huguenot Street, peering into the windows of the old settlers' homes, now museums, some of which date back to the 1700's. Since there was no one about, I could imagine I was walking in Colonial New York.
My time travel continued as I drove, about 20 minutes later, through the parking lot gates of Mohonk Mountain House. This Victorian resort, its main lodge a riot of over-the-top gingerbread, Tudor and the generally eclectic, sits on a huge tract of land with quaintly manicured grounds -- once one of the grand hotels of America.
It remains in the hands of the original owners, the Smiley family, and it retains its idiosyncratic and authentic Victorian atmosphere. Entrance to the main property is restricted to hotel guests, whose meals are included with their lodging. Nonguests who wish to hike the property -- a stretch adjacent to Minnewaska with similar topography -- must pass a checkpoint, wear a badge and pay a fee ($12 on weekends, $9 on weekdays).
Minnewaska State Park is a much better choice for serious hiking. But Mohonk is the place to absorb and understand Victorian esthetics -- not the faux lace-and-curtains Victoriana of home decor, but the 19th-century sensibility. Each of Mohonk's paths winds in a fashion calculated to provide the most pleasing view of the natural setting. Nature is tamed and made softer and more comfortable by wooden benches placed at regular intervals, charming gazebos, clever ponds and other evidences of the hand of man.
I rested on one of those benches and took stock: in four days I'd gone to a screening party, hiked in splendid woods, tasted wine, poked in a flea market, eaten an excellent dinner and even managed to tuck in a sauna. I had had as much variety of experience, and as much fun in Ulster County as in many faraway exotic places, without buying an airline ticket. This novice weekend warrior felt victorious -- and began to plot her next campaign.
 
The bottom line: culture, nature and relaxation
I spent $96.50 a day for food, lodging and activities during my four days in Ulster County.
 
Getting There
Round-trip bus fare from midtown Manhattan to New Paltz, N.Y., cost $31.35 on Adirondack Trailways, which runs about a dozen trips a day, lasting just under two hours. Information: (800) 858-8555.
I rented a 1992 Mercury from Rent a Wreck in New Paltz, 87 North Chestnut Street, (914) 255-5666, for $29 a day. Mileage is free up to 125 miles a day and you must stay within a 100-mile radius of the office.
 
Where to Stay
Kripplebush Bed-and-Breakfast, 160 Kripplebush Road, Stone Ridge, N.Y., (914) 687-0723, is also Abby Johnnes's home. She has six guest rooms in a stagecoach house that dates from the 1840's. My single with bath across the hall was $50; doubles are $65 to $95. No credit cards.
Ujjala's Bed-and-Breakfast, 2 Forest Glen Road, New Paltz, (914) 255-6360, www.ujjalasbnb.com., has four rooms, with lace duvets, antique furniture and lots of pillows. I chose it for its New Age accouterments: there's a sauna and a meditation chamber. Ujjala Schwartz offers advice on rock-climbing and kayaking and canoeing in the area. My room, with bath across the hall, was $80 a night; doubles are $90, $105 with private bath. No credit cards.
 
Where to Eat
The Clove Cafe, 1003 Route 213, High Falls, N.Y., (914) 687-7911, has a sophisticated menu of local game and other delicacies. Dinner with wine, tax and tip came to $48. Lunch served on Friday, brunch on Saturday and Sunday. Closed Monday and Tuesday.
Along Route 209, Stone Ridge Specialty Foods, High Falls, (914) 687-2000, sells takeout foods with an Italian touch, and is putting in tables. I picked up two meaty crab cakes for lunch for $7.50. Closed Monday.
The High Falls Food Co-op, 1398 Route 213, High Falls, (914) 687-7262, has a good selection of organic munchies.
A few miles north of the entrance to Minnewaska State Park, The Log Cabin Restaurant, 5941 Route 44-45, Kerhonkson, N.Y., (914) 626-9838, caters to Ukrainian retirees in the area. The proprietor, Olga Sawchuck, served me scrumptious pirogis stuffed with potatoes and cheese, and topped with brown-fried onions in butter. I washed this down with a draft beer; the tab came to $9. Open for lunch and dinner daily, except Tuesday.
 
What to Do
The annual Hudson Valley Film Festival, (914) 473-0318, presents aprogram of features, documentaries and shorts during the first week of June in Rhinebeck; many screenings are followed by talks and receptions.
Minnewaska State Park Preserve, (914) 255-0752, charges a parking fee of $5, $6 in summer. There are hiking trails, but no overnight camping. Swimming is available at two lakes. The park opens at 9 A.M daily and closes as late as 9 P.M., depending on season.
The wineries on the Shawangunk Wine Trail have varied hours, but most welcome visitors on Saturday and Sunday afternoons in the summer. A list of the participating wineries, and a map of the trail is available at www.hvnet.com. The trail is reasonably well marked by signs with grapes, but taking a map along is a good idea.
The stone houses along Huguenot Street in New Paltz form a National Historic Landmark District. The Huguenot Historical Society, (914) 255-1889, www.hhs-newpaltz.org., runs tours, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. every day but Monday from May to October. Tours, which cost $3, $6 and $10, depending on length, start at the visitors center, 18 Broadhead Avenue.
The grounds of Mohonk Mountain House, New Paltz, N.Y., (914) 255-1000, www.mohonk.com, but not the house itself, are open to the public. Entry is $12 on weekends, $9 during the week; $8 and $7 under age 12. Day visitors can use the nine-hole golf course ($12 to $20) and six tennis courts ($12 an hour) if space is available. HEADLINE: The New Frontier

BYLINE: By Amy M. Spindler 

 BODY:
It seems particularly appropriate that one of the rare pioneering events in American fashion was conceived by a recent immigrant.
 Nine months after moving to American soil, Helmut Lang switched the entire collection calendar, so that for the first time, this February, Europe showed in New York's shadow. 
 It's a petty issue, like a schoolyard squabble. Who goes first, who goes last. Mostly, it's a question of who gets the credit for bringing back fishtail hems, burnt orange and the like. Silly, really, except that fortunes in fashion are often made based on who invented what. Or who copied it at the right moment and made it available to the most people.
 The New York collections were once a full month after Europe's began, leaving American designers little chance of having an impact on the world market: the last to get into magazines, the last to get into stores and, presumably, the last to get into closets.
 "It was very pioneering," Lang says of the decision to move his show. "It changed the whole global calendar in a crazy way."
 That change clearly inspired a sense of patriotism and pride, and raised the level of creativity in New York to a new high. The air here was the same as the air in Europe, which is to say there was a whiff of heartfelt homespun clothes on each continent. But in America, the references were bred in the bone: the inspiration for many of the shows were cultural milestones in American history.
 For starters, there was Helmut Lang's infatuation with NASA, based on his belief that the only way to approach the millennium is not "to be afraid." He cited all the things that NASA has affected in our daily lives, from aluminum foil to toothpaste tubes. But his collection was full of its own invention -- new ways to wear jackets (hung from shoulders like backpacks), new ways to wear pants (covering one leg like chaps), new ways to cinch waists (cummerbunds with pockets) and new ways to dress entirely (all in one piece).
 For Anna Sui, it was the Newport Folk Festival from '63 to '66 that rocked her world. Described in her show's program notes as "Newport's golden age. . .when Mary Travers looked like Julie Christie, Judy Collins loomed as Sweet Judy Blue Eyes and a fresh-faced Bob Dylan had just begun giving the larger world a hard time," this was the beginning of the hippie movement in America, another phenomenon that many shows paid homage to.
 But some of the strongest collections of the season were redolent of John Ford's movies, with their emphasis on strength, courage and independence. In fact, this is the first time in years that Hollywood is making Westerns again, revisionist ones like "Wild Wild West," real ones like "Texas Rangers" (from Dimension, the company that started the teen slasher trend with "Scream") and spiritual ones like "All the Pretty Horses."
 Tales of the American West became unpopular during the last economic boom for one reason: they were about poor people living by their wits. Westerns were about success outside civilization, something the 80's disparaged.
 A decade ago, the spirit of the pioneer was recast as entrepreneurship, and power suits were the result. But in this economic boom, the pioneer is being interpreted literally -- a woman with an artistic bohemian air, more likely to wear a serape than a power suit.
 Marc Jacobs's pioneering princesses wore ruffled skirts and ribbon ties, aprons and jumpers, pony prints and sheer little camisole tops. At Michael Kors, Park Avenue met Wyoming, with visions of Slim Hawks on the range, and the rangy elegance of Gary Cooper. For John Bartlett, Georgia O'Keeffe and Alfred Stieglitz were "a couple who embodied the pioneering spirit of the century, the cultural link between an urban setting like New York and the unknown, as in the Southwest." His pioneers wore leather railroad-worker pants, cashmere C.P.O. shirts and sable furs dyed to look like Hudson Bay blankets. "It felt as though we were jumping off the cliff without knowing where we were going to land," Bartlett says of showing before Europe. "I felt much more uncensored, able to do what I wanted to do without worrying. America isn't about avant-garde -- it's about being a pioneer, which is the legacy of our culture."
 Cowboy and frontier clothing has long been considered the property of Ralph Lauren, the pioneer of the pioneer look. But as the millennium looms, all history seems fair game for appropriation (even the archives of other designers), and the American West seems particularly relevant, since at this point we are all pioneers.
 "The clothes were strong the way an artistic woman is strong, like Georgia O'Keeffe," says Simon Doonan, creative director of Barneys New York. "It was the antithesis to the tarty early 90's."
 Women like O'Keeffe and Millicent Rogers, the Standard Oil heiress who made the Southwest fashionable in the 1940's, speak to this generation. Escape, dropping out of the rat race, can be interpreted as an elitist activity, requiring more wealth than it takes to scramble up the ladder. So there are two American dreams, really: monetary success, on the one hand, and no longer needing that success, on the other.
 "Women today talk about getting away from everything, getting out of the city, getting over the 80's power game," Doonan says. "In the 80's, they wanted power and money and corporate strength. They got it, and it didn't make them happy, so they kept looking further."
 Looking further is now about looking back, returning to a time that was perhaps simpler, but required more strength of character.
 That strength proved to be implicit in what inspired the shows and explicit in the materials chosen. Working with unfinished felt, Ralph Lauren left the West behind as everyone else discovered it, producing clothes that were simultaneously pristine, monastic and militaristic. He regarded this collection as pivotal, as "setting the tone for the new millennium."
 In fact, it was this need to offer meaning that seemed to pervade the season, which was less about fashion than about America itself. And as a permanent record of the event, the designers whose clothes are featured here have agreed to donate them to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute, and Barneys New York (the sponsor of the institute's current exhibit, "Our New Clothes") will be displaying them in its windows until July 28.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 7-25-99: Word & Image;
Rushing the Seasons

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Since we are all obsessed with plans to greet the next century on New Year's Eve, it may seem natural for the media to be rushing the electoral calendar by two, five, even nine years. Politically speaking, as The Economist put it, the Fourth of July this year felt like Labor Day 2000, the time when we would normally just begin to focus on the choice of leaders for 2001. But what is understandable is nonetheless unseemly and in no small way undemocratic.
 With the hedge of only a disingenuous question mark, The Economist itself proclaimed on its Independence Day cover that George W. Bush and Al Gore had their nominations "ALL SEWN UP." And the British weekly was surely speaking with the courage of every other journal's conviction. 
 The New Yorker's Talk of the Town celebrated July 4th in this "off year" with three separate election features. One offered Joe Klein's rendering, in primary colors, of George Bush's heart and soul. Another declared Hillary Rodham Clinton's undeclared run for the Senate to be "the first great political drama of the new millennium." And, that settled, the magazine postulated a Bill Clinton quest after his own Senate seat in Arkansas, in 2002.
 Looking still farther ahead, The New York Times discovered that the new Governor of Minnesota, Jesse Ventura, was plotting his own bid for the White House -- in 2004. The former wrestler was thought to be recruiting Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Connecticut maverick, as the Reform Party's nominee against Bush and Gore next year to gain at least 5 percent of the vote in 2000 and thus qualify for Federal financing in the campaign after next.
 The New Yorker trumped again, with a vision of 2008. It reasoned quite plausibly that Mrs. Clinton would never want to spend her weekends in Buffalo just to share power with 99 other Senators. So she must be planning a run for President in her own second term, after her presumed obligation to support the election and re-election of Gore has been fully paid.
 The simplest explanation for all this soothsaying is that the media are cutting costs. Divining the future is a lot easier and cheaper than documenting the present. And prophecy has twice the shelf life of history; people forget the floods of yesterday but will gossip endlessly about a predicted deluge.
 Another reason for the media's political rush may be the absence of other compelling news. In this time of peace and prosperity, Mrs. Clinton's transformation into a New Yorker became the subject of 232 articles in The Times in the first six months of this year -- almost as many as those tracking the plight and reform of Medicare. A full 16 months before Election Day, Mrs. Clinton was getting more free time on national television than her husband's hauls of "soft" money could purchase in his campaigns. The press corps covering her maiden voyage around upstate New York was twice the size of the entourage that followed Nixon to China.
 But, O.K., a First Lady's solo flight from the White House is a bedazzling novelty. She's still thinking about only 1 of 535 seats in Congress. And why race to resolve every other contest?
 There is, first, the media's penchant for always waging the last war. As the political press discovered only after the Presidential contest of 1996, it was won by Clinton's television blitz of 1995 -- a pre-emptive strike that knocked out Bob Dole long before he was even nominated. So a full-court press in 1999 became the media's predictable approach to 2000.
 A further reason for rushing the season was the shift of many primary elections from June to March. Reacting against the disproportionate political influence of early-voting small states like Iowa and New Hampshire, party leaders of delegate-rich states like New York and California moved their own primaries ahead by three months.
 That seriously damaged the rolling-stone strategy of lesser-known and underfinanced aspirants; they could no longer count on winter walking tours to give them momentum for the television wars of spring. Now the big TV outlays will fall due in dozens of states at the very beginning of the primary season, and the Democratic and Republican nominees will be known a full seven months before Election Day.
 So, obviously, the richer a candidate the better his chances. The media needed only to learn the winners of the financial primaries in 1999 to proclaim the winners of the electoral primaries of 2000. After six months of fund-raising, win, place and show went to Bush, with $35.5 million; Gore, with $18.5 million, and Bill Bradley, with $11 million. By July 1, we read about a Republican runaway and a comfortable though not yet insurmountable lead for Gore among Democrats. Why the opinion polls aligned so perfectly with the financial rolls was a question largely left to sociologists. On to the World Series.
 Note that the newly decisive financial primaries employ some of the same sly techniques to manipulate the media formerly used in conventional campaigns. Candidates who used to underestimate their strength in Iowa or New Hampshire have now taken to poor-mouthing their early fund-raising so as to generate headlines about their doing "better than expected." This propaganda of surprise then serves to command still more contributions from corporate favor-seekers and to scare away donations to any remaining rivals.
 Our politicians and media alike have perfected the art of projecting present strength into future power. They are served by a whole industry that creates political momentum from a combination of wealth and celebrity and manufacture votes from television appearances and commercials. That industry, a post-industrial complex of fund-raisers, pollsters, consultants and media buyers, can turn marquee names like Hillary and the Body Ventura into virtual cash and raise mountains of actual money for office seekers blessed with incumbency or the aura of electoral inevitability.
 Long tutored by Theodore H. White in the offstage arts of "the making of a President," the media learned at the end of the 20th century to project the evidence of fame and fortune far into the future. We just follow the money and take the voters and issues for granted. But inevitably, we will turn our most important political rites into an intolerable bore.
 Letting all this political combat drown out timely policy debate is unseemly. And if you think it's democratic, I'd like to sell you a heavily used bridge to the next century.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Nurtured by a Canal, a Downtown Desert Blooms

BYLINE: By JANE HOLTZ KAY; Jane Holtz Kay is the architecture critic for The Nation as well as the author of "Asphalt Nation" and "Lost Boston."

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
THE Providence that greeted a generation of visitors during the dark days of urban renewal might have stood as an emblem of the demise of American downtowns. Choked with roads, strewn with rubble and crowded with hard-top parking lots, the grim center of this city seemed blighted beyond redemption.
But today this half-mile swath bears a new name, Waterplace Park, and with its new outlook hints of a Venice in New England. Much of the credit goes to the architect William D. Warner, who, though he didn't exactly part the asphalt, has created a model of urban revitalization, turning what was once a desert of hardtop and highway into a canal and promenade. 
 With its waterway, park space, esplanades, restaurants and bicycle and walking paths, the project has begun a transformation of the city's downtown. Inspired by the success of Waterplace Park, the city recently began the next phase of renewal: a $270 million 10-year project that will complete the waterway's passage to the ocean.
The change taking place in the heart of Providence fits into a national trend: American cities are increasingly replacing hardtopped waterfronts and other downtown neighborhoods that had been flattened by highways in the 50's and 60's. In so doing, they are tearing up roads -- or depaving, to use the new term -- to create attractive cityscapes.
Though depaving projects on the scale of that in Providence are rare, smaller efforts are becoming more commonplace. In the 70's, Portland, Ore., took down a highway to build a riverbank park. Recently, San Francisco reclaimed a strip of land that had been cut off from the waterfront by the elevated Embarcadero highway. Boston is burying a downtown waterfront artery in a tunnel. In Louisville, Ky., a half-mile stretch along the Ohio River was made over by dismantling an exit ramp from Interstate 64 to make a walkable link to the city's downtown. And in the South Bronx, a campaign is under way to dismantle a one-and-one-fourth-mile stretch of the Sheridan Expressway and use it to expand a desolate park on the Bronx River.
Of all these initiatives, the one in Providence is "the most ambitious new architecture and engineering project in the nation," said Ann Breen, co-director of the Waterfront Center, an advocacy group in Washington. A photograph of the city before the waterfront project began more than a decade ago would reveal a landscape split in two by roads, highways and parking lots: at the city's crest stood the palatial McKim, Mead & White marble state capitol; below, the dense downtown.
In the early 80's the state proposed a plan that would have repaired the highways but left those that choked the city's center. Dismayed by that prospect, Mr. Warner proposed a plan of his own to jackhammer the asphalt that divided the city and restore the waterfront. His proposal included a re-routing of the Woonasquatucket and Moshassuck rivers, which had been buried by highways. The city signed on.
If "daylighting" is the word used by those who release creeks from culverts, "city making" would best describe what Mr. Warner had in mind. While earlier plans for redeveloping the waterfront had surfaced, Mr. Warner was in every sense the architect behind the realization of Waterplace Park, said Edward Sanderson, the executive director of the State Preservation Commission. It was Mr. Warner's political savvy that saw the project through the bureaucratic labyrinth, aided by the support of Mayor Vincent (Buddy) Cianci and Senators Claiborne Pell and John Chafee, whose backing made it possible to use Federal transportation funds to finance the project.
Walking in the newly created park, boating along the canal's still waters or passing under a procession of 12 bridges, one is hard put to imagine the former dreariness of this area. What visitors encounter today is a tour de force: a curving waterway dotted with lagoons, street lights, steps, platforms for benches, a restaurant and small rotundas. Along the way, bridges and paths fan out into plazas near the campus of the Rhode Island School of Design or create inviting spaces in front of buildings. The palette of materials is large, the architect's way of design traditional: it has neither the thin angles and awkward lines of the deconstructionists nor the clunky pseudohistoricism of the post-moderns.
The architect handles the extremes of scale deftly, from his overall plan to details like the bronze railings, the patterned brick on a bridge or the ornate sewer covers, all of which he designed.
Mr. Warner describes his 12-person office not as an "A & E" firm, as in architecture and engineering, but as an "A & L.A." firm, for architecture and landscape architecture. His attention to the waterfront grounds is obvious: daffodils dapple the slopes in between the river-grass plantings; weeping willows and oak trees trace the banks, and the other regional plants show the care given to the greensward.
Local artists have made Waterplace Park a gathering spot in the summer with Water Fire, an event in which gondoliers cloaked in black mufti glide from brazier to brazier along the canal, each illuminating the night sky. This spectacle has become something of a civic happening, drawing a cross section of city dwellers to the waterfront.
The next phase of the project will enhance the edges of the harbor basin. This austere industrial area, with its odd-lot buildings, will have a more "earthy" look, Mr. Warner says. The rocks sustaining its banks will remain, and a boardwalk, docks and a heritage museum are planned, as is a bicycle path from the waterfront to the city's poorer neighborhoods. Also in the area is a power plant that bears Mr. Warner's signature: the addition of massive black ducts and windows emblazoned with red and green.
While Mr. Warner's Waterplace Park -- not to mention the popular NBC television series "Providence" article, page 29 -- gives the city a new cachet, another new project detracts from the area's urbanity. It is the $435 million 1.3-million-square-foot Providence Place soon to open between the canal and the capitol. Spanning a long city block, this shopping and entertainment complex, with a giant glass atrium called the Wintergarden, is a mall-like intruder on the cityscape.
Dominated by a 4,000-car garage, this looming structure, along with three new downtown hotels and a convention center, could drain customers from the city's core and threaten the vitality hard won by Waterplace. Indeed, the overscaled Providence Place raises questions as to whether the city can build more lively, intimate projects like Waterplace Park as developers push for more conventional projects.
It also invites the larger question: can American cities learn from the success of Waterplace Park? Even as Kansas City, Mo., enhances its handsome system of historic greenways, it expands its Interstate through the city. While Camden, N.J., enhances its waterfront, Trenton succumbs to a retrograde road-widening of Route 29 by the Delaware River.
Nor does simply eliminating asphalt produce utopian architecture. A park in Louisville by the landscape architecture superstar George Hargreaves is sterile. His formalistic design makes the surroundings secondary: in an arbitrary approach to the landscape, he places a triangular "Parisian park" here, a waterfall there and nowhere (practically) a waterside seat. The result is stiff and unyielding, a far remove from Louisville's richly textured parks by Frederick Law Olmsted that hew to river and land.
Still, if results vary, the impetus grows. The urge for green (or blue) relief was made manifest in the last election when 240 communities across the country placed initiatives to preserve open space on the ballot and more than two-thirds passed, reflecting a new constituency for such policies. If today's sprawl to the fringes of the metropolis is the problem, reconstructing the urban core is the solution. Those struggling to save America's cities could learn from Providence's depaving.

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Reconstructing Khmer Classics From Zero

BYLINE: By ROBERT TURNBULL; Robert Turnbull, who writes about the arts, teaches music at the Royal University of Fine Arts in Phnom Penh.

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
ONE gray December afternoon in 1996, Fred Frumberg decided to quit. His secure and salaried post in charge of staff directors at the Paris Opera had lost its charm.
An industrious 39-year-old Philadelphian with a passion for the stage and a distinguished record as a trouble-shooter for big-name directors like Peter Sellars and Francesca Zambello, Mr. Frumberg still relished the adrenaline thrill of opening nights, the last-minute miracles snatched from disaster, even the eyeball-to-eyeball skirmishes with recalcitrant stars like the tenor Roberto Alagna. But now the downside depressed him: a daily grind of singer cancellations, union walkouts, petty opera-house politics and Gallic paper pushing. He wanted out. 
 Six months later, Mr. Frumberg found himself in the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, charged with a radical mission to save a decimated culture.
It was never going to be easy. Days after he arrived, the country collapsed once again into civil war. For 48 hours, Mr. Frumberg was holed up in a Phnom Penh apartment as rockets exploded and gunfire rattled outside. Occasionally he would run the gantlet to the Foreign Correspondent's Club, a gecko-infested colonial building, straight out of a Marguerite Duras novel, where a posse of war correspondents had dug themselves in.
The son of a landscape architect who fought in the Yom Kippur War, Mr. Frumberg spent his teens in Israel and most of his professional life outside the United States. He is proficient in at least five languages. His fascination with Cambodia began after a revelatory holiday there in 1995. Inspired, he said, by the Khmer people's "extraordinary resilience in the face of adversity," he buried himself in studies of the Khmer culture and language once he was back in Paris and sought out leading Khmer emigres.
Soon he met Prince Sihamoni, King Sihanouk's son, who is a dancer and the Cambodian representative to UNESCO Paris, and Nouth Narang, the country's Culture Minister at the time. Within a year, he had been appointed a United Nations volunteer in production management for the performing arts, a post he created and hoped would let him participate in the repair of Cambodia's destroyed heritage.
Between the 9th and 14th centuries, the Khmer Empire dominated the entire region: an adamantine power, extending well into modern-day Burma and Laos, that spawned Southeast Asia's greatest concentration of temples and its most resplendent culture. Pol Pot, the leader of the Communist Khmer Rouge, succeeded in eradicating almost 800 years of artistic endeavor in just three and a half years in a purge of the intelligentsia far more brutal than anything contemplated by Stalin or Mao. Classical dancers were among the first to be eliminated, and between 1975 and 1979, 80 percent of them perished either by execution or starvation.
The 1980's offered some relief. The Khmer Rouge's expulsion from power in 1979 triggered a furtive growth in culture: Cambodia's traditional orchestras -- the Pinpeat and Mahori ensembles -- could once again be heard at weddings and funerals. A few classical ballets, preserved only in fragile memories, were haphazardly resurrected, while those who had dabbled in Yikai and Bassac -- Cambodia's popular and highly elaborate versions of Chinese opera -- came forward with the skills they had been at pains to hide.
But performances were rare. In 1982, the Ministry of Culture assembled a national theater company -- an amalgam of dance and theater to perform at political events or for the occasionally visiting dignitary. However, amateur groups had neither costumes nor resources. Any hope for a major arts revival was short-lived. Surviving artists were forced to work within minuscule budgets and continued to face an enervating daily struggle with corruption and Government indifference.
The situation reached a point of farce when Nouth Narang came close to selling the Culture Ministry building to a Taiwanese businessman. A further blow was dealt in 1994, when the Bassac Theater building, which had been constructed in the 1960's for the National Theater Company, burned down. The company of 248 members -- an amalgam of dance, theater and circus artists earning Government salaries equivalent to $15 a month -- was reduced to playing political events and tourist shows at the only other available space, the ill-equipped, French-built Chaktomuk Theater on the Mekong River.
Mr. Frumberg's priority, he said, was to "bring performance back into mainstream public life, so that the Khmer people could rediscover the glory and diversity of their heritage." But he soon realized that if that was to happen, he would have to raise the money himself. Government coffers were empty, and it rarely occurred to the wealthy foreign relief agencies in Phnom Penh, not to mention local businessmen, to plow even a fraction of their funds into the arts.
Mr. Frumberg had never had to raise a cent, but his concern for the plight of local artists proved persuasive. "I had to get potential donors to understand the crucial role the arts could play in reversing the trauma and tragedy of the last few decades," he said.
In his opinion, contemporary theater provided the best vehicle for tackling Cambodia's social ills head on. Within a month he secured $5,000 from a local beer company for "Destiny," a young Cambodian writer's play about poor Cambodian women who sell beer for a pittance and are forced into prostitution. The play caused a sensation.
Shortly after, he put on a musical entitled "Anyone Can Get AIDS," aimed at addressing the ignorance surrounding Cambodia's growing AIDS problem. Financed in part by UNESCO and by U.C.C. Kampot, a vocational training center for Khmer Rouge war victims set up by an American relief worker, Linda McKinney, the show played to more than 13,000 villagers in a neglected and impoverished southwestern province.
Mr. Frumberg evolved a two-pronged program addressing contemporary problems with contemporary arts, while making an effort to revive classical arts. He and Professor Hang Soth, the head of the National Theater, planned seasons at the Chaktomuk embracing most of the national company's classical disciplines. They included core ballets like the "Reamker," the Khmer version of the epic "Ramayana," and the "Apsara," the dance of the Celestial Nymphs depicted on the great 12th-century Angkor Wat temple, the cumulative symbol of the power the Khmer civilization once held. At the Chaktomuk, folk dance alternated with acrobatics (another product of the Angkor era, it is thought) and Yikai, the genre of music theater that comes closest to a Western musical, like "Tum Tiev," the story of a doomed love between a palace-educated monk and a villager, sometimes referred to as Cambodia's "Romeo and Juliet." Performances of Lakhaon Kaol, the male masked-dance version of the "Ramayana" story, began again in Phnom Penh after an absence of more than 30 years.
Many of these pieces have been painstakingly reconstructed by a handful of old masters who have devoted their lives to the task. One of them is Em Tiay, a dignified 67-year-old woman, who directs National Theater rehearsals every morning in the burned-out shell of the Bassac. There, to the accompaniment of the sweet-toned, rhythmically insistent Pinpeat orchestra, 40 or so female dancers surround her, resplendently swathed in silk sarongs.
Em Tiay gently places her hand on a dancer's shoulders, maneuvering the taut torso. Taking a left arm into her right hand, she holds out a finger to focus the dancer's gaze. In Khmer classical dance, the position of the eyes is crucial. Em Tiay then kneels in front of the dancer, slowly bending her knees to force the waist inward and the buttocks out.
As a palace dancer, specializing in the role of the giant Khong, a character in the "Ramayana," Em Tiay led a cosseted, disciplined life. She spent the Pol Pot years in a village near Battambang, in the northwest, where, remarkably, it was her skills that saved her. Her two sisters, who were also dancers, perished, along with 80 percent of the royal dancers, but Em Tiay's Khmer Rouge village chief insisted that she dance for him while others toiled.
Em Tiay is less than optimistic about the future of classical dance in a country still undermined by factional fighting, corruption and the relentless pursuit of self-interest essential to survival. "In Khmer classical dance, nothing is arbitrary; every movement expresses an inner feeling," she said with elegant resignation. "In these circumstances, it becomes very difficult to teach intangible expressions of joy or the feeling of loss."
Such goals are attainable, according to Proeung Chhien, the dean of choreographic arts at the Royal University in Phnom Penh, "provided we act now, before the older performers fall ill or pass away."
A number of grant-giving organizations have joined the effort. The Rockefeller Foundation donated a fresh set of leather shadow puppets (Sbeich Thom) for use by the last surviving master of the genre, the 82-year-old Ta Tien. The Asian Cultural Council in New York has established a three-year mentor program overseen by the ethnomusicologist Sam-Ang Sam, in which established teachers pass on their knowledge in a structured environment.
A$30,000 Notation Project from the Japan Foundation, which Mr. Frumberg inherited from Kiri Schultz, an American expert on Asia, takes the mentor idea one stage further. Over 18 months, a dozen dance professors and two foreign notation experts are recording as many as 4,000 gestures on paper and video, in the hope that at least 60 classic dances can be rescued from oblivion. The exercise is not simple: "It's often difficult to establish at what point gestures begin and end," Mr. Frumberg said.
By translating the results of such research into professional opportunities, Mr. Frumberg is significantly raising his performers' self-esteem.
When his second contract was drawing to a close earlier this year, students at the Royal University of Fine Arts organized a petition to persuade him to stay in Cambodia. "Mr. Fred is a model for us all to study, a loving man with a heart full of conscientiousness, responsibility and humanity," said Hang Soth, the National Theater head, with tears in his eyes.
Few foreigners in the arts have managed to engender this degree of affection and trust. Cambodia's Byzantine cultural politics and the intense rivalry between leading factions makes the distribution and appropriation of foreign money especially sensitive.
Not only is he an impresario, Mr. Frumberg is also involved in everything from marketing to rehearsal schedules to tearing tickets when no one else is available -- a rather wider brief than he could have predicted on graduating from Temple University in theater studies in 1979. One minute he will be coaxing the local Women's International Group into helping the fledgling Cambodian Symphony Orchestra, the next he will be explaining to employees of Shell Oil why they cannot use the theater foyer to promote a new line of lubricants.
As the pressure mounts, he becomes frantically busy. His office -- in the UNESCO colonial villa opposite the Royal Palace -- becomes a milling marketplace for wannabes of all persuasions bidding for different opportunities. A balding Tuscan wants to bring Luciano Pavarotti to Angkor Wat. "That'll be the day I leave Cambodia," Mr. Frumberg groans.
Is it worth the effort? Mr. Frumberg has his bad days, but nothing provides the answer with more certainty than the carnival-like atmosphere and sense of exhilarating fulfillment generated by the live performances. For years, Cambodian audiences were as out of practice at going to the theater as the artists were at performing in it, but the notion that young Khmers have sold their souls to Thai television and karaoke is an overstatement.
"What is needed now is education and investment," said Chhonn Chuon, a university graduate and recent convert to classical ballet. "The wars may be over, but the country's cultural identity will never recover from its near fatal blow until the Government understands the crucial role played by the arts and humanities."
Religion may also have a part to play. One of the leaders of the arts revival is Prof. Chheng Phon, a former culture minister in the 1980's during the Vietnamese occupation. A bespectacled, Buddha-like bundle in a tangle of off-white robes, he believes that cultural revival can be effective only as part of a national spiritual revival.
His shrine is the $300,000 Vipassana Center in Takhmau, a suburb of Phnom Penh. Here, in his ashram, he has built what he calls his Celestial Theater. With its enigmatically smiling faces, it is modeled on the 12th-century Bayon temple, a 15-minute stroll from Angkor Wat. Every Sunday, students come to spiritual workshops or to hear the master lecture on the four tenets of Buddhism and the true path to enlightenment. Mr. Frumberg is helping to raise money for Chheng Phon's most ambitious project yet, a series of performances depicting the 10 lives of the Buddha.
Cambodia's history is a national obsession -- even the country's flag bears the symbol of the Angkor Wat temple. But Chheng Phon's romantic vision of the Khmer legacy cannot obscure the gaping chasm between Cambodia's former power and its current economic depression. Angkor Wat brings a sense of pride in the Khmer heritage and much-needed tourist dollars, but it also serves to stifle enterprise: living culture is constantly having to play second fiddle to archeology.
"Isn't it time we began to invest in people rather than stones?" asks Hang Soth. "There are over 1,000 temples in this country, none of which are likely to disappear."
That, fortunately, is beginning to happen. UNESCO is poised to deliver $100,000 for performance-related work (a large sum, given the fact that an evening of ballet here costs a mere $2,000 to mount). The big news is the appointment of Princess Buppa Devi, 56, as Minister of Culture. The King's eldest daughter and the top dancer of her generation, she personally coaches students in the repertory, offering her charges welcome validation. A frail woman, ill at ease with her posse of genuflecting retainers, she allows Mr. Frumberg virtual carte blanche, depending on him for advice in areas in which royal protocol would appear to exclude her. Her first attempt at raising money -- for a cultural festival this year -- ended in embarrassment when the King was obliged to pay the dancers' salaries out of his own pocket.
In the end, of course, it will take more than money to guarantee the continued health of Khmer classical culture. In a generous moment, Mr. Frumberg claims the Khmers "won't need me, as soon as they have their confidence back." But he would be the first to admit there is still a long way to go.
If his work is to be sustained, Cambodia needs a revolution in infrastructure, with a new generation of arts managers able to handle all aspects of production logistics. Only comprehensive government-sponsored training programs can insure the longevity of Khmer arts.
In May, Mr. Frumberg began a five-month job in Los Angeles organizing the World Festival of Sacred Music. He returns to Cambodia in the fall. He has to return: hundreds of thousands of dollars have been pledged on condition that he will be around to administer the money.
Marc Rosasco, an American banker who helped sponsor a new set of shadow puppets for the Royal University of Fine Arts, among other projects, said: "Our decision had as much to do with the individual as the project. Frumberg was truly inspiring on how much could be done to revive Cambodian performing arts, both traditional and contemporary."
Mr. Frumberg is busy planning his return. One priority will be to end the National Theater's hand-to-mouth existence by turning the company into a self-generating concern, with enough money to tour. He hopes to set up theatrical workshops for the thousands of Cambodian orphans, as well as further sponsorship of contemporary plays in conjunction with the Asia Foundation. For such a comprehensive program, new performance spaces are needed, and it is not impossible that the Bassac Theater will be rebuilt.
Now that Cambodia is no longer a pariah state and has retaken its seat at the United Nations, foreign money is starting to trickle back. How much of it will go toward culture is anyone's guess. "The more shows we do," Mr. Frumberg said, "the more Cambodian arts organizations can begin to enjoy the luxury of self-sufficiency. Then, with luck, I'll be out of a job."

HEADLINE: Excursions Growing as a Leisure Outlet

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THIS year, the 165 guests at the Emelin Theater's annual fund-raising benefit were treated to a spectacular show, a brilliant sunset on Long Island Sound, produced by Mother Nature.
"We wanted something different this year," said John Raymond, managing director of the Emelin in Mamaroneck. "And when we found we were able to book a cruise ship for the event at the Playland pier in Rye, right in our own backyard, we went for it." 
 And, Mr. Raymond added, the cruise was a hit. "We usually hold the event at a club, so this was novel," he said. "It was a beautiful evening. We had an open bar, a silent auction, a very good buffet dinner and dancing. The feedback was good. Our guests had a wonderful time."
After decades of storm damage put the 192-foot pier out of commission, a major restoration, undertaken by the county, was completed in 1997. Angela Sculti, a veteran cruise operator and president of Custom Cruises, became the licensee. Ms. Sculti, whose office is in the Ice Casino at Playland, opened the inaugural season last year with two theme cruises aboard the Centauri, a 49-passenger, Navy-built Admiral's yacht. One cruise, Islands and Mansions, took sightseers on an hour-and-a-half voyage up the Connecticut shore, and the other cruise, Deck Barbecue, provided a three-hour, backyard-style barbecue at sea, capped with a display of fireworks at Playland.
"At $49 a person it was a sellout," Ms. Sculti said, adding that by the end of the season, revenue exceeded expectations. "We were solidly in the black, which indicates that we have a huge potential audience."
The county gets 10 percent of the income, and Joseph Montaldo, the director of Playland Park, said he expected the new source of revenue to increase year by year.
"We're excited about the cruise activity, which has increased this year," he said. "The pier has been beautifully restored, and it adds another dimension to Playland."
Another excursion line is the Klondike, based at Fort Slocum pier in New Rochelle, according to Madeline Pearson, the manager. The line's "Klondike Princess," a 110-foot boat, is enjoying a very good season, she said. "The business, which has been in operation for 14 years, not only runs excursions and cruises," she said, "but our corporate business increases from year to year.
"A normal cruising is down the Sound to the Statue of Liberty and return. We can pick up clients at points in Long Island and Connecticut. We do a lot of weddings and birthday parties on the weekend."
Ms. Pearson attributes the increase in business in part to the robust economy and to the fact that more people like "something different." The excursions are done on demand.
Another excursion line is New York Waterways, based in Manhattan, which runs a series of commuter ferries in the Manhattan and New Jersey areas. New York Waterways has also increased the number of its excursion all-day cruises up the Hudson River to the Hudson Valley and also to Kykuit.
According to Amy Vecchione, vice president of sales of New York Waterways: "The company has added more cruises this year. It's a low-margin business but customers enjoy it so much, it is a wonderful leisure outlet close to home."
A sampling of cruises added this year, from West 38th Street in Manhattan, includes one that goes up the Hudson to Lyndhurst, costing $49; one to Sleepy Hollow, and also new this year, starting in September, will be a cruise to West Point on Saturdays for $69, which includes admissions to the football games, and also a highlights-leaf-watching cruise, starting Sept. 26 through Nov. 7.
One, which is especially popular, she said, is a two-hour cruise that starts in Tarrytown and goes up to Bear Mountain and back and costs $15, $8 for children. Information on the New York Waterways excursions can be obtained by calling (800) 533-3779.
This year, Ms. Sculti has expanded the fleet, adding the Jubilee, a classic 149-passenger restaurant yacht.
Three cruises are offered aboard the Jubilee. One features the Trattoria Bella, an Italian restaurant serving traditional Italian specialties at sea, and ends with a display of fireworks at Playland. The cost is $69 a person. Another cruise on the Jubilee is called Sunday Brunch and is accompanied by a guitarist. Its price is $39 a person. The third cruise is the Weekend Moonlight Cruise, which includes dessert, dancing and other entertainment and ends at midnight. The fare is $25 a person.
Besides the regularly scheduled cruises departing from Playland Pier, a variety of yacht charter packages, aimed at the corporate market or as special events, are also available. Two yachts, the Excalibur and the Royal Princess, both with climate-controlled, fully enclosed decks, can accommodate 100 to 175 passengers.
"One of our staff coordinates the entire event," Ms. Sculti said. "We offer a full brunch or a dinner buffet with unlimited beverage service, starting at $99 a person."
Business meetings at sea are not only free from distractions but also have the advantage of a captive audience. "From a business standpoint, this is good," Ms. Sculti said. "And besides, everyone loves it. It's a little different."
Brides and grooms have been equally enthusiastic. Many have had wedding rehearsal dinners aboard, Ms. Sculti reported.
"Special events, fund-raisers, parties, conventions -- we handle the lot," she said. "And people say cruising is like a mini-micro vacation."
Future plans include tie-ins with area hotels. "We may possibly bring guests by boat, even from the New York airports and arrange for transportation from the pier to hotels," Ms. Sculti said. "We're also looking at the Sound as a highway that will bring people to Playland by ship from Manhattan and Connecticut during the season."
Salvatore A. DeSantis, the Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, said the cruises were a "wonderful attraction, and we're investigating additional new uses and recreational opportunities for our pier."
The number to call for information on cruises, group rates and charter packages is 925-1128.

HEADLINE: Restoring a Century-Old Glass Tower in Chicago

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
SIX decades ahead of its time, the crystalline Reliance Building soared skyward in 1895 as a scintillating rebuke to its somber masonry surroundings, like a diamond in the rough-hewn Loop.
Not until the late 1950's would Chicago again build an office tower with so much glass. 
 By then, the Reliance was a decrepit antique, worth more for its retail space on State and Washington Streets than for the 13 small floors of offices above. First stripped of its cornice, it was then stripped of dignity when its delicate terra-cotta facade was overwhelmed by a neon sign for a discount clothier.
Today, the cornice is back. The terra cotta is crisp and gleaming again. The clothier is gone, and the tea-leaf reader and prostitutes who worked upstairs have been replaced by construction crews.
The Reliance Building is to reopen in September as a 122-room boutique hotel, the Burnham, named for the architectural firm that designed it: D. H. Burnham & Company, best known in New York for the Flatiron Building.
It is an astonishing transformation. Five years ago, the Reliance Building "was on the brink of falling apart," Mayor Richard M. Daley said. The city acquired the landmark building by eminent domain for $1.2 million and undertook a $6.6 million exterior rehabilitation intended to jump-start redevelopment.
The process was not without critics in the City Council, who wondered why City Hall was pouring money into a building that private real estate interests had abandoned. One alderman suggested using the money to blow up the Reliance Building, allowing the city to sell the land clear and free.
In the end, the Daley administration prevailed. More important, it found a private development team -- the McCaffery Interests, Mansur & Company and the Granite Development Corporation -- willing to undertake the last $19 million leg of the journey, with $2.5 million more in city assistance.
Although city officials project a return on the investment in the form of tax revenues and spending, Commissioner Christopher R. Hill of the Planning and Development Department said the money was almost beside the point.
"All the economics in the world really don't matter," he said. "This building had to be saved to give people a better understanding of the history of high-rise architecture in Chicago."
The 5,500-square-foot floors did not make sense for modern offices. But Dan McCaffery, president of McCaffery Interests, said, "When we looked at it, we thought, 'My goodness, you could lay this out in pretty darn good hotel modules.' "
The result -- already apparent on floors where major reconstruction is nearing completion -- will be a remarkable interior, with public hallways looking much the way they did a century ago; not like a hotel at all but like a well-appointed hive of business.
THE original white Carrara marble wainscoting and ceilings are being kept, as are the mahogany trim, transoms and doors; the terrazzo floors; the glass partitions (though there are new fire-resistant walls behind them) and even the doorknobs, mail slots and ornamental hinges, made of a metal called magnetite with a coating that yields a blue-black finish.
Winding through the upper floors will be the original open cast-iron staircase, whose elegant balustrade carries the same decorative device -- a four-petal Gothic flower, or quatrefoil -- that is used in the undulating ribbons of white terra cotta on the exterior.
Rather than enclosing this staircase, as current building codes would require if it were the only means of exit in a fire, the developers are building two new enclosed stairways through the building. They also plan to recreate the ornate, two-story-high elevator lobby.
In addition, one of the original structural columns -- an open, diamond-shaped riser built up from riveted steel sections -- will be left exposed to show how the tower was constructed.
The architects are Antunovich Associates of Chicago, working with the McClier Corporation, an architectural and engineering concern based in Chicago that also prepared a historical structural report on the Reliance and oversaw the exterior restoration.
Given the deteriorating condition of the terra cotta facade, there was no time to lose. "It's amazing that it wasn't raining off the building," said T. Gunny Harboe, director of preservation at McClier.
About 2,000 of the 12,000 terra cotta pieces were replaced. The cornice was recreated in cast aluminum. And the single layer plate-glass windows were replaced with double-glazed insulated windows.
The operator will be the Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group of San Francisco. In Chicago, Kimpton already runs the 489-room Hotel Allegro (formerly the Bismarck) and the 193-room Hotel Monaco (formerly the Oxford House), both downtown.
Elements like the quatrefoil motif are being used in the new furnishings and textiles, said Susan M. Caruso, president of Intra-Spec of Marina del Rey, Calif., which is designing the lobby, guest rooms and public corridors.
Ranging from 350 to 450 square feet, the rooms are what a hotelier would call intimate and a guest might call small. Rates will begin at $145 a night for rooms, $195 for the larger suites.
The 21-foot-high ground floor, originally occupied by the Carson Pirie Scott & Company department store, will become the 65-seat Cafe Daniel. The tacky commercial accretions of recent decades have been stripped away. The plan is to recreate the appearance of the original uninterrupted window wall.
Y OU got the sense that the building was floating on this double-height story of all glass," said Brian Goeken, senior preservation planner in the landmarks division of the planning agency. "It's really going to glow. That's the intent, to play off this transparency."
The transparency of the Reliance Building was made possible by steel-frame construction, which allowed for vast expanses of glass because exterior walls no longer had to bear the structural load, as with traditional construction. The central panes in the second-story bays measure almost 8 by 11 feet.
Big windows were not merely an esthetic gesture. They helped capture every bit of available daylight. Artificial illumination at the time consisted of carbon filament bulbs, which gave off an anemic golden glow not much stronger than candlelight.
What glass-front buildings gained in illumination, however, they sacrificed in climate control. And so it was not until the development of modern heating, ventilating and air-conditioning systems in the 1950's that they proliferated.
The earliest designs for the Reliance Building were by John Wellborn Root. After his death in 1891, the project was carried to completion by Charles B. Atwood. The hotel will not carry their names, however, but that of their more famous partner, Daniel Hudson Burnham, author of the 1909 Chicago Plan, a sweeping attempt at taming the chaotic metropolis through the development of orderly transportation arteries and public amenities like a reclaimed lakefront.
Mr. Atwood does have his admirers. In "The Chicago School of Architecture" (University of Chicago Press, 1964), the architectural historian Carl W. Condit gave him credit for extraordinary prescience. "One short step further in the design of the Reliance Building and he would have produced the transparent tower that Mies van der Rohe imagined," Mr. Condit wrote. "If any work of structural art in the 19th centur
anticipated the future, it is this one."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes /Giorgio Cavaglieri;
Near 88, a Preservationist Is Still a Maverick

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
NEXT month New York's senior preservation architect, Giorgio Cavaglieri, whose background includes designing airfields for Mussolini's army and recycling German barracks for the United States Army, as well as work with Rosario Candela, the iconic designer of luxury Manhattan apartment buildings, will be 88.
He remains an important figure in the New York preservation movement, but his views of current preservation practice are anything but orthodox. 
 Mr. Cavaglieri was born in 1911 in Venice; his father was an insurance company executive who gave his family a comfortable life. In 1932, Mr. Cavaglieri graduated magna cum laude in 1932 from an engineering school in Milan, and worked in Italy for a few years before service in the Italian army during the war to conquer Ethiopia. At that time, he designed airfields in Tobruk, Libya, later destroyed in the World War II.
 On his return to Italy he worked for several architects, and on his own -- his office archives are full of photographs of alterations to older Classical buildings in Italy, replacing heavy, traditionally styled spaces with sumptuous marbles worked in streamlined Art Moderne style.
In 1938, Mussolini issued a decree stripping Italians who were Jewish of their citizenship, and Mr. Cavaglieri, seeing little future as a Jew in Italy, came to the United States.
"What happened was bad," he says "but others had it much worse." He got a referral to the Palermo-born Rosario Candela, the Manhattan-based designer of super-luxury apartment houses whose practice was only then rebuilding; at that time, Mr. Cavaglieri says, Candela was working on large-scale housing projects.
Later, notwithstanding his status as an enemy alien, Mr. Cavaglieri was drafted into the American military, and followed Allied troops from the Normandy invasion to Berlin; his task was to adapt captured German barracks for Allied use. He won the Bronze Star for meritorious achievement.
After World War II, he decided to avoid the typical large, corporate practice and form his own firm; in 1957, the Italian magazine L'Architettura described him as a "European-style architect . . . following projects directly in every stage, from the original drawing to the last detail."
In 1948, the managing agent of his 1921 Beaux-Arts style office building at 250 West 57th Street approached Mr. Cavaglieri to "brighten up" the entryway, then a typically elegant but old-fashioned bronze screen designed by Carrere & Hastings and R. H. Shreve.
Mr. Cavaglieri's elegantly economical solution was to replace the bronze with a new glass and stainless steel screen, leaving the elaborate lobby and the rest of the exterior intact. It was like using a modern type face for the title page of the Gutenberg Bible, but the client was satisfied and Lewis Mumford, The New Yorker's architectural critic, praised the work, saying it had "a simplicity, a freshness, and elegance altogether lacking" in the 1921 work.
In the 1950's two separate commissions for altering older midtown buildings into union halls were favorably reviewed, and contributed to Mr. Cavaglieri's growing reputation as an alteration specialist.
In 1963 Mr. Cavaglieri was elected president of the Municipal Art Society, and he became increasingly active on the emerging issue of historic preservation -- arguing against a proposed cafe in Central Park, against a demolition proposal for Grand Central and in favor of preserving the Morgan house at the southeast corner of 37th Street and Madison Avenue.
WHEN the old Jefferson Market Courthouse, on Avenue of the Americas and 10th Street, was up for conversion into a library in 1964, Mr. Cavaglieri was a logical choice for what became New York's most prominent preservation project of the 1960's. "He has clearly defined old and new," wrote Ada Louise Huxtable in a laudatory review in The New York Times in 1967. Mr. Cavaglieri inserted frankly modern elements into the Victorian interior -- counters, travertine flooring, fluorescent lights and a stark catwalk above the main reading room.
The commission to alter the old Astor Library at 425 Lafayette Street into the Public Theater came at the same time, and Mr. Cavaglieri again inserted modern functional elements into an older shell.
Other preservation projects have continued to follow and he has also a done series of contemporary building, like the concrete Kips Bay Branch of the New York Public Library, at Third Avenue and 31st Street.
But Mr. Cavaglieri's ideas of preservation are now at variance with those in day-to-day practice. Now a Jefferson Market Courthouse project would be undertaken in hushed tones, with replica counters, tables, chairs and light fixtures. But Mr. Cavaglieri is unapologetic about his own interventions. "What I did then would never have passed the preservation purists," he says in the rich melody of his Italian-accented English.
Likewise, his 1983 renovation of 801 Madison Avenue -- part of a row of brownstones built in 1881 between 67th and 68th Streets -- with a handsome, but super-high-style red-granite front would probably not be considered deferential enough to prevailing rules about restoration.
And Mr. Cavaglieri is not keen on other buildings which seem to pass contemporary preservationist muster, like the replica-Gothic addition to the Jewish Museum at 92d and Fifth, designed by the modernist Kevin Roche to mimic the original building, which was designed by C. P. H. Gilbert.
"I don't think it would be wise or right to interpret the opinion of a dead man" he says, noting that he admires Mr. Roche's other work. "He could have done something much better, but he knew that kind of solution would get the approval."
His most recent preservation commission was a couple of years ago -- the exterior restoration of the Veteran's Administration Headquarters in Newark, a 1920's building. He also is at work on a series of alterations to five branch libraries, redoing the auditoriums -- "very modest," he says -- and repairs to several day-care centers.
The sense that every building should evoke its own time is still very strong with him, but has probably cost him major preservation commissions in the last decade or so. Speaking of St. Peter's in the Vatican, he says that the overlapping changes make the building richer, not poorer, "because each one is what the politics of the time indicated."
"Michelangelo didn't repeat Bramante's drawings, and Bernini left his own imprint, too," Mr. Cavaglieri says.
