HEADLINE: Q & A/Kenneth M. Reels;
Chairman's Mission: Strengthen Control Of Tribal Business

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY

 BODY:
PROMISING to lead the Mashantucket Pequot Tribe in a new direction, Kenneth M. Reels was elected Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Council Chairman by tribal members on Nov. 1, 1998, and began serving his term on Jan. 1.
Mr. Reels has served on the Tribal Council since January 1991, including three terms as vice chairman. 
 In 1995, the Tribal Council assigned the leadership of its Centralization Project to Mr. Reels, the vice chairman then. The intent of the project is to strengthen tribal controls over tribal business, to address the approximately $1 billion debt that has resulted from the tribe's casino and resort development and to plan for the orderly growth of the tribe and tribal businesses.
Mr. Reels has taken a strong personal interest in the tribe's welfare-to-work program, called Work Etc. In conjunction with the state Department of Social Services, the program recruits and trains welfare recipients for jobs at Foxwoods Resort Casino.
He began his employment with the Tribe in 1987 as a property purchasing and contracting officer, and was also a manager in the Tribe's sand and gravel business.
Mr. Reels, 39, and his family live on the Mashantucket Pequot Reservation and also in the family home in New London. The following are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Reels at the tribe's community center.
Q. What were the main points you were trying to make during the recent public forums on Indian sovereignty at New London's Garde Theatre?
A. The forums were an attempt to reach out to the community, to try to inform them about Indian tribes' inherent sovereign rights, about how these laws must be respected, and if people disagree with the laws how they must go through due process to change the law.
It's also to show that the tribe is going in a new direction, that we're not going to tolerate the double standard: the way we're treated and the way others in comparable situations are treated.
The tribe gives a lot. But we're not treated the same as a millionaire from Massachusetts. The state was ready to give Robert Kraft a $400 million stadium, but (State Attorney General Richard) Blumenthal wants to bicker with us about $4 million for state police and other services.
The compact (the Mashantucket Pequot gaming compact agreed to by the tribe and state which allows for Foxwoods Casino) says one state trooper, the same as it is in a town like Preston. The state can't just change the guidelines and make a double standard for the tribe.
Go see how many state troopers are in the casino. There's a lot. We don't necessarily have a problem with them being there. But we have a problem paying for it because its not what we agreed on. It says we have to be audited in the compact. It doesn't say we have to pay for this. The state can put a thousand people (auditors and police) in there. Doesn't mean we have to pay for it.
Q. How to you respond to the tribe's critics who say the laws that allow the tribe to have an Indian casino are based on race?
A. Our goal is to inform people what the law is. The law is based on the Federal Government's recognition that Indian tribal nations are sovereign nations whose sovereignty precedes that of the federal government. The Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988 recognizes this. The law is based on the government to government relationship between the tribal nation and the Federal Government. It just happens that these sovereign governments are Indian sovereign governments. But the law cannot be based on race and it's not based on race.
Q. Are relations between the tribe and the three towns that surround the reservation, Ledyard, North Stonington and Preston, at a low point?
A. We understand we're next door to people and they have concerns about development. But they have to understand, the Federal Government has jurisdiction over the issues that could arise from development. The people in the towns have a right to comment and we will try to respect peoples feeling.
During the third forum the selectmen from the towns around the reservation could have asked Kevin Gover, (assistant Secretary of the Department of Interior, head of the Bureau of Indian Affairs) and other officials from Washington about the Federal law. But they didn't come to the meeting, and they didn't ask.
Everything we're trying to say is based on law. When they (the anti-annexation people) speak at their meetings they talk with feeling, but what they are saying is not consistent with the law.
Leadership to me is not just responding to the squeaky wheel that's making the most noise, its not about listening to these 12 people who always end up going to the meetings in the three towns and end up yelling at me. That's why we're reaching out to the region. That's why we had the forums in New London. We're reaching out to the majority, to the people in Norwich, New London, Groton, and Westerly. But I still say to the people of the three towns, come talk to us. Come to the forums. Tell us what kind of development you want.
The people in the towns have to understand that we're not the reason they're paying high taxes. We're all about lowering taxes. The focus is who can create opportunity. Who can create jobs. The more people with jobs that offer the benefits that our jobs offer the less money government has to pay. The more businesses paying taxes the less taxes residents have to pay.
This is a stolen land. Ledyard, Preston, and North Stonington have land that we need to get back under our jurisdiction so we can finish our resort, so tribal members can live in our community. It's being selfish when people are keeping their land open land, just so no one else can live on it.
Q. A point you have raised is that the Federal law is a two-edge sword that could work against Indian tribal nations. Are you concerned that opposition to Indian casinos across the United States could lead to new Federal laws that could change the rules regarding the taxation of Indian gaming or the annexation of lands into Federal Indian reservations?
A. We worry about that all the time and that's why we work with national Indian organizations, and make donations to these organizations and hire lobbyists and do whatever we legally can to protect our interests and our rights. This is nothing more, but nothing less than what all groups do in the United States.
Q. Are you concerned about other Connecticut Indian Tribes becoming Federally recognized and establishing competing Indian casinos?
A. In the 1970's all the Connecticut tribes promised to stick together to support one another. That's why I reach out to all tribes. I haven't forgotten where we came from, and what the struggle is. I wish the Paugussett War Chief MoonFace Bear was still here today, because all the struggles he fought are still being fought today.
I know the state-recognized tribes petitioning for Federal recognition are Indians tribes. The state knows this. That's why they're state-recognized tribes.
Our goal is to see Indian country motivated again. We want to bring back the movement that existed in the 1960's for equality, for human rights. We want to have a march from here to Hartford in honor of our ancestors and the battles they fought to maintain their rights, their tradition, which we continue.
Q. During the second forum it was asked whether there's a limit to the amount of land the tribe wants to annex to the reservation. Is there?
A. There are tribes that have sued for a whole lot of land and they have a right to. We're still trying to reach out, instead of just going to court.
Still offering to meet with people from North Stonington, Preston, and Ledyard and maybe we can come to agreement about how much land over so many years can be annexed, and leaving an option for future generations to continue the negotiations. Letting the courts decide doesn't create the long-term working relationship we need. Q. You have acknowledged that the Simond family has traced its ancestry to the Mashantucket Pequot's 1857 tribal list, but you have also said the tribe's constitution legally excludes the family's membership. The constitution allows only people whose ancestors were on the 1900 and 1910 censuses to be members. Are you planning to amend the tribal constitution to let other families, such as the Simond family, into the tribe?
A. Yes, I'm doing that. I know the Simond family and I know their ancestors are Mashantucket Pequot. I also know the Apes family, they're the descendants of William Apes, the first Indian writer in the United States, (who lived during the 19th Century), and some of them work at the museum and its impossible to justify why they can't be tribal members. So I want to amend the constitution so that membership will be based on descent from anyone on any tribal list since the 1637 Mystic Massacre. If you can establish your descent from anyone on these lists you should be able to become a member of the tribe.
This is not about who likes who and who dislikes who, this is about being a tribe and if you're part of the tribe you're part of the tribe and you have a right to live in the tribal jurisdiction.
In the end this is what putting land in trust means. Its about providing for the needs of the tribe for generations to come. Its about providing economic opportunities for everyone.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1483 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Pelham Parkway;
A Polyglot Enclave In Central Bronx

BYLINE: By MAGGIE GARB

 BODY:
ON a scorching Sunday earlier this month, the vast lawns at the center of Pelham Parkway were dotted with sunbathers and dog-walkers. Joggers rounded the dirt paths edging the greenspace and young parents pushing strollers meandered along shade-speckled walkways. It was a slice of Paris in the Bronx, a tree-lined boulevard linking Bronx Park to Pelham Bay Park.
"On a summer day, people hang out on the parkway like they're at the beach or at Central Park," said Oscar Cabrera, a broker with the Coldwell Banker Beautiful Homes real estate brokerage. "It's the heart of the neighborhood." 
 The parkway's official name is the Bronx and Pelham Parkway. It slices through the Pelham Parkway neighborhood, a narrow band of apartment buildings and houses that cuts across the central Bronx. To the west lies the 661-acre Bronx Park, which includes the New York Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo.
Residential streets are lined with a vibrant blend of housing types, from the Pelham Parkway Houses, a 1,200-unit public-housing development, to half-million-dollar detached houses to the north of the parkway and east of Williamsbridge Road. Eight- and 10-story Art Deco and Tudor-style buildings line the parkway while one-, two- and three-family houses set behind postage-stamp sized yards flank the side streets south of the parkway.
In the summer months, the neighborhood's many gardeners turn their tiny plots into elegant gardens. Grapevines wind across fences and day lilies, gladiolas and impatiens add bursts of color.
While most residents define the neighborhood as any place within walking distance of the parkway, its boundaries are murky. Some say the neighborhood extends just a block or two either side of the parkway, but City Councilwoman Madeline Provenzano, whose district covers Pelham Parkway, says the neighborhood runs as far south as Neill Avenue and north to Waring Avenue.
"The city maps are not clear on the boundaries," she said. "But whatever the boundaries, it's the access to the parkway and the beauty of the parkway itself that defines the community."
The parkway has caused some controversy in recent years as aging trees along the roadway have caused several serious car accidents. Members of Community Board 11 have been pushing city officials to reconfigure the parkway to move traffic away from the trees.
"Right now the biggest issue in this neighborhood is the parkway," said John Fratta, the board's district manager. "The trees have gotten so large that they're right along the street and the slightest mistake when you're driving and you're up against a tree."
Although the Department of Transportation has not yet released its plans, Councilwoman Provenzano said plans to reconfigure the parkway were "in the works" and that $16 million had been allocated in next year's city budget for reconstruction of the roadbed. The work is expected to begin next spring and will last for a couple of years, she said.
If the parkway is the neighborhood's jewel, Bronx House, a settlement house that opened in the South Bronx in 1911 and moved to Pelham Parkway in the mid-1950s, is its heart. Run by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, Bronx House is a community center, providing social services and entertainment programs for all neighborhood residents of all ages including preschool and after-school programs, a summer camp, a single-parents' support network, English-language classes for recent immigrants, free kosher lunches for the elderly and a mutligenerational chorus. The building, which is on the Parkway at Bogart Avenue, has a gym, indoor pool and meeting rooms. Yearly membership fees are $65 for seniors and $425 for families.
I CAN'T picture Pelham Parkway without Bronx House," said Blanche Comras Roskin, chairwoman of the settlement-house board. "It's the place that brings everyone together."
Ms. Roskin moved to Pelham Parkway in 1940 when the neighborhood was more like a suburb than an urban neighborhood. "We've gone through so many changes," she said. "It's become more congested, more like a city. Lots of new people have moved in, but it still feels a little like a suburban town."
The neighborhood's earliest settlers were German farmers in the late 19th century. By the 1920's, Italian and Eastern European Jewish immigrants were fleeing the tenements of the Lower East Side and migrating to the frame and brick cottages of the central Bronx. In the 1930's, the parkway was closed on Sunday mornings for professional bicycle races.
After World War II, developers blanketed the neighborhood's side streets with one-, two- and three-family brick houses, selling them to Italian and Jewish families.
In the 70's, newer immigrants -- some from the Caribbean and others from Asia -- moved to Pelham Parkway. In the last five years, ethnic Albanians, many from Kosovo, have flocked to the community.
An ethnically and economically diverse neighborhood, Pelham Parkway's commercial streets, White Plains Road and Lydig Avenue, reflect its polyglot lineage. Jamaican and Italian restaurants, Chinese fast-food outlets and kosher butchers pack the storefronts.
Housing prices were relatively stable until about two years ago. As prices in Manhattan soared, prices in Pelham Parkway increased substantially, brokers said. One-family houses, which sold for about $190,000 a year ago, are going for about $225,000 this summer, said Sam Brown, an associate with ReMax Deal-Finders. Two- and three-family houses are selling for as much as $300,000 and $400,000, respectively, said George Bookis, a broker at Aztec Realty.
"If you can't afford Riverdale, then you buy here," Mr. Bookis said. "We're seeing houses sell for the asking price and in certain instances people are willing to pay several thousand dollars over the asking prices. It's been a wild market."
Rentals, too, have gone up, with three-bedroom apartments renting for as much as $1,500 a month and one- and two-bedroom apartments going for $600 to $900, Mr. Bookis said. Residents and interns at the nearby Bronx Municipal Hospital Center often rent apartments in the neighborhood, he added.
Young couples and recent immigrants are drawn to Pelham Parkway by its low crime rates and public elementary schools. The community, which is within the 49th Police Precinct, has the second lowest crime rate in the Bronx, following Riverdale, said Mr. Fratta of the community board.
"It's a very safe neighborhood," said Carol Rawlinson, a social worker who has lived in Pelham Parkway for 10 years. "You don't find the drug element here. Everybody knows everybody, everybody looks out for their neighbors' kids. It's a real close-knit neighborhood."
Ms. Rawlinson's two daughters attended the neighborhood's elementary schools, which she said were excellent. Pupils at the four schools -- P.S. 83, 89, 105 and 96, all within District 11 -- attained some of the highest reading scores for public grade schools in the Bronx last school year.
The children go on to two intermediate schools, I.S. 144 and I.S. 135.
Some parents choose to send their children to one of three Roman Catholic, k-8 grade schools in the neighborhood -- St. Lucy's, St. Clare's and St. Francis Xavier. Annual tuitions for parishioners range from $1,620 to $2,450 and for nonparishioners, $2,160 to $2,750. Tuition at St. Catherine's, a girls' high school, is $3,900 per year.
Mr. Fratta of the community board said the troubled reputation of the neighborhood's Christopher Columbus High School "unfortunately lasts." But, he added, "they have really gotten their act together."
IN the four years since Gerald Garfin took over as principal, Mr. Fratta said, Columbus has shown improvement. Although the school remains overcrowded, with 3,400 students packed into a building with a capacity of 2,400, attendance rates and standardized test scores have improved, Mr. Garfin said. The school's dropout rate has fallen from 7.2 percent in the 1994-95 school year to 3.8 percent last year. Last year 48 percent of the seniors graduated after four years, and an additional 38 percent graduated in no more than five years, he said.
Mr. Garfin, who graduated from Columbia High School in 1960, said that in his tenure as principal he has secured more than $1 million in grants, including $500,000 from the Comprehensive School Reform Demonstration. The three-year Federal-state program finances new courses and curriculums in schools considered "at risk."
Mr. Garfin also said the school had 13 advanced placement courses and a summer program to prepare students for S.A.T. tests in their senior year.
"When kids leave this building, I want them to have the same feeling I had when I left 39 years ago," he said. "And I loved this place. We need to get rid of that negative image. The school is a part of a great neighborhood and they should be working together."

PONIES AND PILOTS: In the late 19th century, a thoroughbred race track stood in the northeast corner of the neighborhood. The Morris Park Race Track, south of Pelham Parkway along Williamsbridge Road, was owned by John A. Morris, who made his fortune running the Louisiana State Lottery. The track shut down when Belmont Park opened in 1903, and a few years later the site was used for early public trials of powered aircraft. In August 1908 the American Aeronautics Society held an airplane design contest there. The winner, a triplane, "was beautifully designed, but it couldn't fly," said Lloyd Ultan, the Bronx Borough Historian.

HEADLINE: Medical Center Begins to Thrive on Its Own

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
UNTETHERED from county life support less than two years ago, the Westchester Medical Center, once a department of the county government, has been breathing well on its own on most days, hospital officials report.
"Our problems now are the problems of most hospitals," said Alfred B. DelBello, chairman of the Westchester County Health Care Corporation, which now runs the Medical Center. 
 Without interference from the County Executive's office, the input of 17 sometimes balky members of the Board of Legislators and the tortuous ways of government, the hospital, now officially a public benefit corporation, must survive or fail on its own, Mr. DelBello said.
Edward A. Stolzenberg, president of the Medical Center, described the center's current association with the county as "a very arms-distance relationship" and said that although the Medical Center now pays its own way, he prefers it that way.
It was a little like getting a gift but having to take the giver with the gift, he said.
It has been what both sides are calling a winning deal. From the county's point of view, the release seven years hence from its annual stipend to the public hospital is similarly welcome. Westchester's move to divest itself of the hospital, with its policy of never turning away patients, is expected to save taxpayers $185 million.
For the hospital as well, the economics seem to make sense, and already, the first full year of independent operation has been a success, Mr. Stolzenberg reported.
In addition to operating at 100 percent bed capacity, the the institution, which has a $400 million annual budget, finished last year with a $5 million surplus, compared with 1997, when it was still under the control of the county and finished with a $7 million deficit. The largest source of income for the hospital comes from insurance payments for in-patient services, said Carin Grossman, a spokeswoman for the hospital. Mr. Stolzenberg attributed the gains to the former county hospital's learning to perform like a sleek private business rather than a government bureau.
Part of the Pinnacle Healthcare, a network that includes Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle, Yonkers General Hospital and the Hudson Valley Hospital in Peekskill, the Medical Center is now able to respond quickly in the highly competitive managed-care industry, he said.
In another sign of growth, the Medical Center -- which serves seven counties in the Hudson Valley, northern New Jersey and parts of nearby Connecticut, including Fairfield County -- ended last year with the highest number of organ donations in the state. Besides performing bone marrow and cornea transplants, it is one of only four hospitals in the state offering full abdominal transplants (liver, kidney and pancreas).
Aside from the country's busiest transplant hub in Pittsburgh, Westchester Medical Center has the largest kidney transplant program in the Northeast and the fifth-largest pediatric cornea transplant program in the United States. It also performs the second-highest number of bone marrow transplants in the state.
Continuing its drive toward economic independence, the hospital has obtained a $150 million loan from the Federal Housing Authority to build a 120-bed children's hospital and trauma center. Construction is to begin next month.
Bruce K. Komisae, executive director of the Children's Hospital Foundation, said all rooms in the 250,000-square-foot Children's Hospital would be designed so that parents can stay with their children.
In 1997, the most recent year for which figures are available, there were 743 newborns treated at the hospital, 2,610 pediatric surgeries, 2,100 pediatric emergency room admissions, 54 pediatric burn cases and 26 multiple births (including one set of quadruplets).
Another sign that the institution is taking a new direction is Mr. Stolzenberg's announcement that he is adding programs that will make the Medical Center what hospitals refer to as a quartenary care institution, one that offers more advanced medical procedures.
Tertiary care centers perform open-heart surgery, for example, but not heart transplants, which quartenary care centers do perform. As another example, tertiary care centers perform bone marrow transplants but do not offer gene therapy.
The goal in upgrading, Mr. Stolzenberg explained, is to make the hospital more specialized and less competitive with community hospitals.
Dr. Tauseef Ahmed, director of the Medical Center's Zalmen A. Arlin Cancer Institute, said that the hospital is already taking research it has completed in the laboratory to the patient's bedside -- for example in the area of blood technology. The cancer institute also hopes to establish an umbilical cord blood center by harvesting what Dr. Ahmed said was "now a wasted resource." The idea would be to use the umbilical cord blood, which is rich in basic cells, to treat leukemia patients.
Neither tertiary nor quartenary designations are given by the state, the State Health Department must approve all programs offered by a hospital.
One of the major disappointments for the Medical Center since its spin-off from the county was the Health Department's initial refusal this winter to approve the hospital's application to perform heart transplants. The Medical Center transfers about 10 pediatric heart cases a year to Boston Children's Hospital.
"In the long run, if we do not have heart transplants, we could be adversely affected," Mr. Stolzenberg said, explaining that the hospital would resubmit its application to the State Health Department. "In order to avoid competing with community hospitals, we have to move to the next level."
The Medical Center has state certification to perform cardiac catheterization and open heart surgery, Kristine Smith, a spokeswoman for the Health Department, said.
The Health Department indicated that one reason the Medical Center was refused certification for heart transplants was because it is geographically too close to New York City, where two hospitals already provide those services.
The other approved heart transplant programs in the state are at New York Presbyterian and Mount Sinai Medical Centers in Manhattan, at Buffalo General Hospital and Buffalo Children's Hospital, at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester and at Albany Medical Center.
But Mr. Stolzenberg observed that because the Hudson Valley population served by the Medical Center was separate from the population served by metropolitan hospitals, a regional hospital should be certified for heart transplants.
That was not the only disappointment for the Westchester Medical Center. Early in the spring, a kidney was misplaced in what Mr. Stolzenberg described as a mistake.
"It's not the first time there has been a mistake, although I hope it's the last, but mistakes get made," he said.
As a transplant patient waited for surgery on April 20, his new kidney was mistakenly tossed into the garbage by a worker cleaning up between surgeries, the hospital said. The worker apparently thought a corrugated box in the operating room was empty, and more than an hour later, the missing organ was found in a recycling bin.
The Medical Center said it did not believe the delay affected the viability of the organ.
Looking ahead, Mr. Stolzenberg said that much of the hospital's energy in the months to come would be spent on burnishing its image. He said the purpose would not necessarily be to draw more patients, because beds in the Medical Center are already well used. His concern was that the public not perceive of the Medical Center as "the prototypical county hospital offering substandard care."
Mr. Stolzenberg said: "People think that if they get sick, they'll go to New York City, but if your car slams into a bridge on the Sprain Parkway, it's my helicopter that's going to be there and my trauma center that will take care of you. And it better be good."
Also, hospital administrators will soon focus on solving continuing financial problems. Mr. DelBello said that like all hospitals, Medicare and Medicaid cutbacks continue to undermine the Medical Center's efforts to thrive. Mr. DelBello, a lawyer and former Lieutenant Governor, Westchester County Executive and Mayor of Yonkers, said that managed care companies were "in essence, financing themselves on hospitals' backs" by delaying payment.
Before the county spun off the hospital, the 650-bed medical and surgical institution was fully subsidized and had been since the 1920's. County Executive Andrew J. Spano, Mr. Stolzenberg and the governing board in January signed off on the contract that progressively reduces the county's subsidy, from $31 million in 1998 to $26 million this year and to $20 million in 2000. By 2006, the hospital will receive no money from the county.
Because the Medical Center will need new sources of revenue as its subsidy diminishes, the county is allowing it to build on 33 acres of nearby county-owned land. Mr. Stolzenberg said the governing board was considering building a hotel for people visiting patients and possibly an assisted living residence and even a health club.
The first step toward independence were taken under former County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. But when Mr. Spano took over, he reworked the initial separation agreement. At the time, Legislator Thomas J. Abinanti, who heads the Health Committee of the Board of Legislators, said the previous administration "had failed to cross its t's and dot its i's" with the hospital. He explained that too many issues had been unresolved, for example, how much the county would pay for services it received from the Medical Center like the treatment of sick and injured prisoners from the County Jail in Valhalla.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In a Strong Market, Shortages Bedevil Developers

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THESE are good times and bad times for home builders in New Jersey.
A strong state economy, low mortgage interest rates and recent stock market gains all continue to feed the demand for new houses. Construction financing is also available, increasing production. Last year the number of housing permits issued rose by 3,327 to 31,345, nudging New Jersey past the 30,000 mark for the first time since 1989, according to state figures. 
 But at the same time, with the state's unemployment rate at 4.9 percent, skilled construction workers are in short supply. So are certain building materials -- particularly drywall, the paper-covered plasterboard used in nearly all interior construction -- and to a lesser degree, insulation and lumber. In turn prices are inching up.
Add to that what industry professionals say is the scarcity and rising cost of properly zoned and approved land and the result, they say, is a tremendous squeeze on the time and the cost of producing new homes. In response, developers say they are changing the way they do business to meet the realities of today's market.
Andrew C. Cattano, director of codes and technical services at the New Jersey Builders Association in Robbinsville, called the material and labor shortage "an increasingly frustrating issue," which is causing some delays in construction projects. Though no one has reported lost sales the shortages "add to the cost of building a home," he said, noting that some builders because of the strong market "try to absorb it in their sale prices, but others cannot because their prices are already at the top."
To counter the situation some builders are working their crews longer hours or hiring temporary laborers.
"There's no slack in the process," said Nicholas Minoia, president of Westminister Communities, a division of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park. "Buyers are selling their current homes quickly and want to move into their new homes. We're bringing in an army of temporary workers to help us get caught up with our delivery schedule."
Mr. Cattano said that he also noted "more use of alternative lumber products like engineered wood, plastic wood and facia board" -- the last two used, respectively, to construct decks, or exterior trim on windows or eaves. The shortage of drywall is more pronounced, he added, and "there really is no substitute for it."
But according to the National Association of Homebuilders in Washington, new drywall factories are scheduled to open later this year or next year, which will increase the supply.
The land issue, however, is the most vexing. In turn, some builders are turning to small, previously ignored sites or to larger tracts that were not developed because the builder did not or could not proceed or were passed over because they were too difficult to build on.
Others are pursuing industrial and commerical sites that could be rezoned for housing. And still others are expanding into the southern or western portions of New Jersey where land is more available.
John G. Udell, president of Weichert New Homes and Land, a land broker and marketer in Morris Plains, said those efforts had kept new home production moving. But, he added, given the housing demand the number of permits issued in 1998 could have matched the 57,000 issued at the peak of the last building boom in 1987 "if land was available."
Other challenges, he said, are the lengthy approval process and land prices, which continue to rise as competition among developers and conservationists increases. Today, land constitutes 35 to 40 percent of the cost of a house, compared with 30 percent several years ago, Mr. Udell said.
A further challenge, added Joanne Harkins, director of land use and planning at the Builders Association, is that "most of what is being built is expensive housing, which is pricing many people out of the new home market." In the first quarter, state figures show, the average price of a new house in New Jersey was $251,000, up from $227,500 from the same time last year.
The Builders Association predicts that construction will slow later this year and into 2000 as the inventory of land for which construction approvals have been received dwindles.
Still, builders are scrambling to bring new homes to the market.
Mr. Minoia of Westminster Communities said his company had extended its focus beyond central and northern New Jersey into both the southern and western parts of the state. An example is Westgate at Beaver Brook -- 107 town houses, ranging in size from 1,700 to 2,200 square feet and in price from $196,000 to $265,000 -- that the company is building on 24 acres not far from the intersection of Interstate 78 and Route 31 in Clinton in Hunterdon County.
GIVEN the "shortage of large land deals in New Jersey," Mr. Minoia said, the company is also looking at sites that are small or outside the state.
Wayne Patterson, a senior vice president at Toll Brothers, of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., a national builder active in the state, said his company was "working a lot harder to find sites" and is searching in areas of the state "that are a little more remote," including Hunterdon and Sussex Counties.
He said that this year Toll had secured 14 sites, some with approvals in place and others that must be taken through the approval process. Among them is a 43-home subdivision just north of Route 181 in Sparta in Sussex County.
"Yes, there is a lot of competition, and land prices are rising, but so are sale prices," Mr. Patterson said. As a result, the market for the higher-priced homes Toll builds has reached some areas where they previously would not sell, including Sussex County, he said. The homes it will construct in Sparta will have 3,500 to 4,500 square feet and sell in the mid-$400,000 range.
Yet even in areas like Sussex County the competition is rising. The Kalian Companies of Red Bank, for instant, sold 38 of 41 homes in a project called Pheasant Run on Route 611 in Green Township and wanted to repeat its success, "but large developable parcels are becoming extinct," said Anthony F. DiLorenzo, Kalian's vice president of sales and marketing.
The company wound up piecing together two parcels totaling 100 acres about a half mile from Pheasant Run. Together they will yield 19 lots and, if further subdivided, perhaps as many as 33, Mr. DiLorenzo said. Half of the site, he added, will not be developed because of environmental and open-space zoning restrictions.
The homes, with 2,100 to 3,000 square feet, will be similar in size to those at Pheasant Run. But given increasing construction costs they will sell for $5,000 to $10,000 more than the earlier ones, which sold for $225,000 to $290,000, he said.
The company was luckier in Raritan Township in Hunterdon County, where it took over an approved 239-unit project from a previous developer who did not move forward. It will have 58 town houses and 181 single-family homes on 95 acres on Dayton Road.
"This is one of the last large parcels with that many lots that we're working on," he added, noting that "we see the future limited to sites for 10 to 25 houses, that's it."
PINNACLE COMMUNITIES of Millburn, which builds high-end single-family homes, is also looking for small parcels, like the six-lot subdivision it recently purchased on McCain Court in Closter. Brian Stolar, Pinnacle's president, said his company was willing to go after the site and pay $2 million "because it allowed us to get into a town in Bergen County" where land is scarce and it had been approved, removing the risk. The houses, averaging 4,000 square feet, will sit on half-acre lots and sell for $900,000 to just over $1 million.
Mr. Stolar said his company also was pursuing previously approved projects that never moved forward because they are on difficult development sites. An example is the 35-acre hilltop site at Ratzer and Alps Roads in Wayne the company has contracted to buy and will close on in three months.
Instead of constructing the 35 town houses in several buildings that had been approved and would have required substantial blasting, Pinnacle will build 35 single-family homes on small lots. By clustering the homes, Mr. Stolar said, his company will reduce the amount of blasting by nearly 50 percent and meet the town's requirement to leave half the site undisturbed. The homes will range in size from 2,500 to 3,500 square feet and in price from the high $400,000's to mid-$500,000 range.
Today's developer, he said, must come up with creative solutions.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2999 words

HEADLINE: Appraisers: Getting to the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
IT is an innocuous-looking packet of papers, or, these days, an E-mail -- several pages evaluating the "subject residence," floor plans, photos of "comparables" and a dollar figure -- that can make or break a deal: the appraisal.
Clark Halstead, founder of the Manhattan brokerage that bears his name and himself a former appraiser, likens the appraisal to the Oracle at Delphi, "where kings and commoners sat around a hole in the stone until black or white smoke came out -- black smoke means the deal's in trouble, white smoke means clean and green straight ahead." 
 For the appraisal industry itself, however, the road has been rough in recent years -- buffeted as it was by regulatory reform following the savings-and-loan crisis of the late 80's and then radically reshaped by computer technology.
The residential transaction can be stressful for all the parties: buyers, sellers, brokers, even the lenders. "And the appraiser only adds to the stress," Mr. Halstead said. "Unfortunately, the Oracle doesn't speak in this case until late in the deal," often not much before the closing.
The buyer always worries whether the price is too high. "And if the appraisal is below the contract price," Mr. Halstead said, "he is consumed by buyer's remorse and tries to renegotiate, or walks away."
The seller thinks the deal is done, and envisions closing on that next dream house. "So when the appraisal comes in low, he is traumatized, not prepared to renegotiate," Mr. Halstead said, "and feels badly served by that fickle buyer."
The broker, having already mentally deposited the commission, has to scramble. "The broker has two courses," Mr. Halstead said, "get the old appraiser to consider new comparables or convince the parties to use another appraiser."
And another player in the drama, the mortgage broker, under pressure to meet quarterly lending goals, has visions of bonuses dancing out of his head. "Lenders actually refer to mortgage loans as sales: 'How are your sales going?' the boss wants to know," Mr. Halstead said. "Everybody's hanging on this. That's why it's like the Oracle. If you get white smoke, it's party time."
A white puff rose over 18 Bertha Lane in Massapequa Park on Long Island in April when Richard Meyer, president of Meyer Associates, an appraisal company in nearby Bellmore, submitted his valuation for the four-bedroom expanded Cape.
The agreed-upon price for the house, with its new kitchen, finished basement and a rear deck, was $238,000. The appraisal price: a nearly on-the-money $242,500.
And then there was the 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom in downtown Manhattan that, because of an architectural quirk, opened onto a 2,000-square-foot terrace. "People get emotional about outdoor space," said Jeffrey Jackson Satkiewicz, chairman of the appraisal firm Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson. "And when a property is unique, like that, there's nothing to compare it to."
Black smoke rising.
"The contract price was $1 million," Mr. Satkiewicz said. "We appraised it at $750,000. The buyer tried to renegotiate. The seller wouldn't budge. So the buyer walked away. This was six weeks ago."
"Two weeks ago," Mr. Satkiewicz said, "the same buyer came through purchasing another property; about the same size inside, but the terrace was 1,000 feet rather than 2,000, and they were paying $600,000. They were happy to have $400,000 more in their pocket than to have the extra space."
The process is sometimes no picnic for the appraiser: tramping through and nosing into other people's property, clipboard and tape measure in hand; toting up square footage, noting the gas station behind the back fence, the ancient oil heater; deducting for defects and factoring in upgrades and amenities, like the finished basement, the new kitchen, the fireplace, and, in more rarefied environs, the racquetball court, the sumptuous landscaping, the reflecting pool.
There are hazards to the trade, Mr. Meyer said: "Measuring houses in the snow and falling into a basement window well. Being pulled over by the police in exclusive neighborhoods -- we're taking pictures and it looks like we're casing out a burglary."
"The other day," Mr. Meyer said, "one of my appraisers was doing a two-family in Brooklyn and he was attacked by the tenant. She was being evicted because she hadn't paid rent and took it out on the appraiser."
The 90's have been a tumultuous time for the industry. And in the estimate of Bert Thornton, president of the 19,000-member Appraisal Institute, a trade association, "the profession has changed more in the last five years than in the previous 30."
Perhaps as nothing else, computers have streamlined and standardized the process, rendering an array of data -- from economic overviews and regional residential trends to specific information on the most recent sale of "comparables" down the block -- available, literally, at the push of a button. So, too, can the final appraisal, complete with digital photographs, be E-mailed to the client (usually, though not always, the lender) almost instantaneously.
Hand in hand with the computer revolution has been the ripple effect on appraisers stirred by the globalization of money markets, particularly given the allure of an enduringly vibrant United States economy. "There are no boundaries today," Mr. Thornton said, "so you have a lot of capital flowing in and out of the United States" -- with investors from all over the world wanting a slice of the American home-loan pie through what Wall Street calls securitization. "The loans are pooled," Mr. Thornton explained, "rating agencies rate those pools of loans and they are securitized, sold as shares."
AT the same time, in a market where capital for lending is plentiful and mortgage rates have been low and steady, the computer has made it possible for so-called subprime borrowers -- those with less than exemplary credit histories -- to be granted mortgages quickly.
"The lender requires an appraisal on a property, and these days that is probably the biggest condition for granting a mortgage," said Keith Gumbinger, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J. "In recent years, even folks with poor credit have been able to obtain mortgages, albeit at higher interest rates."
Computers have taken much of the subjectivity, and bias, out of mortgage origination through what is called credit scoring -- the strictly numerical calculation of a borrower's credit history and capacity. That, in turn, expeditiously tells the lender what type of mortgage it can offer. "And that has lent itself to faster pooling and easier securitization of the mortgages themselves," Mr. Gumbinger said.
"Now that virtually any borrower can get a mortgage," he said, "the lender still needs to be reassured that the property has value, and whether it is fairly valued against similar properties. And, of course, that is the need for your appraisal."
Since the late 80's, forces other than the computer have reshaped the appraisal process. In a kind of tectonic convulsion, the industry was rocked by the nation's savings-and-loan debacle, with Government regulators laying part of the blame for that tidal wave of irrational S. & L. lending on the ill-considered and sometimes unethical performance of some appraisers. "There are, as in any profession, some unscrupulous appraisers," Mr. Thornton said.
Dominick Pompeo is president of Diversified Valuation Group in South Ozone Park, Queens, as well as a former chairman and current member of the New York State Appraisal Board, the agency that licenses appraisers. Congressional investigators found, Mr. Pompeo said, "that 50 percent of all losses by S. & L.'s were due to faulty or fraudulent appraisals."
Either the appraised value was so high that it had no basis in reality, Mr. Pompeo said, or the appraiser was simply unqualified. Mr. Pompeo recalled how his office analyzed a lending institution's portfolio and found that it had lent $2 million on a Manhattan property it believed to be worth $4 million, "based on an appraisal by someone who was unqualified."
"What the bank didn't know," Mr. Pompeo said, "was that it was a loft building, subject to the Loft Law, which restricts rents and requires that the building be brought into residential code compliance." The appraiser had forecast rents that were not allowable and disregarded the cost of bringing the building into compliance. The true value, he said, was $600,000.
"There were a lot of improprieties leading to the S. & L. crisis, a lot of shady characters inflating values," said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, the company that produces the Douglas Elliman Manhattan Market Report. "Until then, it was an unregulated profession that was not held accountable."
BUT in 1989, in response to the S. & L. collapse, the Government enacted Title 11 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act, requiring that anyone appraising federally insured properties be state licensed, and establishing minimum requirements -- 2,000 hours of field experience (now 2,500), 120 hours of classroom training and passage of a written test.
The law also allowed states to choose mandatory or voluntary licensing status: mandatory meaning all appraisers had to meet the minimum requirements to perform federally related appraisals; voluntary meaning only those doing Federal work need be licensed. New York is a voluntary state -- a choice that has caused some consternation.
In 1994, the Federal Housing Administration shook up the industry again. It discarded its list of 8,000 designated appraisers, chosen by rotation to perform federally related appraisals, and adopted a program called "Lender-Select" -- meaning the lender of any mortgage to be insured by the Government could choose any state-licensed appraiser. Problems arose.
"The lender has a fiduciary responsibility to F.H.A.," said James Park, a member of the Appraisal Institute's client services committee and president of the JP Appraisal Service in Alexandria, Va. But a General Accounting Office study, Mr. Park said, reported that under Lender-Select the F.H.A. insured many homes that did not meet its requirements and, "maybe more importantly, put people in the unfortunate position of buying homes that had significant problems."
In some cases, the buyers defaulted. "F.H.A. ends up holding the property and has to pay insurance to the lender," Mr. Park said. "They then have to sell the foreclosed property, many times at a loss. And, ultimately, the American taxpayer bears the burden."
Mr. Pompeo of the New York State Appraisal Boardis troubled by some shifts in the industry. In the past, he said, banks hired appraisers directly. Now, increasingly, they rely on mortgage brokers to provide clients, so the broker selects the appraiser.
"No longer is the lender a disinterested party because his remuneration depends on the mortgage being completed," Mr. Pompeo said. "If the broker is unscrupulous, and the property has attributes that the bank and the buyer should be aware of," an unethical broker "would wish the appraiser to ignore it. And people who are not adhering to appraisal standards are being rewarded by work from brokers who want a predetermined result in their appraisals."
One trend that pleases cost-conscious lenders, but troubles some appraisers, is the "drive-by appraisal" -- usually employed in suburban settings -- in which the appraiser assumes that the interior of the house is typical of the market.
Last month, to address some of the problems, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced a Home Buyer Protection Initiative, a program that, among other things, creates an appraisal education program for consumers, mandates greater specificity in identifying building deficiencies and requires that the buyer receive a copy of the appraisal no less than five days before closing.
Although lenders constitute, by far, the majority of appraisal clients, the buyer is entitled to a copy of the appraisal. And it is usually the buyer who pays the appraiser's fee, as part of the closing costs. Fees vary according to the complexity of the property. So, for example, a half-hour perusal by Mr. Meyer of that Cape in Massapequa Park might cost $250, while Mr. Satkiewicz's more extensive inspection of a luxury Manhattan co-op could cost $1,000 or far more.
Upon arriving at the property, the appraiser starts by calculating dimensions -- using a tape measure or, perhaps, a sonar device that, like a bat, bounces a signal from wall to wall, then emits a disembodied voice intoning: "Sixteen feet, four inches."
Then, Mr. Miller said: "We sketch a floor plan, assess the condition of the floors, walls, ceilings, anything visible; and take note of upgrades," like a new kitchen, "and amenities," like the pool.
Through multiple listing services, official records or, wherever possible, actual visits, the appraiser collects information on comparables. "In the case of co-ops," Mr. Miller said, "we get hold of the current co-op financial statement; or, for houses, we're going to town hall or the local M.L.S. to look at recent transfers in the neighborhood."
Then begins the actual valuation work -- a complicated and not entirely scientific process depending largely on the appraiser's knowledge of the community. "Let's say you have two properties that are identical in every respect except for one amenity, such as the view," Mr. Miller said. "In the case of an apartment, the subject residence could have a direct view of Central Park above the tree line, while the same apartment below the tree line might have sold for 15 percent less."
In a typical suburban community, Mr. Meyer said, "upgrades such as new kitchens, a pool, the rear deck could increase values, cumulatively, by 10 to 20 percent of the total value."
UPGRADE by upgrade, amenity by amenity, the home under examination and its comparables are factored in to arrive at an estimate of market value. "It's a mix of the appraiser's objective and subjective experiences," Mr. Miller said.
One morning last month, Mr. Satkiewicz walked through a four-bedroom condominium on the 31st floor of the Grand Millennium at Broadway and 66th Street and was immediately struck by the terrace and its wraparound view of Central Park, the spires of midtown Manhattan and the Hudson River. "It curves around, almost juts out," he said.
His sonar measuring device in hand, Mr. Satkiewicz calculated the terrace at 197 square feet -- just one of a panoply of amenities he would account for during his 90-minute tour of the apartment, but one that, he said, "gives it star quality."
Later, Mr. Satkiewicz returned to his office to crunch numbers.
"There are five comparables on this appraisal," he said, "and they sold for between $976 and $1,129 per square foot." Using that range, he chose $1,000 per square foot as his base for further calculation.
"We adjust for exterior space by comparing sales of identical apartments that have exterior space to those without," he said, "and isolate the value of the terrace."
Saying that research and experience "tell me that terraces are worth half the square-foot price for inside the apartment," Mr. Satkiewicz valued the terrace at $500 per foot. He multiplied the 197 square feet of terrace by $500, for a preliminary figure of $98,500 in added value to the apartment.
"But that's just the scientific part," Mr. Satkiewicz said. "There are things that are not quantifiable but need to be factored in: one is what you see from the terrace; the second is any improvement that enhances its utility, in this case, the terra cotta tiles and the wiring for surround-sound stereo. In my judgment, those add 50 percent to our base figure of $98,500," or $147,750 in added value.
That, however, is just one factor in the equation. "We go through the process for each of the major upgrades and amenities," he said, "and get an adjusted range of sales prices for all the comparables." With the comparables taken into account, Mr. Satkiewicz said, "we select a value within the range that we think best represents the subject's position in the marketplace."
His appraisal of the apartment, which the current owner bought for $2.3 million in January 1997: $3.51 million.
 
Survey Shows Amenity Values
 A survey of what people are willing to pay for the amenities that lift their Manhattan apartments out of the ordinary shows that a health club in the building raises the price by 30 percent and a view of Central Park is worth 60 percent more than the value would be without that view.
The survey was done by the Mitchell, Maxwell & Jackson appraisal company for the Corcoran Group residential brokerage. It uses as its base the average price for two-bedroom apartments (not including lofts) below 96th Street, and then factors in the differences in price for a two-bedroom that comes with a particular amenity.
In 1998, the average price for a two-bedroom was $488,870, according to the report. But, the price of a two-bedroom with a Central Park view, for example, was $782,192, or 60 percent higher than the average price for a two-bedroom elsewhere. And a two-bedroom with a river view was $562,201, or 15 percent higher than the average two-bedroom.
A two-bedroom in a building with a health club and pool was $635,531, or 30 percent higher than the average. One with a wood-burning fireplace was $615,976, or 26 percent higher; with concierge services, $557,312, or 14 percent higher, and with a terrace or balcony, $552,423, or 13 percent higher than the average two-bedroom.
The report also indicated that the price of a two-bedroom in a prewar building was $586,644, or 20 percent higher than the average, and was $640,420, or 31 percent higher, for a two-bedroom in a condominium building. And two-bedroom penthouse apartments averaged $806,636, or 65 percent higher than the typical two-bedroom.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
A Crime Fighter With a Zero-Tolerance Policy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
ABOUT three weeks ago, Joseph J. Santiago started his fourth year as Newark's Police Director by suspending nine officers without pay and denouncing them for what he called an intolerable breach of trust.
Days earlier, some of them had hit a 23-year-old man arrested on charges of molesting a 10-year-old boy, he said. Other officers placed the man in a station house cell and failed to stop prisoners from punching him, he said. And, he continued, others failed to tell superiors about the beatings. 
 Mr. Santiago called a news conference to issue his scolding. As television cameras whirred, he issued a "declaration and warning" to Newark's 1,500 police officers and detectives: police brutality will not be tolerated, and a "blue wall of silence" will not be tolerated. The station house beating, he vowed, would not be allowed to tarnish the department's reputation or undercut his commitment to hold all officers to the "highest standard of conduct."
Mr. Santiago, 51, took command of the department in July 1996 with orders to overhaul its image and performance. Federal authorities had just indicted the director at the time, William R. Celester, on fraud charges, which included spending $29,500 from a police account on vacations and gifts for his wife and girlfriends. In a referendum a few months earlier, Newark voters, by better than 2 to 1, said they had no confidence in the department.
Mayor Sharpe James gave Mr. Santiago, a career Newark police officer, the task of improving rank-and-file morale, putting more officers on the street, reducing police response time to residents' calls, and cutting crime, including drug peddling.
Over the last three years, Mr. Santiago has instituted major changes, developed a reputation as a strong-willed reformer and won high praise from Mayor James. But his public berating of the nine officers and his warning to others suggests his demands for high standards of conduct are ignored by some.
In a recent interview, Mr. Santiago said more "good cops" must tell superiors about colleagues who are breaking the law or department rules and regulations.
"That's not popular here," he said. "Police officers don't want to hear that. A lot goes on because of the silence of good guys. The people who provide protection by silence are as much a problem as the bad ones."
He said that "good cops" have a sworn duty to speak out against those who don't abide by the law.
Since becoming director, Mr. Santiago has dismissed 70 officers, 21 of them for a variety of crimes, including receiving stolen property, said Rocco Malanga, deputy director for public affairs. Forty-nine others have been discharged for violating department regulations, including failing to follow orders, testing positive for drugs, refusing to take drug tests, missing court appearances, and chronic lateness or absenteeism.
From 1996 until the end of 1998, violent crime, including murder, rape, robbery and aggravated assault, has dropped 36.5 percent, from 8,871 to 5,637, the department said.
Mayor James called Mr. Santiago a "role model."
"He's been highly innovative," Mr. James said. "His work ethic is exemplary. And he's been aggressive but fair." He said police officers responded to residents' calls more quickly than in the Celester days, and more patrolmen were visible on the streets.
This delights Mildred Crump, a former councilwoman who voted against confirming Mr. Santiago in 1996.
Ms. Crump, who lives in the South Ward, said she was seeing more and more officers on street patrol chatting with teen-agers. "I think that's wonderful," she said. "It's time we had police officers as role models for kids rather than drug dealers, who pretend they're their friends when they're their worst enemies. Everybody is extremely pleased. They're very upbeat."
Clement A. Price, a history professor and chairman of Afro-American studies at the Newark campus of Rutgers University, said Mr. Santiago had taken over a demoralized force that had lost considerable support in the community. Like Ms. Crump, he praised the increased police visibility on the streets and the drop in crime.
"The department is on top of one of Newark's most notorious problems: street-level crime," he said. "The perception of Newark as a dangerous place has been very much challenged by Mr. Santiago's police force. I think he's done an extraordinary service."
Mr. Santiago, the son of a lawyer and a housekeeper, once thought about joining the priesthood or applying to the United States Military Academy at West Point. But he decided on police work. "I was just drawn to it," he said.
AT 17, he began working with the Newark department as a cadet, shoveling out the stables of the mounted patrol. He graduated from the department's academy in 1969 and rose through the ranks to become deputy chief before Mayor James appointed him director. In 1981, he received a bachelor's degree in political science and history from Kean College.
Mr. Santiago cites several reasons for the drop in crime, including the good economy, the nationwide decrease in crime rates and his management innovations. Since taking over, he has hired 400 extra patrolmen, increasing the uniformed force to 1,500. And he has installed a citywide crime-fighting strategy called Command Status, or ComStat.
The system originated in New York City's police department and was introduced here by Jack Maple, once deputy commissioner for operations in New York. Under ComStat, the location of every crime is plotted on computerized maps, allowing easy analysis of neighborhood crime clusters or trends in each of Newark's four police districts. Every Thursday, the district commanders and their staffs meet with Mr. Santiago and his top aides to study the crime maps and draft crime-fighting strategies. Mr. Santiago requires each commander to devise the strategies. They are then printed in playbooks that all officers and detectives in the four districts receive, outlining their individual responsibility in the strategy.
"It structures their day and activities to focus on a problem in an area," Mr. Santiago said. "In the past, cops went out and were left to their own devices. Police officers worked autonomously. They never worked under direction."
District commanders are also questioned, sometimes pointedly, at the Thursday meetings about any spurts in crime in their jurisdictions.
"It's about accountability," Mr. Santiago said. "It's very uncomfortable, standing up there and explaining yourself and what went wrong. At ComStat, you can't fake it. Either you know your business or you don't. It's a return to a fundamental process: was this done? was that done?"
Mr. Malanga, the deputy director for public affairs, said the questioning about crime increases can sometimes become grueling for the district commanders. "It's almost like they're on trial," he said.
A leader of one of Newark's two police unions, who spoke on condition of anonymity, called the questioning at ComStat meetings an inquisition. The union official called Mr. Santiago an "intelligent guy." "A lot of things he does in theory are fine," the official said. But, he added, Mr. Santiago is also quick-tempered and sometimes browbeats subordinates.
"People skills are not his strong point," he said.
Mr. Santiago brushed off the union leader's criticism.
"They can say what they want," he said. "That comes with the territory. I get conflict from everyone Would you rather have 1,500 disgruntled employees or 300,000 satisfied customers?"
Mayor James also dismissed union grumbling.
"You can't say yes to everyone," the mayor said. "He wants them to work. More's expected of them, and they're doing more and they're winning greater acceptance from the community."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
If the Price Isn't Right

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:
Congratulations! You've just been offered a terrific job with a company you've always admired. The problem is that the salary offer is very low -- not only when compared with industry averages, but also in relation to other salaries at the same company. Sure, the offer is somewhat higher than your current pay, but relocation expenses and higher living costs in the new city will eat up the difference. Should you push for more money, or would that hurt your chances of getting that dream job?
First things first. Have no fear about asking for more money, experts advise. Unless the person making the offer is from another planet, she expects you to do so. If you don't, she might wonder if you're the prize catch she thought you were.
"Look at it this way," said Leigh Steinberg, a sports agent in Newport Beach, Calif., who negotiates pay packages for a living. "If you are selling a car for $10,000 and someone walks up to you and says, '10,000? Sure, that sounds like a great price,' and you execute the sale, you will have a really sneaking suspicion that you underpriced the car." 
 Mr. Steinberg advised assembling an "aggressive" but "not completely irrational" counteroffer to the company. "Research is key," he said. But don't just look at pay scales; study the person across the desk. "Look at the negotiating style of the person," he said. "Do they have a reputation for playing tough until the last minute? A reputation for bullying and blustering?"
That information will help you prepare for the coming face-off. "You cannot let yourself be intimidated," he said.
A practice run can prove particularly helpful for people who are uncomfortable with confrontation, he said. "Have somebody who talks loudly argue this out with you ahead of time," he advised.
In the actual negotiations, use your research to show exactly why you deserve a higher offer, in line with industry standards. "Everyone wants to think of themselves as fair," Mr. Steinberg said, so mentioning your pay concerns to the employer will make her feel a need to respond. Maybe she doesn't have a lot of negotiating room on salary, but perhaps she can find other sweeteners, like a signing bonus or extra vacation.
No matter how frustrating the process, keep your cool, said Tom Wallace, a New York literary agent. Too often, he said, people view such talks as a personal, not a business, matter. "The adrenaline starts flowing," he said. "They get all red in the face."
But an emotional response only undermines your position. When a client becomes upset over an offer, Mr. Wallace said, "I remind them it's not meant to be a slap in the face and that we'll just say no."
Through the negotiations, remember the minimum salary you'll accept. If it's offered, take it, Mr. Steinberg advised, but try to arrange for a salary review in a few months or set up performance goals that will prompt a bonus or pay increase. If this really is your dream job, he said, you may want to get your foot in the door now, then prove your superior value.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

Pamela Addison, A. Gifford Miller

Pamela Beth Addison, a lawyer, was married yesterday to City Councilman A. Gifford Miller. The Rev. Gilbert S. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Beyond the Savings Rate

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE Government's announcement last month that the savings rate was the lowest since the Depression has prompted much unease. After all, in a time of such plenty, how can Americans not be putting away some of their surplus to prepare for harder times?
The answer is not only just that we are spending everything we earn. Actually, the savings rate is negative, meaning that we are spending more than we earn. One report says baby boomers, especially, are misbehaving, having outstanding debt equal to 95 percent of annual personal income. Are we embarrassed yet? 
 Well, maybe we don't have to be. William G. Gale of the Brookings Institution says that if capital gains were figured into what we save, then the savings rate would be at its highest in 40 years.
The key here is that saving money isn't the only way to build wealth. If you already own stock, you've generally seen its worth soar over the last decade. And if you already own a home, chances are its value has grown, too. The effect of such gains is that you don't feel so compelled to save a big part of your paycheck.
The buildup of wealth "has a tremendous influence on what boomers do during their working lives," said John Gist, associate director of the Public Policy Institute at AARP, co-author of a study on boomers' saving.
"If they know they'll also have a pension, Social Security," Mr. Gist said, "that affects how much of their income they'll save."
Boomers' wealth has indeed climbed steadily. Mr. Gist said that from 1984 to 1994, the latest year for which data are available, the median net worth of boomers -- those born between 1946 and 1964 -- more than tripled, from $12,989 to $41,500 (all figures in 1994 dollars). In 1994, boomers' median wealth equaled 130 percent of their annual salaries, versus 46 percent in 1984.
These are strong numbers, and capital gains are a huge part of them. Mr. Gale and John Sabelhaus of the Congressional Budget Office, have found that since 1995, capital gains have accounted for more than 80 percent of growth in household net worth.
The most comfortable beneficiaries of rising home and stock prices have been older boomers -- those born by 1954. Mr. Gist has found that those born later don't have the savings that older boomers had at the same ages.
In 1984, when many older boomers were in their 30's, they had an average net worth of about $34,000, in 1994 dollars, according to Mr. Gist. In 1994, when the younger boomers were in their 30's, their net worth was $23,000, on average.
It's not that the older boomers are necessarily smarter. They were just lucky enough to hit their economic stride when housing was cheaper and income growth was stronger. They also tended to marry younger, a factor that leads to higher savings. Ten years later, those advantages have resulted in fat 401(k) plans and high home equity.
Beginning in 1982, as stocks were climbing, older boomers "were starting to make very good money," said Ray Ferrara, of Provise Management Group, a financial planning firm in Clearwater, Fla. "The younger baby boomers are just now 35 and just starting to make some decent incomes, but not as good as their older brethren."
Elaine Gonzalez of Tampa, Fla., and her husband, David, are younger boomers who are trying to save for a home, but it's slow going. Although they started putting money in a universal variable life insurance policy, which has investment value, more than 10 years ago, they didn't do much else. In the past year, they enrolled for the first time in 401(k)'s.
"We just have enough money to pay our bills and have a bit of a balance in our checking account," said Ms. Gonzalez, 39, a customer service representative in the travel division of American Express. "We don't have a savings account or anything like that. I'm putting some money aside, but I'm not going to kill myself now to put every single cent I have into the future."
The capital gains that have helped the older boomers make up for a low savings rate, of course, could be our fool's gold. Who can predict where markets will be by the time we retire? But we always have been a confident generation.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Jaguar S-Type;
A More Compact Cat With a Classic Face

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
IF the least expensive car you offer costs $55,000 and you want to double your sales, what can you do? For Jaguar Cars Ltd., the answer seemed simple: Develop new, more affordable models to attract customers who might like a Jag but had never thought they could afford one.
Moving down-market can be risky. Mercedes-Benz had to change the design of its A-Class after that subcompact, which is sold in Europe but not in America, rolled over in safety tests. DaimlerChrysler's sales of the Smart, a tiny, innovative car developed with the Swatch watch company, have fallen short of expectations. 
 Jaguar has no plans to sell anything as small as the A-Class or the Smart; the Ford Motor Company, Jaguar's parent, will put other nameplates on its econoboxes. Still, within a couple of years there will be a compact Jaguar sedan, sized and priced similarly to the Mercedes C-Class. And for 2000 Jaguar is offering the S-Type, which competes with medium-sized luxury sedans like Mercedes's E-Class and BMW's 5-Series.
Starting just above $40,000, the S-Type is about $15,000 less the Jaguar XJ8, and the company expects it to attract younger buyers. Jaguar plans to sell about 20,000 S-Types annually in the United States.
My test drives of two versions of the smaller Jaguar, plus strong early sales figures, suggest that the company is on track. Though less expensive than its siblings, this cat shares the traits of its species: distinctive appearance, luxurious accommodations and powerful, graceful performance.
 The rear-drive S-Type feels, looks and acts like a Jaguar although it shares its basic architecture with the Lincoln LS -- the first instance of "platform sharing" since Ford bought Jaguar in 1990. But the engineers have done a remarkable job of disguising the common underpinnings. The LS feels stiffer, firmer and -- in a first for Lincoln, quite Germanic; the S-Type is silky, smooth and plush in the British tradition. This platform will also be used for a very American car, the 2001 Ford Thunderbird.
I did not immediately fall in love with the look of the S-Type, as I typically do with Jaguars. The car seemed to lack the brand's usual sexiness and glamour, as exemplified by the drop-dead-gorgeous XK8 coupe and convertible. But others clearly disagreed; many people I encountered thought the car was stunning, and as I see more S-Types on the roads, its styling has grown on me.
The car certainly resembles the high-performance 3.8 S-Type of the 1960's. In particular, the new S-Type's most prominent feature is an elliptical vertical-bar grille straight out of the Jaguar history book. In fact, the much-celebrated Mark II 3.8, built from 1959 to 1967, provided inspiration for Geoff Lawson, the design impresario for the company who died recently at age 54.
But while current Jaguars generally have the most shapely rumps on the road, the S-Type's rear end doesn't stand out. The back was raised to create more trunk space for the car's presumably more practical owner. At 13.1 cubic feet, the space is about right in this class, but it is shallow, requiring that suitcases be laid flat.
While the silhouette is similar to the 1960's models after which the S-Type was patterned, its proportions differ from its modern siblings, with their low roofs, long hoods and tapered tails. This is largely due to the car's more compact size; it is 6.5 inches shorter than the XJ8. And the rear window evoked the Lincoln Town Car more than the bigger Jaguar.
Inside, though, this is clearly a Jaguar, down to the distinctive scent of the soft leather. There is rich wood, of course, but it is a lighter "mushroom-stained maple" than the walnut used on other models.
The S-Type officially accommodates five, but its back seat is on the tight side for a car of this size. The front seats are extremely comfortable and supportive.
The car has the usual luxury-class safety features: dual front air bags, side bags up front, traction control and anti-lock brakes. It can be equipped with all kinds of gadgets, including rain-detecting windshield wipers; a stability control that selectively applies the brakes to help prevent skids, and an obstacle-detection system that beeps as the car backs toward an object or a person. You can have a satellite-guided navigation system with Jaguar Assist, which sends help if an air bag deploys. The navigation controls were not at all intuitive; lacking a user's manual or verbal instructions, I repeatedly tried to program a destination. Frustrated, I gave up every time.
The S-Type can be ordered with a $4,300 communications package that includes the most expansive use of speech recognition in any auto on the road today. Using simple voice commands, the driver can make calls on the cellular telephone, set the radio station, play a compact disk or cassette tape and adjust the heat and air-conditioning. In total, the system allows 44 commands.
The S-Type's driving dynamics are excellent, and the car delivers graceful power in a purely Jaguar way. The base engine is an all-new 3-liter V6 rated at 240 horsepower and 221 foot-pounds of torque. Also available is a 4-liter V8 (281 horsepower, 287 foot-pounds) used in other Jaguars. The new Lincolns have versions of both engines. The S-Type comes only with smooth five-speed automatic transmissions; there will be no stick shift for the United States.
Subtle character differences exist between the V6 and V8 models. The S-Type with the V8 obviously has more raw power -- impressive power, indeed, for highway cruising and passing maneuvers. But the V6 may appeal more to enthusiast drivers, since that car's lighter weight makes it feel more nimble. An optional sport package ($1,100) adds more spirited performance to either version with larger wheels, performance tires and "Cats," for Computer Active Technology Suspension, which automatically adjusts the ride from firm to soft depending on how the car is driven.
Jaguar has for decades had the stigma of inferior quality and dreadful reliability, but all that seems to have changed since Ford took over. In the most recent ratings by J. D. Power & Associates, Jaguar ranked at the top in initial quality, after hovering near the bottom of the list only seven years ago. And Jaguar has cleverly priced the base versions of the S-Type a few thousand dollars above the equivalent new Lincolns, but a few thousand below the 5-Series and the E-Class.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Feline grace in a practical, less pricey package.
