HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Global Food Fights: The Worst Are Yet to Come

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt.

 BODY:
FARMERS in Vermont know what they don't like: mud season, summer tourists who hang around the town green too long after buying their maple syrup, and agricultural imports from Canada. Now add one more to the list: the World Trade Organization.
Last week, in a sometimes raucous meeting in a chapel here within view of Lake Champlain, they implored a team of American negotiators to keep the World Trade Organization from running their lives from the shores of Lake Geneva. "The W.T.O. is a farce," said Susanna Jones, an organic farmer and political activist here. "It was created as a shield to protect corporate profits around the world. Why do we put up with a central organization that can tell us how we can farm and what we can eat?" 
 Good question, and Ms. Jones is not the only one asking it.
Farmers in Europe are screaming about the W.T.O., too, but for different reasons. While American farmers view the rule-setting group as a kind of mysterious and unaccountable body issuing edicts from Switzerland, Europeans think it is just a tool of the United States. How else to explain the W.T.O.'s rulings that Europeans must drop rules against genetically modified farm products from America, or face sanctions?
In Geneva, the view is different still. From the inside, the W.T.O. looks like a disorganized disaster, so plagued by infighting that it took months to agree on the next director-general to run the place. In the end, they struck a compromise last week that left everyone unsatisfied: having each of the top two candidates serve for half the six-year term.
In short, five years after its creation, the World Trade Organization is making everyone unhappy -- probably just what you would expect from the first international body charged with dragging entrenched interests around the world into a global trading system that operates by global rules.
UNTIL recently, farmers haven't had to worry much about those rules. Farm subsidies and import restrictions on agricultural goods have usually been too hot politically for negotiators to handle. But now they will be the main subject of the next big round of global trade negotiations, which begins later this year in Seattle.
And you can hear the screaming from Osaka and Oshkosh and Orleans. Farmers, already smarting from record low prices for soybeans and corn and apples, are fearful that the all-powerful W.T.O. ("Would you like to see our black helicopters?" one official of the organization asks, mocking the conspiracy theorists) will force changes they have long resisted.
So the Japanese are trying to torpedo the talks before they start, saying they won't give an inch on rice or other products crucial to their "food security." The Europeans say that, for the health of their residents, anything genetically modified will be banned. France's farm minister undiplomatically noted last week that the United States had the "worst food in the world."
And then there are all those unhappy American farmers, who cannot agree among themselves precisely what the United States should be trying to get out of these negotiations. Certainly not freer trade with Canada, milk and dairy farmers told August Schumacher, Undersecretary of Agriculture, because the United States would be the loser. Vermont's organic farmers sound a lot like the Europeans. They, too, rail against genetically modified products, and a few activists demanded that the corporate charters of companies like Monsanto be revoked.
Big corporate farmers -- who are also big political contributors -- want the global rules written to allow them the widest latitude possible in using genetically modified seeds, which will soon account for two-thirds of America's soybeans and half its corn. "Our goal is to give people around the world the choice of what kind of agricultural products they want to buy," said Peter Scher, who runs the negotiations for the United States Trade Representative's office.
But what Washington calls choice, the Europeans and Vermonters call dangerous arrogance. Right now they are fighting over what kind of labels go on the American goods, because the Europeans know that a big, easy-to-read "GM" for genetically modified will assure that the American goods rot on the shelves.
A result is that the superpowers are about to clash over supermarkets.
It is the kind of battle that sounds technical, but quickly pits powerful political forces on several continents against one another. After all, the battles over bananas and beef have already risen to the presidential level several times.
As elections near, both in the United States and abroad, protectionist sentiment is bound to turn small food fights into bigger ones. And for all its talk about the benefits of global trading rules, it is still unclear that Washington will be able to convince farmers here that the W.T.O. is less threatening than a carload of leaf-peeping tourists with New York plates.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
At Last, the Euro Looks Ready to Climb

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE euro, Europe's single currency, has made a rebound in the last week and a half that investors should not ignore.
After falling 13 percent since its January debut, to a low of $1.0136 on July 14, the euro has jumped 3.6 percent, to $1.0503. More important, some currency analysts think that the euro's worst days are behind it. 
 "It's a very critical juncture," said Karen E. Parker, the currency strategist at Chase Manhattan Bank. The reason, of course, is that market turns offer investors an inviting opportunity.
In this case, Americans can buy European stocks or bonds while they are still relatively cheap in dollar terms. Then, if the euro strengthens, they can watch it magnify their returns. That would be the opposite of what happened in the first half of the year, when the euro's plunge eroded Americans' gains in European stocks -- sometimes turning them into losses.
At the beginning of the year, the consensus, especially among European strategists, was that the euro would rise. Ms. Parker, however, predicted a decline, although she did not anticipate how fast it would be.
Now her outlook is changing. "We're on the verge of calling a bottom in the euro," she said.
Any long-term turnaround for the euro requires a shift in the economic growth trajectories of Europe and the United States: Europe's growth must accelerate, and America's must slow. If that happens, investing in Europe will become more attractive and the money that flows in will help lift the euro.
Several reports last week indicated that the shift might be starting. The Ifo economic research institute reported that its index of business confidence in Germany, Europe's largest economy, jumped to 92.9 in June, from 90.5 in May. The increase was bigger than expected and could signal that businesses are ready to increase investment and hire more workers, all prerequisites for a good economic rebound.
In the United States, the May trade deficit, a record $21.3 billion, indicated that surging imports and slowing exports were putting a drag on economic growth. In the wake of the report, Chase reduced its forecast for second-quarter economic growth to an annual rate of 2.5 percent, from 3 percent.
The growing trade deficit also has a benefit of its own for the euro. As the United States imports more goods, foreign businesses reap more dollars. The exchange of those dollars into local currencies weakens the dollar and lifts the other currencies.
The euro could also be lifted faster and farther if investors who have been shorting the euro all year are suddenly forced to switch their positions to avoid big losses. That may already be happening.
Ms. Parker warns, however, that this euro rally could fade. A long-term rally, she said, depends on the enactment of broad economic reforms in Europe, including corporate tax cuts, changes in pension and other employee benefits and easing of restrictions on cross-border mergers. Those changes, she said, would spur growth.
Still, she said that signs of revival in Europe -- combined with the narrowing gap between higher United States interest rates and lower European ones -- mean that the euro might bottom at $1.03 in the next two months and could climb as high as $1.08 in the year ahead. That would leave it 7 percent below its debut level.
Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and a self-proclaimed euro-skeptic, has taken his own conversion a little further. He thinks the euro could jump quickly to $1.10.
TAKING advantage of a turn in markets is among the most difficult tasks for investors. And the bounce of the euro in the last week and a half is just one example of how fast the outlook for a currency can change. That is why some money managers ride out market declines rather than betting that they can get out and then get back in at just the right moment.
Nonetheless, the euro opportunity is attractive. If this is not the bottom, it probably isn't far away. And if you believe that Euroland is turning around, getting in today will not seem so late a year from now.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Little Asias, Across Dixie

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
WHERE can you find immigrant entrepreneurs from Asia revitalizing urban neighborhoods today?
Try the South. 
 Large-scale Asian immigration is a relatively new phenomenon in the states of the former Confederacy, beginning in earnest only in the 1970's, after the Vietnam War ended. The first clusters appeared in the big metropolitan regions of Atlanta, Dallas and Houston. By the 1990's, the Asian population in the South was growing rapidly, increasing by almost half from 1990 to 1996, to nearly 1.5 million. And with the immigrants came the same entrepreneurial culture that has been at work in older Asian-American communities for decades.
Asian immigrants now head south for many of the same reasons that other business people do: low housing costs, rapid economic growth and a generally pro-business political environment. Nowhere is that more evident than in Houston, which over the last quarter-century has become home to the South's largest Asian-American business community.
Houston's wave has been led by people like Don Wang, founder and chief executive of Metrocorp Bancshares, the parent of Metrobank, the largest of the city's six Asian-American-owned banks.
When he came to Houston in the early 1970's, Asian-owned business barely registered in the dizzying energy-led boom. As the boom fizzled, Houston began bleeding population, with 140,000 residents, mostly white, leaving the region in the 1980's. But Asian and other immigrants began arriving in growing numbers. The city's Asian-born population swelled from 2,500 in 1965 to 67,000 in 1990, and demographers expect the 2000 count to be 100,000-plus, or more than 7 percent of the city's residents.
"In the 70's, oil made Houston boom, but it also brought in immigrants," said Mr. Wang, whose bank, now 12 years old, is now the fourth largest based in Houston. "When the oil crisis came, everything dropped, but it actually was our chance to become a new city again."
In contrast to the American-born residents who left town during the oil bust, he said, Asian immigrants saw the region's slump as an opportunity to acquire real estate, buy homes and start businesses in fields like food processing, distribution and electronics assembly.
The results are most striking in Houston's close-in suburban districts, just outside the Interstate 610 loop that encircles the center of the city. The Bellaire Road area, once a declining working-class neighborhood of aging shopping centers, has become widely known as Houston's new Chinatown. Crowded with Asian-owned banks, including Mr. Wang's, and an array of Asian-oriented grocery stores, restaurants and business service firms, it looks and feels less like the Texas oil patch than like Flushing, Queens, or the San Gabriel Valley east of Los Angeles.
"Well, we still have one fried-chicken place left somewhere around here -- it's kind of the last outpost of the native culture lost amid the new Chinatown," Chao-Chiung Lee said over dim sum in one of the area's many Asian-oriented mini-malls. Mr. Lee is president of Stoa International Architects, which has designed many buildings in the area.
ASIAN immigrants have also been responsible for the rapid growth of the adjacent Harwin corridor. Once a forlorn strip of office and warehouse buildings, the area has been transformed into a car-friendly bazaar for off-price goods for much of East Texas. Discount furniture, novelties, luggage, car parts and electronic goods are sold by more than 800 shops owned largely by Chinese, Korean and Indian merchants, up from roughly 40 a decade ago. In that time, commercial property in the district has more than tripled in value, and vacancies have dropped from nearly 50 percent to the single digits.
Asian-American businesses have also contributed to a turnaround in some long-depressed parts of the city center, including the vicinity of Houston's tiny original Chinatown. Among the most successful of the food processors, grocery companies and restaurants now there is Kim Son, a large Vietnamese restaurant founded by seven members of the La family, who escaped their homeland and survived a harrowing stay in a refugee camp in Indonesia before reaching Houston, nearly penniless, in 1980.
Each of the seven began working 12-hour, minimum-wage shifts at a convenience store, and within two years the family had accumulated $20,000 in savings, according to Tan La, now 39.
In 1982, Mr. La, his parents and his siblings used their savings to open a small restaurant, which grew rapidly even while Houston's economy was sputtering. "Times were tough, but people were still eating," he said. "Maybe it was that the price was reasonable, very affordable. The regular Houstonians kept coming in."
Today, with Houston on the rebound, the regulars keep flocking to the downtown restaurant, which now sprawls over 11 times its original space. Branch restaurants in two other locations, including one in the affluent, mostly white Galleria district, lift the family business's annual sales above $7 million; 200 people work for the company.
"Houston is really changing," Mr. La said with a slight smile. "People want to come downtown now. It's become a very good environment. It has to do with us but also with these Texans -- they are adventurous and like to try new things."

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Agent for the Women of the Hour

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER

 BODY:
SUE RODIN's trip to the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta changed her professional life. Having watched two of her marketing jobs disappear -- one in a corporate downsizing and the other after an unsuccessful spinoff -- Ms. Rodin, then 49, was wrapping up a consulting stint with Avon, a sponsor of the Games, and considering starting a business of her own.
Sitting in the stands, she watched as American women snared gold medals in basketball as well as in soccer and softball, two new Olympic events for women. The seats were filled, she noted, and not just with females. 
 On the flight back to New York, Ms. Rodin said, she had an epiphany. "The whole thing about women's sports kind of crystallized at that time," she said. "The Olympic experience reinforced for me that there could be an opportunity if I specialized in women's sports -- that there might be an opportunity to make a difference and make a living."
Ms. Rodin is now one of the few sports agents specializing in representing women. Three of her nine clients are soccer players basking in the adulation after the American team's victory in the Women's World Cup -- the co-captain, Julie Foudy; Carla Overbeck, and Tiffany Roberts.
In fact, her first client was Ms. Foudy, whom she signed in 1996. Ms. Foudy said she considered going with a larger agency, but decided that she did not want to be a small fish in a big pond. "I think what I like about Sue is she is really committed to women's sports," Ms. Foudy said. "We didn't need to sell her on the idea that this team was going to be big or that women's soccer was going to be big."
Last Tuesday, Ms. Rodin talked on the phone in her modest, windowless Manhattan office with marketing executives at Sports Illustrated for Women, trying to juggle plans for a luncheon with them on Wednesday with a commitment the same day with Women's Sports & Fitness magazine. The previous day, her soccer clients had met President Clinton, and that night they would appear on "The Late Show With David Letterman."
Promoting her female clients was not always an easy sell, Ms. Rodin allowed, but now "I'm not necessarily calling people," she said. "They're calling me."
Suddenly, manufacturers are mailing her products that they hope her soccer players will endorse. And she no longer has to spell Ms. Foudy's name to the people in marketing departments at cosmetics companies.
Despite the media hoopla over the soccer team's triumph, it has yet to yield any of the million-dollar endorsement deals that athletes dream of, and Ms. Rodin still commutes to her office from Queens, where she grew up.
But prospects are improving. According to Ms. Rodin, the soccer players' speaking fees have already doubled: Ms. Foudy now commands $10,000 an appearance. And Pepsico, a sponsor since 1996, has announced it will back the team's fall tour and use Ms. Foudy and the goalkeeper, Briana Scurry, as spokeswomen for Pepsi-Cola and Aquafina bottled water. That deal will earn Ms. Foudy fees "in the five figures," according to Dave DeCecco, a spokesman for Pepsi.
And Ms. Rodin has rising hopes for a doughnut deal for Ms. Foudy. "She loves doughnuts," Ms. Rodin said. "She's addicted to doughnuts. Everyone who knows her knows about that."
It remains to be seen how successful the soccer stars and Ms. Rodin's other clients will be at landing the kind of endorsement deals that enrich male stars like Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods.
Nationally televised team sports are a new phenomenon for women. The Women's National Basketball Association, the first women's league to win wide attention across the country, was founded only two years ago. No professional soccer league has emerged.
Without continuing exposure on television, a female athlete who excelled during the Olympics, say, has less luster for advertisers than a male professional player, said Bob Williams, president of Burns Sports, a sports marketing company that helps companies sign athletes for endorsements. The top male athletes garner endorsement income of $10 million to $45 million a year, he said, while the leading women draw no more than $6 million.
Henry Schafer, executive vice president with Marketing Evaluations/ TVQ, a company that rates celebrities on their public appeal, noted that no female athlete has scored in the top 10 since the firm began conducting surveys on popular athletes in 1988. But women's participation in sports has been rising steadily for decades, ever since Federal law began requiring public high schools and colleges to spend equally on men's and women's sports programs.
Not only are women more interested in sports, but they are buying more of the merchandise advertisers want to sell. Over all, women now spend more on sports apparel and athletic shoes than men do, according to the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association, a trade group.
Ms. Rodin, 5 feet 9 inches tall, played softball and basketball as a teen-ager -- well enough, she thinks, to have played in college on a scholarship if such things had been available then.
Women's sports have come a long way since her own youth, but Ms. Rodin has few illusions. "I think we're making progress, but it takes a little time economically," she said, a bit wearily. "We just can't expect to go from ground zero to million-dollar contracts overnight."
But she added, brightening: "For once in our lives, we have a little leverage."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Can Profits Keep Surging All Year? A 'Yes' Vote

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
CORPORATE AMERICA is rolling in dough. So too, it must be added, are those who have bought and held shares during the last few years. This is not an incidental relationship.
The reporting season for second-quarter profits is about half over, and the results are much better than most had reason to expect even six months ago. 
 Through the end of last week, better than half of the companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have reported an average profit gain of more than 15 percent from the same period in 1998, according to First Call. And there is a good chance that profits will rise at a double-digit rate for all of this year, compared with a 4 percent increase in 1998.
The trouble is, many people worry that the game will soon be up. They think the market, which has been struggling with stratospheric price-to-earnings ratios, may fall sharply when S.& P. 500 earnings gains revert to historical norms, around 7 percent.
But Thomas M. McManus, equity portfolio strategist at Banc of America Securities, thinks this earnings run could last a long, long time, and he took some time last week to explain why. Here are some excerpts:
 
Q. You are of the view that this period of strong earnings growth can continue for the indefinite future. Why?
 
A. I sense a significant underlying shift in the ability of American companies to grow earnings.
For many, the roots are in consolidation, which has been important in terms of combining two attractive businesses, maintaining the same amount of revenues but with a much smaller cost base. That doesn't happen instantly, but over a couple of years.
Even without consolidation, companies have continued to restructure, coming up with a different mix of businesses that are growing faster, are less cyclical and in areas that are attractively positioned. The best example here is General Electric, which has been restructuring its businesses for 20 years.
 
Q. So what does this lead you to conclude?
 
A. That there is a higher secular growth rate for S.& P. earnings than most are willing to concede. And the cyclical rebound off of the decline in earnings last year has occurred sooner and been more robust than anyone had forecast.
 
Q. What is your current earnings forecast?
 
A. At the start of 1999 we were more optimistic than most, and thought S.& P. profits would rise by about 10 percent from 1998 levels and a further 14 percent in 2000. At the beginning of May, I revised those numbers up, to a gain of 12 percent this year and 16 percent in 2000. And I think we are going to raise estimates for this year and 2000 again.
 
Q. What do you say to those who say the S.& P. is overvalued at these levels?
 
A. I think anyone who is saying the market is overvalued this year, be it the Fed or stock market strategists, is not taking into account that the underlying business mix has improved at least as much as General Electric has improved because of a very rapid turnover of components in the index. It now has less cyclicality and greater sustainability than it did in the past and deserves to trade at a higher P/E multiple relative to any interest rate you might choose or any competing market benchmark around the world.
Also, people should be focusing on free cash flows, not earnings. Net income is only the first approximation of profitability. The real value to investors is the amount of cash a company can take out and still be left with a business that is just as good as it was before. Companies like Microsoft and Intel are like that, and that is one reason they trade at such high multiples to net income.

Q. There are plenty of folks who are worried about the effect that Year 2000 computer problems will have on the economy and earnings. Do you share those concerns?
 
A. It is my view that profits are actually being negatively impacted right now.
Last week, for example, W. W. Granger admitted their costs went up by $7 million and their revenues were cut by $10 million in the last 10 days of June because they adopted a new computer system. It is my hunch that is their Y2K compliance system.
 
Q. Which companies or groups of companies are likely to enjoy the most rapid earnings growth over the next year or so?
 
A. We could see continued improvement in a whole host of companies.
Right now, the market is looking for trends of earnings repair, or a bounce off the dip we saw last year.
Individual companies we like include Ethan Allen, the furniture manufacturer and retailer, which experienced a significant hit last year. We also like W. W. Granger, which is investing heavily in its Internet presence. We are also very attracted to the semiconductor capital equipment sector, and really like Novellus in that area. And we like technology generally.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3203 words

HEADLINE: Qwest's Game OfAggressive Phone Tag

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON

 BODY:
ON a balmy Saturday in mid-June, 70 of Joseph P. Nacchio's closest friends and family members gathered at his northern New Jersey home for boccie ball and a late supper to celebrate his son's high school graduation. Also attending were a few colleagues, including Jack Grubman, who had worked with Mr. Nacchio at AT&T years before.
Mr. Grubman, now a top telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, had helped advise Global Crossing on its recent mergers with U S West Inc., the smallest regional Bell company, and the Frontier Corporation, the nation's No. 5 long-distance company, based in Rochester. Global, like many young telecommunications concerns these days, hopes to use fiber optic cables to transmit data over the Internet. U S West and Frontier would give it what it needed most: revenue and customers. 
 But the rumor on Wall Street the week before the party was that one of Global's rivals, Qwest Communications International, was on the verge of making unsolicited offers for the two companies. If true, it made for an awkward situation on Mr. Nacchio's backyard deck: Mr. Nacchio is Qwest's chief executive. "There's a lot of speculation out there about when you are going to come with an offer," Mr. Grubman said at the party, a swing band playing in the background.
Mr. Nacchio said he replied with a shrug, "We may, we may not."
Mr. Nacchio was in fact about to embark on the largest double hostile takeover in American history. As he crawled into bed that evening, he was almost giddy. "I think we both had a lot of trouble sleeping that night," said his wife, Anne Esker Nacchio, "not because we were worried, but because we were excited."
The next day, Qwest made offers to buy both U S West and Frontier for a total of $55 billion in stock and cash, in effect topping Global's stock offer of $47 billion. Soon, scores of bankers, lawyers and negotiators began shuttling between Denver, where both Qwest and U S West are based, and lawyers' offices in New York as often as commuters on a subway. The result was last Sunday's compromise, for U S West to merge with Qwest and for Global Crossing to acquire Frontier -- a deal that most analysts agree gives each company the prize it needed most.
But what many participants had hoped might be worked out amicably in days, instead took weeks of almost Machiavellian maneuvering. Clandestine meetings were held in airport hangars and hotel rooms, far from prying eyes. Tempers flared as the battle at times seemed personal. And Denver's most celebrated billionaire was forced to step in and broker not one but two vital relationships. Without his effort a compromise might never have been reached.
Not everyone is savoring the victories, however, especially investors in Qwest and Global Crossing; each stock has tumbled, with Qwest closing on Friday 42 percent off its 52-week high, and Global 35 percent.
"Despite being a sensible solution, this is not a happy one for everyone involved," said one person involved in the talks. "A lot of value was lost by investors in this whole escapade."
 
'A Lot of Adrenaline Flowing'
Mr. Nacchio was a little nervous as he drove to the offices of Kekst & Company, a New York public relations firm, on Sunday, June 13, the morning after the graduation party, where he planned to announce the offers.
Qwest's bid was simple: The company was willing to pay $55 billion in stock and cash for both U S West and Frontier, about 22 percent more than Global Crossing's all-stock offer was worth based on the previous Friday's closing prices. The move was risky; not only was Qwest trying two hostile takeovers at once, but both targets had signed merger agreements with Global Crossing months before that would be tough and expensive to break.
Mr. Nacchio, who grew up in a scrappy Italian neighborhood on Staten Island, attacks competitors with a take-no-prisoners style. But even his friends say that sometimes his abrasive personality makes him an easy target for detractors. He was recently described in The Economist as having "all the swagger and verbal braggadocio of Joe Pesci's mobster in the film 'Goodfellas.' " Mr. Nacchio took offense to the stereotype, and wrote a letter to the magazine in response: "The overwhelming majority of Italian-Americans are not mobsters," he said.
The day Qwest announced its bids, Mr. Nacchio recalled, "I had a lot of adrenaline flowing." Minutes before the news release went out, he called Joseph P. Clayton, chief executive of Frontier, to tell him of the bid. Philip F. Anschutz, the secretive billionaire who owns 39 percent of Qwest and is chairman, called Solomon D. Trujillo, chief executive of U S West. Mr. Nacchio thought a call from Mr. Anschutz, whom Mr. Trujillo knew, might "take the edge off," he later recalled.
Mr. Trujillo, for his part, turned down several requests in recent weeks to be interviewed for this article.
The news of Qwest's offer, though unwelcome, came as no surprise to executives at Global Crossing. They had worried that Qwest and a partner might enter the bidding war. Global's top management conferred immediately with its advisers at Salomon, but there was little to do except wait and see how investors reacted. Robert Annunziata, the chief executive, was barred from commenting publicly about Frontier and U S West until Global filed documents with regulators. And, anyway, Global had a provision in its merger contracts that allowed it to review any competing bid.
Meanwhile, Qwest investors revolted. On Monday, the day after the announcement, the shares collapsed 24 percent, to $34.125, in record trading volume. That was troubling for Qwest, because the company was offering its own stock as currency. When the stock price dropped, so did the value of its dual offer, making it almost comparable to Global Crossing's. Mr. Nacchio and his advisers had clearly miscalculated the market response.
As one investment banker not involved in the deals said at the time, "This will be a Harvard Business School case study someday on how not to launch a hostile takeover."
Qwest's attempt to promote the deal during that week's roadshow was equally disastrous. Investors bought Qwest with the promise of owning a supercharged growth company. But if Mr. Nacchio bought U S West, Qwest's growth rate would be halved. "I think the whole strategy is absurd," said Robert Gensler of T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund company in Baltimore, one of many analysts to balk at the move.
By the time Mr. Nacchio got back to his Denver office on Thursday, June 17, he had 600 E-mail messages waiting. No one, Mr. Nacchio said, seemed to understand Qwest's rationale, least of all the news media. "Business Week has a story coming out, and you are not going to like it," Mr. Nacchio recalled a board member telling him that Thursday. Mr. Nacchio had been interviewed, he said, but instead of a news article, the magazine published an editorial criticizing his bids, calling him "a telecom bureaucrat dressed up in Internet clothes."
Mr. Nacchio did not mask his anger. In a conference call with advisers later that afternoon, he lashed out. "What is going on here?" he barked, according to one person on the call. "Why can't we get any good press?" Mr. Nacchio later told aides to try to set up meetings with top editors at major news outlets so he could explain his plan.
 Mr. Nacchio said he thinks some news accounts were planted by Global to try to undermine his offers. "It demonstrated they hadn't done their homework on me, and I wasn't going to back down," he said. He called the stories "hurtful." (Mr. Annunziata of Global Crossing said neither he nor any of his executives planted negative reports.)
But Mr. Nacchio's public relations campaign did little to sway the audience he needed most. On June 17, Frontier reaffirmed its merger with Global Crossing, which is based in Bermuda; four days later, U S West did the same.
Their message was clear: Sweeten the offers or go away.
 
'A Ton of Bricks on Your Heads'
On June 22, nine days after Qwest made its offers, Mr. Nacchio was awakened by a telephone call from Mr. Anschutz, Qwest's largest shareholder, wishing him a happy 50th birthday. "How do you feel?" Mr. Nacchio said Mr. Anschutz asked him. "Tired," Mr. Nacchio replied, "but I'm not sure if it's age or if it is this deal."
Mr. Nacchio and his negotiating team, which included Craig Slater, who is one of Mr. Anschutz's trusted advisers, had begun a "Dear Sol" letter-writing campaign to pressure Mr. Trujillo of U S West to accept Qwest's offer. Instead, advisers say they annoyed him, and Mr. Trujillo demanded that they stop. Qwest was also planning to make revised offers that were more palatable, but exactly how was up in the air. Among other things, U S West wanted protection in case Qwest's volatile stock plummeted further.
Mr. Nacchio and Mr. Anschutz discussed several different options -- more stock or a guarantee of cash, perhaps -- and decided to keep Qwest's board members on standby in case a quick vote was needed on a revised bid. By day's end, it was: Frontier shareholders would be offered a guaranteed $48 in stock and $20 in cash, and U S West shareholders $69 in stock, for each share.
The total value of the offers -- about $50 billion -- was not as rich as the first, but seemed better than Global Crossing's. And both companies' stockholders would be protected from volatile price swings as well, something Qwest hadn't offered originally. Qwest planned to make its revised offer the next morning.
Mr. Nacchio, who had been working at home in his library, took a few hours off that night for a quiet barbecue with his wife and two sons. (Their birthday gifts to him that day included the "Godfather" trilogy on video and a promise to wash and wax his Porsche.) And he called Mr. Grubman of Salomon, in part to send a message to Global to back off.
Mr. Nacchio was still fuming about the Business Week editorial, and he said he told Mr. Grubman that "it was a bad tactic for Global to go after me personally." He also told Mr. Grubman that another bid was coming, saying, as Mr. Grubman recalled it and Mr. Nacchio confirmed, "I'm going to drop a ton of bricks on your heads."
The new bids posed a problem for Global Crossing. Its founder, Gary Winnick -- a financier and a former colleague of Michael R. Milken -- had turned a $15 million investment in an undersea cable into more than $5 billion of Global stock. For Global to succeed, it needed the cash and customers Frontier and U S West could provide. Mr. Winnick's biggest fear was losing Frontier, because he coveted its long-distance network.
He knew it would be inappropriate to approach Qwest directly about a compromise, so on the afternoon of June 26, according to people close to the talks, he stopped by the Malibu home of a trusted friend, Ken Moelis, a Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette executive in Los Angeles. The two walked on the beach, and Mr. Winnick asked Mr. Moelis: Could he help with Mr. Anschutz?
Mr. Moelis, who was not advising Qwest, called Lou Friedman, another Donaldson banker who was, and told him about the visit. Maybe a deal could work, Mr. Moelis thought. Qwest, the nation's fourth-largest long-distance company, was interested in U S West mainly for its local customers. And Frontier, while important, was less vital to its strategy.
It took executives and bankers two days to negotiate a meeting of about eight Qwest and Global executives and advisers at the O'Hare Hilton in Chicago on June 30. "Everyone was terrified," one person close to the talks said. "No one trusted each other. They didn't want leaks. The implication was it would show weakness."
When the two camps convened at 10 A.M. in room 3002, a Salomon banker laid out Global's concerns first: Mr. Winnick was prepared to give U S West permission to negotiate with Qwest as long as Qwest was willing to drop its bid for Frontier that day. No way, said Mr. Slater, Mr. Anschutz's adviser. "This isn't going to be unilateral disarmament," he said, according to people who were there. "It's trust, but we'll keep our nuclear weapons pointed at you." Mr. Slater said Qwest would drop its bid for Frontier only when a deal with U S West was struck.
For two hours, the two teams bickered. "Part of the negotiation with Global Crossing was helping Qwest get in to U S West to talk," said one person close to the talks. "U S West could have hidden behind legal issues if it wanted to." By noon, Mr. Slater and his team were so frustrated that they threatened to walk out of the negotiations and called their pilot to fetch them. But after three more exhausting hours, they were no closer to a compromise.
A flurry of calls were made over the next 24 hours to both Mr. Winnick and Mr. Anschutz. Those led to an informal understanding on July 1 that allowed U S West to negotiate with Qwest as long as Qwest agreed to drop its bid for Frontier when a deal with U S West was signed. Also, Global would receive half its original $850 million breakup fee. That afternoon, Mr. Winnick and Mr. Anschutz confirmed the informal understanding by telephone. Later that day, U S West said it would begin talks with Qwest. Frontier also said it would hold talks with Qwest.
 
Maneuvers, and a Deal
An agreement between Qwest and U S West might never have been reached without the stealthy maneuverings of Mr. Anschutz, the press-shy Denver billionaire who made his fortune in oil and railroad investments. Most recently, he sold the Southern Pacific Railroad in 1996 for $5.4 billion, tripling his $1.8 billion investment.
Like Mr. Winnick, he is guarded and private, driven to finding opportunities where none are clear. But in this case, his motivation was self-evident: to further protect his 39 percent investment in Qwest, which since June 13 had lost one-quarter of its value. As the largest shareholder, he had the most to gain in welcoming Mr. Trujillo into the Qwest fold. "Guys like Anschutz and Winnick, they want to make money," said one person involved in the talks. "They don't want to be known as the guys who remade the telecommunications industry."
Because U S West had originally approached Global about a merger of equals, it was not technically for sale. So Mr. Trujillo and his board were demanding a merger with equal power. One concern was that Qwest had no experience running a local telephone business. And Mr. Trujillo wanted to make sure that his ideas and those of his management team would get an equal airing once the companies were combined. "U S West was concerned about Qwest slashing and burning its management team," a person close to the talks said.
In fact, mutual suspicion pervaded every aspect of the negotiations, to the point that seemingly trivial details like a demand by Mr. Trujillo to drop a sentence and move a paragraph in the news release would snag the deal's signing for hours. (He prevailed on the sentence, which said he would report to Mr. Nacchio; the paragraph, explaining each of the top executives' titles, ultimately stayed put.)
Mr. Anschutz began talking about management issues with Mr. Trujillo on Thursday, July 8. One solution discussed was to name Mr. Trujillo president of the local and wireless business and a vice chairman of the combined company. But that was a nonstarter; U S West feared that a vice chairmanship would be perceived as one step away from early retirement.
Talks between executives in New York stalled over the weekend, too. Mr. Slater was running in Central Park on Saturday when he received a call on his cell phone from Allan R. Spies, U S West's chief financial officer, informing him that the day's planned negotiations might be postponed, said a person close to the talks. Mr. Slater and his team went to the offices of Davis Polk & Wardwell, the lawyers advising Qwest, to await Mr. Spies's call. The meeting never happened, and Qwest's advisers ended up watching the Women's World Cup soccer finals on a television in the law office library.
Four days after discussions began in earnest, negotiators struck paydirt. Mr. Slater and Mr. Spies, along with two other executives from Qwest and U S West, met at U S West's hangar at a small airport outside Denver on July 12. The four men mulled over a compromise that had surfaced earlier: naming Mr. Anschutz, Mr. Nacchio and Mr. Trujillo co-chairmen.
Mr. Nacchio would still be chief executive. But to make that palatable, Mr. Trujillo would have the authority to present his own ideas to the board, even if Mr. Nacchio disagreed. Mr. Trujillo would be named president of the local and wireless business. And top jobs at the combined entity would be divided equally between executives from the two companies.
Mr. Anschutz didn't love the concept at first. "Phil thought the market would perceive him as an arbitrator," said one person close to the talks. "He was the referee, and he didn't want to be." But he soon warmed to the idea, as did Mr. Nacchio, who was traveling that day. Later that afternoon, Mr. Anschutz went to Mr. Trujillo's office, and the two men agreed that it was an arrangement they all could live with.
With management issues all but behind them, negotiators spent several long days and late nights -- until the boards' meetings on Friday night -- working out the details.
The drama of Qwest's battle for U S West overshadowed the story of Frontier. After preliminary discussions stalled, Rolla P. Huff, president and chief operating officer, said he called Mr. Nacchio on July 13 -- the same day Mr. Nacchio and Mr. Trujillo had dinner at the Brown Palace Hotel in downtown Denver to discuss their future -- to gauge whether he was serious about buying Frontier. Mr. Nacchio said he was, but Mr. Huff said he suspected then, as he does now, that Mr. Nacchio was not as interested in Frontier as he was in U S West.
 
But Will It Work?
Last week, the Qwest and Global Crossing compromise was greeted with little fanfare on Wall Street. Analysts called it the logical outcome, as did the principals.
"At the end of the day, we thought U S West was good, but we had our limits on what it was worth," said Mr. Annunziata of Global Crossing.
Mr. Nacchio said, "It was O.K. to let Frontier go."
Communications companies, like Qwest and Global, are aware that if they do not transform themselves -- placing one foot in the new digital universe of the Internet and the other in the traditional world of cable or copper wires -- they risk likely death. In essence, that is at the core of the brawl for Frontier and U S West.
But betting on an unpredictable future takes its toll. "I'm just physically tired," Mr. Nacchio said, sounding weary on a telephone call on Thursday from Boston, one of several cities he visited on a whirlwind roadshow to discuss the merger. "I've only seen my wife three times in the past three weeks."
Mr. Nacchio says he is confident that Qwest's merger with U S West will succeed. But it will be several years before he, or Qwest investors, know for sure. Still, "Qwest can never be the same," Mr. Nacchio said. "Once we started, we knew we could never go back to what we were before."

Young telecommunications companies, like Qwest Communications International and Global Crossing, must transform themselves -- with one foot in the digital universe of the Internet and the other in traditional cable or copper wires -- or risk a likely death. Here is how a four-way fight turned into two deals.
 
CHAIN OF EVENTS
MARCH 17 -- Global Crossing, founded by Gary Winnick, announces that it will buy the Frontier Corporation for $11 billion, or $63 a share.
MAY 17 -- Global Crossing and U S West announce that they will merge in a deal valued at $37 billion, or $60 for each U S West share.
JUNE 13 -- Qwest makes a hostile offer of $55 billion in stock and cash to acquire both U S West and Frontier, in an effort to pry them away from Global Crossing.
JUNE 17 -- Frontier says it is still in a deal with Global Crossing.
JUNE 21 -- U S West announces that it, too, will stick to its deal with Global Crossing.
JUNE 23 -- Qwest revises its offer to $69 a share in stock for U S West and $68 in cash and stock for Frontier, or $50 billion in all, with the cash component to increase if its stock price drops too far.
JUNE 30 -- Representatives of Qwest and Global Crossing meet to consider a truce. Items discussed: Allowing U S West to negotiate with Qwest if Qwest drops its bid for Frontier; a breakup fee to be paid to Global Crossing.
JUNE 30 -- Frontier's board agrees to let management talk to Qwest about its offer, but reaffirms its merger agreement with Global Crossing.
JULY 1 -- Qwest and Global Crossing reach an understanding. U S West's management is allowed to begin talks with Qwest about its offer.
JULY 3 -- Representatives of Qwest and U S West begin meetings to discuss regulatory issues and the role of U S West's management in a merged company.
JULY 12 -- An agreement is struck to make Mr. Trujillo of U S West a co-chairman in a merged company and give him authority to go to the board with ideas. Mr. Nacchio will head the combined company.
JULY 16 -- Qwest's and U S West's boards approve a merger of the two companies.
JULY 18 -- Qwest says that U S West has agreed to a $36.5 billion merger, expected to close in about a year. Global Crossing says, in turn, that it will continue with its $11 billion acquisition of Frontier.

HEADLINE: The Nation: You Could Look It Up;
What He Promised. And What He Did.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHY, a reporter asked President Clinton at his news conference on Wednesday, did he ridicule George W. Bush's slogan of "compassionate conservatism"? Another reporter wanted to know what the President found objectionable about the Texas Governor's "trying to present a new moderate face for his party, just like you did for the Democrats."
Mr. Clinton responded that Governor Bush had not met the responsibility of Presidential candidates to "make their positions clear on the great debates going on now and make their positions clear on what they would do if they got the job." 
 Then, Mr. Clinton offered this version of his own race for President in 1992: "The first thing I did was tell the American people what I thought was going on in our country and what I would do. And if you remember, the late Senator Paul Tsongas and I were actually almost ridiculed at the time because we both put out these very detailed plans of what we would do. If you go back and get one of those plans now, you'll see that virtually everything we said we'd do we did do, except for the things we tried to do and were defeated on."
Is that right or not?
No one can challenge Mr. Clinton's point that he offered a detailed agenda, which he refined over the months. By the fall, he and Al Gore had published a 240-page book called "Putting People First" that offered explicit proposals on issues running the alphabetical gamut from agriculture to women.
Some of the promises were grand, like cutting the budget deficit in half, guaranteeing Americans affordable medical insurance, "ending welfare as we know it" and providing equal economic opportunity for all. Other promises were microscopic in their detail, like saving $2 million in 1993 by adjusting nuclear waste disposal fees for inflation. And some were simply unmeasurable, like the pledge to give America "the best-educated, best-trained workforce in the world, linked together by transportation and communication networks second to none."
But if the quantity, breadth and specificity of Clinton promises cannot be contested, one can quibble with his view that he accomplished, or at least tried to accomplish, "virtually everything" he promised to do.
The fact is, Mr. Clinton did reach many of the goals he set in 1992, was thwarted by political opponents on some and never even tried to achieve others. On the central issue of the 1992 campaign, the economy, his goal of halving the deficit was left in the dust. The budget was balanced, and Mr. Clinton is now able to foresee enormous surpluses in Government accounts. The unemployment rate fell to the lowest level in decades and millions of new jobs were created. Inflation was tamed. The American economy became, as Mr. Clinton pledged it would, second to none.
In addition, over the opposition of Republicans in Congress, President Clinton fulfilled promises to enact a tough gun-control law, finance 100,000 new community police officers, increase the minimum wage, start a national service program, give workers time off to deal with family emergencies and block efforts to restrict abortions.
Working with and in many cases following the Republicans' lead, he expanded international trade, ended the 60-year-old national welfare system, reduced the size of the Government work force, gave tax breaks to cities for special empowerment zones and won authority for a line-item veto, which was ultimately found unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.
On some other goals established in 1992, Mr. Clinton made an effort but was stopped by Congress. His most spectacular failure, of course, was his proposal to provide affordable health insurance coverage for all Americans through local networks of insurers, hospitals and doctors. As a campaign theme, it sounded workable. When Mr. Clinton submitted a plan along those lines after he became President, it proved to be unwieldy and unpopular and died while Democrats still controlled Congress.
Opponents forced the President to withdraw his promise to let homosexuals serve in the military. He instituted instead the compromise policy of don't-ask, don't-tell, which satisfies no one.
CONGRESS also stopped the President from keeping his promises to "rebuild America" by spending billions on a jobs and public works program. And it rejected his proposal that companies with striking workers be prohibited from hiring replacements.
Mr. Clinton simply broke other promises. Here are some of the ones he reneged on:
Even before he took office, he dropped his proposal for a middle-income tax cut.
He never tried to repeal the limit on how much money people over 65 can earn before their Social Security benefits are reduced.
He gave lip service to campaign finance reform but exerted no effort to attain it.
He quickly forgot a plan to require businesses to spend 1.5 percent of their payroll on continued education and training of workers.
He never ended tax breaks for companies that shut down American plants and ship jobs overseas.
He never made improvement in China's human rights record a condition for favorable trade status.
Instead of fighting an increase in the gasoline tax, he sponsored legislation that raised it by 4.3 cents a gallon.
Paradoxically, the fewer promises from 1992 Mr. Clinton kept, the more popular he became. His grandest achievements were in his first year in office, and the public did not seem particularly grateful. By the end of his second year, his Presidency was in shambles, and Republicans won control of both houses of Congress.
Then Mr. Clinton began thinking small bore. He won re-election in 1996 without big promises and has concentrated since then on blocking Republican ambitions. "There was a misreading of how much change people wanted," explained Mr. Clinton's former adviser, Harold M. Ickes.
Perhaps that is why George W. Bush is promising so little. And maybe, just maybe, it's why President Clinton is egging him on.

HEADLINE: The World: Ominous Signals in Iran;
In Islamic Mideast, Scant Place for Jews

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

 BODY:
TO those who monitor events in Iran, the arrest of 13 Iranian Jews on spying charges this year is a menacing sign that bigger trouble may lie ahead -- trouble that, unchecked, could cause one of the last two Jewish communities of any size in the Islamic Middle East to follow most of the others into virtual oblivion.
Until the arrests, Jews in Iran had survived the 20-year dominion of Iran's ruling ayatollahs better than many feared in 1979, when the Islamic republic was declared. In fact, the 30,000 Jews in Iran, while down from the 80,000 who lived there before the revolution, constitute the largest Jewish community to have survived in the Muslim Middle East and North Africa. The only other one of similar size is in Turkey, another non-Arab country, where about 20,000 Jews remain. 
 The Iranian Jews' significance becomes clearer when their endurance is measured against what happened elsewhere after the birth of Israel. From Morocco through Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, Egypt, Yemen, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Turkey, Jewish communities that totalled perhaps a million people in 1948 dwindled between the 1950's and 80's to the point that barely 60,000 -- including the 50,000 in Iran and Turkey -- remain.
But now, Iran's Jews must worry that tactics used against Jewish minorities elsewhere could erode their security, making migration more attractive. For the time being, the American and European diplomats who have been leading a discreet campaign to persuade Iran to drop the spying charges remain hopeful. They point to the opprobrium that would be sure to fall on Iran if the cases come to trial, or -- improbable, but still possible, in the view of experts on Iran -- if the Jews were convicted and sentenced to long prison terms or death.
The case has unfolded slowly. When the first of the 13 was arrested in January, the State Department kept the matter quiet, hoping diplomacy could resolve the issue. But that had not happened by early June, when Iran announced the arrests over the state radio.
The spying charges bear every earmark of a trumped-up case. Those arrested -- including a rabbi, three Hebrew teachers, a kosher butcher and even, by some reports, a 16-year-old boy -- were originally picked up for alleged infringements of Iranian laws that conflict with Jewish practices. The rabbi was charged with teaching Hebrew, the language of Jewish prayer; others were accused of closing their shops on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath.
Their actions were condemned as evidence of disloyalty to Iran, and thus as proof that those arrested were in the service of "world arrogance" and "the Zionist entity," meaning the United States and Israel. By escalating infractions of religious laws into treason, the conservatives who control Iran's police and courts evidently hoped to stir antagonism toward the West and place fresh obstacles before Iran's reformist President, Mohammed Khatami.
BY no coincidence, the charges originated in the southern city of Fars, a stronghold of Islamic conservatives loyal to Ayatollah Ali Khamanei, Iran's supreme leader. Although the violent clashes earlier this month between students supporting President Khatami and security forces loyal to the Muslim clerics have now abated, the underlying dispute between those favoring a broadening of freedoms and the clerics' insistence on tight control remains. With it, at least theoretically, remains the risk that other Jews might become political pawns.
It is a situation redolent of the hazards Jews have faced throughout history, made more poignant in Iran by the fact that Jews there seemed, until the spying case, to have a more secure place than elsewhere in the Muslim Middle East. The Islamic constitution recognizes Jews as a religious minority, allows them a representative in Parliament and accepts Jewish laws on burial and divorce. In Teheran, 27 synagogues function, Jewish schools flourish and the Jewish hospital is among the city's most respected.
Now all this could be at risk, and with it a crucial vestige of the Jewish settlement that has left a deep imprint on virtually every country in the Middle East. According to estimates in the "Atlas of the Jewish World," a survey by Dr. Nicholas de Lange of Cambridge University, as many as four million Jews lived in parts of the Roman Empire beyond Judea, the Jewish homeland, at the dawn of the first millennium; most of these lived in the Arab lands that now surround Israel. On the eve of the third millennium, these countries together could not muster a Jewish population as numerous as those that were once to be found in many of the major cities of the region.
Iraq, where there were about 150,000 Jews in 1948, has about 70 now. In Syria, there are about 300, in Lebanon about 80, in Jordan, Egypt and Yemen fewer still. In Saudi Arabia there are no Jews, at least by official count. In Morocco, which had about 300,000 Jews in 1948, about 6,000 remain. In Algeria, which saw 115,000 Jews emigrate hastily to France at independence in 1962, the count is down to a few hundred. In Tunisia, which counted 105,000 Jews in 1950, there are no more than 2,500. In Libya, where a 1931 census counted 24,500 Jews, one recent count put the number of Jews remaining at 5. In Turkey, a community of 90,000 in 1948 has shrunk to less than a quarter of that now.
While flight from the Muslim lands has been precipitous in the last 50 years, a slower decline dates from the Middle Ages, when the rise of Christian Europe attracted large westward migrations among Jewish populations in the Middle East. Other factors, including local pogroms, prompted Jews to leave over the centuries. But in the modern era, the watershed was the creation of Israel. Living in a Jewish state was an attraction in itself; a surge of hostility among Arabs toward Jews, or at least toward Zionism, was another factor.
Still, many of those who left did so reluctantly, and many chose not to leave until much later. This attests to something widely accepted among Jews who have lived as minorities in Muslim nations -- that the Islamic world has been less fertile ground for anti-Semitism than the Christian lands of Europe. Why this has been so has been endlessly debated, but Islamic scholars cite stories from the life of the Muslim prophet, Mohammed, to show that respect for Jews was close to his heart.
Nothing in Jewish experience in the Middle East came remotely close to the Holocaust. But even long before Hitler's killing machine, Jews in Muslim countries were comparing their experiences favorably with those of Jews in Europe. In his survey, Dr. de Lange quotes a Jew writing from Constantinople to Jews in the Rhineland in 1454. "Is it not better for you to live under Muslims than under Christians?" he wrote. "Here, every man may live at peace under his own vine and fig tree."
SINCE 1948, of course, there has been no lack of discrimination toward Jews in Arab countries. Eighteen months after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, Iraq convicted 14 people, nine of them Jews, on dubious spying charges and hanged them from lampposts in a Baghdad square. In many Arab countries, Jews could not emigrate, or could only on forfeit of all they owned. Jewish religious practices were restricted. In many countries, Jews were excluded from government employment, at least at the top.
Some Jewish historians have argued that Israel, or at least Zionists, must accept a share of the blame. These scholars cite the Zionists' plan to encourage Jews everywhere to migrate to Israel, and link that plan to covert Israeli intelligence operations in the years after 1948. One often-cited case involves a bungled Israeli intelligence schemet in 1954 in which bombs were placed at key centers in Cairo, including the American library, with a view to disrupting relations between Western countries and President Gamal Abdel Nasser. These historians say another aim -- and certainly one effect -- was to encourage Egypt's 50,000 Jews to flee to Israel.
Avi Shlaim, a professor of international relations at Oxford University who has written on relations between Israel and the Arab states, says that actions like these accelerated the flight of Jews from communities where many might otherwise have remained. But Dr. Shlaim, whose own family left Iraq for Israel in 1950, believes that now that the Jewish communities in the region have all but vanished, not even a lasting peace between Israel and the Arab states will lead to their regeneration.
The reason, he says, is not that the Arab states or Iran are innately anti-Semitic, but that they lack democratic institutions and economic opportunities. "I can't imagine anyone in their right mind going back to Iraq, or Syria, for that matter," he says. King Hassan of Morocco, who died last week, "held out this opportunity to Moroccan Jews all along, and even they haven't exercised it," Dr. Shalim added. "The most I can imagine now is that Jews born in these countries may eventually want to return as tourists, but nothing more."

HEADLINE: The Oracle of the Fed

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, who has been chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for a dozen years, is a past master of the art of Delphic Congressional testimony. So perhaps it is understandable that many Congressmen take for granted that he is always that way, and seem to have trouble understanding him when he decides to make himself perfectly clear.
That is what happened last week, when Mr. Greenspan testified before a House committee on the very day the House was voting for a massive tax cut. It was, he said, not a good idea. He got to say it over and over again because Republicans kept seeking Greenspanian ambiguity where it did not exist. 
 Mr. Greenspan is not a fan of big government, but he is an economist concerned about a sizzling economy that could rekindle inflation and that may -- he concedes he is not at all sure -- have produced a stock-market bubble. Last month the Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates a bit, and, in one of the more oracular parts of his testimony, Mr. Greenspan seemed to hint that more tightening was likely. In that atmosphere, the last thing he needs is a tax cut that would provide more economic stimulus. "I'm saying, hold off for a while," he testified.
But while there is no economic need for a tax cut now, there might be one in a few years. As Mr. Greenspan noted, the business cycle should not be presumed dead just because we are in the midst of the longest peacetime expansion in American history. "At some point," he warned, "this economy is going to slow down and perhaps slow down quite significantly."
That is when a tax cut would be needed. Unfortunately, the bill passed by the House could provide just the opposite. It calls for a series of cuts in individual income tax rates, but would delay the cuts if the interest expense on the Federal debt rose. But that is just what happens as a result of recessions, which cause tax receipts to fall and welfare costs to rise. The bill would cut taxes, in other words, unless a tax cut was actually a good idea.
That provision to delay the cuts was put in to pacify Republican moderates worried about deficits. They bought it, not worrying about the perverse economic effects or about the fact that it would delay only the reductions in individual income tax rates, which happen to be the only parts of the bill that benefit lower- and middle-income taxpayers. The other parts of the tax bill, including a reduction in capital-gains tax rates, a phase-out of the estate tax and a variety of special-interest breaks for corporations, would not be affected. The campaign contributors seeking those breaks will be pleased.
Mr. Greenspan is treated reverently on Capitol Hill, but it appears that the Republicans do not want to heed his advice to run a surplus and pay down the national debt, while saving a tax cut for when it is needed. It may be up to President Clinton to use his veto pen to prevent this folly from becoming law.

HEADLINE: Idealism at Home

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Joining Peace Corps Inc." (Preludes, July 18), discussed how Peace Corps volunteers hone business skills while expressing idealism. But what about two other national service programs, Vista and Americorps? 
 I am a former Vista volunteer and now a manager and recruiter for these programs. I find that the applicants have similar idealistic intentions -- and the desire to help themselves and their careers. Unfortunately, these volunteers receive little notice, yet they initiate grand change in struggling areas nationwide.
I brought my compassion, business skills and experience to my Vista work in Paterson, N.J. Through entrepreneurship training and small-business development, I continue to help inner-city teen-agers realize the power of self-employment and self-confidence. Vista continues to bring positive change to the community, and I have found a welcoming place there for my career to prosper.
 
NICOLE MANDARANO

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JULY 18-July 23;
If It Weren't for Those Darn Profits...

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS

 BODY:
Last week's action in American equities put the lie to the often-heard complaint that investors, swept up as they are in the Internet gold rush, had stopped caring about company profits. Now, in the thick of the season for second-quarter earnings reports, it's clear that investors do care about profits: They hate them.
 Well, maybe that's a bit flippant. But in a week when company after company and sector after sector weighed in with robust profit reports, all the major stock market indexes sagged. 
 Two explanations came to the fore. Analysts suggested that many investors saw the earnings reports as a cue to take profits, following the "sell on the news" half of the old saw about market timing. And testimony on Capitol Hill by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, about the likelihood of a hair-trigger tightening of monetary policy at the first sign of inflation left many market watchers feeling that an interest rate increase might be imminent.
 That feeling produced a corresponding downdraft in the bond market, with the long bond yield rising above 6 percent. Perhaps counterintuitively, though, the dollar lost ground for the week against both the euro and the Japanese yen. PATRICK J. LYONS

HEADLINE: Study Contradicts Foes of Estate Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Congressional opponents of the estate tax say it discourages savings, costs the economy more than it raises for the Government and makes it very difficult for a family-owned farm or business to be passed to the next generation.
But all of those arguments are contradicted by Government tax and economic data, according to a book-length study that will be published tomorrow in the policy magazine Tax Notes. 
 The article comes after the House passed on Thursday night the Republicans' bill to cut taxes by $792 billion, including the repeal of the estate tax. Similar legislation was being considered in the Senate but the outcome of the repeal is in doubt because President Clinton has promised to veto it.
Yet the article in Tax Notes seems likely to have a profound effect on the debate over estate taxes, experts say. Data from estate tax returns and other records do not support the claims of estate tax opponents, according to the article, by Charles Davenport and Jay A. Soled, professors at Rutgers University who teach estate tax law and business management.
The estate tax is projected in the Federal budget to raise about $28 billion this year. That is less than one-third of 1 percent of the gross domestic product, which is too slight to retard economic growth, the authors say.
While the tax rate on the largest estates can be 55 percent, Internal Revenue Service data cited in the study show that in 1996 the average tax on estates of $600,000 to $1 million was 6 percent.
It costs the I.R.S. 2 cents on the dollar to administer the tax, the authors calculate. They say the combined private and Governmentcosts total about 7 cents on the estate tax dollar.
Professors Davenport and Soled said Congressional testimony by critics of the estate tax contending that the tax costs more than it raises was based on flawed data, including a study that estimated that every dollar raised in Federal income taxes cost the economy 65 cents more. That figure was dismissed as absurd by the authors.
They also disputed another contention of the critics, that rich people spend heavily in their later years in order to reduce estate taxes. Instead, the authors say, many rich people save more money to offset the tax.
They say that the reasons family businesses are not passed to the next generation have little to do with estate taxes. A primary reason, the authors say, is the burden on heirs who want to keep the business and must raise cash to pay off those heirs who do not.
While the estate tax nominally begins when net worth at death exceeds $650,000 ($1.3 million for a married couple), Congress lets a couple pass on $4.5 million untaxed if they own a business and $7.4 million if they own a farm. Only about 1 in 1,000 American families is worth $7.4 million.
The estate tax will be paid this year by the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans who die.
The Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation estimated last week that repeal of the estate tax would reduce Federal revenues by $75 billion over the next 10 years, even though the Federal budget projects the estate tax will raise more than that amount in the next three years alone.
The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, who had not seen the article, said that he was skeptical of its claims and any data drawn from I.R.S. records.
"Every dollar taken by the death tax is a dollar taken out of savings when what this country needs is more private savings," said Mr. Archer, the author of the House Republicans' tax bill. He said the costs of the estate tax included discouraging wealthy foreigners from moving to the United States with their capital and skills.
As to whether existing exemptions are enough for farms to stay in families, he said, "The input from the Ag Belt is totally contrary to that."
The authors say that among the virtues they see in the estate tax are that it taxes some money that has slipped past the income tax system, it is paid only by those most able to pay, it encourages financial planning and charitable giving and it tends to ease the trend toward concentration of wealth. The richest 1 percent of Americans now own half of all stocks, bonds and other assets, a record level, according to Professor Edward N. Wolff of New York University.
Experts say the Tax Notes article may be as influential as the 1994 Yale Law Review article by Edward J. McCaffery of the University of Southern California Law School, who exhorted liberals to join conservatives in opposing the estate tax as inefficient and unfair. Since then, the Tax Notes article says, "talk about the death-tax has been a monologue by the tax's opponents." The article is available at www.tax.org on the Internet. 
http://www.nytimes.com
